PETITION.TITLE: Compass Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the overwhelming support of the Australian people for the resumption of Compass Airlines operation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:-
recognise the overwhelming public support for Compass resuming operations;
agree to work with interested parties to facilitate Compass resuming operations;
provide clear guidelines under aviation deregulation to ensure that fair and adequate facilities are made available to all operators and the public immediately.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Aldred (from 14 citizens), Mr Andrews (from 13 citizens), Mr Atkinson (from 14 citizens), Mrs Bailey (from 14 citizens), Mr Baldwin (from 13 citizens), Dr Blewett (from 14 citizens), Mr Broadbent (from 13 citizens), Mr Ewen Cameron (from 14 citizens), Mr Chaney (from 13 citizens), Mr Connolly (from 14 citizens), Ms Crawford (from 14 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 14 citizens), Mr Ferguson (from 14 citizens), Mr Fife (from 14 citizens), Mr Tim Fischer (from 12 citizens), Mrs Gallus (from 14 citizens), Mr Gibson (from 14 citizens), Mr Gorman (from 14 citizens), Mr Steele Hall (from 15 citizens), Mr Halverson (from 14 citizens), Mr Howard (from 14 citizens), Mr Howe (from 13 citizens), Mr Barry Jones (from 14 citizens), Mr Jull (from 13 citizens), Dr Kemp (from 14 citizens), Mr Lee (from 14 citizens), Mr Lindsay (from 14 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 14 citizens), Mr McGauran (from 14 citizens), Mr Mack (from 14 citizens), Mr Melham (from 14 citizens), Mr Peacock (from 14 citizens), Mr Prosser (from 14 citizens), Mr Reid (from 14 citizens), Mr Reith (from 14 citizens), Mr Riggall (from 14 citizens), Mr Rocher (from 14 citizens), Mr Ronaldson (from 14 citizens), Mr Ruddock (from 14 citizens), Mr Scholes (from 14 citizens), Mr John Scott (from 14 citizens), Mr Les Scott (from 14 citizens), Mr Shack (from 14 citizens), Mr West (from 14 citizens), Dr Bob Woods (from 14 citizens) and Dr Wooldridge (from 14 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Civil Aviation Authority: AMATS Program
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain Airline Pilots, draws to the attention of the House the direction that the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) is taking Australian Aviation. We therefore request the CAA is not permitted to implement the UNPROVEN procedures associated with the Airspace Management and Air Traffic Services (AMATS) programme.
The principle areas of concern include the following:

PETITION.PARA: 1.The removal of the DIRECTED delivery of amended operational information such as, amended forecasts, weather observations and NOTAMS;
2.Removal of information on Visual Flight rules (VFR) aircraft from the DIRECTED traffic information service;
3.The requirement for pilots to monitor multiple radio frequencies simultaneously;
4.The large reliance on the "see-and-avoid" principle of separation for high performance passenger aircraft, a concept that is a flawed and unreliable method of collision avoidance; and
5.The removal of the proven AFIZ system and its replacement with the UNPROVEN MTAF system.

PARA.TAB: Which we believe will lead to reduced and unacceptable safety levels.

We the undersigned also wish to voice our deep concern about the CAA's failure to listen to the express concerns of industry members, and its seemingly deliberate campaign of misinformation about changes to procedures.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to ensure that passenger and crew safety is safeguarded by preventing the implementation of the UNPROVEN procedures associated with the AMATS programme.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife (from 19 citizens), Mr Peter Fisher (from 13 citizens) and Mr Smith (from 16 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: ABC Television: Investigation By Ombudsman
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, are deeply concerned by the continued political biases and deplorable disregard for common decency displayed by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Further, we are alarmed that the Corporation is able to conduct itself in this manner without accountability to an independent authority.
We believe that it is totally unacceptable that a publicly funded body can undertake any action it chooses, free from public complaint and scrutiny.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the members of the House of Representatives will act to empower the Commonwealth Ombudsman—either of his own intention or in response to a complaint from a member, or members, of the public—to investigate any action that relates to a programming decision of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrews (from 966 citizens) and Mr Shack (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
(1)(a)makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children,

TAB.TAB: (b)makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.

PARA.TAB: (2)creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble).
(3)will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that:
(1)By Act, Parliament ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
(2)The Parliament take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Webster (from 13 citizens) and Mr Harry Woods (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the below men and women of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: We believe that the government bears total responsibility for the funding of tertiary education and that it should be accessible to all sectors of the community, we are concerned about the continuing decline in both the quality and the accessibility of tertiary education due to inadequate funding, the introduction of H.E.C.S. fees and insufficient student income provisions (such as Austudy), therefore, we call upon the assembled members to ensure the Federal Government implements the following:
abolition of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (H.E.C.S.)
issuance of an official statement opposing the introduction of up-front full fees
elevation of student income provisions, such as Austudy, to at least the poverty line
reduction of the age of independence for Austudy from 25 to 18 years
provision of sufficient recurrent funding per student to entice and retain quality academics at just salary levels
provision of sufficient capital funding per student to ensure the provision of necessary facilities, such as libraries, computers, laboratories and lecture theatres,
your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that your Honourable House will support these demands for the provision of publicly funded, accessible, quality tertiary education in our country.

PETITION.TITLE: Relocation of No. 2 Flight Air Training Corps
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia, draws to the attention of the House, the proposal to relocate the No 2 Flight Air Training Corps, from Wanneroo to Leederville.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
ensure that the No 2 Flight Air Training Corps remains in Wanneroo and is not relocated to Leederville;

seek funding from the Department of Administrative Services to enable the only flight in Western Australia currently not funded, to access sufficient project monies to complete and maintain its facilities already under construction at Landsdale; and
prevent the loss of this valuable youth organisation to the northern corridor of Perth, the second fastest expanding residential region in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography: Pay Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of Mackay region draws to the attention of the House the increasing frequency of pornographic programs on television, and the considerable proportion of the PAY television market in the US which broadcasts pornographic material.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to legislate
to restrict the telecasting of pornographic programs to after 10.30 pm at night, and
that, in the introduction of PAY television into Australia, licensees be prevented from broadcasting pornographic material on PAY television.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which wars such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
(i)call on the Federal Government to outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations, government and private.

(ii)call on the Federal Government to lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology to unstable regions and to countries with dictatorships.

PETITION.TITLE: Racism: Residency Status
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that under standing legislation and regulations the danger that a racist may be given the privilege of Australian Permanent Residency or even the honour of Australian citizenship. There is nothing to stop this sort of ridiculous situation happening.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House enact legislation or regulations that Immigration authorities should refuse entry into Australia to any person who is known to have uttered racist remarks or practised racist policies; furthermore that a person who made racist remarks or practised racists policies should not be given Permanent Resident status and furthermore that a person who has uttered racist remarks or practised racist policies should not be accorded the privilege of Australian citizenship.

PETITION.TITLE: Festival of American Folklife
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled;

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, are dismayed by the Australian Governments refusal to accept the invitation to be the featured country at the 1993 Festival of American Folklife at the Smithsonian Institute in Washington, USA.

This is a unique opportunity to showcase Australia's folk traditions and encourage tourist trade from America. We trust that the reinvitation to the 1994 Festival of American Folklife will be readily accepted.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortions: Government Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:

PARA.TAB: Every abortion kills an unborn human baby. More unborn Australians are killed every year (80,000) than the Australian death toll for the whole of World War II (30,000).
Australia's population is aging. Our live birth rate is below replacement level.
About 98 percent of abortions in Australia are performed for non-medical reasons (see SA Health Commission statistics).
Post abortion depression is a silent epidemic and is linked with the growing incidence of child abuse by mothers who have previously had abortions.
The Australian Government should not fund the killing of future Australian citizens.
Mothers with problem pregnancies need positive help to carry their babies to full term.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
pass the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990, and
help pregnant women with problems to continue their pregnancies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Yellingbo Post Office
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned (residents of Yellingbo) demand our Post Office be returned.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS: Dutch Language Broadcasts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the House that under the new broadcast schedule of the Special Broadcasting Service the members of the Dutch community in Victoria have been deprived of a disproportionate amount of transmission time in their native language on radiostation 3EA. That the decision to so reduce the amount of broadcasting time in Dutch precludes an adequate functioning of the Special Broadcasting Service as required by the Broadcasting Act and leads to great concern and disappointment amongst those residents of Victoria who were born in the Netherlands, Flanders and the former Dutch East Indies.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to advise the Governor General to command the Chairman and members of the board of Directors of the Special Broadcasting Service to review the relevant decision and to give proper regard to the demographic realities in allocating broadcast time on radio 3EA.

PETITION.TITLE: Security Bonds: Family Reunion Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament Assembled, the petition of the undersigned respectfully sheweth:

PARA.TAB: That the 1991 Budget decision to impose the refundable Security Bonds supplementing Assurance of Support Agreements and the non-refundable health levy will cause considerable hardship and make it financially impossible for many lower income overseas born residents/Australian citizens to reunite with members of their family.

The Security Bond completely ignores the important contribution to successful settlement effected under the Family Reunion Program and the indirect cost benefits derived in regard to housing, mental health, employment and welfare systems.
The Health Levy amounts to "double dipping" as the Medicare Levy through the taxation system will also apply.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will overturn the Budget decision and dispense with the introduction of the Security Bond and Health Levy and reviews other more equitable and traditional options for debt recovery which address individual situations of default.
And your petitioners in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of citizens of Australia resident on the Central Coast of New South Wales respectfully showeth that we condemn the Labor Party's proposal to turn our backs on our history and declare Australia a republic, now or at any future time.

Our great nation was settled by British pioneers, either voluntarily or forcibly, and it is to these people and that country that we owe our heritage. Our men and women fought bravely under the banner of the Australian flag, which bears the Union Jack proudly in its top left hand corner, in several great wars, they fought for Monarch and country. This is our free and democratic tradition.
This flag must remain our emblem as a tribute to those who laid down their lives on and off the battlefield for our freedom.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House does not allow this destruction of our connection with the great and noble British Empire of which we are so proudly a part.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Sexual Abuse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House, legislative change requested in cases of Child Sexual Abuse:
1.Children to be allowed to give evidence regardless of age.
2.Child orientated courts using closed circuit television, videotaped evidence, and a child advocate, trained in legal procedures and child development—to advise or assist court.
3.Uniform laws nationwide, including mandatory reporting to central registry in all states of the criminal offence of Child Sexual Abuse.
4.Treatment of offenders to be under strict supervision in confinement or treatment programmes linked to the criminal justice system.
5.Education of the judiciary, lawyers, doctors and other professional people dealing with Child Sexual Abuse.
6.Enquiry into Family Court procedures involving Child Sexual Abuse allegations.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House takes the necessary steps to bring about legislative change to ensure the above processes are adopted.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Hospitals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:

PARA.TAB: (1)They are completely satisfied with the existing Repatriation Hospital system.
(2)They are aware that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs have guaranteed on a number of occasions:

TAB.TAB: (a)no Repatriation General Hospital will be transferred to a State until a satisfactory agreement has been reached on matters, such as priority of access and quality of health care for Veterans and War Widows, and unless the interests of hospital staff have been adequately safeguarded; and
(b)no final decision will be taken if the RSL has reasonable cause for dissatisfaction with the proposed arrangements.

PARA.TAB: (3)They have reasonable cause for concern that integration of Repatriation Hospitals into State systems will represent a serious erosion of their rights and privileges.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that "the existing Repatriation Hospital system be retained under the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to ensure Repatriation General Hospitals remain centres of excellence for the health needs of the Community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: TV Reception: South Gippsland Highway Region
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of South Gippsland in the State of Victoria draws to the attention of the House that since aggregation of television reception commencing on 1st January, 1992 residents of the area on and around the South Gippsland Highway from Toora to Hedley, have suffered at worst the total loss of reception from the ABC Channel, to severe ghosting on channels that they still receive and in the extreme case, no reception at all. Technical advice received to date, would indicate that the installation of new antennaes to meet aggregation requirements will not overcome the interference from the surrounding hills.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to render technical assistance in the form of a translator station to be located at the Barry Beach Marine Terminal for relay of all signals into the Toora/Welshpool area.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Second Frequency
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of N.S.W. and Vic. draws to the attention of the House that the rescheduling of programmes on radio S.B.S. is a divisive measure damaging to a multicultural nation.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House approve a second frequency for radio S.B.S. in order to adequately meet the needs of newly arrived communities without penalising the ageing and minority migrant groups.

La petizione di certi residenti del N.S.W. e Vic. desidera indurre l'attenzione della camera dei deputati sul fatto che la ristrutturazione dei programmi della radio S.B.S. e' un'azione divisoria che danneggia una nazione multiculturale.

I richiedenti percio' desideranno che la camera approvi una seconda frequenza per la radio S.B.S. per poter adeguatamente rispondere alle necessita' delle nuove comunita' senza penalizzare quelle piu' piccole, o quelle che stanno invecchiando.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment—Call for Election
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Bendigo draws to the attention of the House the significant level of unemployment in Australia, and its effect on the well being of the community and the Country.
We particularly draw to your attention the increase in the level of unemployment during the past 12 months, which has jumped from 8.1 per cent to 10.6 per cent, and is expected to rise further.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Government to:

PETITION.PARA: Immediately call on the Governor-General to issue the writs for a general election to provide an opportunity for all Australians to decide upon the economic direction of the Nation.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia: Christian Commonwealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, call for the full and total recognition by Federal Parliament and the High Court and all government agencies that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth according to law and its heritage traditions and customs.

That as Australia prepares for the Centenary of Federation on 1st January, 2001 AD, we celebrate our Centenary as a Christian Commonwealth as described by the Founders of Federation such as Sir John Downer, who said "The Commonwealth will be from its first stage a Christian Commonwealth" and as stated in our Federal Constitution—"humbly relying upon the Blessings of Almighty God. . .
That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD.
(1)The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem—"God Bless Australia" to the tune of "Waltzing Matilda".
(2)The Adoption of a Christian National Motto—"One Nation Under God", for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
(3)The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.
(4)The retention of our Christian Prayers at the daily opening of Parliament in the standing respectful presence of all Members of Parliament.
(5)The retention of "God Save the Queen" for Vice Regal Functions as our Royal Anthem and as our National Hymn for all other civic functions.
(6)The retention of Christian Christmas Carols in our State Schools and other civic functions during the Christmas Season.
(7)Officially inform the United Nations and all the other nations of the world that Australia is a Christian Commonwealth.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will reaffirm our Christian Heritage as a Christian Commonwealth.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House the current campaign which is being waged by the Communist Government of Serbia and its agents against the aspiration for independence of the Republic of Croatia.

We particularly draw to your attention the fact that Croatia has satisfied the conditions of international law for independence, and that it has made every effort to enter into meaningful dialogue with its opponents in Serbia. These have been to no avail.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House as a matter of urgency offers immediate recognition to Croatia as a sovereign nation.

PETITION.TITLE: Land Mines in Cambodia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the appalling plight of the Cambodian people maimed by land mines as documented in the Report of the Joint Agency Mission to Cambodia (1989) and Report of Asia Watch: Land Mines in Cambodia (1991).
Your petitioners request the House to:
i)urge the Federal Government to ensure that in any aid package allocated to Cambodia, the clearance of land mines be given high priority;

ii)request the United Nations for a review of the Protocols to the UN Convention on Prohibitions or Restrictions on the Use of Certain Conventional Weapons which may be deemed to be excessively injurious or to have indiscriminate effects;
iii)call on member nations of the United Nations for a total ban on the manufacture and use of anti-personnel land mines.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions : Deeming Provisions
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that pensioners of this country strongly protest against the application of the Deeming Provisions which relate to financial institutions and cash. The Provisions state that interest will not be deemed on the first $2000 ($4000 per couple); but we consider that this figure is unduly harsh in the present economic climate, especially when taking into account amounts required for food, clothing, licences, rates, insurances, and the fact that most people in their later years would like to travel before their health precludes this.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will consider increasing the Deeming Provisions to exclude the first $3500 ($7000 per couple).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws the attention of the House to the need to redress falls in the real value of the pension relative to wages, and the need to alleviate poverty among low-income Australians.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:
(1)Increase the basic pension rate by $15 per week
(2)Introduce a $20 pw supplement for pensioners with no other income
(3)Increase rent assistance
(4)Abolish the "deeming" legislation
(5)Extend fringe benefits to all pensioners, and
(6)Remove the $2.50 and other charges for prescriptions, in the 1991/1992 Budget of the Commonwealth.

PETITION.TITLE: Liquefied Petroleum Gas: Price
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia sheweth, that your petitioners are aggrieved over the frequent increases in the price of liquid petroleum gas over recent months, and the serious negative impact this is having on domestic users, particularly those people who are living on fixed incomes such as pensions.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the parliament either instruct the Prices Surveillance Authority to set the maximum price of liquid petroleum gas without linking it to the prevailing world price, or provide a subsidy to those domestic users who desperately need relief from escalating world parity prices.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Conflict in East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Queanbeyan and Canberra districts draws to the attention of the House the prolonged and bloody conflict between citizens of East Timor and the government of Indonesia.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to do its utmost to ensure a peaceful resolution of the conflict and ask the United Nations to organise a genuine referendum of the indigenous people of East Timor to determine their wishes for independence or incorporation into Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled;

PARA.TAB: This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating and important natural resources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and the purity of air and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (the peoples' arm of the UN), has proclaimed an Australian ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade from 1988;
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive and peaceful purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a healthier and safer future.
Your petitions therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that a world-wide ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5, 1992 with FIERY, the First International Earth Repair Year, and that this will be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly.
This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local & global unification and co-operation to stop the current destruction and start repairing our Earth by:
growing billions of trees to replace forests lost and to replenish the atmosphere;
hygienic composting of all presently wasted organic materials into humus to revitalise soils;
establishing globally, permanent, self-sustaining, organic agriculture to end world hunger;
reallocating annually 10% of all military budgets, personnel and resources, within each nation, to fund and support the ERA Decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Dili Massacre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of 14 citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we wish to protest at the continuing Indonesian occupation of East Timor and to deplore the massacre of Timorese civilians in Dili on 12 November.
Your petitioners therefore urgently request the House of Representatives to urge the Australian Government to vigorously promote:

PETITION.PARA: 1A credible United Nations investigation of the Dili Massacre; and
2the placing of United Nations observers in East Timor to prevent further human rights abuses;
and further call upon the Australian Government to:
1join with European Parliament members in immediately ceasing military aid to, and imposing of economic sanctions on, Indonesia; and
2demand a United Nations referendum on East Timor's right to self-determination.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX 1991
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

The arms trade is not only detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from socially beneficial areas—for example, health, education and social welfare—but is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of the people of the Third World.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Cease all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.
Direct all Federal and State Government Departments and instrumentalities to withdraw from participation in and support for AIDEX and similar arms fairs in Australia and overseas.
Close down AIDEX 1991.
Establish a register of all applications for arms transfers and offset agreements which would be subject to public scrutiny.
Redirect all monies currently being used to promote the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX 1991. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX 1991, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX 1991.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Materials to Minors
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House our objections to the availability of pornographic materials to minors.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising

The RAN apprentice training establishment at HMAS Nirimba is to close as a consequence of the Government's Defence Force Structure Review (FSR), which examined the most cost effective method of training the Australian Defence Forces (ADF) as a whole. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory I present the special report of the Committee proposing that the name of the Committee be changed to the Joint Committee on the National Capital.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This proposal has arisen out of the Committee's desire to emphasise the significant change in the focus of the Committee's activities that has occurred since the introduction of self-government in the ACT, and to reflect more accurately the Committee's new responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: The Joint Committee on the ACT was first established in November 1956. Until the ACT became self-governing, the Committee was concerned primarily with matters relating to the detailed planning and development of the Territory. Much of its work involved the examination of proposals to vary the plan of the road layout of Canberra. The Committee's responsibility now, after the introduction of self-government in the Territory, is not to examine road variations or other municipal matters, but to focus on issues relating to the national significance of Canberra. Matters of particular local or Territory-wide significance are now considered, as they should be, by the Territory Government and not by a committee of the Commonwealth Parliament.

Most of the Committee's work in the current Parliament has reflected its interest in Canberra as the national capital. The Committee has conducted two inquiries into the development of the national capital. It has examined aspects of Canberra's national and arterial road systems in assessing the transport options prepared by the National Capital Planning Authority for the new town of Gungahlin, and most recently the Committee has reviewed the first proposed amendment to the national capital plan. In addition, the Committee will soon begin an inquiry into environmental management policies and practices in those areas of open space in the Territory that are of national significance.

Through its work in this Parliament, the Committee has established itself as the parliamentary guardian of those aspects of Canberra which contribute to its character as the national capital. This responsibility is embodied in the Committee's resolution of appointment, which charges the Committee with the task of inquiring into, and reporting on, the national capital plan and any amendments to the plan.

Although many of the individuals and organisations with whom the Committee deals frequently are aware of the Committee's new focus, it has become evident that some people are either unaware that a change has occurred or are now uncertain about the Committee's role. A change of name from the Joint Committee on the ACT to the Joint Committee on the National Capital would help overcome this uncertainty. In particular, it would emphasise the fact that there has been a change in the Committee's focus and indicate more clearly the Committee's new responsibilities.

So to formalise the change of name, the Committee recommends that the Government move a motion in the House proposing that the Committee be known as the Joint Committee on the National Capital. As well as proposing the name change, the motion should provide for the current membership of the Committee to be continued and for the new Committee to continue the work of the Joint Committee on the ACT. A draft notice of motion specifying these matters is attached to this report. I move:
That consideration of the report be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with sessional order 102B the debate is adjourned. Resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 19 December 1991, on motion by Mr Johns:
That this House:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)notes that:

PARA.TAB: (a)water is one of Australia's most valuable resources;
(b)its use, treatment and availability vary enormously throughout the nation;
(c)there is debate as to whether this resource is managed sufficiently well so that the water available to the next generation will be at least as good as that currently available; and
(d)together, water and sewerage activities involve total employment of 35 000 workers and $2 billion worth of investment annually; and

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2)calls on the Government, in conjunction with the States and other authorities, to:

PARA.TAB: (a)consider how Australia can achieve more efficient and environmentally sound use of its water resources; and
(b)develop a national strategy for sustainable water quality management.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting this motion moved by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns), I would point out at the outset that Australia is a very dry continent and water is obviously very important. Because of Australia's dryness, our waterways are doubly precious compared with those overseas. In much of this continent the volume of water that rivers carry is small compared with world standards. This is especially so in droughts when the flow of rivers can almost stop even in our biggest river systems. This summer we found ourselves in another drought situation in eastern Australia, especially in southern Queensland and the north and west of New South Wales. At one stage we were faced with the largest blue-green algae outbreak in Australia's, if not the world's, history.

PARA.TAB: This, I believe, was a symptom of a more serious degradation of our waterways. We have come to recognise that there are many types of algae in our river systems normally, not all of them toxic. The ones that were causing concern mainly centred around the blue-green anabaena algae where you can have up to 5,000 cells per millilitre and still remain safe. However, with recent outbreaks, concentrations went up to 500,000 cells per millilitre. Of course, none of this is new. I believe there was a report in one of the British medical journals back in 1879 recording the first stock deaths in South Australia from algal poisoning.

The situation we faced in early December in this country was that in New South Wales we had four river systems infected at a serious level. The Darling River system was infected over 1,000 kilometres from Mungindi to Wilcannia and the algae were spreading south rapidly. The Hawkesbury system had algal blooms near Sydney. The Murrumbidgee River was infected near Hay and Balranald and the Williams River near Newcastle. In Victoria we had the Tooborac water supply infected and Lake Wallace in the western districts, and also Lake Mokoan. In Queensland the Condamine River had algal blooms and in Western Australia the Peel River near the Harvey Inlet, 90 kilometres south of Perth, had a nodularia strain of blue-green algae. In South Australia Lake Alexandria was hit earlier last year. The summer before, of course, in New South Wales the water supply at Lake Cargelligo was affected, as were the Chaffey Dam near Tamworth, Lake Keepit near Gunnedah, Lake Glenbawn near Muswellbrook and also the Carcoar Dam. I believe that is a warning to us that blue-green algae outbreaks have the potential to become the major water resource management issue of the 1990s and beyond, and there is a great need for research and assessment to understand and best manage this problem.

The phenomenon of blue-green algae outbreaks is imperfectly understood. It is a combination of many things, including temperature and stagnant water. If the water is clear, in other words not turbulent and muddy, it allows the release of nutriments. Under these conditions the algae grow profusely, particularly if the volume of the water is down so that the concentration of these nutriments is increased. The main nutriment in this is phosphorus. Phosphorus is a main source of food for the algae and they also need nitrogen, although the anabaena algae can fix their own nitrogen from the atmosphere. Work is being done at the moment on determining necessary phosphorus testing levels and also trying to identify the source of this phosphorus in the river systems.

All this is exacerbated by the absence of natural filters in the rivers. The river beds of our waterways normally have plant growth which utilises this phosphorus. However, various things such as European carp have eaten or destroyed many of our reed systems and this has exacerbated the problem. Also we have had in many areas a degradation of vegetation along river banks. I acknowledge that it is hard to do much about that but we are going to have to revise our practices with our river banks and perhaps look to planting more trees along them and preserving those trees that we already have.

We were fortunate that this was a cooler summer than normal. The rains that we have had, particularly recently, have stirred up the water, lowered the temperature, broken up the algae and in many areas flushed them away. We have to do, of course, much more work on determining the source of these nutriments. It appears that the main culprit is the sewerage outlets. Country cities may have to look to tertiary treating of their sewage, which is not done now except in the Canberra-Queanbeyan area, where they discharge only 0.5 parts per million of phosphorus into the river system. In other inland cities, where they do not engage tertiary treatment, the concentration can be up to 30 times higher than that. The sewage from cities like Dubbo, Tamworth, Wagga, Orange, Bathurst and Albury eventually flows into the Murray-Darling system.

Run-off, of course, is an important consideration. Animal manure from sheep and cattle flows into the rivers, and certain fertilisers such as superphosphate, which is mainly spread in the tableland areas and not in the western division of New South Wales, flow into these rivers too and there is a build-up over many years of sediments which are released under certain conditions. Of course, overgrazing—grazing right to the edges of the river banks—and irrigation run-off can aggravate this problem.

But having said that, I want to say something about the cotton industry, because it has been blamed when I believe it is not the culprit that many people think it is. There is little or no run-off from cotton now. Most cotton plantations are flood protected and have had irrigation tail water return systems in place for a long time and they indeed use very small amounts of phosphorous fertilisers.

The main downside from cotton growing is that they pump the river levels low and decrease the flow and, in that manner, increase the concentration of the nutriments. But chemical monitoring now goes on near cotton plantations and the algal blooms are often in river systems thousands of kilometres away from where cotton is grown. Of course, the main cotton rivers, the Macintyre, the Namoi and the Gwydir have had no blue-green algae growing at all.

I have had the opportunity to inspect some of this blue-green algae, particularly in the Darling River system, and the only green that you could see up there in that drought stricken area around Tilpa where I went, was the river itself. It looked like pea soup that had been through a blender, floating around on top of the river as well as having blue colonies of actively growing algae. But even there I was surprised to see the fish were still jumping out of the water and the stock losses were almost zero, so it poses the question of just how serious this algae problem is. I do not think that even that basic question is yet answered.

Now, what should we do? In the short term there is little we can do. We have fortunately had the flushing effect from rain. We can look at releasing water from dams. The New South Wales Government has sunk 10 bores between Bourke and Wilcannia and, putting that water through activated carbon filters has ensured clean town water and clean stock water.

In the long term we have to do more work on the nutriments and the sediments which may, of course, be there for decades. We have to look to vegetating banks and be conscious of nutriment run-off. We could consider the use of artificial aeration of water in dams to break up the layering or thermal stratification of the system, such as pumping oxygen into the base of the dams, which has been done in some areas. Biological control needs to be looked at, including cyanophages or algae eaters. We have to monitor food and plant webs in the river systems and perhaps do research on enzymes to neutralise the toxins.

A national task force has been set up which has to be properly funded, so that it can prepare action programs for the consideration for the future on how we should manage nutriments and run-off. We also have to coordinate the States into a federal system better than we have, so that they are not all acting in isolation.
In conclusion, the summer that we have had has given us a very serious warning of what a massive problem this can be. More needs to be done in the future. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the most important issues facing Australia. I think it is good that this debate is taking place because the environment has been hijacked in Australia in the past by people who promoted issues which were really not of any great consequence.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that water, water quality, and the associated problems with soil erosion and salinity are the number one pollution problem in Australia—the number one environmental problem. I would say that it is followed by problems of city pollution. It is an indictment of our sundry environmental groups that they have spent so much time looking at trees and attacking forestry when, in fact, we have in Australia probably the best forest management in the world.

Blue-green algae are clearly a problem. One of the great dangers of this is that if we do not get on top of this problem very quickly, it will be taken over by the environmental movement and it will become the cause of the moment. As the dire threats of greenhouse warming are shown to be false and not supported by the available evidence—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong.

—The Minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, is wrong. If she reads all the material, she will find that I am in fact absolutely right. As that occurs, I think there is a chance that these people in the environmental movement will move into the blue-green algae field.

PARA.TAB: One of the problems caused with algae is that you often do get a lot of death of fish and stock when algae die—even when they are not toxic algae. This can be caused through a sudden increase in turbidity in the water, cutting down photosynthesis. What happens there is that they simply absorb all the oxygen from the water and the fish die as a consequence. It is rather interesting that when this has occurred on occasions on the Ord River, people have blamed chemicals used by the horticulture industry there. The real problem was in fact the rotting in the water of vegetation which, like algae, is tied into photosynthesis.

With the blue-green algae, it is quite clear that the main cause of nutrient enrichment is sewage from towns. We do have to take this seriously. We have to make sure that there is tertiary treatment of effluent and that calcium is removed. There are many ways of doing this and I am sure there are chemical processes. I know that in the area of the Nullarbor, where I have spent a lot of time and where we have a phosphorus deficiency, it is caused because of the redness of calcium, which locks up phosphorus. It may be possible to lock up phosphorus simply by locking it to insoluble calcium phosphates. In any case, this must be tackled, and tackled as a priority.

Agriculture is a peripheral cause. I think this is a very good case for supporting the proposals put forward from the Riverland for a campaign for clean food from a clean country. I think it is a very exciting program and it seeks to sell our product at a premium by assuring the world that we are using the minimum of chemicals, we are using the minimum water and that our product is grown under the best possible environmental conditions—conditions that will give you sustainable agriculture. Clearly, it is a waste. Farmers are costing themselves money if nutrient that they apply to the ground has been washed into rivers, and this is something which we must be careful of. I think it will call for much more careful soil testing to see whether applications of fertiliser are absolutely necessary, and at what levels they should be applied.

So the opportunity does exist for making a big impact on this problem. Given the nature of Australia, we are always going to have periods of recurring drought and there is no doubt that this problem occurs most when river levels are low. As the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) pointed out, it is this that tends to concentrate the nutrient in the available water. So we are going to have to look at better control of river flows, perhaps by better manipulation of dam levels, but in any case there are limits as to how much Australia can do that, given our shortage of rain. Water is a big problem for our cities and it is something of which Australia has become very much preoccupied.

I think it is important that we do not go overboard and be panicked. There is, after all, abundant water for our cities, and this is contained in our oceans. At the present level of technology, desalination of sea water costs something around $1.80 a kilolitre. It is expensive by present standards, but the cost will decrease as technology improves. I foresee that we will get that cost down to a level which would certainly be justified for city consumption.

Because water is such an emotional problem in Australia, we tend to get fed from time to time the snake oil solution. We have one of those in Western Australia right now where the State Government is, in fact, committed to spending $3m to research carrying river water from the Ord River to Perth. The proposal is to take it to Perth via a pipeline that will cost us some $9 billion.

It is amazing how much support this has. The Government—and I might say the Opposition is equally as culpable because it too has gone along with this undoubted snake oil scheme—has gone out and asked people, `Would you like to have an assured supply of water in Perth from the Ord River?'. People then say, `Yes, of course I would', and you have an overwhelming response from people saying yes. However, if the question was, `Would you like an assured supply of water from the Ord River at prices which you cannot afford?', the answer would have been no.

The truth is that the very best estimate of the cost of that water, if you discount the capital costs, is something between $3.50 and $4 a kilolitre. That is if you discount the capital costs of something like $9 billion to get it there.

The visionaries say to me, `Ah, but you have no vision. Do you not see the towns springing up along the road? Do you do not see along the length of this pipeline the new settlements producing irrigated produce?'. I must say here that this overlooks the fact that we would have trouble selling such produce at the moment, but they are potential markets for the future. They say to me, `Do you not see Australia being greened in the centre?'

The reality is that there are mechanical limitations to what a pipeline can carry because water cannot be compressed. A pipeline of 1.6 metres diameter will carry about 50 million cubic metres of water to Perth per year. That is enough water to irrigate 50 square kilometres of land to a depth of one metre. Given that the evaporation rate over a lot of my electorate is two or three times that, in reality it would be possible to irrigate something less than 20 square kilometres.

Twenty square kilometres is not very much and from an aeroplane it would be very hard to find. Once the water was used to irrigate these towns to the extent of 20 square kilometres, there would not be any water left for Perth, never mind water for Adelaide. The proponents of the scheme only make it work by using the water in one place, shoving it back into the pipe, and taking it to be used somewhere else. It is a nonsense scheme and I think it is absolutely appalling that the State Government and the State Opposition are supporting the use of $3m of taxpayers' money to do this.

It is often said to me, `Ah, but if it was not for the pipeline you would not be existing in Kalgoorlie'. That is nonsense. In 1900 when it was decided to start that pipeline, Kalgoorlie was the booming centre of Western Australia. It was paying, in 1900, a shilling a gallon for water. It made sense to put a pipeline in, and bear in mind that the Kalgoorlie pipeline is only about 550 kilometres whereas we are talking about a pipeline of four times that length. Remember, the Water Authority of Western Australia has clearly shown that length is important to the economics of a pipeline.

What the pipeline did in the goldfields was to reduce the cost of water and gave an assured supply of water. It was of enormous benefit. It will be a pity if we are blinded by this great achievement and support the nonsense being put forward by certain people at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on this motion put forward by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns). Water as we know is one of our most precious resources but Australia being the country that it is, a land of contrasts, means we have either too much or too little. We have too much rain in the north of Australia or we have too little in the south of Australia. We have drought conditions throughout many areas of Australia at this moment while at the same time we also have flooding in this vast country of ours.

PARA.TAB: Australia is a very arid country in many parts of it. We have a small strip around the coast where there is adequate rainfall and where there are adequate water supplies, but we either have too much rain in the north or too little in the south, or vice versa depending on the season. The variation of rainfall throughout this country means it is extremely difficult to calculate and is never consistent.

The rainfall generally falls too close to the coast where we have little ability to store or conserve that water. Many of our northern rivers are of short length and the rainfall that falls in many of those areas flows out to sea. We have too little rain in many areas of the inland, too little rain to enable a harvest to take place or to supplement the water supply in towns in the inland parts of Australia. We have too much water in many respects and much of that water is of poor quality. The quality of that water is affected by salting or else polluted by other factors.

One of the things that has emerged in the debate on Australia's population and migration into the future—and one of the considerations that has not been given a great deal of attention, of course—is how much water we have to support a population or an increased population. In fact, Australia's population may never exceed 50 million unless we do something dramatic about the conservation of water and the improvement of the quality of water which is available. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who preceded me, mentioned desalination and the impact that desalination could have in the future, provided, of course, that the technology can be further advanced and the cost of desalinising water can be brought down to a level at which people can afford and get a good quality water as a result of that desalination.

The scarcity of water throughout Australia has always been a problem and the distribution of that resource presents some massive problems for Australia. In fact, when I was a member of the Victorian State Parliament, the State Parliament set up a salinity committee which looked at a number of different areas. It brought down a report entitled The Salt of the Earth and tried to identify some of the causes of salination of land and salination of water throughout this vast country. The report was extremely well done. One of the important things the committee recognised was that the salt affected areas—saltpans, salt marshes, saline streams and ground water—have been a feature of the environment in western and northern Victoria since long before European settlement. In fact, the salinity problems were here long before this country was settled, and settled in the numbers that we have come to understand now.

We have had that problem for many years. The salinity committee of the Victorian Parliament made some excellent recommendations, many of which have been implemented. In fact, many of the areas of northern Victoria along the Murray irrigation area have adopted a lot of those recommendations and are looking at ways of arresting the ongoing salinity problem there.

As a rural area, of course, the Bendigo Federal electorate is dependent on water for both urban living and agricultural production. Even this year the grain growing in that area was affected either by too much rain in one burst or too little, in many instances, and, of course, that affected the grain growing production in that area.

Another problem which has been mentioned by my good friend the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) was the recent outbreaks of toxic blue-green algae. That problem, of course, has highlighted the importance and necessity of developing a national strategy for sustainable water quality management. The small township of Tooborac, not far from Bendigo, had its water supply halted and cut off because of algal bloom in the main reservoir. Water use was severely restricted, with none available for industry, agriculture or non-domestic use.

There is also the matter of ground water. Ground water, of course, is a valuable resource and one which is receiving much more attention now than it ever has in our past. The United Nations has been doing quite an amount of extensive research on this and has come up with a ground water policy. I quote briefly from the United Nations Charter on ground water management because I believe that it is extremely important. Recommendation I provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Government should formulate and adopt a long-term policy to protect ground water from preventing pollution and over-use. This policy should be comprehensive and implemented at all appropriate levels. It should be consistent with other water-management policies and be duly taken into account in other sectorial policies.

That matter has also been addressed in the Weekly Times, which is circulated throughout Victoria. It was highlighted in that paper as recently as 19 February, with an article headed `Out of sight, but water issues still bubble'. That article indicated that about 97 per cent of the world's fresh water resource is ground water and that most countries are dependent on its continuing purity. It went on to say:
The situation is so serious, the United Nations released an international ground water charter in 1989, the product of 10 years' research.
The important aspect from the point of view of agriculture is that the Victorian Farmers Federation water resources chairman, Mr John O'Brien, said:
. . . the majority of Victoria's ground water users did not object to paying for ground water management, but disagreed with the way pricing was brought in.
However, he went on to say:
Quite a few of the ground water users are now aware of the management function of the Rural Water Commission and they see that there is a need to manage ground water. . .

The point that I want to stress is that while ground is a very valuable resource, it has to be managed effectively and consistently so that the quality of that water is maintained. There are many areas throughout Australia where that quality of water is available; where it is a known resource. There obviously needs to be further examination and further exploration of the volume of water available. It is a valuable resource for Australia, particularly if we adhere to the quality and performance of that water and the ability for both urban and rural users to use that ground water in the effective production of crops which could be harvested in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I also served on the Natural Resources and Environment Committee of the Victorian Parliament as chairman of its inquiry into water resources in south-west Victoria. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be well aware of that inquiry. That inquiry addressed the question of water resources on a catchment basis in that south-west area of Victoria. It addressed the question of how water could be best harvested and conserved and how the quality could be maintained for the servicing of regional cities such as Geelong. The Victorian Government has embarked on a State-wide program on that issue. It has investigated and is concerned with the better management and harvesting of water so that the quality can be maintained.

I compliment the honourable member for Petrie on bringing this very important issue forward. There is a lot of research and information available on maintaining the quality of water for all Australians, and I know that in many respects Victoria has led the way in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of water conservation is the responsibility of all Australians. It should not just be the responsibility of the rural areas of Australia, because people in towns and cities also have a very important responsibility in that area.

PARA.TAB: National problems relating to water resources in the future will relate to quality and not just quantity. We must work to ensure that future generations of Australians will be able to rely on the same quality of water as that enjoyed by the present population. As with other problems relating to the issue of sustainable development, we must come to realise that water is a finite resource. This point was driven home by the toxic blue-green algae blooms which occurred in the Darling River last year.

As noted in its report, the Murray-Darling Basin Commission's investigation of this problem found that the algae blooms were the result of serious discharges into inland rivers. During an average year effluent from towns surrounding the Murray-Darling Basin add 500 tonnes of elemental phosphorus and 2,790 tonnes of nitrogen to the river system. This urban water pollution is added to that which occurs from farming and grazing, and a toxic cocktail of nutrients is created which feeds the growth of the blue-green algae.

The report of the Murray-Darling Commission found there to be three interrelated sources of the toxic algae bloom. The first, as I have indicated, was the pollution of the waterways which fed the algae from several different sources. The second was the reduced flows in the rivers in the basin due to irrigation and domestic demand. It found that something must be done to reduce the high level of wastage associated with water use. Finally, it found that the degradation of the river ecosystem was a significant factor in the spread of the algae and had resulted in the destruction of creatures which had kept the algae in check in the past. The most important point to be learned from the blue-green algae bloom in the Murray-Darling Basin last year is that action must be taken to ensure that all levels of government do all in their power to ensure the maintenance of quality in our water supplies.

In comparison with many other countries around the world, Australia is lucky in that it has, by international standards based on population, a plentiful supply of water. The answer to the problem of how to effectively manage our water resources is to use the resources we have more effectively. The manner in which this will be achieved is through a reduction of the level of wastage occurring at present in water usage.

Throughout Australia the level of water consumption is increasing at a level far in excess of the level of population growth. An investigation last year into the level of water consumption in Australia's second largest city, Melbourne, found that the level of consumption was growing at four times the level of population growth. The city's water consumption is at present around 459,000 million litres a year and is growing at a rate of 2.2 per cent per year. If this rate of increase continues, permanent water restrictions may be needed to be introduced within 14 years.

It is not the increase in population which is leading to this possibility; rather it is an increase in the rate of water use per head of population. Clearly, what is needed is a public education campaign to reduce the level of wastage. More dams, with their considerable economic and environmental costs, are not the answer. We must learn to manage the water resources already at our disposal more effectively.

The Federal Government has played an active role in the management of this most vital of natural resources. Its policies in this area are part of the Government's overall commitment to the goal of promoting ecologically sustainable development. The manner in which it has set out to achieve these goals has been through three primary mechanisms: the Australian Water Resources Commission, the AWRC; the Murray-Darling Basin ministerial initiative, the MDB; and financial assistance programs, particularly the Federal water resources assistance program, FWRAP.

The Australian Water Resources Council is made up of the Federal, State and Territory Ministers who have responsibility for the management of water resources and is chaired by the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The AWRC is at present involved in addressing a number of issues in water resources management, and is attempting to develop a shared policy framework and a national agenda in this area.

The Council has, in recent times, agreed that the issue of water quality should be taken into account when developing water management strategies, especially with regard to the issue of water quality management. In March of last year it issued a discussion paper which foreshadowed a framework through which water agencies could implement policies that are complementary to each other and the development of programs for water quality management.

The national water quality strategy is at present being developed by the AWRC to encourage a common approach to water quality management throughout Australia. It will do this through the use of guidelines which will be used in determining issues on a State by State basis. The strategy will recognise the interrelationship between environmental management and water resources management. The focus of the strategy will be to achieve sustainable use of Australia's water resources by ensuring that the quality of this resource is not only protected but also improved.

The creation of guidelines will provide policy direction to future planning and action in this area. The need to raise the level of community awareness of water quality issues is important if the development and implementation of the strategy is to be successful.

The Murray-Darling initiative is an initiative of the Federal, New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian governments. The initiative is designed to address environmental and water conservation and management issues in the basin. Out of this process have come two policy strategies. One has been a natural resource management strategy which has as its aim the provision of a strategic framework to achieve the sustainable use of natural resources within the region through planning and management programs, as well as joint community and government action. Part of this strategy is to improve the water quality of the Murray River and to preserve the natural environment of the basin and preserve sensitive ecosystems with respect to salinity.

In addition to these two important policy initiatives in the area of water resource management, the Government is also involved in the funding of other water related initiatives through the Federal water resources assistance program, FWRAP. This program was introduced in 1984 to help achieve the Federal Government's water policy objectives.

The aims of the program are the efficient development, use and management of the nation's water resources. The way in which the program does this is through the provision of funding to the State and Territory governments for water resource development and management. Under the program the Federal Government provides financial assistance for works and measures that advance the Federal Government's water policy objectives. The assistance provided has taken the form of loans for projects in the form of business ventures, or grants for projects that have no business goals.

So the Federal Government has certainly played its part in ensuring that our water resources are more effectively managed. However, if a comprehensive national strategy for sustainable water use is to be developed, State government cooperation in the process is required. The Australian Constitution limits the role which the Federal Government can play in this area. Under the Constitution the States have primary responsibility for water resources management.

For the development of a coordinated national approach to take place on this issue, a great deal of cooperation between all levels of government must occur. As in other areas of environmental policy, it is necessary to develop a national strategy, as problems related to the degradation of our water resources do not begin and end in any one State. Take, for example, the Murray-Darling Basin, which covers territory under the control of three different State governments. The development of an effective management strategy for this area takes the cooperation of the three State governments concerned as well as the overall coordination by the Federal Government.

What must be understood when discussing this issue is that the problem of how to effectively manage this resource is not unrelated to the problem of ecologically sustainable development. While no-one argues that we must pursue economic development if we are to progress as a community, there is a growing recognition within the community that environmental factors have often been undervalued when calculating our overall standard of living. There can be no question of the link between economic growth and a well managed environment.

Water, as a resource, should be managed in such a way as to ensure the maintenance of its essential function within the ecosystem. A balance needs to be found so as to ensure that the economic, social and environmental issues related to development can be settled in a satisfactory manner. It is important that research be carried out into the quality and quantity of water needed to ensure that river and wetland ecosystems are maintained, to minimise a repeat of the type of toxic algae outbreak which occurred in the Darling River last year.

The Government has moved in a satisfactory manner to ensure that those responsible for water resource management act in a cooperative and coordinated fashion. The Government is well on the way to providing focus to efforts to maintain a high quality water supply and reduce the environmental damage caused by water pollution. It has recognised the fact that, while it is unnecessary and potentially very expensive environmentally and economically to increase the quantity of water available for use, it is essential that the quality of that supply be improved.

So I endorse the sentiments embodied in the motion and expressed by other members here today, and I hope that a national strategy for sustainable water quality management is developed. It would be a catastrophe if the next generation were to be condemned to having to accept a water supply significantly below the standard that we presently enjoy.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! The time for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)recognises the vital role of small business in our economy; and
(2)condemns the Government for its poor economic and wages policies which have crippled the small business sector.

Mr Deputy Speaker, one of the most tragic consequences of the policy paralysis which has surrounded this Government—and this is in spite of last night's spending spree—is its impact on the small business sector. The Government has been so caught up in its leadership struggle and in filling just one job that it has completely neglected the plight of the small business sector.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, while small businesses have been grappling with the poor economy and struggling to survive, members of the Australian Labor Party have neglected the real issues to bicker amongst themselves. The result is clear. A lack of a comprehensive small business policy agenda, ongoing poor economic conditions, consistently low consumer confidence and growing unemployment have all led to the worst increase in small business bankruptcies on record. In fact, it would be fair to say that this has been the Government's only real achievement in respect of small business; that is, to bring about the worst decline of the sector and the greatest increase in the number of bankruptcies on record. The last financial year alone saw the number of business bankruptcies and personal bankruptcies grow by over 53 per cent. This is a huge increase in itself but is made more significant when one considers that it represents over 13,000 firms and individuals that have gone to the wall. That is 13,000 business proprietors who have lost their livelihood and families who have lost their homes.

Unfortunately, the number of small business bankruptcies is likely to get worse before it gets better. An analysis of the quarterly figures shows a rising trend. Bankruptcies increased by 52 per cent in the March quarter of 1991, by 55 per cent in the June quarter, and by a massive 72 per cent in the September quarter. Whilst the percentage increase fell slightly over the December quarter, continuing poor economic conditions, high unemployment and a very flat Christmas trading period all point to a further substantial increase in bankruptcies over the March and June quarters.

However, the Government must be careful not to take these figures as representative of the true situation. Things out there are much worse. As the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) admitted, bankruptcy statistics do not reflect the many thousands of small business proprietors who do not reach the bankruptcy stage but who just close their doors and walk away.

In looking at the decline of the small business sector, it is important to consider not only the number of bankruptcies but also the reasons given for them. According to the 1990-91 annual report required under the Bankruptcy Act, economic conditions were the main cause of business bankruptcies. But what have we heard from this Government about the crisis confronting the small business sector? Absolutely nothing. Indeed, it has shown a continuing reluctance to recognise the plight of small business.

Nowhere has this been more evident than in the economic statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last night. Sure, the Prime Minister gave us a lot of flowery words and painted a very rosy picture. But the crucial question is not so much what he hopes to achieve but whether he can deliver the goods.
