We should not forget that the Prime Minister is the same man who said, `There will not be a recession, we will not let there be a recession' and, `I knew we had to have a recession but I did not want to tell you'. He is the same man who said in February of 1990, `We will not have a scorched earth policy, we will not destroy business activity, and we will not destroy employment'. In November 1990 he said that the worst impact of the recession had passed. Then in December 1990 he said that the recovery would occur in the middle of 1991.

How can the one million Australians who are unemployed and the 13,000 bankrupt small business firms ever believe anything that the Prime Minister has to say? What about the thousands of small business people who accepted his word that there would be no recession and who borrowed money to invest in new plant and equipment, only to be caught out by the worst recession in 60 years? How can they ever trust this Prime Minister?

The small business sector is one which the Australian nation cannot do without. In fact, more than any other group, the small business sector has the potential to lead us out of this recession and to contribute most to employment growth. There are nearly 800,000 small businesses, comprising 96 per cent of all enterprises and employing just on 2.5 million people. In spite of this very significant contribution and its vital role in the provision of an infrastructure base, small business goes largely unnoticed by this Government.

Certainly we see very little consideration of the sector in the development and implementation of policy. This was illustrated again in the lead-up to the Government's economic statement last night. The Prime Minister made a big show of holding well publicised meetings with big business, trade unions and welfare groups. But where in the initial consultation process was small business represented? Only after some prodding—indeed, it was almost as an afterthought—did the Prime Minister even meet with the Small Business Coalition, much less hold meaningful discussions with the industry. It is not surprising to note, therefore, that last night's statement actually contained very little for small business.

Business costs, including fuel, payroll taxes, superannuation levy and the training levy, were not addressed. Similarly, the Government's increased funding to encourage small business to export will help only 700 of Australia's 800,000 small businesses.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! I draw the attention of the honourable member for Forrest to the fact that he is entitled to make passing reference to events in the House but he is not entitled to debate a matter which is not before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. If the Government was serious about enabling small business to maximise its contribution to Australia's economic recovery, it should have adopted measures contained in the coalition's Fightback package. Fightback offers small business tangible policies to meet its potential and to plan with certainty and confidence. No longer will small business be subject to wild fluctuations in interest rates and the damaging boom and bust cycles that confront industry today. The coalition will also reform the tax system to reward small business people for hard work and effort, to lower their costs and to enhance their competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: Given our commitment to make business more competitive, the coalition will abolish $20 billion worth of taxes on business, including the wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, petrol excise, customs duties and the training levy. In doing this, we will reduce business costs and make small business both domestically and internationally competitive.

We will remove taxes from exports. The coalition's goods and services tax will be zero rated on exports and we will also be providing rebate on the GST on business inputs. In fact, all of the GST on inputs to business, whether for exports or domestic consumption and including raw materials, motor vehicles and fuel, et cetera, will be rebatable. This is fundamental to the coalition's commitment to reduce small business costs. It is interesting to note that this is one point that the Labor Party blatantly misrepresents or through sheer stupidity fails to recognise.

Small firms will also gain substantial cash flow benefits. They will have the use of the GST collective on sales from the time of collection up to the time of remittance for business and trading purposes.

Administration of the GST will also be relatively simple and, contrary to the Government's scare campaign, will not increase the administrative burden nor the administrative costs of small business. Small business will not have to introduce new systems to accommodate the GST, nor will it have to complete reams of paperwork. Indeed, calculations of the GST will utilise existing accounting records and remittances will involve the completion of just one form. Finally, small business will not have to issue sales receipts beyond those already issued by business.

Again, the Labor Party has failed to comprehend these facts or else it is blatantly distorting them. Either way, it is a measure of its desperation that it has to resort to such blatant and immature scare tactics. The coalition will also substantially reduce income tax rates and provide comprehensive measures which give consumers more disposable income, thereby boosting demand and production.

Another significant component of our tax reform program is the introduction of a capital gains tax roll-over. This is one area that the Government got wrong last night. It failed to recognise that the roll-over would encourage the growth and expansion of small business as well as the generation of a significant number of employment opportunities. Indeed, the Government's half-hearted measures announced last night fell well short of the comprehensive reforms for the capital gains tax outlined in the coalition's Fightback! document.

Reform of the industrial relations system is also essential. Award wage rises, compulsory superannuation and the training levy all have a significant and additional cost impact on small business without providing any real benefits. Small businesses are forced to pay the wage increases negotiated by the Government and the Industrial Relations Commission but, in a lot of cases, do not realise any offsetting productivity benefits. The coalition is committed to changing this by deregulating the labour market to enable employers and employees to negotiate their own enterprise agreements. The benefit to employers will be through better productivity and lower costs, while employees will gain because of a potentially higher take-home pay, more flexible conditions of employment and better working conditions and a better working environment.

Small businesses have long supported this policy and have lobbied Government for similar measures. But because the Government is tied to the trade union movement, it cannot deliver on this important area of reform. An accelerated program of reform in the transport system, on the waterfront, an education system targeted more towards the changing needs of our society, a national savings strategy and a better health care system are other features of the Fightback package.

The sweeping nature of the coalition's proposals, the very substantial benefits that will accrue to small business, are a clear indication of the Coalition's commitment to that sector—a commitment which has not been demonstrated by this Government so far. The bottom line is that, under a coalition government, small business will be free to reach its full potential and once again take its rightful place as a significant contributor to employment and to our national wealth and prosperity.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) has just resumed his seat and has endeavoured to use this debate to score a few political points. But if one looks at the history of small business in this nation and the record of this Government in relation to small business, then one can only say his criticisms are unwarranted and they are politically motivated.

PARA.TAB: It is a pity that the honourable member did not bother to read the economic statement from last night and also did not bother to ask his researchers or take the time himself to go back and see just what this Government has been doing in the area of small business over recent years. Had he bothered to read the Beddall report, he would not be standing up in this chamber making such outlandish statements. If he had bothered to see what has taken place in recent times through the structures that the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) has brought forward, he would also not be making these criticisms.

This Government initiated the first inquiry ever into small business. One recalls that when the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) was the Minister for Science and Small Business he initiated this approach. It was taken up by a committee headed by the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. After two years the Beddall report was brought down. I would say that it was hailed by people right across the nation, right across the political spectrum. It was supported by people of all political persuasions. It was not something supported only by the ACTU; it was supported by the chambers of commerce, by the CAI, and by the small business associations, because they saw that for the first time a committee of this Parliament had got to the real issues.

The Committee brought down 66 recommendations, 57 of which have been acted upon or are in train. That leaves only nine that have not been dealt with, yet the honourable member for Forrest has the audacity to stand up here and say that this Government does not recognise the importance of small business in our economy. I point out that this was the first inquiry. In spite of the fact that we have across from us an Opposition which is supposed to be a supporter and promoter of small business in the community, it was this Labor Government that acted on this matter.

The honourable member for Forrest talked about the problems of small business; I acknowledge those. I acknowledge that there have been real difficulties for small business in recent years, but let us not forget the part played by the banks in all this. We have seen official interest rates drop something like 10 points in the last 20 months, yet small business in my area still faces overdraft rates of 18 per cent. The banks have been generous in that they have dropped rates down to 16 per cent. The official rate is 8 per cent.

We see a real dilemma for small business because not only have they been locked into high interest rates, they have also not been able to borrow further. Those who have tried to borrow to extend their overdraft have been told, `No, you can take part in overdraft and part in a cocktail loan'. I have said in this House before—and I restate it because it happened again recently—that a small business person had to take part of his need

SPEECH.PARA: in an overdraft form and the rest on Bankcard.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Bankcard.

—I am glad the honourable member for Fadden has acknowledged this because he has a special knowledge of small business and I acknowledge his expertise in this field. It is ridiculous that people cannot go out and borrow in overdraft terms, but must take so much at 16 per cent on overdraft and the rest at 23 per cent on Bankcard. That has been very much the approach. There have also been some difficulties when banks have refused to lend for motels, hotels and small businesses. They have had amazing restrictions, ridiculous restrictions, saying that people have not had expertise in the field.

PARA.TAB: I had a case of a fellow buying into a fruit shop. He was even including in his business administration for the next six months, one of the owners, the previous owners, who was going to work for him for six months, yet the bank knocked back the loan because they said he himself did not have experience in that business. In a fruit shop! Quite amazing. The same has been true in so many other industries where the banks have taken a hardline view because of the mistakes they made in previous years in lending practices.

But setting that aside, let us come back to what this Government has done. If one looks at this, one particularly must give credit to the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs. This man, because of his knowledge of small business, his expertise and experience in it, his commitment to it and his understanding of its vitality and its potential to turn this country around, has done everything required of him. Most importantly he has listened. He was the first to sit down and talk to small business. He was the first to set up a small business coalition.

Let us recall what the record shows: 35 business associations representing all sections of the economy—the Council of Small Business Associations of Australia, the Australian Small Business Association, the Chamber of Commerce, the CAI, the Chamber of Manufactures, the MTIA, the MTAA, the Motor Trades Association of Australia, including the service station people, and the real estate institutes through the REIA—have sat down in consultation and discussion and brought forward some major recommendations.

It has also been this Government through that Minister that inquired into the franchise problems in that industry. It is this Government that carried out this inquiry and brought together a task force. It did not just talk about it; it came up with the goods. Members who took the opportunity to read the report, which was released in December last year, would know that it is revolutionary. It is the sort of report we needed. It is a comprehensive policy, not to regulate the franchise industry but to allow self-regulation. Some control is kept by using the banking industry as an instrument to ensure that those that do not play the game in franchising are not going to be able to get the money.

I see this as a very, very important and positive approach. Now it has got to go to the States; it will come about only with the support of State Ministers. But I am sure, I am confident, that what the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs set out here with the support of private enterprise will be achieved. He has been able to sit down with franchisers and franchisees of the legal and banking industry and come up with what is certainly a proposal and policy that will be a catalyst to vitality and growth in the franchising industry.

It was also that Minister, with the backing of other members on this side of the House—and, I might say, also of some Labor senators, Democrats and others in the Senate—who changed the Trade Practices Act to expand the effective impact of section 52A on unconscionable conduct. Consumers have had protection under section 52A of the Trade Practices Act, but small business has not. It has been this Government—the previous Prime Minister, backed by the present Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and Cabinet—that has moved to expand section 52A. It has been the same Government that has ensured that there have now been major changes coming out of the deliberations that took place on 6 February. Those small business leaders who met with the Prime Minister put forward a number of propositions. Yet the honourable member for Forrest says nothing is taking place in the economic statement. If only he would read it, if only he would go to the issues of capital gains, he would note that the exemptions on goodwill have been increased from 20 per cent to 50 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no goodwill. Now that they are going broke they can't give their businesses away.
—The honourable member really wants to sit down and talk to the small business people in his electorate, because they have a lot to say. They can teach him something.
—There are not many left. They are going broke.

—That is ridiculous, totally ridiculous. I know one can make generalisations and go out there to try to politicise things; but the honourable member should go and talk to those people, and he will find that they will applaud this measure. What it will mean is that they do not pay capital gains tax on up to 50 per cent of that goodwill element. It will give them that capital mobility; it will allow them to move into other businesses—not expand their own, but to sell and buy into something else knowing full well that they have that capital underpinning because they will not be paying capital gains tax on it.It just amazes me that the honourable member has not bothered to read that. It amazes me that he makes these criticisms strictly from a political point of view.

PARA.TAB: But let me go further. We find also in the economic statement a deferral of company tax payments for 1991-92. It is only for two months, it is only short term, but it acknowledges the problems that small business has been suffering in that recession. It is necessary short term relief that this Government is giving now; similarly with the new debt write-off provisions and debt for equity swap opportunities for the banking industry. Small business has been arguing for years that there ought to be greater incentive to banks to write off debts without winding up and destroying a business. This Government now says there shall be a tax benefit to those banks that wipe off bad debts. There is also now going to be tax recognition of debt for equity swaps.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! I would give the honourable member the same advice as I gave the previous speaker, that this is a debate on a motion, not on the economic statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept your point, Mr Deputy Speaker. The other matters you would be aware of are the triple increase in export funding for small business and the new depreciation provisions.

PARA.TAB: Let me go to another issue because the honourable member for Forrest raised the Opposition's perceived advantages of the GST. He ought to talk again to small business, because what the GST means is a burden on small business. Small business would become agencies for the Australian Taxation Office; it would be legally responsible for the collection of that tax; it would mean that it would have higher operating costs; it would have to purchase new equipment for outlays and for cash registers. One fellow says he will have to employ a person for at least eight hours a week just to meet the cost and the need to determine what tax has to be paid and what has been collected previously.

Why does the honourable member not talk to the tourist industry, the spare parts industry, the transport industry, the hairdressing industry and the petroleum industry? If he bothers to do that, he will find they are opposed to what Opposition members are about. It is a burden that they do not want; it is a cost to them; they do not want to play the role of tax man; they want to get out there and become viable, make money for themselves and expand. What the Opposition is proposing is not going to do that; it is going to fetter each and every small business in this country. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak to the motion moved by the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser). Having listened to the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), I feel that maybe we live in a different country, because all the incentives and benefits for business that he talks about are certainly not what I hear in talking to people on the ground. It amazes me that he can really believe the rubbish that the Government has been putting out in recent times, that he can believe that small business is getting a good deal under this Government.

PARA.TAB: I have asked the previous Prime Minister and this Prime Minister (Mr Keating) over a number of months to come down to my electorate and to talk to the business people in my electorate about the problems they have on the ground. I find it interesting that the honourable member for Capricornia, who is so interested in telling us all about the good side of business, does not even remain in the House to listen to some of the problems that exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you get a reply?

—I have not had a reply from the Prime Minister, no. The fact of the matter is that they do not want to listen to small business. They want to talk about going out and listening to them but they go down to Victoria and talk to the Wally Currans of this world. These are the problems that we face.

PARA.TAB: When we address these issues what we need to do is get away from the statistics. We heard from the member for Forrest earlier talking about the bankruptcy levels that exist. When you look at the Fraser years there were 3,860 bankruptcies on average every year. The average number under the Hawke administration was 7,520. Surely that says something about the direction in which business is going. The point has already been made by the Minister and by the shadow Minister that not all businesses go through the process of being declared bankrupt, that many of them simply close their doors.

The fact is that in the December quarter there were 4,137 bankruptcies. That is more in that December quarter than the total figure on average per year under the Fraser Administration. Despite this we have the honourable member for Capricornia coming in here and saying that the Government has done all these wonderful things under the Beddall report. If they are so darned wonderful, why have we got bankruptcies increasing at the rate that they are?

TALK.START.PARA: —They are at record rates.

—That is exactly right, as the Shadow Minister for Tourism indicates. When we talk about statistics, they can be adjusted to say exactly what people want. It has been said by some that we are exporting more. Part of the reason why we are exporting more in the way of steel products is that we cannot sell the darn things in Australia. And we are selling them at cheaper prices to enable competitors to sell back in against our own manufacturers in this country.

PARA.TAB: I would like to look at an area that I believe is a true gauge of where the country is headed, and that is the area of the real estate agents. In fact, I go to the real estate agents in my area regularly to have a look at how factories are being rented, and whether there is an increase in rentals or not. That is the real indicator, that is where we get the first indications of where things are going.

We listen to this Government talking about recovery, but let me just tell the House what some of the real estate agents are saying in my area. They tell me 75 per cent of small businesses are struggling to pay their rent; that the great majority of businesses are behind with rent payments and some of them are `quite behind'; that in the last 12 months things have been decidedly worse; that a large number of small businesses are relocating to cheaper premises or having their rents deferred since landlords prefer to do sweetheart deals rather than have the factory empty.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have sent the country broke.

—That is exactly right. The real estate agents also told me that cash flow problems are particularly noticeable at the moment; that there are problems for businesses associated with the Nissan plant closure, even though that is in a neighbouring electorate to mine; that things are getting worse and have never been so bad; that the demand for rental properties is low and there is very little business, and that this month is the worst they have experienced.

PARA.TAB: They are the comments of people in the first line, if you like, which indicate whether businesses are going to succeed or not. What they are saying to us is that business cannot pay its rent. Business cannot pay its rent because of what has been occurring over the last few years under this Government with its policy of high interest rates.

I recall the comments of the honourable member for Capricornia who said that interest rates have been high and they have been locked in at those high rates. Who does he think got them to that position? Interest rate policy is the only mechanism the Government knew to use to try to look after the economy in this country. The real problem with this Government is that what it wants to do is come out and say how wonderful things are on the surface but when we get out and talk to the individual people in the street it is a totally different picture.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are out of touch.

—They are out of touch as the member for Forrest and as the shadow Minister says. Now in contrast to that, what we are doing within the coalition with the Fightback package is giving people opportunities. We are going to cut away the costs that are going to make the difference between businesses being able to succeed and not.

PARA.TAB: Payroll tax, $5.8 billion a year, is a major impost on business. By cutting that away we will be able to provide people with a reduction in cost. In fact, if one looks at tax levels overall, one will see that we will be cutting in excess of $20 billion out of the cost to business. That means that business will be able to compete with overseas competitors. It is no good throwing money against the wall and saying, `Here is the opportunity for jobs to be created'. The fact is that the Government will have to continue to throw money against the wall because they are part time jobs the Government is creating. The life span of these jobs will be two or three years. They will not be available on a long term basis.

What we are trying to do and what we must do if this country is to get back on its feet is to offer full time opportunities. We have to address the area of small business. Ninety-six per cent of the businesses in this country are small businesses. We have to give them the opportunity to compete. That is not something the Government has addressed. It is all very well to say, `We are going to provide a few jobs here and we are going to provide a few jobs there through throwing money at the wall'. We must give businesses the incentive to continue and give them the opportunity to see a light at the end of the tunnel. In recent years that light has been very dim indeed.

I believe that the shadow Minister for small business, the honourable member for Forrest, is very correct with the motion he has moved with respect to this Government's performance, or lack of performance, in the area of small business. The Government should look at the real issues of businesses on the ground and talk to the people who have mortgaged their houses and put all of their savings into a business that they had hoped they could keep for their family as an ongoing concern, only to find themselves being put into the situation of bankruptcy through no fault of their own. I stress that point—through no fault of their own but through the handling of the economy by this Government. I believe that we as a coalition must stand up to address those issues and do something for those people. That is what the Fightback package does.

It was interesting to hear the comment earlier that in fact we are not addressing small business issues. The fact of the matter is that our package will give the opportunity for jobs to be created in small businesses. I take the point that was made that there will be businesses that will not get the benefit of the payroll tax initiative directly. They will get it indirectly because jobs will be created within the system. People will be able to get jobs and buy goods once again. That has not been happening. We have had to readdress this whole direction and the whole recipe.

If the Government suggests that its policies will do anything in the interests of small business then all I can suggest is that Government members come and talk to people in my electorate. They have refused so far. I am not looking for political gain out of this. I want them to come and listen to the problems that I face on the ground in one of the largest small manufacturing electorates in the country. When they have heard those comments I would ask them to think again about the rhetoric that they produce in this place to the effect that small business is looking rosy. I can assure them that in the electorate of Isaacs, in many of the neighbouring electorates and, I would suggest, around the country that is just not the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a typical Liberal speech with a lot of talk about what is happening in the economy and very little talk about what the Liberals would do to fix it. It is salutary to recognise that small business does thrive when the economy is thriving—there is no doubt about that. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said the other day, when we became the Government the size of our economy, as measured by the GDP, was $171 billion. Last year it grew to $405 billion—a rapid growth, whichever way you measure it. That rapid growth in the economy was matched by a rapid growth in small business.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) spoke about bankruptcies. He made the comparison with the Fraser years and talked about using statistics. It is obvious that there were fewer small businesses in the Fraser years. There are a lot more small businesses now. It might be a good exercise to have a look at the ratio of businesses that are failing now compared to the ratio of businesses that failed during the Fraser years. I think the honourable member would find that there was not much difference.

I have a pamphlet from the Sydney Business and Technology Centre which has a scheme for helping small business. It says that 85 per cent of small businesses succeed when they start in a business incubator—that is what the Business and Technology Centre is promoting—and that 80 per cent fail when they do not. I know we should take what we read in advertising with a grain of salt, but in the pamphlet it says that Australia has one of the worst failure rates for small businesses in the world. What the people at the Business and Technology Centre are saying is that the main reason for small business failure is lack of management technique and lack of management know-how. So, for whatever reason a small business fails, it will fail whether times are good or times are bad. It is just that more of them fail when times are bad.

The honourable member for Isaacs also talked about the Fightback package—quickly becoming the`Dieback' package. I listened very intently, but the only thing he mentioned in the whole speech was the abolition of payroll tax. The simple fact is that small business does not pay payroll tax—it is big business that pays payroll tax. So we should not look for any advantage for small business in the Fightback package because there is none. In actual fact, the Fightback package has within it the one element which will send more small businesses broke—the goods and services tax.

I refer to an article by Mr John Morine in the magazine called Australian Small Business and Investing. The article is based on the New Zealand experience of the impact of GST on small business. Mr Morine is a chartered accountant who has worked with the GST in New Zealand. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Sunday at the beach with the family will be a thing of the past, as you spend your `leisure' time grappling with GST returns and trying to unscramble your accounting records from taxation complications you do not understand.

Thus the experience in the country next to us which brought in a goods and services tax has been that small business failures have shot up remarkably. In the same article, Mr Morine refers to the tax-take in New Zealand and says:

a tax-take to the Government of $5 billion per annum, of which $1.25 billion or 25 per cent is lost in meeting the cost to the business sector of complying with the GST legislation and accounting for tax,
an estimated 20 per cent dissipation of time and resources for small business proprietors.

In weighing up the Fightback package and its impact on small business, we should not talk about payroll tax, because in actual fact the abolition of payroll tax is a disadvantage to small business. Let me explain why. If I were a retailer with a small family business retailing anything at all—shoes, curtains or any other household goods—competing against a firm such as Myers which does pay payroll tax, because my small business does not pay payroll tax, if the Opposition were to take off the payroll tax, that would give the advantage to Myers. Thus that would advantage big firms over small business.

PARA.TAB: As I have mentioned before in reference to the article by Mr Morine, a firm such as Myers has the accounting capacity to accommodate a GST, but the small businessman does not. The small businessman runs his own business and he must make the adjustment. He must get the accounting records to have a look at the goods coming into his business and the value he has to add to them. He has to subtract the GST from what he bought and he has to add on the GST to what he sells. Then he has to remit that to the taxation department on a monthly basis. The amount of book work involved in this is going to be horrendous for small business. Mr Morine, based on his experience, has this advice to offer to small businessmen in Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: If you and the other 800,000 or so small business proprietors throughout Australia do not succeed in getting the GST removed from the political agenda, you will rue the day you took no action. Act now. Otherwise you may not survive.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday in this chamber the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) referred to a Canadian report which said much the same thing. One would think that any political party or any politician worth his salt might actually go in and do a little bit of research about what impact the Fightback package, or the `Dieback' package, has on small business. When we look at New Zealand and Canada, two countries which have recently introduced the GST, we see that the impact on small business has been horrendous in both cases. The fact is that a small business at the present time only fills in one tax return when it pays its company tax.

I did not hear the honourable member for Isaacs mention in his speech that under the Fightback package company tax is going from 39c to 42c. That is another little thing in the Fightback package which I am sure small business will appreciate. The only form they fill out is when they pay their company tax at the end of the year. But have a look at what they are going to do now—they will have to get a tax collector's number, a big badge from the Taxation Office saying, `I am tax collector number whatever'. It is going to run into six or seven digits, and you can see them wearing it in their shops as official tax collectors for the Tax Office. It is going to cost small businesses; it is going to cost them time and it is going to cost them money. But not only that, when we sit down and look at the goods and services delivered by small business, they are by and large the goods that do not carry any tax now. When we go down to get a haircut there is no tax on that, but under Fightback it will be 15 per cent. What do honourable members think that is going to do to demand for the goods and services that small business provides? Do they think putting 15 per cent on top will actually increase demand or suppress it? It is a multiple choice question and I will leave them to mull over it. However, my instincts are that putting 15 per cent on those goods and services supplied by small business will actually cause demand to drop.

Maybe the next speaker can answer this: will demand go up with a 15 per cent tax on goods and services or will it go down? I cannot for the life of me see why this 15 per cent is a good thing for small business. I cannot see why a goods and services tax as announced in Fightback! will help small business people when they are going to spend their weekends, as Mr Morine says, not down at the beach with their families but grappling with GST returns.

Why is that good for small business? I cannot see it, but I am always open to persuasion. I have yet to hear it. I listened intently to the speech from the honourable member for Isaacs. He talked a lot about incentive—I thought `incentivation' might pop out—the light at the end of the tunnel, all of this good stuff, all of these heroic statements, all the motherhood statements, but the only thing he mentioned was the abolition of payroll tax and, as I pointed out, that is going to be a disadvantage to small business when it competes with big business.

He also talked about competing overseas. Let me give you the tip: most small business does not compete overseas. Some do, and for those we will be making sure that, through the export access program, which we boosted last night from $4m to $12m, they will get the assistance they need. But most small businesses compete within Australia; they compete amongst each other. There is nobody from overseas small businesses competing with ours. So, despite that talk about overseas competition, it is not a major factor. It is a factor but only a very minor one, and we addressed that last night.

In conclusion, let me say this: the Fightback package is a disaster for small business. It will not only suppress demand but it will also mean that small business will spend more of its time in complying with tax requirements, furnishing tax records to the Taxation Office and in the end it will mean that more small businesses will hit the fence. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this private member's motion introduced by the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser). Next December is the twentieth anniversary of the election of the Whitlam Government and the beginning of a steady decline in the fortunes of this nation and the morale of its people. Indeed, the record of the past 20 years speaks for itself. There is a record of incompetence and mismanagement, of social engineering and of systematic plundering of the nation's accumulated wealth, particularly small business wealth. It is the industrious middle class and its productive sector which have been decimated.

PARA.TAB: When E.G. Whitlam narrowly won the 1972 election, Australia's foreign debt was barely a ripple on the radar and the nation enjoyed some status as a member of the most prosperous nations club. Our small businesses were also prosperous. Today, Australia's circumstances are different. The status has dramatically changed. The level of foreign indebtedness has reached alarming proportions and the debt servicing burden is now absorbing a large fraction of our nation's savings, thus cutting into the nation's future growth potential—growth that can be generated by small business. The net cost of interest service is now approximately 20 per cent of export income, compared with 17 per cent in 1988-89 and less than 5 per cent in the early 1970s.

Australia is rapidly approaching the danger zone of 25 per cent and is highly exposed to the effects of a downturn in the world economy, especially a fall in commodity prices. Many small businesses are well above the 20 per cent danger zone. It costs them more than 25 per cent of their income to service their debt. At the same time we have, of course, lost our position in the most prosperous nations club and now we barely make the second eleven. The tragedy of more than a million unemployed and a depression we had to have is the culmination of 20 years of business bashing—not BHP bashing, but small business bashing. A loony left wing and anti-business policies emanating from Canberra and the Swanston Street soviet have caused this.

I want to describe to the House how businesses, particularly small businesses, have been decimated by Government policy. In 1973 the Whitlam Government abruptly reduced the tariff protection on clothing and footwear by some 25 per cent. This was a sudden change without reference to industry. Since 1973 tariff policies have been totally inconsistent. While there are undoubtedly strong arguments for tariff reduction in Australia, business has simply become the Government's whipping boy. Not only has it become ruthlessly exploited as a source of revenue, but also it is consistently assaulted by ridiculous bureaucratic changes and interference. A parts supplier to the car industry in my electorate of Dunkley has finally had enough and virtually quit Australia—it has quit production, in particular. Initially it believed it could cope with the Button car plan and it was able to cope with many changes. However, it finally came to the conclusion that it felt it was not wanted. The cost has been in jobs—jobs for ordinary Australians whose opportunities have been exported overseas.

I am concentrating on the last 20 years and it has taken that long for industry, particularly small business, to reach its present parlous state. No amount of snake oil rhetoric and vote buying by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) can change this. Business generally, and small business in particular, is, I believe, far weaker now than it has been since the disaster of the 1890s.

I will explain why. In the Depression of the 1930s businesses did not have to pay termination redundancy payments. They did not have to pay long service leave. Employees who were retrenched in the 1930s did not get these payments. The unions would say this is progress; however, I question the definition of progress. In recent decades companies have been weakened enormously, with the resulting unemployment that now afflicts well over a million Australians. I realise that it is not the employees' fault that they were retrenched; it certainly was not the employer's fault. The blame must be laid at the feet of Australia's protected army of meddling bureaucrats and the social engineering busybodies whose loathing of business has become so evident in government policy.

There are businesses in my electorate of Dunkley which are unable to retrench any more employees. They simply cannot afford it; there is no money left. The best employees, left until last, will not get their entitlements. The businesses will not survive; they will go bankrupt.

When payments such as termination redundancies became part of the award system they were little more than an enormous back pay costing billions of dollars—probably hundreds of billions of dollars in todeb's terms. The absolute tragedy is that our youth will continue to suffer. The 35 per cent youth unemployment is a catastrophe that will haunt the nation for a full generation at least.

Even the Government has admitted that businesses will not commence employing people in the short term. They will seek greater efficiencies from those already employed. Why should a small business operator employ additional people? Through no fault of the business person, he could run into another recession and have to pay out far more huge payments on redundancies and terminations. One cannot even put money aside to cover these payments. The Taxation Office will take 40 per cent. So if a person is entitled to a $5,000 redundancy package, which is not uncommon, the business person either has to find the money in depressed conditions or put aside $7,000 in good times.

The wealth of this country and the prosperity of small business that have taken so long to achieve are in great danger of being squandered by the spoiled baby boomers whose demands have so weakened our wealth creating capacity. They pour scorn on the achievements of the past and the struggles of our forAlears to create a prosperous and civilised society in what was very often a hostile environment.

The great wealth of our mining and pastoral industries and the opportunities created in business and industry have underpinned much that we value in Australia. However, very few seem to realise that wealth creation is a difficult and risky business. It can only be created in a very small number of ways: growing it, mining it and manufacturing it. Only these products can be traded and exchanged for wealth.

A century after the Great Depression of the 1890s, Australia is again in a bad way. The miners, mainly large businesses, are expanding overseas, as they appear to have little faith in the future of this country. Manufacturers, mainly small businesses, are not in a position to compete with imports, despite what the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) just said. Small business does have to compete with imported products. It is a huge factor when you set up a small business. No amount of taking the so-called hard decisions will change the situation.

Apart from honourable members opposite, it is almost impossible to find anybody in Australia who would agree with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that businesses are now competitive, better equipped and more confident than in past decades. It is not true. Most businesses I have visited—and I have visited more than 200 in my electorate in the last two months—are surviving in spite of the Government.

Just a moment ago, I referred to the very limited ways in which wealth can be created. Now I will describe the pall of gloom that has settled over small businesses due to high business rates. The pall of gloom is basically the result of complete misreading of the economy. There has been no real attempt to solve the problems facing business. I have made out a list of those items which affect business, which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Is leave granted?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen it. Is it a table?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Provided it meets the normal requirements, it may be incorporated.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

INTERJECT.PARA: SOME ASPECTS OF BUSINESS IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder how many of these problems were faced by businesses trying to survive in the Depression of the 1930s. Not many I suggest. Indeed, how very many small businesses can grow in Australia is a mystery to me. The tax regime makes it impossible for a small business to generate its own capital. It is forced into debt. The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) mentioned that small business does not collect payroll tax. Most payroll tax applies above 12 personnel in Australia, so most small businesses do collect payroll tax. The honourable member for Canning got it wrong. A small business person in Australia faces personal income tax, corporate tax, capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, provisional tax, sales tax, payroll tax, withholding tax, prescribed payments, import duties, Customs compilation charges, registration fees, licence fees, stamp duties, land tax, Federal tax on—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to support the first part of this motion, which says that we should recognise the vital role of small business in our economy. Who would not support this proposition? The small business sector of our economy is vital to the well-being of this nation and I recognise that immediately. I support this proposition.

PARA.TAB: The sector contains over 800,000 businesses that employ well over two million Australians. They are a source of innovation in terms of product and work practices and also in terms of introducing many of our great entrepreneurs to the marketplace and enabling them to make a start in the business world. Who would not support such a sector? It is, however, a very varied sector which ranges from the local deli and supermarket and the local newsagent to service providers such as plumbers, electricians and veterinarians. It also includes enterprises—such as I was proud to be a member of before I entered this place—for high technology, innovative product design, through which Australian industry can be upgraded and access to production of new technologies made available to Australian industry. It is, in other words, a very varied sector that we lump together merely because of the size of the enterprises: they are called small, or often small-medium, enterprises.

In the small business sector, it is quite typical for many firms to be forming and other firms to be moving out of business or going bankrupt. That is the normal order of a market economy such as we are members of. As new businesses form, so old businesses tend to go out. As the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) pointed out, because the small business sector has been larger during the 1980s and early 1990s, there have been more businesses coming in and more going out in the form of bankruptcies.

The second part of the proposition I find more difficult to support, so I will oppose it. It seeks to condemn the Government for its poor economic and wages policy which has crippled the small business sector. What can a government do that would most help this very diverse but extensive small business sector? The most important thing a government can do for this sector is to produce aggregate growth of the economy and the market in which the small business sector operates. If we look at the record of this Government during its nine years, there has been a very substantial growth of the Australian economy, from an aggregate of about $170 billion to an aggregate of about $405 billion.

This figure represents a growth rate of the economy of almost double that achieved during a similar period of the coalition Government. It represents a growth rate of just above 4 per cent per annum during those nine years and a growth in jobs of 1.5 million, a growth rate of 23 per cent. That contrasts with a growth rate in jobs during the previous Government's term of just over 300,000, or 5 to 6 per cent. During the term of this Government, we have seen the most substantial fillip that can be given to the small business sector, that is, a growth of the aggregate economy and the market within which it operates.

As well, we have seen efforts to alleviate problems which small business in the past has faced, as is well known to this House. Many small business people fail because they feel they lack the skills to run and operate a business. During the period of this Government we have increased very substantially training programs in business skills in the school system, the universities—where they have been designated an area of national priority—and in the TAFE system.

Similarly, the provision of labour to small business has been given attention. The unit costs of labour have been reduced, the number of industrial actions or strikes by labour has been reduced, and workplace reforms have ensured greater flexibility in the operation of our work force in small business places. We have ensured that our skill training programs have been locally designed in order to meet local enterprise skill needs.

I note in this respect that Skillshare is a local job market training program that the Opposition promised at the 1990 election to abolish, but I see that now it may well have changed its mind for the next election. I welcome this change.

Very early in the life of the Government we deregulated the finance sector with a view to making finance more readily available to small-medium business enterprises. It is true that all these reforms have witnessed some difficulty over the last 18 months with the onset of a recession which we all regret, which has been worldwide, and which would have been enormously difficult to avoid totally even with 100 per cent hindsight. This has led, as is typical of the trade cycle, to an increase in bankruptcies and to a reduction in the percentage of businesses being formed. Nonetheless, this recession will come to an end and small business will go into a boom economy once more.

Over the last two years we have paid great attention to the formation of a specific small business reform program based on the Beddall report, which was brought down in January 1990. By way of reaffirming the commitment of this Government to small and medium enterprises, I draw the House's attention not only to the extensive reform program suggested by the Beddall report but also to the progress that has been made in implementing that report which by now has been almost 87 per cent implemented.

What are the arrangements that have been put in place for small business in particular as a result of this specifically targeted small business reform program? First of all, improved consultative arrangements have been implemented with respect to the national small business forums and with respect to the national executive of small business agencies, and it has led to the creation of a Small Business Coalition which is therefore capable of consulting with government on the same basis as does the trade union movement or large businesses.

In the dialogue which led up to last night's statement we note that on 6 February the Small Business Coalition met with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in order to have its input into the 26 February statement and the results are there for all to see. We have improved the export access program in order to improve access to export markets for small business. Taxation reform has already been introduced with a view to streamlining tax administration and reducing compliance costs for small business. The operation of the market has been improved by extending section 52A of the Trade Practices Act to include commercial transactions, subject to the Cooney committee report, which was tabled in December 1991.

The franchising task force has already been referred to and retail and commercial tenancies are also under scrutiny for reform. The regulatory framework has also been changed with the federal paperwork reduction strategy. Finally, we have under review two inquiries, one from the Industry Commission and one from the Martin inquiry to improve access to finance for small business.

I have already referred to the management and business skills training strategy. This has been extended and when the now Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) was the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, he gave a commitment to extend the training of skills formation for business to the small business forum, and that will be implemented. A number of other provisions have been instituted with a view to improving the condition of small business and its operation.

Now in contrast to this I note the effects of the introduction of a GST package which the Opposition has designated Fightback. What would be the impact of this on small business? Two things need to be noticed. First of all, the goods and services tax of the type being proposed by the coalition would be a fully value added tax, which would be collected at every stage of production and distribution and processed for all goods and services. That would create a whole new load of paperwork for small business whether they are manufacturers, wholesalers, service businesses or retailers.

There are currently about 70,000 wholesale sales tax collection points in Australia. Under the GST proposal there would 850,000. I note that the honourable member for Canning referred to a New Zealand study of the effects of the GST published by John Morine in the Australian Small Business and Investing journal. I would like to quote a Canadian Federation of Independent Businesses study entitled The GST and National Tax Tragedy. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The findings of a survey of small businesses indicated that 70.6 per cent of respondents found that the GST had a negative impact of their business with 8 per cent believing the impact to be positive, while 14 per cent found no impact. The results clearly illustrate the regressive effects of taxes like the GST as smallest firms had the most problems with the tax.

Now in recognition of this, last night's statement introduced a range of new taxation measures and fiscal policy initiatives designed to improve the lot of small business. I will refer to them briefly. There is a substantial increase in capital gains tax relief for small businesses; a two-month extension of the 1991-92 company tax payments; a tripling of funding support to $12m for assisting small enterprises to get into export markets; the introduction of pooled development funds; changes to banking regulations to allow banks to write off loans to troubled businesses trying to trade their way out, and a commitment to banks to expand their lending. (Time expired)

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—The time allocated for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)recalls that the Australian Government was represented at the World Summit for Children in 1990 and that, on behalf of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, several promises were made regarding the needs of the world's children, namely:

PARA.TAB: (a)to cut down on all preventable child deaths by the year 2000;
(b)to cut maternal death rates by half by the year 2000;
(c)to reduce severe and moderate malnutrition among children by one half of the 1990 level;
(d)that a goal be set for the provision of clear water and sanitation for all families;
(e)that basic education be available to all and that at least 80 percent of all children complete primary education;
(f)that education be provided for at least half of uneducated and illiterate adults, especially women; and
(g)that children be provided with protection in situations of armed conflict;

SPEECH.PARA: (2)notes that to give effect to the above promises the Australian Government promised an interdepartmental committee to develop a plan to effect these aims by the end of 1991; and
(3)regrets that with less than two months left in 1991 there has been no announcement from the Government regarding the honouring of this commitment.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion is seconded.

—Honourable members will recall that the Australian Government was represented at the World Summit for Children in 1990 and that on behalf of the then Prime Minister of this country, Mr Hawke, several promises were made regarding the needs of the world's children. I might say that Australia was one of the few countries that were not formally represented at that conference by its Prime Minister but we were represented somewhat belatedly by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans. The promises that were made were to cut down all preventable child deaths by the year 2000; to cut maternal death rates by half by the year 2000; to reduce severe and moderate malnutrition among children by one half of the 1990 level; that a goal be set for the provision of clear water and sanitation for all families; that basic education be available to all and at least 80 per cent of all children complete primary education; that education be provided for at least half of the uneducated and illiterate adults, especially women; and that children be provided with protection in situations of armed conflict.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members should note that, to give effect to these promises, Australia promised that an interdepartmental committee to develop a plan to effect these aims by the end of 1991 would be put in place. I must say that I very much regret, and it is part of the terms of the motion, that, with less than two months to go in 1991, there had been no announcement from the Government regarding the honouring of this commitment. I should say, however, that finally the Government did establish an interdepartmental committee on 19 December, very much at the end of the year and three weeks after this notice of motion was given by me. I suspect that it was not a coincidence. No doubt the Government was intending to put in place these matters in a timely fashion, but it was some three weeks after this notice was given. It is extraordinary that the Government has taken a year to put in place the first steps towards development of a national plan of action which was supposed to have been completed by the year 1991.

At the World Summit, 71 world leaders gathered and made a commitment to support the rights of children and to give every child a better future. The impetus for such a gathering came from some most alarming statistics which brought home rather forcefully the magnitude of the problems confronting the children of the world. Nearly 15 million children under five die each year; half a million mothers die annually as a result of pregnancy or childbirth; some 40 per cent of children under five in the developing world suffer from malnutrition; only half the children in the developing world have access to clean water for drinking purposes, and fewer have access to sanitary waste disposal facilities. Nearly 100 million children of primary school age are not taking part in any education programs; about 50 per cent of adult women and 30 per cent of all adult men are illiterate and over 100 million children are suffering as a result of war and are victims of exploitation and abuse.

The 10-point plan of action aims to reduce many of these problems by the end of the decade. It is an ambitious undertaking for any nation and it is aimed primarily at alleviating child mortality and suffering, though its scope is much wider. Australia committed itself to the plan of action, which sets out the following 10-point program to protect the rights of children and to improve their lives. The list is quite comprehensive. I could in fact give the first sentence of each one but if it is in order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have a table setting out the 10 points, which I would seek to incorporate in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member should table the document. If it is in order it will be incorporated in Hansard.

—I ask honourable members to look at those points. They will see that we have set ourselves a formidable task. No-one would argue that such a task ought not have first priority in the business of government. After all, we are speaking of no lesser objective than the health, education, safety and long term well-being of the planet's most precious assets, our children.

PARA.TAB: It has been estimated that the additional annual cost of programs to prevent 50 million child deaths in the 1990s will reach approximately $2.5 billion by the end of the decade. No-one would argue that the objectives of the plan are not worth this price. No-one, for example, could in all conscience argue that the cost of a day's weapons production has an equal value to the lives of 50 million children at the same cost. The majority of these children will die from preventable diseases: diarrhoea, measles, tetanus in new-born babies, and acute respiratory infections such as pneumonia. The technology to prevent these diseases is at hand: oral rehydration for diarrhoea, antibiotics to stem the effects of pneumonia, and immunisation against measles and tetanus, as well as other diseases that can be wiped out, including polio.

The cost of oral rehydration therapy salts is only US10c and yet, of 11,000 children who die daily from diarrhoea, 7,000 succumb to dehydration which the oral rehydration therapy can prevent. Another 7,000 die from acute respiratory infections, mainly pneumonia. The cure is about $US1 for a course of antibiotics. Even though these two therapies have been available for decades, about 100 million have died from diarrhoeal dehydration and acute respiratory infections during that period.

The coalition accepts, in principle, the provisions of the plan and believes it is incumbent upon all of us to do what we can to ensure that the children of the world receive a better future. We also recognise that Australia may have some difficulty in achieving the targets implicit for Australia in the plan of action. The Council for Overseas Aid has calculated that Australia has made a commitment to spend an additional $110m per year on projects to benefit children. Clearly, there will have to be a readjustment of priorities in budgetary terms to make this target attainable.

The Government will also have to review all of its programs involving children. Most especially, this should involve a review of government responsibilities to the children of Australia. In 1989 Brian Burdekin, the Commissioner of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: There has been an almost complete failure to satisfactorily address the needs of our children, and many of these kids . . . are living in the most appalling conditions and in some cases, tragically, are literally dying . . . Children (are) reduced to hopelessness and to death from diseases which could have been avoided by effective programs and timely responses.
He was not talking about the problems as they exist in the Third World or in a developing country or in another country. He was speaking about the problem as it exists within Australia.

PARA.TAB: Here in Australia there are over half a million children living in poverty, and it was estimated in the Burdekin report that there are as many as 75,000 homeless youths. Two years after the Burdekin report, child poverty and homelessness are worse than ever. Also, while the provision of basic health services, such as clean drinking water, would normally have been seen as a priority only for a developing country, many Aboriginal children live in circumstances without access to basic services. Child mortality rates in the Aboriginal communities are significantly above the Australian average.

The causes of the problems the plan of action is designed to address are varied and complex. Many countries around the world are enduring the pains of economic recession and structural adjustment, and so poverty and all its consequences will be on the increase. To halt this trend, the entire web of interlocking causes must be addressed. It is incumbent upon all of us to address these causes; not only to address the present crisis but to prevent the cycle of poverty. We are very much a part of this. The expense is not only financial. The greater expense is in political will, time and commitment. Putting forward this effort, time and commitment involves a long term investment in the future of our children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before I call the next speaker, the honourable member for Dundas sought leave to have a document incorporated in Hansard. Unfortunately, it does not meet the requirements. The honourable member for Dundas might care to seek leave to have that document tabled.
—It was produced in a form of columns I hoped would meet the tabling requirements.
—It does not meet the incorporation requirements.

—Unfortunately, because it is raised at this stage, Mr Deputy Speaker, I omitted the points I would have made by summarising some of the plan of action. It is important, I think, to make sense of the contribution, that the 10-point plan of action be available to readers rather than simply tabled, which makes it available only to members of the House.
—Perhaps the best course of action would be for the honourable member to seek leave to speak again later in the debate.
—We could move for an extension of time now.
—It is private members' time; there are other members who wish to speak. That is a matter for the House to decide.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Smith) agreed to:
That the honourable member for Dundas be granted an extension of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 10-point plan of action is, first, that we will work to promote the earliest possible ratification and implementation of the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Programs to encourage information about child rights should be launched worldwide, taking into account the distinct cultural and social values in different countries.

PARA.TAB: The second is that we will work for a solid effort of national and international action to enhance children's health, to promote prenatal care, to lower infant and child mortality in all countries, among all peoples. We will promote the provision of clean water in all communities for all their children, as well as universal access to sanitation.

Three, that we will work for optimum growth and development in childhood through measures to eradicate hunger, malnutrition, and examine and thus relieve the millions of children of tragic sufferings in a world that has the means to feed all its children.
Four, we will work to strengthen the role and status of women and promote responsible planning of family size, child spacing, breastfeeding and safe motherhood.

Five, we will work for the respect of the role of the family in providing children and will support the efforts of parents and other care givers and communities to nurture and care for children from the earliest stages of childhood through adolescence. We will recognise the special needs of children who are separated from their families.

Six, we will work for programs that reduce illiteracy and provide educational opportunities for all children irrespective of their background and gender, and prepare children for productive employment and lifelong learning opportunities, that is, through vocational training that enables children to grow to adulthood with supportive and nurturing cultural and social context.

Seven, we will work to ameliorate the plight of millions of children who live under especially difficult circumstances; victims of apartheid and foreign occupation, orphans and street children, children of migrant workers, the displaced children and victims of nature and man-made disasters, the disabled and abused, the socially disadvantaged and the exploited. Refugee children must be helped to find new roots in life. We will work for special protection of the working child, for the abolition of illegal child labour and do our best to ensure that children are not drawn into becoming victims of the scourge of illicit drugs.

Eight, we will work carefully to protect children from the scourge of war and take measures to prevent further armed conflicts in order to give children everywhere a peaceful and secure future. We will promote the values of peace, understanding and dialogue in the education of children. The essential needs of children and families must be protected even in times of war and in violence ridden areas. We ask that periods of tranquillity and special relief corridors be observed for the benefit of children where war and violence are still taking place.
Nine, that we will work for common measures for the protection of the environment at all levels so that children can enjoy a safer and healthier future.

Ten, we will work for global attack on poverty which would have immediate benefits for children's welfare. The vulnerability and special needs of children in developing countries and in particular the least developed ones deserve priority, but growth and development need promotion in all states through national action and international cooperation. That calls for transfers of appropriate additional resources to developing countries as well as improved terms of trade, further trade liberalisation and measures for debt relief, and also implies structural adjustments that promote world economic growth, particularly in developing countries, while ensuring the well-being of the most vulnerable sectors of the population, in particular, the children. I thank the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to address the concerns of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) on behalf of the Government and to recognise the involvement and concern of that member in human rights issues.The World Summit for Children, as he has said, was held in December 1990 under the auspices of the United Nations and it produced two key documents: the world declaration on the survival, protection and development of children, and a plan of action to give effect to the world declaration. The declaration and the plan of action, as you, Mr Deputy Speaker, have heard, cover areas such as child and maternal health, food and nutrition, education, support for children in difficult circumstances and international aid programs.

PARA.TAB: `Difficult circumstances' becomes a euphemism in the face of the reality of family life in many parts of the world. We speak a lot of how we support family life and the family structure. For many people the destruction of family life will result from the destruction of members one by one.

UNICEF reports that in 1992 a quarter of a million of the world's children are dying every week and millions more are surviving in the half-life of malnutrition and almost permanent ill health. This is not a threatened tragedy or impending crisis; it is happening today. If this number of children were killed in an earthquake, flood, cyclone, then the nations of the world would be catapulted into action. And so I welcome the summit initiative. These children are the poor and the powerless and they are the victims of preventable conditions: malnutrition, disease and war.

Australia ratified the world declaration in May 1991. In September 1991, the then Prime Minister endorsed the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) having carriage of developing the Government's response to the world declaration. He could not have chosen a more socially conscious person to do so.

The Minister has taken the responsibility very seriously and, to date, the following work is under way: a high level interdepartmental committee, referred to by the honourable member for Dundas, has been established to coordinate the Government response. The Committee has met three times, most recently on 5 February, and is currently drafting the Australian reply to the plan of action and to the key and sectoral goals listed in that plan.

The development of the plan of action will require involvement of all levels of government and non-government organisations and, of course, the Opposition. The then Prime Minister expanded the net of shared responsibility to all State Premiers and Territory Chief Ministers last year, seeking their support and involvement in the development of Australia's plan. The Minister will follow this up with discussions on the Australian plan at the next health and social welfare Ministers conference in April in Sydney.

The Minister has also written to all national peak bodies—and this is very important—advising them of the arrangements in place for the plan, inviting their important and essential contribution to the Australian document. The invitation enlists the cooperation of nearly 40 non-government organisations representing all major women's, youth, public health, charitable, Aboriginal and family policy organisations.

Moreover, the Minister recently met with senior UN officials in New York to discuss the Government's development of our strategy. The UN has agreed to Australia lodging an interim report by the end of March 1992 and then a full report with input from all levels of government and the non-government sector by the end of the year. Thus, in that time, we will be able to build up a response that comes from the Australian community with the leadership of the Australian Government.

The Government has established a full process for finalisation of the Australian plan of action and processes to report on our strategies and progress in meeting the goals listed in that plan. I am pleased to report that Australia is in fact well in advance of most industrialised countries in preparing our national program of action. As a matter of interest, no other industrialised country has yet completed its plan of action report. Only two countries—the United States and Japan—have completed a draft report.

The UN planning and coordinating office for the plan of action is briefed on Australian action to date—we are working closely there—and is expecting our draft plan of action by the end of March. I understand that, of the 116 member countries in the UN, 23 have progressed beyond Australia and completed their national program of action—all of them from developing nations for whom the plan is principally intended.

Of course, it behoves us all in the developed nations to honour that commitment which we have already given. That is what the Government is doing. It is honouring its commitment to implement the plan of action arising from the World Summit of Children. We take it very seriously. We recognise the international responsibility of Australia as a mature nation with much to offer in alleviating the need of children worldwide.

As the declaration itself notes, countless children around the world are exposed to dangers that hamper their growth and their development. Each day, 40,000 children die from malnutrition and disease, including AIDS, from lack of clean water, from inadequate sanitation and from the effects of drug problems.

These problems are especially rife where they can least bear them—in the least developed countries. The major goals listed in the plan to be addressed by each country focus on child and maternal health, on basic health care provision, on education and literacy, on the alleviation of poverty, and on renewing economic growth. The task for all countries in the United Nations is to ensure services and support for the fundamental needs of children.

The declaration states that at present over 100 million children are without basic schooling—the key to opportunity to be able to better their situation—and two-thirds of them are girls. The provision of basic education and literacy for all is among the most important contributions that can be made to the development of the world's children. Half a million mothers die each year from causes related to childbirth. Safe motherhood—prenatal and postnatal care—must be promoted in all possible ways.

How does Australia stand in achieving some of the major goals and targets set out in the plan of action? I am forced to be briefer than I wish to. Infant mortality—that is, mortality of babies and children under five years—currently stands at around 10 per 100,000. That is 0.01 per cent. In the US mortality stands at 11 deaths per 100,000. Neither figure is good. It is a bad situation, but I must report on the comparative situation. Maternal mortality in Australia is currently around 3 per cent per 100,000, or 0.003 per cent, a record on maternal health that compares favourably to the US and UK statistic of eight per 100,000.

A third major goal of the plan of action endorsed by Australia is to ensure universal access to basic education and completion of primary education by at least 80 per cent of pre-school children. In Australia in 1992 we have a net primary school enrolment ratio of 97 per cent for boys and 98 per cent for girls. These are some examples of the major goals which Australia must address in the plan of action. Maternal health and education are vital to ensuring the protection and survival of children.
