I will quickly mention two key areas of government action that are pertinent to our achieving the goals set out in the plan of action, that is, the national women's health program and the national Aboriginal health strategy. The Government has stated in the national agenda for women its commitment to developing a comprehensive women's health policy and has nominated areas for action, including establishment of national breast and cervical cancer screening programs, promoting increased community awareness of sexually transmissible disease and teenage pregnancy, funding of non-government family planning services, research into contraception, evaluating home birth services, and improving accessibility to and availability of health services, including health education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to record my appreciation to the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) and the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) in allowing indulgence for the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) to continue his speech in this quite important debate.

PARA.TAB: Today in the developing nations 40,000 children under the age of five will die from preventable causes and diseases. Twenty-five thousand of these children will not have reached their first birthday. We are talking about a disaster of almost unbelievable proportions. It is a catastrophe that is occurring not once in a lifetime, not once in a decade, not even once in a year, but every single day—every 24 hours. These awesome statistics represent the tragic reality behind the words of the motion before the House. We should think about it for a moment, because it is difficult to comprehend the magnitude of the problem we are confronting: almost 15 million children—the equivalent of almost the entire population of Australia—dying unnecessarily each year.

In the time allocated for the debate on this motion today, 2,000 more children will die. Twenty-eight will have died by the time I complete this sentence. The figures are terrible enough but what is even more terrible is the fact that many of these deaths are preventable. As a result of modern medical and scientific techniques and developments, we already have at our disposal the means by which we can prevent or cure—quite easily and for relatively little cost—the diseases which kill so many of these children. Diseases such as measles, pneumonia, tuberculosis, diarrhoea, whooping cough, tetanus, diphtheria and polio are now almost non-existent or well under control in the majority of the developed countries. But these are still the childhood killers in the developing nations.

Each day almost 8,000 children die from measles, whooping cough and tetanus—all of which can be prevented by inexpensive vaccines. Each day almost 7,000 children die from dehydration resulting from diarrhoea. The cost to cure each child is a few cents. Each day 6,000 children die from pneumonia, which can be readily and successfully treated with low cost antibiotics.

Infectious diseases are not the only problem. Malnutrition is also a major threat. Despite the fact that we already possess the skills and technologies to produce more than enough food to feed the world, deaths from malnutrition amongst children in the developing world are, in fact, increasing.

It is estimated that at present more than 40 per cent of children under five in the developing world suffer from malnutrition. One-third go to bed hungry every night of their lives. That figure of 40 per cent represents more than 150 million children. In reality, the number may be much higher. Nearly 23 million children are classified as being severely malnourished. This means they weigh about 70 per cent, or less, than the norm for their age.

Not all of these children will actually die of starvation, although most will suffer permanent physical and mental damage. However, because inadequate diet weakens the immune system and thus increases a child's vulnerability to infections which may otherwise be easily overcome, malnutrition is regarded as a major contributory factor in the overall death toll.

Many people believe that famine, war and poverty are the only causes of malnutrition, but this perception is not correct. Lack of basic nutritional information, inadequate health care, unclean water and unsanitary conditions can also result in severe malnourishment. The problem will not be solved simply by providing handouts of food in times of crises.

There is a lot of truth and commonsense in the well-known saying which was first adopted and widely used in the 1960s by the Freedom From Hunger Campaign: `If you give a man a fish, you give him a meal; if you teach him how to fish, you feed him for the rest of his life.' That one simple word `teach' holds the key to many of the developing world's current problems.
We do not need to wait for miracles. We already have the knowledge. We know what the solutions are and many of them are directly and significantly related to providing better education and training.

Something must be done. Something can be done. It is simply a matter of establishing the correct priorities and then getting on with the job. We must not sit back waiting for others to make the first move, or be lulled into a sense of false security by thinking this problem belongs to someone else. All too often when overseas aid issues are discussed one hears the argument, `Charity begins at home'. Perhaps it does, but that does not mean it should end there.

Certainly, we have our challenges on the home front. For example, about three years ago it was estimated that 500,000 Australian children were living in poverty. In 1990 the figure had risen to 800,000 and was still climbing. Many Aboriginal children still suffer chronic ill health, with mortality rates significantly higher than the Australian average. Yes, we have our difficulties, but we can no longer afford the luxury of only worrying about our own backyard because we simply do not have our own backyard any more. Today, our backyard includes the rest of the world, and it is some of our closest neighbours who are suffering most from the problems addressed during the World Summit for Children in 1990. At that time it was said:

SPEECH.PARA: A successful World Summit can make the 1990s the decade in which the shameful large scale deaths and widespread malnutrition of the world's children are consigned to history, providing a permanent gift from the last decade of the 20th century to the people of the new century.

They were stirring words and a worthy objective. But what is actually being done to turn the rhetoric into reality? Unfortunately, very little, and time is running out fast. Fine words are all very well, but what is needed is some adequate and appropriate action. We have to stop talking and start doing. According to UNICEF's state of the world's children report for 1991, in addition to the 40,000 children who are still dying each day from preventable malnutrition and disease, there are 150 million more children in ill health and suffering from poor growth, and over 100 million children aged between 6 and 11 who are not in school.

PARA.TAB: We can endorse, express support for, sign and ratify declarations and conventions which we are told will advance the cause of the world's children until we are blue in the face, but in the final analysis the problems will remain unless and until the parliamentary and bureaucratic Neros at home and abroad actually stop fiddling and start implementing practical solutions.

While we are busy stating our good intentions, developing official responses, examining options, consulting with other government and non-government organisations, establishing formal departmental mechanisms, committing ourselves to this, and pursuing that, out in the real world the situation is getting worse not better. Some women are still having to spend five hours or more each day carrying water home to their families, water which often is not even safe to drink.

One hundred million children of primary school age are not getting any education at all. About 50 per cent of adult women and 30 per cent of adult men are illiterate. Over 500,000 maternal deaths—99 per cent of them from developing countries—are occurring each year as a result of pregnancy and childbirth. Millions of children are dying from preventable causes and millions more are suffering from exploitation and abuse or are the innocent victims of wars and other forms of violence.

It is very easy to acknowledge the problem and accept our obligations to assist in finding some solutions. However, actually doing something about it—making something happen—is the real challenge. This motion, moved by my colleague the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock)—and I commend him for his initiative in this regard—is an attempt to get the bureaucratic transmission system out of first gear and into overdrive before the whole thing bogs down completely. That is what usually happens if you keep the wheels turning for too long in the one spot. We have to get a move on.
It is now almost 18 months since the World Summit for Children. Since then more than 20 million children have died needlessly. The promises have been made. Surely it is time that they be honoured.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) and the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), I acknowledge the commitment that has been shown by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), a Liberal, regarding the plight of children, his special concern.

PARA.TAB: I do not think there is anyone who would not support the objectives that were enunciated at the World Summit for Children in 1990: they have cross-party support. The objectives and goals are such that they have to be pursued. I strongly support what the honourable member for Casey has said. This is not a time for political point scoring. I certainly hope that has not been the objective of the honourable member for Casey or the honourable member for Dundas in the vague criticisms of the Government.

I intend to elaborate on some of the things that have been done, because this Government has acted in a number of ways and it is not just tied up in bureaucratic red tape. We have to understand that we are dealing with a worldwide problem. That is the complexity of the problem, yet we have an opportunity to take advantage of changing circumstances in the world. I cannot think of any other time in the last four or five decades when there has been such an opportunity to redirect the wealth of the world, to redirect our expenditure, to those who need it most. There is clearly that opportunity, because of the reductions in the tensions between East and West and the agreement to cut back on nuclear weaponry, defence forces and expenditure on the instruments of war. This is the time to grab those dollars and put them where they are most needed.

The President of the United States talked about a new world order. I think we need to set a new world priority that simply should be caring for kids. If we can do that by way of all-party agreement and international agreement then we can get things done. But it is not as simple as some would have it; it is not a matter of a magic wand approach. As I have considered the motion moved by the honourable member for Dundas, I have come to appreciate very much the fetters and barriers that exist because of the sovereignty of nations, the differences in culture, and the discrimination in some nations against women and children, particularly female children. There are also problems in terms of trying to get other nations to set different priorities and to set this priority on a fast-track agenda, so it is not going to be simple.

Also, an international problem, and one that comes back to our own nation, is a belief amongst people that if we are going to give assistance, make sure it gets to those who need it. In the past we have tended to leave many services to voluntary organisations. One could list pages and pages of those across the world that have helped those in need. But there is always the fear that if we give, our aid may not get there because of problems that exist in other administrations and the cost of delivery and transport. We need to address that. Whilst I understand why the honourable member for Casey would argue that this is a worldwide problem and that we need to deal with it on a worldwide basis—and I hope I am not flying in the face of the opinion of others—we need to take a regional and very domestic approach to this issue. I do not see that we, as a nation of 17 million people with our limited resources, can be trying to address the problems in South America or Africa. We could do much more good if we were to target our own neighbourhood, the South Pacific and the South East Asian area.

If the new world approach would be that nations who have wealth in the industrial structure were given a backyard, as it were—and I take the comment by the honourable member for Casey—and that was their responsibility, then maybe some of these changes could be fast-tracked. There is no-one who would not argue for a reduction in infant and child mortality; there is no-one who would not support a reduction in maternal mortality; there is no-one who would not want a reduction in malnutrition—and so the list goes on. But saying to someone that we are going to try as a nation to deal with the world I do not think is acceptable.

As a government we also have a responsibility to start at home first. I know we have an international responsibility. I accept that, and I believe our Government has endeavoured to meet that responsibility, not only at a discussion stage at world summits but also within our region and through the Commonwealth of Nations. We are certainly trying to do what we can for our own nation, but money is not the issue.

It does not matter how much money a government pours into a project, that does not guarantee its success. I recall the comments by the previous Prime Minister when he expressed the desire that no child in this nation should have to live in poverty. That was a principle that was desirable, it was acceptable across the nation, but to say that that can automatically happen just because governments give money is simply not understanding the problem. There is no guarantee that parents will spend their money on their children, and we have seen this in the Aboriginal and Islander area where special assistance had been given in the education field. But questions are raised today on whether that money is being well spent.

The money that is given under family allowance supplement has been massively increased by this Government. We have ensured that hundreds of thousands of families are benefiting from this assistance, as with rental assistance. When it comes into that area, into a structural form, we can be assured that it will be spent on residences, on accommodation. But when governments give cash, there is no guarantee that it is going to be spent to improve the quality of life of children. We hope that it works out that way, we hope that parents take up their responsibility and give due priority to the children's needs. But this Government, understanding that, has seen a need to build an income support system. It has seen a need to ensure that FAS is available. In fact, there are now 1.5 million children in this country receiving family allowance supplement and this is being increased immediately by another $3 per week. It is part of that $300m package for low income families and children. It will be dollars in the hand but we can only hope as a parliament that it will be used properly on the kids. This is the same whether one looks at it nationally or internationally: will the money be spent properly? Accountability and monitoring are very important.

We as a government have embarked on a campaign to reduce child poverty. We have raised child payments to something like 15 per cent of the combined married rate of pension. We have committed ourselves to a yearly increase. As I mentioned before, we have family payments targeting the low income families; we also have FAS and rent assistance. We have seen a massive increase in these in the last few years. Since 1983 family payments have increased by something like 92 per cent for families with two kids below the age of 13 years and 135 per cent for those between the ages of 13 and 15. And yet there are still problems out there. A half a million kids are still in trouble, so we really need to rethink our priorities.

We have ensured as an Australian government and as a nation that we have a health insurance system called Medicare to guarantee that the million families that were not covered before are now protected with health insurance and some support medically. We have ensured also that there has been money for public housing. We have tried to address the problems of child violence. It was the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Ms Fatin) who set up the National Child Protection Council, and honourable members will recall that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) has also involved himself in terms of changing the Family Law Act to try to handle cases of child abuse. So we even have Family Court staff required to report suspected cases of abuse.

What I am saying to the House is that financially we have tried to do our bit; legislatively we have tried to do our bit; in a monitoring and accountability aspect we have tried to do our bit—and yet the problem still exists. We do have a youth social justice strategy, we are targeting child homelessness, we are targeting Aboriginal and Islander children. We have a range of programs. The SAAP program, the supported accommodation assistance program, is excellent. It has been hailed as one of the great initiatives of this Government—and yet there are still kids who do not have a bed at night. Every night now under our scheme there are something like 10,000 women and children being accommodated, but it is not enough.

I take up the points that have been raised by the honourable members who spoke before me that we need to make this the top priority. Whilst we have invested millions of dollars, in fact $1.5 billion, just in child-care, there is need for more. We need to expand our vision from the domestic to the regional to the international. So I support what the honourable member for Dundas said and I support very much the comments made by the honourable member for Lilley because I think she got to the kernel of the issue here. But we need to work on these issues together, we need to cast aside party political affiliations and say, `We have responsibility as a parliament to care for kids in this country, in our region and across the world'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have three children and I find it very difficult to contemplate my own survival if anything happened to those children. But every day mothers with no less affection for their children than I have for mine watch their children waste away and die. It is one of the anomalies of modern life that while most homes in white Australia and the rest of the Western world have a TV and a video, a washing machine, a stove and a fridge there are millions of families who do not have enough food to keep their children alive. As the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) pointed out, a fraction of the money spent on armaments would save the lives of millions of children.

PARA.TAB: One thing that strikes me when I see the television footage of people dying in Africa is that the majority are women and children. Because they are more poignant, they are more likely to be the focus of the television cameras. But I suspect that the truth goes deeper than that and that, while the men try to survive, it is the mothers who sacrifice their own lives to stay with their children and watch them die.

While women in this country fight for the right not to be patronised and to be judged for their abilities and not their gender, many women in Third World countries are fighting for the right to live and for the right for their daughters to live. In many cultures, probably most, sons are preferred to daughters, with a consequent higher mortality and poorer lifestyle for female children. Studies in India and Bangladesh show that girls are breastfed for a shorter period and are given less nourishment than are boys. In other Asian countries it is the girls whose rations are cut when there is a food shortage; it is the girls who are denied medicine when there is an epidemic.

Female infanticide still occurs in China and more girls than boys die before the age of five. Some African countries still practise female circumcision, with its consequent negative effects on women's health. Five hundred million women die each year in childbirth. Two-thirds of the world's 1,000 million illiterate adults and 100 million illiterate children are female.

While I was collecting these statistics I was interested to read that `studies conducted in Kenya and Indonesia have shown the higher the level of the mother's education, the lower the infant mortality rate' and, further, that `an uneducated girl's prospects for self-improvement are not good, which in turn affects her children's prospects'. I am sure that this is true, but there is an underlying message that I find a little discomforting. It is that women's education must be fostered because it will advantage the health and prospects of her children. Even in Western literature we can still detect the belief that a woman's role as an individual is not as important as her role as a nurturer of children. I would have no objection to this if the role of men was also seen in this light. I believe the survival of children is the most important thing we can work for and the welfare of both men and women should be subservient to this.

Whether we like it or not, whether we are in a boom or a recession, Australia has an obligation to assist global action to save children and improve their lives in our own and other countries. I congratulate the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) for moving this motion, and I condemn the Government for failing to act sooner in honouring promises made to the World Summit for Children. As always, the action is a pale shadow of the rhetoric.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like, first of all, to indicate my support for the general thrust of the motion and to resile from the remarks of both the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus), who has just resumed her seat, and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) in their criticism of the Government. Having listened to the remarks of other members on the Government side and from having talked to the responsible Minister, I believe that a great deal of action has been undertaken.

PARA.TAB: In response to the comments from the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), and confirming the comments of the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), unfortunately it is extremely difficult for any action to be taken on an international level, especially in the context of children's rights, because they are the single most powerless group in every community and their mothers, the women, are the next most powerless group in every community and country in the world.

I would just point out to the House and to honourable members opposite that the Government has taken some firm action in this regard, but that unfortunately a lot of action, a lot of consultation and a lot of planning are required if we are to achieve any substantial change, any sustainable change, in the area of children's welfare and the welfare of their mothers. I thank the House for the opportunity to make a comment on this matter.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue her speech when the debate is resumed.
Debate resumed from 12 September 1991, on motion by Mr Halverson:
That the House:
(1)calls upon the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC) of Burma to cede legal authority to a civilian government as mandated by the Burmese people in the elections of May 1990;
(2)condemns the arrest and detention of Burmese citizens for the peaceful expression of their political views;
(3)condemns the SLORC's disregard of human rights and fundamental freedoms; and
(4)urges the Australian Government to:

TAB.TAB: (a)call upon the UN Human Rights Commission to continue and expand its scrutiny and action over the human rights situation in Burma;
(b)affirm its support for the resettlement of genuine Burmese asylum seekers who are without other safe and reasonable alternatives; and
(c)call upon the Government of Thailand to accord Burmese refugees temporary safe haven and access to procedures for third country resettlement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The absence of a Nobel Peace Prize award ceremony is a good indicator of the state of politics in a candidate's country. The refusal of the Burmese junta, the State Law and Order Restoration Council, to allow Aung San Suu Kyi to accept the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize in December was symbolic of its continuing repression of the democracy movement. Various human rights groups, such as Amnesty International, the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights and Asia Watch, have published documented reports about the total lack of basic freedoms under martial law imposed by the military junta since it seized power in September 1988 and its continuing refusal to respect the results of the May 1990 elections.

PARA.TAB: According to Amnesty, as many as 1,500 political prisoners have been arrested since 1988. About 200 were arrested in the first seven months of last year alone, some of whom received prison sentences of up to 25 years. Those gaoled included elected members of parliament, student activists and Buddhist monks. According to the United Nations, Burma's growing prison population now includes hundreds and hundreds of children. The reasons for detention range from distributing party leaflets, talking about a possibility of a provisional government, to putting up posters of national heroes at a national festival and writing an exam paper in an ethnic minority language. UNICEF is now attempting to help these children.

The Burmese `outlaw government' denies holding any political prisoners, maintaining that all those incarcerated are common criminals and insurgent terrorists. The junta is thus trying to eliminate non-violent opposition the same way as it has dealt with armed insurrection. The results of these policies have been tragic. Human rights abuses, forced labour, torture and execution of civilians that were previously witnessed along the Thai boarder are now being committed nationwide. Entire villages have been razed and thousands of people are forced to relocate. Some 20,000 refugees have crossed the border into China. Tens of thousands of people have been displaced as a result of the Army offensive against the guerillas of the current ethnic minority. Most have fled to Thailand, joining more than 40,000 people already living in at least 16 refugee camps.

As a result of a terror campaign against the Muslim minority, up to 100,000 refugees from the Arakan state have been forced to take refuge in neighbouring Bangladesh. Only last month, nearly 1,500 villagers fled to the Indian state of Nagaland to escape fighting in Burma's Sagaing Division.

The junta's strongest foreign supporter is China, which has emerged as Burma's leading trading partner and main arms supplier. It has agreed to give a $US9.3m free interest loan for unspecified economic projects and to build a television station. Under a deal worth at least $US1.4 billion, China has been supplying the regime with a wide range of weaponry, including jet fighters, tanks, artillery, patrol boats and so on.

Other countries that have been guilty of supplying arms to this repressive regime include Pakistan, Yugoslavia and other cash-strapped eastern European countries. According to reports, Swedish rockets, manufactured under licence in Singapore, have been sold to the junta. Even Japan became involved. In 1990 it shipped at least 500 trucks to Rangoon, ostensibly for civilian purposes.

The modernised and expanded Burmese armed forces—they now comprise over 300,000 troops—have shown scant respect for the territorial integrity of Burma's neighbours. Burmese troops have repeatedly crossed into Thailand in order to attack rebel bases from the rear. In August last year Burmese troops penetrated 30 kilometres into the Indian State of Mizoram to capture dissidents. In December last year, they clashed with the Bangladesh army inside Bangladesh territory, resulting in casualties.

With peaceful political dissent in Burma virtually stifled, it has become vital that international pressure be applied against the military junta in order to compel the regime to respect fundamental human rights. Unless pressure, both diplomatic and economic, is significantly escalated, the military junta will be able to continue its repressive regime while Australia and the rest of the international community do not match their rhetoric with action. The world reacted with shock and horror at the events in Tiananmen Square; that event pales into insignificance compared with the savagery being perpetrated by the brutal regime in Burma.

Efforts over the past year to increase diplomatic pressure have been a good beginning. The United Nations General Assembly's resolution in November last year—this was the first human rights resolution critical of a particular country ever to receive unanimous endorsement—is an auspicious beginning. Expressing its concern at the grave human rights situation, the resolution stressed the need for an early improvement of the situation and urged the Burmese Government to allow all citizens to participate freely in the political process in accordance with the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

United Nations resolutions are not enough unless they are backed up. While Australia, the European Community and the United States have imposed an embargo on military sales and, in some cases, banned economic assistance, the Burmese Government has yet to feel its impact. For example, while the World Bank has refrained from funding new projects, it has continued disbursements for projects sanctioned before 1988. These amounted to about $37m in 1991, besides providing more than $80m in debt relief since 1988. Japan, following the same policy, disbursed more than $130m in 1991. So it goes on from other Western countries.

The cessation of aid programs is not enough. Industrialised countries have refused to ban investment and trade activities in Burma. Since October 1989, eight oil companies have signed oil exploration contracts with the military junta and paid blood money. This includes BHP, which reportedly paid the junta $6m to explore for oil. Such actions can only bolster the confidence of the regime and also give it reassurance that future oil revenues are in the offing. Singapore, Japan and South Korea are important trading partners and sources of vital spare parts and other goods critical to the Burmese economy. Indeed, to Australia's shame, we even repaired aircraft parts there last year for the Burmese armed forces. The Thai Government has signed lucrative deals with the junta which involve stripping the country of its precious resources, including teak, gems and fish, while ignoring the plight of the Burmese people.

Very importantly, I want to make a comment about ASEAN. Burma's immediate neighbours, the ASEAN countries, have been singularly reluctant to comment on the atrocities of the regime and prefer to take shelter behind a professed policy of what they hypocritically call `constructive engagement'. At the ASEAN summit last month, Singapore's Prime Minister, Goh Chok Tong, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not interfere . . . we just have our bilateral contacts.
The Philippines Foreign Minister, Raul Manglapus, had this to say:
I am not going to tell them to restore democracy. We want to see how we can cooperate with them.

What a disgrace. The consequences of such a pitiful response, both regional and international, to the atrocities of Burma are obvious. They have been condemned in the United States Senate, where Senator Daniel Moynihan of New York has said that ASEAN is weak and has failed its responsibility as an economic group within South East Asia to continue to criticise what is happening in Burma.

PARA.TAB: I call on the Australian Government to introduce in the United Nations a proposal exploring the possibility of denying the Burmese Government its credentials as a member of the United Nations and calling on the United Nations to ensure that economic sanctions against Burma encompassing aid, trade and investment are brought into play as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my colleague who spoke before me, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), for the strength of his support for the motion before the House and for his additional suggestions as to action that the Government might take. This motion was first put on the Notice Paper by me but I was unavoidably absent from the Parliament at the time when it was brought on for debate. It was kindly moved by my colleague the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson). I thank him for doing that because the issues that are raised are important. The motion calls upon the Government of Burma, the State Law and Order Restoration Council, SLORC, to cede authority to the civilian government, as mandated by the Burmese people in the elections of May. The issues are important for any who are concerned about human rights issues. These matters are of interest to very many members of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: It is 20 months since democratic elections were held in Burma and there has been no handover of power in all of that time. Those elections saw the National League for Democracy, led by Aung San Suu Kyi, win 396 of the 485 seats in the Parliament. I do not know that there could be a clearer expression of will. Yet Aung San Suu Kyi has been put under arrest and others who have supported democracy have also been detained. Aung San Suu Kyi was awarded a Nobel Peace Prize in 1991, while still in detention.

Amnesty International—all of us in this Parliament give great credit to it—has not been given permission to visit Burma and is unable to check the testimonies of many. But it does say that some 1,500 people by name have been identified to it as political prisoners, prisoners of conscience, and that this may be only a small proportion of the total number of people under arrest. It includes monks, members of legally registered political parties and those involved in non-violent underground organisations, ethnic minorities and the student movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including children.

—Including children, my colleague reminds me. Reports of rape, torture and forced labour are widespread. Twenty thousand people have been forced, conscripted, into carrying supplies across mountains to front-line troops. Many of them have been beaten. It is said that the bodies of murdered porters can be seen floating in rivers.

PARA.TAB: All of this is the case. Burma's leaders have behaved in a totally internationally unacceptable way. They must transfer power to duly elected representatives, they must release all political prisoners, they must stop human rights abuses and they must cooperate in constitutional reform. This does have implications for Australians. We can act in ways which might help. I commend the Government for its action in placing an arms embargo upon Burma, but there are other sanctions that ought to be explored and carefully looked at. I would encourage the Government to do so.

The internal strife creates substantial refugee problems. Many people have fled over the border, into Bangladesh or into Thailand. Even though we know the standards that ought to be accorded to those who seek asylum, regrettably some of our neighbouring countries do not. In this regard, I note that Thailand has been reported to be forcing people back. It is a matter upon which our Government also ought to remind Thailand, which we have assisted in the past by resettling bona fide refugees, of its obligations to provide safe haven and sanctuary to those that are involved.

Clearly, there is an active role for the Government in relation to this matter. It needs to be made clear to the SLORC that real reform is possible and that change of government is absolutely essential to accord with the wishes of its own people. Australia, in concert with the international community, needs to bring all of its weight to bear on the Government of Burma to ensure that this ceding of political authority does occur and the reform process can begin.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member for Dundas will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, gentlemen and friends. First of all, I grieve—no, I will change my tack a bit today; I will not grieve. I would like first to congratulate Ray Groom, the new Premier of Tasmania, and the new Speaker, Michael Hodgman. Outside the House this morning I was accosted by the media. I smiled at them all and they said, `Bruce, what do you think of Mr Keating's package?'. I said, `What do you mean?'. They said, `Will it be good for unemployment in Tasmania?'. All I said was, `Look, the people of Tasmania have shown what they think of the Labor Party, its alliance with the Greens, and what it did to Tasmania'. So that was my answer. I said, `They will need to pull a rabbit out of the hat'. I am not saying that Mr Keating is a rabbit. I would never run anyone down, as honourable members know.

PARA.TAB: I will start to grieve a bit. I am particularly worried about what is happening in Tasmania at the moment. The Liberal Party was elected there; we are all pretty fair. The Greens got 12 per cent of the vote. Suddenly we had, first of all, a train hold-up. Some people decided to hold up a train in Tasmania and got away with it. The media gave them plenty of publicity, but they got away with it. That is okay. Then I saw that two people, one of whom was here on holiday from England—that lovely country—decided to stow away on a French boat which was to go to the Antarctic. The other stowaway was a Tasmanian. I will name him. I have named him publicly today. I am not a gutless wonder as honourable members all know. I named him outside and I will name him again today because there is a bit of history associated with him. His name is Mr Maddock.

I decided to check this fellow very carefully—Grant Douglas Maddock. He stowed away on that boat and he got a six months suspended sentence. If it were me, Bruce John Goodluck, they would have locked me up for 50 years. It is like Bellamy when he came to Tasmania. He came to go to gaol. They would not even give me a passport if I wanted to go to see the Queen and said that I wanted to go to gaol over there. The world has gone mad. But I go back to this Grant Douglas Maddock. I watched that protest at the Picton River. Sure enough, Grant Douglas Maddock was one of the protesters. I checked the records and in 1986 when we had that Farmhouse Creek protest, who do you think was down there? Tell me, honourable member for Bass, my good friend.

TALK.START.PARA: —Grant Douglas Maddock.

—Exactly, the same person. I grieve today for the ordinary Tasmanians, the ordinary men and women who want to work, the people down at Geeveston who want to pay their bills, who want to pay off their log trucks and their tractors. I grieve for the ordinary people there who want to work but cannot because of a protest.

PARA.TAB: It is an interesting scenario. Last week, if the honourable member for Bass and my good friend from Melbourne, great bloke—

TALK.START.PARA: —Higgins.

—Sorry, I could not think of it for a minute. I know the honourable member for Bass, of course, but the name of the electorate of the honourable member for Higgins just slipped my mind for a minute. Last week I decided to do something. I did what a lot of Australians would believe in. I have never called a person a dole bludger in my 16 years in parliament. I have always tried to help legitimately unemployed persons. They see me and I try to do my best for them. But I will have no truck with those people who are unemployed and protest. How can they find a job while sitting up a tree? They just cannot. I said that the Department of Social Security and the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett) should have a look at the protesters down at the Picton River to find out who was unemployed and why those who were unemployed were not looking for a job. It is as simple as that. I said it nicely and gently. One would have thought that I had pulled the world apart. Everybody said that I was infringing human rights, that I was doing this and that and that I was a rabblerouser. One would have thought that the world was coming to an end.

PARA.TAB: I have already had a go at the editor of the Hobart Mercury, my local paper, so he knows what it is all about. After I read the editorial I could not eat my breakfast on Saturday morning. I thought, `I have not got a friend in the world'. The editorial did not name me. It named `politicians'—plural. I know that I am twice as good as most and I told the editor that too, but he did not like that one. The editorial read:

SPEECH.PARA: Politicians who seek to control or restrict the activities of people by suggesting their dole payments could be at risk if they indulge in certain activities are playing a dangerous and undemocratic game.
Probably all unemployed—protesters or not—would willingly "sacrifice" their spot in the dole queue for a place on the benches of any parliament house.
This was referring to me, of course. As I said, I challenge every person that is on unemployment benefit to have a go at running for parliament to see whether he can do a better job than I do.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will understand the point that I was trying to make. All I was saying was that if these people are unemployed, they should be looking for a job. That is fair enough, is it not? Do honourable members not agree? Even my colleagues on the other side would agree. If someone is unemployed, he should be looking for a job. He should not be stopping other people from trying to find work. We have people there watching the protesters at the moment. Workers are watching them on the Picton River. They are saying, `We want to get to work', but the protesters will not let them.

We have created a problem in Tasmania. The police do not want to go in there and stop them. Do honourable members know why? They do not want to go in there because they do not want to see that famous doctor down there, Dr Bob Brown, being pulled out from under a bulldozer because that gives credence to his kind. It makes a paper god of him. Television stations everywhere—including the ABC; you name it—always show Dr Bob Brown being pulled out of a mud pile away from a tractor. They show him as a martyr. There is no thought for the ordinary worker down there, no thought for me or any of my kind who try to stick up for the inarticulate who cannot express themselves, the people who do not want to be involved in this sort of thing because they are frightened of reprisal. No, just Dr Bob Brown. I hope I am making my point clearly because it is terribly important.

If we allow these people to continue and do not stop them, what is going to happen to Australia? If we let them stop trains, board a French ship as stowaways, go to the Picton River and stop decent people from finding a job, what is going to happen? So we have to fight them and fight them hard. That is all I have been saying. If they are unemployed, we should check their credentials; if we find that they are not looking for work, we should stop their unemployment benefit. That is fair enough.

The taxpayers of Australia are crying out for reform. These taxpayers cannot even afford to pay their own bills so, when they see somebody stopping another person from finding a job, of course they get nasty and angry. That is what is happening at that lovely little town of Geeveston. The people there want to work but cannot work because of a protest. It cannot be stopped because they are frightened of the publicity that the greenies will be given. That is all they want—publicity. If they did not get any publicity they would not do it, would they? They would not be out in the bush trying to stop decent people from working. So we have an awkward situation.

There is now a yawning chasm between the protesters in the Picton forest and the people of Geeveston. Unemployment and a dedication to their radically polarised beliefs are the obvious factors common to the two sides. The gulf is exemplified by two men: Mr Jonathan Murphy, who has been in the blockade since it started 11 days ago, and Mr Barry Young, unemployed since Australian Paper Manufacturers, APM, closed its operations in the area on 19 July 1991.

Mr Murphy, 25, is an unemployed musician who is hoping for some casual work in the next few days—probably whistling up a tree. Mr Young, 50, hopes to get some work when the apple picking season comes. It is pathetic. We have an unemployed musician stopping this man trying to get a job. We have gone from the sublime to the ridiculous and it is about time that we all woke up. I do not mind pointing out these people and telling their history. Like the other fellow who is down there—what is his name?

TALK.START.PARA: —Maddock.

—No, not Maddock. I have already talked about Maddock. He was the one who had his car blown up the other day. He was the fellow who went to Iraq and sent faxes back to Tasmania that came out through the Democrats office saying that toy bombs were being dropped by the Americans to kill women and children. These people need exposing. (Time expired)

—Last night in this House the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating) delivered an economic statement that will provide the path for recovery for this nation into the next decade. It was a broad-based policy; it was Labor policy.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Order! I would remind the honourable member for Hinkler of standing order 82 which prevents discussion of a matter which is on the Notice Paper for this day. The honourable member is not really at liberty to discuss in this debate the specifics of that statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not do that because there will be plenty of time over the next 12 months for both sides of the House to discuss that policy. However, what is clear and significant from last night's statement is that the community now has a clear choice between two ideologies. Last night the Prime Minister outlined Labor's ideology and late last year the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) outlined the conservative ideology.

PARA.TAB: Never since Federation has Australia seen such a clear choice. Even though people are probably a little more articulate and wear newer or flashier suits than they did in 1890, the choice today is exactly as it was in 1890. When one takes away the wrappings, the real choice is between grassroots Labor philosophy, as outlined in the policy statement last night, and tory philosophy, as outlined in the Fightback package. I welcome that because it gives people a chance over the next 12 months to see in which direction each political party wishes to take this nation. It is the responsibility of both sides of this House to argue and articulate the reasons why people should endorse either point of view. I certainly welcome that challenge.

Although it will take time for the general public to digest the various policy statements from both sides, there is no doubt in my mind that it is a clear choice between, on the Government's side, vision, a future for this nation, and compassion and understanding, and, on the other side of the House, special privilege. The only clearly unique thing to have come out of the Fightback package is the goods and services tax.

As was said in this House yesterday—and will be said again and again across this country—the Leader of the Opposition and the conservatives have embraced a goods and services tax in order to be different. The goods and services tax has existed in Canada for something like 12 months and has been an unmitigated disaster. Why any political party would wish to embrace so dearly a tax that is regressive and distributes wealth from average wage earners, pensioners, the disabled, the unemployed and struggling farmers to the wealthy defies logic. That is really the clear choice that is going to be argued in this place and outside it over the next 12 months.

The real bottom line is that one cannot tax one's way out of a recession with a regressive tax. Worse than that, when one analyses the effects on this country of a goods and services tax, one sees that it is even more illogical that the Leader of the Opposition and the conservative parties would wish to embrace such a tax. First of all, it is inflationary. We are now in a better position to be internationally competitive. Inflation is down to 1 1/2 per cent and we are leading the OECD—I think only one other country in the OECD has a lower level of inflation than Australia. At a time when we have achieved that and we are in a position to expand and develop our export markets, the Opposition wants to bring in a tax that would simply blow inflation through the roof and destroy that competitiveness.

We are a trading nation and we have to export the bulk of our commodities. We have a population of only 18 million. Not only do our primary industries, our resource industries, have to sell their products overseas; our expanding manufacturing industries also have to sell a large part of their products overseas. Consequently, it defies logic to bring in a policy that would disadvantage the export sector.

What disappoints me more than that is what this regressive tax will do to people on low and fixed incomes. I was at a meeting only last week with a group of pensioners. One elderly lady, who is a widow, said to me that she had spent over $3,000 renovating her home. Under a goods and services tax she would be paying 15 per cent tax on those renovations. That lady is on a fixed income. One could give many other examples of people on fixed incomes who would be hit with the tax. But if one looks at equity and superannuants—people who have provided for their own retirement; people who have either some very small or, in many cases, no pension at all because they do not come under the level—one will see that those people will pay 15 per cent tax as soon as they take a dollar out of the bank. But they have already paid tax on their money. They have paid tax on their money through their life, but they will be taxed again at 15 per cent.

What is it going to achieve? It has been argued that it is going to abolish wholesale sales tax, which at the present time contributes something like $10,000m to the economy, and replace it with a tax that will pick up something like—and it is arguable—$25 billion. The point is that it is going to come out of people's pockets. The point is that every time somebody puts his hand in his pocket when he goes into a supermarket, a drapery or any store whatsoever, the Opposition's hand goes in too. Fifteen per cent tax goes into the coffers.

If one looks at the rural sector—Mr Deputy Speaker, I acknowledge that you have a compassion and understanding, as you have a large rural electorate like mine—one will find that many farmers will pay no tax this year and some will pay very little or no tax next year because of commodity prices, the drought and, in some instances, sadly and ironically, the floods that we now have. Yet under the conservative policy, those farmers will pay 15 per cent tax on everything they purchase.

We have heard the rhetoric about compensating the export sector, but let us look at the industries that do not have an export market or that have a very small export market. Let us look at the fruit and vegetable industry. It is a $700m industry for Queensland; 15 per cent of $700m is $100m—$100m in tax. This tax will not go to the growers, the agents, or the transport companies; it will go into Consolidated Revenue. It will dampen demand because families have a limited amount of money to spend. If 15 per cent at the retail level is going to go in tax, only 85 per cent of their purchasing capacity will go back to farmers. That is what it really means. What is so bad about it is that there is no tax on fruit and vegetables at present. There is no wholesale sales tax; there is no tax whatsoever on fruit and vegetables, meat, bread and milk.

Conservative philosophy is to tax the basic necessities of life. So it is going to be very easy over the next 12 months to highlight the difference between opposing philosophies. I believe that only once will the conservative parties regret the goods and services tax—for the rest of their political lives, because what it will do to the Australian people will ultimately be done to their political fortunes: it will destroy them.

That is only part of the Fightback policy. One of the worst aspects of it is the industrial relations policy, the free-for-all, a return to 1890. It is ironic, as I said at the start, that nothing has changed and that the tories today are no different to what they were in 1890. There is talk of using the waterfront; talk that workers will have to work more for less today, as the Leader of the Opposition has said; and talk of throwing troops into the waterfront. They are no different to the arrogant squatters who in 1890 bought a crooked magistrate in Rockhampton and sent 600 troops out to Barcaldine. Nothing has changed.

Over the next 12 months I am certainly going to welcome the opportunity to articulate the differences between the philosophy of special privilege that those on the other side of the House espouse and the philosophy that we on this side of the House put forward. Certainly, last night was the start of the debate, and we are going to win.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nice fellow as he is, I cannot let the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) get away with such unadulterated rubbish. What he should understand, and indeed I think a lot on his side of the House already understand it, is that there are big differences between the Hewson Fightback package—that package is funded; it stands for equity, it stands for efficiency, it stands for less tax and it stands for two million real jobs—and what we found in One Nation last night. Last night's statement is an unfunded con job. The honourable member and some of his colleagues know it, and the people out there in Australia know it.

PARA.TAB: On numerous occasions in this place over the last four years I have referred to 10 February 1964 as one of the worst disasters in the peacetime history of this nation and of the Royal Australian Navy. Many honourable members will recognise that I speak of the collision between the destroyer HMAS Voyager and the aircraft carrier and flagship of that time, HMAS Melbourne, off Jervis Bay, claiming 82 lives.

Since 1988, both in this place and outside, I have supported the compensation case for some 80 survivors through to a successful High Court supposedly precedent setting action for one of them in 1990—the so-called Verwayen case. Although that gentleman's claim has now been settled, regrettably many other survivors and their families still bear the scars of the tragedy: the scars of psychological trauma, of persistent nervous shock, of domestic instability, of financial strain and, very importantly in this parliamentary setting, of misplaced confidence in a government which espouses social justice—a point repeated last evening by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his One Nation statement—but, alas, a government which demonstrably has failed to put its money where its mouth is and has failed to live up to its compassionate rhetoric.

Late last year I was informed of another two cases—one in Victoria, the other in Queensland—where claimants have succumbed physically and/or emotionally to the trauma of the Government's continuing obstructionism. To illustrate, I refer to an editorial entitled `Justice at last' in the Brisbane Courier-Mail in September 1990, which stated in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The view that the Commonwealth has behaved with despicable bureaucratic self-interest in the Voyager case would result in very little argument in the general community. The High Court ruling, paving the way for compensation claims by the survivors of that horrific 1964 naval accident, is a signal victory for social justice.
It went on to say:
The Commonwealth long denied liability for compensation. Mr Hawke's first government lifted the statute of limitations on the case in 1985, then slammed the door—
when it found there might be substantial compensation claims in the offing.

The High Court Verwayen judgment supposedly means that the Commonwealth, as the employer of people paid to defend the country, cannot claim exemption from civil compensation if they come to harm in the course of their natural or normal duties. This is not only an important precedent but also a simple reflection of elementary justice, albeit achieved in this instance only after a tortuous confrontation with the Commonwealth. I regret to say that the path to justice continues to be obstructed by the Commonwealth at every turn.

PARA.TAB: To illustrate the Victorian case I referred to earlier, at long last on Monday of this week the Supreme Court in Victoria cleared the way for that survivor, Mr Clark, to pursue his $800,000 damages claim against the Commonwealth. Mr Clark told the court that he had received medical and psychiatric treatment over the past 27 years. The judge said he was of a view that the psychological effect on Mr Clark of the loss of the expectation of compensation would be devastating. The judge also ruled that the Commonwealth was not entitled to rely on a combat defence; that is, that naval exercises at the time of the disaster in 1964 were so interwoven in military procedure that the Commonwealth owed no duty of care to the Navy personnel.

I regret to say that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and Defence Ministers present and previous are perpetuating such injustices by refusing to intervene and by relying on legalistic jingoism in each individual case. Squirm as they may about their rationale, Ministers know that the bottom line for the Commonwealth is a total compensation bill of perhaps $30m. That is their real objection, but they continue to rely on every peripheral, arguably specious, defence.
I refer the Attorney-General in particular to page 45 of Mr Justice Coldrey's judgment in the Clark case, where he said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: It would, of course, have been open to the defendant—
in this case the Commonwealth—
if it lost the Verwayen case—
which indeed it did—

to withdraw its defences against all remaining Voyager claimants on the basis of consistency towards an otherwise homogeneous class of persons and in order to prevent any perception of discrimination and injustice. However, the history of these cases indicates that this was never regarded by the Commonwealth as a relevant consideration.

I would say simply to the Attorney-General: enough is enough. Forget the historical differences. Why continue the frustration and desperation of the Voyager survivors? Why continue to prolong the judicial processes when the results are inevitable, and why not make some out of court settlement to each in this group to be negotiated quickly, and very quickly indeed?

PARA.TAB: Historian Tom Frame's recently launched book Where Fate Calls about the Voyager sinking should be a salutary reminder to the people of Australia, to Federal governments, irrespective of party political colour, and to this Government in particular. On the broader issues in the book, once again question marks arise about some of the evidence given in the Voyager royal commissions of 1964 and 1967. This is reiterated by Tom Frame's account of the deathbed admission of a great Australian, the late Governor of New South Wales, Sir David Martin, about some of his incomplete evidence given as a young naval officer at that time.

No-one wants a witch-hunt nearly 30 years later, and sensational media headlines questioning whether Voyager's commanding officer, Captain Stevens, was on drugs at the time of the collision do not help anyone. Naval historians such as Tom Frame and perhaps others will still be pursuing the Voyager issue in another 30 years. However, it remains a national tragedy that the public at large, particularly many of the families of the 82 men who died, may never have the undisputed truth. That said, what the people of Australia should understand now in particular is the degree of intransigence by the present Government on the compensation issues for Voyager survivors. Many, I have to

SPEECH.PARA: say without any exaggeration, are physical and mental wrecks.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has talked about his leadership style and makes the point that he calls the Government's major policy shots, as he did in this place last evening. I hope that he will place the compensation issue in this category, and I hope that he will direct the Attorney-General accordingly. I hope that he will ensure that 1992 sees all outstanding Voyager compensation claims cleared from the Commonwealth's books. The Keating Government owes that both to the cause of good government and to the memory of Voyager and its brave ship's company.
Mr Deputy Speaker, may those who perished rest in peace and may those who survived be allowed to pick up the pieces of their lives after nearly 30 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a matter of concern; that is, the way in which matters in this country are now presented to the Australian community. I went through the last period of conservative Opposition in this country and am aware that when one takes away a person's God given right—that is, the right to govern—regardless of what the electorate has said, the persons concerned are aggrieved. The conservative parties have a fair record of making sure that the electorate does not have a say in the results of elections. They are entitled, although they have never yet been able to, to devise and put forward workable alternative policies to convince the community that they should be returned to power.

PARA.TAB: Recently we have seen probably the greatest disaster ever to befall the Australian people, the Fightback package. I do not intend to go into detail on that now, other than to say that Canada has a GST. The GST there costs small business 1.75c for every 5c in taxes that go to the Federal revenue. That is not bad for a penalty on small business!

In the United Kingdom Mrs Thatcher is famous for her remarks, `How can you hurt the poor? They have got nothing to lose'. She was certainly never going to do anything about redressing that. Mrs Thatcher went through an entire period changing the tax system, dividing and destroying the nation. We can all see that Britain is destroyed today. There was a period of euphoria when it appeared that there was an increase in the British economy. That increase was due to North Sea oil and not conservative governments. On Thursday of last week Jaguar collapsed, following Rolls-Royce into the scrap heap.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like Nissan.

—Nissan has not collapsed; it has withdrawn. For 16 years straight Nissan lost money in Australia. It may just have been the case that there was a conservative government for eight of those years, but those opposite would never admit that, because they are so holy and pure and have never been wrong.

PARA.TAB: I want to go through some of the things that conservative parties in opposition have promised people in this country and some of the things that they have promised when in government. It is a salutary exercise to find out how many of those things they promised were actually delivered. Some of us will remember when there was child endowment for the first child. Some will not remember that it was Menzies who excluded the first child in 1941 when child endowment was brought in. But in 1949 it was a good election winner, and in 1950, on election to office, he delivered on that promise—five shillings for the first child. When Menzies retired in 1966, the endowment for the first child had never been altered. It was altered on 14 February 1966—it became 50c with the advent of decimal currency. A delivery!

In 1953 the Prime Minister told Australians that they had three years to prepare for war. That same Prime Minister then reduced the defence budget. That is all old hat, I suppose. We then had the Petrov election in which the phoniest pack of garbage ever perpetrated on the Australian community was perpetrated on the night before the House was dissolved for an election, when the Leader of the Opposition was absent. In 1966 we fought the election on `All the way with LBJ'. Young Australians were conscripted to go to Vietnam in exchange for certain economic concessions from the United States Government. That is why Australians went to Vietnam.

In 1963 the Liberals made a big fuss about the fact that the Labor Party Federal Conference met in secret—the 36 faceless men. The number was not right, but that is not important. The Liberal Party Council still meets in secret. Its members are not prepared to have their discussions out in the open and in the light of day.

In 1972 we had the notorious pump-up Budget which the then Treasurer admitted before it was passed through this Parliament contained a lot of rubbery figures. It did; $1.5 billion was artificially pumped into the money supply in order to create economic buoyancy before that particular election. That was done because McMahon was going to be beaten; Whitlam was a better leader and a more promising Prime Minister. That was the reason. The conservatives had already dumped a man of substance in John Gorton. They stabbed him in the back. But that was not important. They did not win that election.

In 1975 Australians were made another promise—people should remember these promises—`We will index the tax rate so that governments cannot steal funds through bracket creep. Tax thresholds will be automatically increased with inflation'. That promise was never met either.

In 1977 the government of the day, immediately before an election, legislated for massive tax cuts and had the people from the Taxation Office working overtime assisting its election campaign by answering people's queries about how much the tax cuts would be as a result of the changes which had been made in the tax rates, which did not apply at that time. The Liberal Party advertising told people, `Ring up the Taxation Office and they will tell you how much you will get from the tax changes'. It is only a coincidence that in that election Gough Whitlam promised to abolish payroll tax by taking back the tax cuts, and the reaction was shock, horror. How many of us remember the handful of dollars? I think $70 was shown as tax cuts, which was about 10 times as much as most people would have ever got. How many remember that, as soon as the Parliament reassembled, the taxation cuts were legislated out of existence? The election was over. The conservatives had won; damn the people of Australia.

In 1976 Malcolm Fraser introduced family allowances—and I acknowledge that that was one of the best things that he ever did—by consolidating the tax rebates and the child endowment payments into one payment and making the payment to all Australians. Those on low incomes, those who did not pay large tax and those who did not pay any tax all benefited from what was previously a tax rebate in an unfair system. What happened? Despite 10 per cent inflation in every one of the years that Fraser was in office—and that was the average, 10 per cent—there was a movement of over 60 per cent in the cost of living. In 1982, when another phoney Budget was brought in for an election, family allowance payments were still set at the rate that they were introduced at in 1976. Those opposite always pay their compensation and dues, and take it back as soon as they get into office.

They have now made promises in the Fightback package. What has happened overseas? If conservative governments are as good as it is alleged they are—and we are told that they are infallible almost to the extent of being papal; certainly, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) believes he is—why is it that after 40 years of conservative Presidents in the United States, 28 of them Republicans, that country is in an awful mess? In the last eight to 10 years, the only people in the United States who have increased their incomes are those in the top one per cent of income earners. The bottom 90 per cent of Americans are worse off now than when Reagan was elected President over 10 years ago. It is a conservative government there. It has done all of those things that the Leader of the Opposition is promising to do in this Parliament. It has made a mess of that country in exactly the same way as the Fightback package would make an unholy mess in Australia.

The Fightback package contains nothing for Australians. In fact, the promise is that in five years time, under that package, 90 per cent of Australians, like 90 per cent of Americans, will be worse off because of a conservative government—if it were to last that long. People would be worse off; there would be more unemployment, more inflation and fewer jobs. That is the promise.

There is one other thing that should be considered, and I will close on this point. It might be that if members of the Opposition stopped putting their own personal advancement, their own desire for office, below everything else, they might sometimes think of themselves as Australians.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Estate Listing of Private Property

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this month more than 300 landowners in my electorate of Forrest, mainly farmers, received a brief letter from the Executive Director of the Australian Heritage Commission. In each case this letter spelt out the Commission's intention to list all or part of the landowner's property under the National Estate. No specific reasons were given for these proposed listings and it comes as no surprise that the landowners began asking questions about the possible ramifications of the Heritage Commission's actions.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, this matter is now one of the most significant issues confronting the rural community throughout the south-west of Western Australia. The Heritage Commission, with the assistance of the Department of Conservation and Land Management, CALM, spent around a year assessing the forest regions of the south-west to enable guidelines to be determined for the protection of areas of heritage significance. This included considering areas of listing under the National Estate. Subsequently, a report has been released jointly by the Heritage Commission and CALM which sets out the broad objectives of this whole process of land assessment.

Let me say, at the outset, that the south-west of Western Australia is one of the most diverse regions in Australia. It is the location of some of Australia's most significant resource, extraction and processing industries. It is also characterised by some of the most unique and spectacular areas of environmental significance.

For years, the mighty karri and jarrah forests have provided the basis of the local timber industry and at the same time have been a major tourism drawcard. Amongst the forests are nestled the region's farming lands, which add significantly to the region's overall diversity and wealth.

One of the problems of previous assessments of the area of possible environmental significance has been the ad hoc approach taken. However, most people agree that the latest approach, which is based on a complete regional assessment, is a better way to go. Indeed, the Heritage Commission in its report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . protection should be focussed on the regional occurrence of each (environmental) value, taking into account its abundance, spatial and temporal distribution, spatial characteristics, variation, and condition, rather than on individual locations of value in isolation.

In other words, just because a clump of old jarrah or karri trees is found in an area of little other conservation significance, this does not automatically mean the area should be listed. Instead, it should be considered to determine just how important it is within the whole region. If sufficient karri stands exist elsewhere in appropriate quantities, then there is little sense in restricting the use of this one particular area of land. Clearly, regional land management is the best option, as I will mention later in my speech on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the way this particular region has been assessed leaves much to be desired, not just from the point of view of the farmers but from the point of view of forestry and industry as well. I appreciate that the Heritage Commission has acted fully in accordance with the provisions of its governing legislation. However, while it has consulted jointly and in detail with CALM regarding the areas managed by this Department on behalf of the Crown, this consultation was totally lacking when it came to dealing with areas of privately owned land, which is beyond the general scope of CALM's authority.

I appreciate that the report is a draft and that landowners are entitled to make submissions on its recommendations. The fact remains that this report helps cement in place the proposed listing. As anyone who would have dealt with the bureaucracy knows, reaching this stage of the proceedings is like getting one's foot in the door.

A far more appropriate course of action would have been to involve all the parties concerned with this issue in the planning stages. This includes individual farmers, their representative bodies such as the Pastoralists and Graziers Association and the National Farmers Federation, timber operators and their industry groups and others with entrenched interests in the region, particularly the mining industry.

The lack of adequate consultation was highlighted by the fact that the Heritage Commission organised a meeting to discuss the issues, yet gave farmers so little notice of the meeting that many were unable to attend. Furthermore, landowners still do not know why their properties were proposed for listing. It is no wonder many people think the whole deal is a fait accompli. Indeed, a letter from the Executive Director of the Heritage Commission goes so far as to describe the whole process as `very successful' and further goes on to say it `will be a model for similar projects both in Western Australia and elsewhere in Australia'.

How can the Heritage Commission say it has been `successful' when the full implementations have not been worked out yet. Already, the National Association of Forest Industries has expressed major reservations about some of the recommendations, while the whole farming community is in an uproar about the possible effects on their land holdings. This is hardly a measure of success and I would suggest that judgment should be reserved until the dust has settled and everyone has had time to assess the full impact of this report. What are the main concerns expressed by private property owners whose land has been targeted in the National Estate listing? The Heritage Commission says:

SPEECH.PARA: A listing in the Register (of the National Estate) has no direct legal constraints on owners of private property. . .

Why are landowners concerned? In a nutshell, they do not trust the decision makers and they are uncertain about the long term implementations that could be involved. Contrary to the Commission's advice, there are direct legal constraints on listed areas whenever decisions concerning them involve the Commonwealth Government. For instance, if the landowner considers an offer from a foreign investor then the Foreign Investment Review Board may well be involved. This could lead to complications concerning any environmental obligations imposed on a foreign investor.

PARA.TAB: Even the indirect consequences are worth considering. As no-one is quite sure what approach a future government might take, National Estate listings may be viewed in a bad light by many people. This uncertainty about the future listed lands is bound to be reflected in the values of the properties of land, and landowners disadvantaged accordingly.
The Heritage Commission's report unwittingly points to yet another major concern; it in part states:

SPEECH.PARA: Because many forests designated for timber production are listed in the Register of the National Estate, national estate forests have increasingly become the focus of a more general debate.

One result has been an undifferentiated perception by the general public that areas of national estate forests should not be logged; regardless of the values for which they are listed, or their management regime.

In other words, the Commission is virtually admitting that the National Estate listings in themselves attract an irrational response from some quarters. In my experience, most people even confuse National Estate areas with national parks.

PARA.TAB: It is not too far-fetched to imagine a situation wherein a government would bow to political pressure from lobby groups to clamp down on the use of National Estate areas, thereby restricting the productive value of the areas to landowners. Other aspects of the draft report are of concern as well.

Throughout the report mention is made of appropriate management to protect identified values. Yet there is no indication of what this means for private properties. If a form of land use management has been proposed then the Commission must spell out exactly what this is and what it means to landowners. On the other hand, if the Commission is of the view that National Estate listing never makes any difference to landowners in any way and never makes any difference to the use of their properties, then the obvious question is: why list the land in the first place?

It is time the Government, and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) in particular, came out of the shadows and answered these concerns. This is a far-reaching issue for landowners in the south-west and affects their very livelihoods.

Indeed, a report released by CALM sheds even more light on the whole matter and hints at the sort of treatment we might expect in the future.
