In the report's fine detail, there is mention of how the widest possible range of native landscapes, ecosystems and species can be conserved, including the part where it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . identifying and protecting the most threatened habitats by reservation of public land or, in the case of private land, by land purchase, or by negotiation with landowners if necessary.
As the Heritage Commission has now identified what it considers to be significant areas, this particular statement by CALM opens up a Pandora's box as to how those areas may be treated in the future.

PARA.TAB: I have, today, asked a number of parliamentary questions of the Minister and, until she is prepared to spell out exactly what the long term implications of this whole matter are, the landowners of the south-west have every right to be concerned. Until the Heritage Commission resolves these matters in full, the coalition believes proposed listings should be withdrawn. If the Commission does not see the sense in this, then the onus is squarely on the Government to use its powers under section 25 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act to direct that these listings should not be proceeded with.

My shadow ministerial colleagues Senator Michael Baume and the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) have highlighted the importance of cooperative agreements on land management between the Commonwealth and State governments. However, we are of the view that such far-reaching proposals should have involved those who would be directly affected. For these reasons, I call on the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories to intervene in the matter and withdraw the proposed National Estate listings. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Multiculturalism and the History of Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to grieve for what I see as a growing concern about the future of Australia. I have for a long time been concerned that there seems to be a growing dichotomy between rural and urban Australia. One of the facts of life is that most of the wealth in Australia is created in rural areas; the urban areas are there mainly as a result of the wealth that is so created. This is not to say that they are any less worthy, but there has to be this recognition.

PARA.TAB: One of the problems we have in Australia is that there is a constant battle in this country between what I would call the nationalists, those people who put Australia's interests first, and the internationalists, those people who see Australia as some cog in an international wheel. I think it is true to say that the nationalists have the numbers on the ground, but the internationalists have the power.

The internationalists have infiltrated very much into the teaching professions and into the academic and political circles. It is they who have foisted upon us the culture of the colony. For many years Australia was a colony of the United Kingdom. When we could see things changing in Europe, I believe we, with undue haste, helped to push Britain into the Common Market and tied ourselves very rapidly to the apron strings of America. People now want to tie us to the apron strings of Asia. We have been told that Australia is part of Asia; we must become part of this new dynamic region. The first, and probably the worst, offender in this regard, of course, was Garnaut in his Australia and the Northeast Asian Ascendancy. It is a very worrying thing.

If we get to the nub of this matter, we have to say to ourselves, `What is causing this division in Australia? What are we doing in society that is causing this division?'. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that one of the most profound causes of this is the policy of multiculturalism. It is a policy that has never been supported by the Australian people, for which no government has ever had a mandate. It was a policy that was foreshadowed by the fellow with the gaudy ties on our side of politics during the Whitlam Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that like you?

—Gaudy ties without style and taste. It was implemented as a policy by Malcolm Fraser in a grubby exercise in which he thought he could collar the ethnic vote. There is no ethnic vote and to believe that there is one is inherently racist because it implies that ethnics are more easily manipulated than Australians. But that is how the die has been cast. We now have this very powerful multicultural industry which does not represent migrants, except for a very small number; it represents the sectoral interest of a few people but it has the ear of both major parties in this country.

PARA.TAB: We have seen an upsurge in demands for republicanism in Australia lately. Republicans have tried to make this a nationalist issue. It is not a nationalist issue; it is an extension of multicultural aims. If people read very carefully what republicans are saying and look at the structure of those groups that are reporting republicanism, they will see that they are heavily infested with well-known multiculturalists. The idea is that Australia has no history, that we must wipe the slate clean, have a clean sheet of history on which people can impose their multicultural version of Australia's history. I find this very offensive; in fact, it is downright dishonest.

It is true that the multiculturalists are saying that we have no history of our own. I heard the Australian of the Year, Archbishop Hollingworth, speak while I was driving my car and I had to stop I was so appalled. His suggestion was that, as we have no culture of our own, we should adopt the Aboriginal culture, we should be very grateful to the Aborigines for 40,000 years of culture. Would it not be great, this learned gentleman said, if we could all meet in a pub in London and talk to each other in an Aboriginal language so that the Poms could not understand us. That is absurd. Firstly, if Australians talked to Englishmen in London, they probably would not understand them. Secondly, I find that totally ignorant and very, very offensive.

If one looks at the history of Australia, it is a proud history. We cannot forget, nor should we forget, the history we inherited. If one looks at the contributions Australia has made to the world one finds that Australia gave the world the eight-hour day. Australia gave full adult suffrage. Australia was one of the first countries in the world to introduce female suffrage. Right from the inception of this country as a Federal Commonwealth we have had the vote for women; Britain did not get it until 1922. The Torrens land title system is, in my view, the most equitable form of land ownership in the world. It is now slowly spreading to the United Kingdom and I am sure it will eventually even get into that very backward area of the world in this respect, the United States.

It is a cause of concern, I believe, for the whole of Australia not only that we are supporting this policy of multiculturalism, but also that we are supporting it while we see it tearing at the very fabric of this nation. If we are to succeed, we are going to have to have a united nation, because only by being a united nation can we be a strong nation. Multiculturalism is fabricated on the basis that culture equates with race. It says that people of different races cannot have the same culture. This, of course, is absolute nonsense. I recall when I was actually censured by this Parliament about four years ago for making a very mild remark. My remark at the time was that we should slow down South East Asian immigration to a rate at which the country could accommodate it. I was censured by both sides of this Parliament on that occasion. The only support I got was from Asians. It came from two sources: what I call the Sri Lankan stream, who said, basically, `We would rather have a British culture and English is our language', and the Chinese, who said, `Look, we like this country here and we don't want all these Asians stuffing it up'. They realised that, in terms of economic downturn, social pressure is going to feed into society intolerable strains.

While the Liberal Party says that it will cut immigration in the long term, if one looks at the history of Liberal Party policy, one will find that it has been a high immigration policy. As was explained to me by one Liberal member recently, `How else are you going to keep wages down?'. That is the Opposition's agenda, certainly not mine. But the fact is that it has agreed, and in the short term it will.

What is the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) actually saying? He is saying, `When the economy turns up, I will vastly increase immigration'. That is a very serious thing; it is a very serious error; it is not what Australia needs. He then compounds this problem by saying,`If we do not increase immigration, somebody will do it for us'. So here, at one fell swoop, the Leader of the Opposition is giving away Australia's national sovereignty. I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if the Leader of the Opposition really feels this way it is incumbent on him to immediately abolish Australia's armed forces. He is clearly not prepared to use them and he is clearly going to deliver Australia into the hands of someone else. For my part, I thought that is what we bought the F111 aircraft for—in the final analysis, to defend Australia's national sovereignty. I believe the national sovereignty cannot be for sale and we must take a strong stand in this regard.

Every illegal migrant boat that lands on the shores of my electorate puts Australia at risk in the long run. Unless we are prepared to take immediate action—firstly, to stop this and, secondly, where it is successful, to return the people speedily to their country of origin—we are putting ourselves at risk. In the future, for instance, when we get 10,000 illegal migrants arriving in a boat, one of the large countries in our area might say to us, `Well, look, we think it would be racist to send these people back to Bangladesh or wherever they come from'. This is a totally intolerable position, as I said. The only way we can overcome it is to increase our surveillance now and to have a firm national resolve that Australia will have none of this.

I believe Australia has one of the most equitable societies in the world. It is a society that has been developed from a culture which, I believe, has got a lot of good things going for it and it appals me that we are continually subjected to denigration of the history of Australia. It is a proud history, one which I am proud of, one which I am afraid my children are not being imbued with in the schools as they should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on the speech of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) about republicanism and on people trying to thrust on Australia a form of government to which we are not accustomed. As most honourable members would know, it is amazing if a member's office gets more than a couple of phone calls or letters on an issue. But one subject I recently had a number of phone calls to my office about was the speech on republicanism by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his welcome to the Queen.

PARA.TAB: Many people phoned my office or contacted me and asked me what right the Prime Minister had, in a speech of welcome to the Queen, to touch on the subject of republicanism. I was absolutely overwhelmed and amazed by the number of people who contacted my office. As we know, these types of comments by the Prime Minister are only a diversion to take people's minds off the real issues in this country, that is, unemployment and our huge foreign debt.

I want to speak today about some things happening in my electorate which I am not pleased about and which I am certain that those people who are experiencing these things are not happy about either. The first issue I want to touch on is the Maude Post Office. Maude is a small township to the west of Hay on the Murrumbidgee River. It is only a small settlement but it has a small shop, a post office agency in the shop and a few other buildings. The people in that area rely very much on that shop and that post office agency.

We all know that at the moment Australia Post is trying to rationalise its services. We welcome that because we really cannot have an overrun of costs, particularly in a time of a recession, but I think we have to stop and think about what is happening in outback Australia.

We all know that most of the mining ventures and most of the farming ventures where our wealth comes from are in isolated areas or rural areas. No longer do people wish to stay in those areas unless they have services provided to them. Most Australians live on the east coast of Australia or in other coastal belts, whereas those people who produce the wealth of the country live in outback areas in places such as Maude.

It is Australia Post's intention to close down the agency in Maude and have a roadside delivery service. This, of course, will make the shop unviable. I am not just talking about Maude here; there must be many other places the same. I think it is time that those people in politics and in the Public Service thought about just where the wealth of this country is coming from and say to those people who are living in those areas trying to create some wealth, `Look, we will support you. We will keep you there'. If they do not, I am afraid these people will say, `We have had enough—enough is enough. Our coastal cousins are doing all right in a good climate by the sea. Let's go and join them'. If that happens, I do not know where the wealth of this country will come from.

Another situation in the same vein concerns the mail services around Cobar and Wilcannia. Some of the mail services have been cut from a three-day to a two-day delivery and some from a two-day to a one-day delivery. The same thing goes for these areas as goes for Maude. It is not good enough to cut services. Many of those people rely heavily on the mail service. I would like bureaucrats—people in the Public Service—and politicians to think about what they are doing. We really do, as I said before, have to keep those people there on the land creating the wealth of Australia.

Another call I have had in the last few weeks came from a gentleman complaining about the Austudy allowance. He was not the only one; we have had many complaints before. Apparently in the past, when $60,000 was earned by both parents, one could still receive $20 a week in Austudy allowance. The amount of earnings applicable to eligibility has been reduced from $60,000 to $40,000 plus so much for each additional child.

In my electorate—no doubt in other electorates also—even in the best of families a slight tiff might develop between teenage children and their parents. The teenagers may want a new motorbike, a push bike or something else; arguments may develop and the children may leave home saying that the money from Austudy should be theirs. Some teenagers cannot get Austudy because their parents earn too much. Others who have an argument with mum and dad move out and, unfortunately in many cases, move into a de facto relationship at a tender age so that they can get the independent Austudy rate.

There are many people in my electorate who have written to me about this. It is something that I will certainly be taking up with the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett) in the hope that something can be done about it. I know that in the payment of any benefit there is always a loophole, but what is happening is affecting families. The payment of this allowance is not meant to do that; it is meant to be a help to families. I think we should look very closely at what is happening.

Another matter I raise concerns the mining town of Cobar in my electorate. As most people know, the mining industry in that area has run into problems with low metal prices and high operating costs because of the nature of the mines. There has been a decrease in the number of people working in the mines in Cobar. This, added to the problem of drought in the area—fortunately over the last few weeks we have had some rain around Cobar which may help—and the recession, has caused a lot of unemployment in Cobar.

Unemployment in Cobar is handled by the Dubbo office of the Department of Social Security. Dubbo is a fair distance from Cobar. People from Cobar wishing to contact the Department of Social Security can call a 008 number in Dubbo to get assistance. There have been many complaints because when people ring that office—and we all know the Social Security offices are very busy at the moment—they are passed from one person to another; the phone drops out; and they have all types of problems. Then, of course, there is a problem with mail, filling out forms and all that type of thing. Many unemployed people have problems in getting their money in time so that they can support their families. It is already a big enough trauma trying to feed one's family, to pay rent and to get on with one's life without having this situation develop. I have written to the Minister for Social Security asking him to do something about it.

The Cobar Enterprise Development Agency has collected a petition from the people of Cobar. I believe that the petition has 1,200 names on it. That is a great number of people from an area such as that. That is something else that I would like the Minister to look into.

Next I touch on the matter of sales tax exemption for those who may be invalid. People who are invalid may purchase a vehicle for travelling to work and that vehicle is exempt from sales tax. But, if they are not working, they cannot claim the sales tax exemption on their vehicle. I have had a letter from a lady whose husband is a quadriplegic as a result of a car accident. As part of his rehabilitation program, she tries to take him to physiotherapy. But in order to do that, because of the equipment she has to carry, she needs a larger vehicle. She lives in outback New South Wales. There is no public transport so, unless this lady can purchase a bus, there is no way that her husband will be able to leave the home. When she wrote to the Government, she found out that in this situation there is no sales tax exemption on vehicles

I know the problem that the Government faces, but I think this matter is something we should look at, because it is a problem. I know that most honourable members here would have struck that problem in their constituencies. I ask the Minister to have a look at it again. I will certainly be taking it up with him.

Finally, I think there is a fairly strong feeling in my electorate at the moment about the urge to change the Australian flag. I do not know whether we are conservative or whether we believe we are nationalistic, but certainly I am one person who always says that perhaps one day in the future the flag will be changed by our children and grandchildren. I hope it is never changed, because I believe in the Australian flag the way it is. I see no reason to change the flag.
There is a lady in my electorate, Mrs Daisy Murray, who has written a little song to counter some other songs that have been written about changing the flag.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not going to sing it, are you?

—I will not sing it this afternoon, Mr Deputy Speaker, so you are safe there, but I am sure in the future you will hear this song. I think it will make you very proud of the Australian flag. This song was written by a little lady who is a real pioneer of the district. She is very proud of the Australian flag and she would not like to see it changed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Goods and Services Tax: Effect on Sporting Clubs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was recently approached by some constituents involved in local sporting clubs who were concerned about the effect the GST might have on their sporting club operations. I know that would be a concern also to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin), who is at the table and who shares with me a deep interest in sporting affairs.

PARA.TAB: I immediately went to the Hewson tax manifesto to see what was involved there. Obligingly, in supplement No. 5, it gives an example of how it affects sporting clubs. I do not have time to go through that entire example here, but it sets out how a soccer club would have to pay a goods and services tax on all the equipment it purchased. It then goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time, the club bills its 300 members for annual subscriptions of $100 each, plus 15 per cent GST, making the final subscription $115 per member.

In the subsequent couple of paragraphs, it sets out other areas in which the GST would apply. The club would, in fact, have to pay GST on the travel cost for teams and officials, equipment, postage, and affiliation fees to parent bodies. Individuals would have to pay a GST on their membership subscriptions, hiring of facilities, purchase of clothing, sportswear and other items. Those things are set out quite clearly in the policy.

PARA.TAB: But when one goes further into it, one finds that the list of those items which are affected by the GST and which will injure the sporting clubs in our country is much more extensive. There is, in fact, to be a GST charge under the Hewson tax manifesto on free equipment and other donations and sponsorships.

In a very interesting article which appeared in the Bulletin a couple of weeks ago, the Opposition spokesperson in this area, Senator Michael Baume, is referred to quite extensively. I quote from that article:

SPEECH.PARA: For example, Baume says GST will be charged on free equipment supplied by manufacturers as well as on other agreements such as contra-deal sponsorships.

Many clubs in my electorate rely very heavily on that sort of voluntary donation and support; they are clearly going to be penalised under the GST policies. In fact, according to Senator Baume in this article, even services from non-profit organisations to other non-profit organisations may be subject to the GST. It refers in particular to the drug testing which is performed by voluntary organisations such as the Australian Sports Drug Agency. Senator Baume, so this article says, is not quite sure whether these organisations will be taxed on that and he has referred that to the Opposition's little think-tank that is working its way through these and other problems.

PARA.TAB: The article goes on to point out quite clearly that the Australian Sports and Drug Agency services provided to groups such as the New South Wales Rugby League organisation would be charged a GST on those medical services. So there is no doubt at all about what will happen in the professional codes of various sports or where any organisation operates on other than a non-profit basis and, at this stage, we are still not sure what the Hewson tax manifesto would do for non-profit organisations sharing their services.

The list is more extensive. Player insurance and referees' fees are all subject to the GST. Coaching courses are specifically referred to as being subject to the GST. I refer honourable members to their electorates and the various vacation and weekend classes that are conducted by different sporting clubs across this nation. In my own electorate, although the swimming season is now drawing to an end, I am still reminded of the many children who benefit from swimming classes that are conducted by various swimming clubs throughout Brisbane. Some of these classes are school based, some are district based, and all will be subject to a GST.

I need not point out that, at present, none of these things are subject to a tax of any sort. Tennis lessons, gymnastic classes and ballet lessons conducted throughout the country will have a GST imposed upon them and there will be no compensation, none whatsoever.

The article quite specifically refers to Senator Baume's comments and it quotes him as saying `There will be no compensatory cash grants'. In fact, when our cousins across the Tasman introduced this, they had the good sense to try to compensate sporting clubs. The Liberal Opposition in this country does not intend to do that.

There is, of course, another effect of this and that is the impact it will have on the volunteer workers who will be required to maintain the massive amount of paper in tracking through the system all the GST payments made by these clubs and, of course, all the receipts taken in by these clubs.

Time will not allow me to refer in detail to some of the statements made by people across the Tasman, but it is interesting to note that the New Zealand Assembly for Sport has recognised that in the last 12 months there has been a dramatic fall-off in volunteers, who are critical to the sporting development of the youth of the country. It is a pernicious tax; it is an evil tax; and I will fight against it.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:
That grievances be noted.
