TALK.START.PARA: —These days there is certainly a greater sophistication in the Australian electorate as far as economic matters are concerned. I suppose after eight or nine years of great economic hardship that is not surprising. This sophistication is going to cause the Government's new `Kickback' package some considerable problems because the community is now much better aware of how things are paid for when they are launched by governments or, in fact, promised by other political parties. The question I always got when I was doorknocking in the last two Federal election campaigns was, `Where is the money coming from'? Fightback!, the coalition's package, is in stark contrast to the Government's `Kickback' package because it is clearly and demonstrably funded.

PARA.TAB: The `Kickback' package promises to build three new major railways, finish major upgrades on eight more lines, build three major urban ring-roads, upgrade two major highways, build new air terminals, the multifunction polis, a national power grid, plus, plus, plus, and all for $2.3 billion. I ask honourable members how on earth, if it took $100m to build the Hume Highway-Goulburn bypass alone, are we going to get all these things for $2.3 billion? Come on, members opposite! Pull the other leg; it has bells on. I want to touch on one brief association—(Time expired)

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Before I call the next honourable member, once again I draw the House's attention to standing order 82, which precludes discussion on matters on the Notice Paper. The Prime Minister's statement is on the Notice Paper for debate later this day, so discussion on that question is out of order in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must admit, Mr Deputy Speaker, that observations of Opposition members since the launch of their Fightback package has not always been a pretty sight and it did not change last night. I swear to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I could see a mist developing before the eyes of Opposition members because their peepers were changing into weepers. The come-hither look and the glad eye that Opposition members gave themselves in the Fightback package took a decided turn last night. It was as though the Sydney Morning Herald cartoonist, Moir, on Monday had a premonition of the response to the Prime Minister's economic statement. How correct he was.

PARA.TAB: Like all propaganda, the Fightback package is but a monologue. It seeks not a response from the Australian people, but an echo. Not only will the Australian people fail to respond; they will, over time, silence that echo. In its courting and wooing of the Australian electorate over recent months, the coalition failed to see that it is drying wood for a fire that will not burn for them. Its Fightback package is nothing more than a joy-ride and a picklock for the privileged. It reflects its itching-palm avarice. It is larceny on a grand scale; a smash-and-grab raid of the under-privileged, people on fixed incomes and the Australian wage and salary earner.

The Opposition is like a static observation balloon. From it we can goggle, gawk and gape, but we cannot go anywhere and it certainly will not be on this side of the House in 12 months time. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In and around the electorate of North Sydney, the Government has initiated a major assets sale of public lands worth many millions of dollars. I refer to the Commonwealth owned land at the CSIRO site adjoining the Lane Cove River, Cockatoo Island, Army lands at Chatswood, Willoughby and North Sydney and the submarine base at Neutral Bay. This follows major State Government sales.

PARA.TAB: Disposal of public lands, particularly in a dramatically expanding urban area, is a short term policy limiting our children's heritage. It will be almost impossible to obtain land for the many public needs in the future. The current policies of asset selling to reduce debt must be rejected as short term and not dealing with the causes of debt. Bad as short term asset stripping is, it is compounded by the complete irresponsibility of ignoring the effect of those sales on the local community and washing its hands of the effects of future development of the sites.

Responsibly, the Government should dispose of sites only with firm controls for future development, prepared after consultation with the community and local government. Government is supposed to represent the interests of the community, not behave like some foreign absentee landlord with a `take the money and run' approach. It is expected to behave better than the avaricious developer out for a quick profit.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has asked where the money for the Government's policy proposals will come from. The policy is balanced and will be funded. But we all know where the money would come from for its policy proposals—out of the pockets of the pensioners, the disabled, the farmers—
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member is addressing a matter which is on the Notice Paper. He is clearly out of order.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—My understanding is that the honourable member is actually referring to the Fightback package rather than the Prime Minister's statement, so his comments are in order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. It will come out of the pockets of the average working people of this country. It is being done to help the yuppies and the privileged in Vaucluse and Toorak who believe that manual labour is a Mexican bandit. In fact, having listened for two days to the debates in this House, I can only say that if Wirths Circus ever needs some clowns all it has to do is look at the front bench on the other side of this House. I can assure honourable members opposite that what the Labor party is going to do to its Fightback package is exactly what General George Patton did to the German army. As we go into the Opposition's heartland, the shambles of the GST, we spread all the way along the highways just like the Wehrmacht was. I can tell members opposite this: as average Australians understand the regressivity of this tax and the nastiness that is hidden behind the gloss of the yuppies that put it together, they will keep the Opposition on the other side of the House for the next two decades.

—Geelong should be retained as one of Australia's pre-eminent wool selling centres. Whilst wool selling is conducted using the sale by sample method, there is no compelling reason to centralise wool selling operations. To centralise sales by sample in Melbourne means wool brokers will incur costly transport charges in moving thousands of sample boxes to Melbourne showrooms. Existing wool brokers operate effectively in Geelong using single floor warehousing systems. The National Wool Centre at Geelong successfully combines wool sales with history and tourism. Under the present selling method, the process is efficient if sample boxes are located close to warehousing operations. Also, Melbourne would experience difficulties with continual back-to-back sales as show floor space is limited.

PARA.TAB: Geelong is an internationally recognised wool centre to which woolgrowers from South West Victoria and the Wimmera naturally gravitate. There is little difficulty in wool buyers from Melbourne accessing the National Wool Centre via the West Gate Bridge. Geelong wool sales also help inject money into businesses such as motels and local food service companies. I call upon the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation, Mr Mac Drysdale, to again consider my request of December 1991 for Geelong to be retained as a major wool selling centre after the completion of current reviews into the nine centres around Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the House that today a petition was tabled in this House and worded as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that under standing legislation and regulations the danger that a racist may be given the privilege of Australian Permanent Residency or even the honour of Australian citizenship. There is nothing to stop this sort of ridiculous situation happening.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House enact legislation or regulations that Immigration authorities should refuse entry into Australia to any person who is known to have uttered racist remarks or practised racist policies; furthermore that a person who made racist remarks or practised racists policies should not be given Permanent Resident status and furthermore that a person who has uttered racist remarks or practised racist policies should not be accorded the privilege of Australian citizenship.

I simply comment, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this petition was signed largely by people in the Jewish community. I am sure that the House would understand what they have had to endure in the past. The Australian Jewish community, understandably, is sensitive about racism as directed towards it. We also ought to understand that everyone is concerned about racism developing in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want publicly to extend an invitation to the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) to visit my electorate any time he likes to undertake his supposed dismantling activity of the Opposition's GST. I place only one condition on the invitation; that is, that he will be honest enough in my electorate to concede, as he failed to concede in the grievance debate earlier today, that every time a GST applies on a business input it will be rebated to that business so that, from a farming point of view and a small business point of view, the GST is effectively tax neutral.

PARA.TAB: We have heard the honourable member for Hinkler and others suggest that this was an additional tax. That is errant nonsense. The intention of the Fightback package is to take less. He may happily debate with me any time he likes where we are going to make the pruning of $10 billion; but make no mistake, the Opposition will take $10 billion less in taxation, so people effectively will be taxed less under the Opposition than they will be under the Government. All I ask from the honourable member for Hinkler is at least sufficient honesty to concede that this is not an additional tax and that every business input that incurs a GST has that GST rebated to it. Thus farmers will not be disadvantaged in terms of the relativity between the GST and the wholesale sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take 30 seconds, but I am sure that honourable members on the opposite side of the House would be very interested in a little survey I conducted in my electorate today. We did not want to waste taxpayers' money on unnecessary phone calls, so my two secretaries made only 66 calls. The question they asked the people of the Hunter Valley was this: `If you had a choice between Keating's package and that slowly disappearing Fightback package, for which package would you cast a vote?'
—The one that is going to abolish sales tax.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.
—I am sorry to bring such sad tidings, but the score was Keating 68, Hewson nil.

—I waited last night to hear the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) say that the Government was going to do something about the payroll tax. But it did not occur. The GST abolishes seven taxes, one of which the Government has already abolished. If there is anything that is an impediment to employment in this country, it is a payroll tax. It is iniquitous; it should never be there; it is costing us a lot in exports; and it is certainly doing a lot of people out of work.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that in 1985 the Prime Minister, who spoke to us last night, wanted to bring in a goods and services tax, as did his predecessor. What happened was that the unions said, `No, we will not allow you to do this'. But today he came in and said, `It is impractical; it is impossible to do this'. It is not impossible. The Government knows this. It is running frightened. I heard its speakers a while ago; its boys are running frightened.

I say to the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) that the average Australian, irrespective of what happens in the Hunter Valley, wants change. Nothing happened last night that will give change to Australia. Nothing happened last night that is going to give extra jobs to our young people around the countryside. Mr Speaker, if you look at the papers this morning you will realise that, because they have summed it up very adequately indeed. Mr Speaker, do not worry; there is time to go. I believe that more people will want the GST. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We see a lot of crocodile tears about payroll tax. It was brought in as a wartime measure. During the entire period of the Liberal Government between 1949 and 1972 it was in vogue. In 1977, during an election campaign, the Liberal Party opposed its abolition. It was transferred to the States by Gorton as a revenue tax. By the time the Liberal Party went out of office in 1972 it was up to 7 1/2 per cent. I think that if the Liberal Party wants to say anything about payroll tax it should apologise for what it did with it and for not doing something about it in the seamy years in the early 1950s when it had plenty of money to do it.

—I would just like to congratulate Ray Groom, the new Premier of Tasmania, and the new Speaker of the Tasmanian Legislative Assembly, Mr Michael Hodgman. Although I never look for jobs, I make this one request of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating): if the Government makes a decision, would it make me the Governor of Tasmania?
—Order! It now being close enough to 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. It is stated on page 121 of the `One Job' statement that the medium term scenarios are not forecasts; they are `outcomes conditional on key assumptions and the related policy settings'. What happens if just one of the key assumptions is wrong? Therefore, how can you say, `the Government will lower the tax rates over the next four years' when the whole package will collapse if just one key assumption is wrong?

—I assume that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is telling us that there are no key assumptions in his own particular package. If he wants to have a competition about key assumptions, let him come right along and we will have such a competition.
—Try answering the question.
—I am going to answer the question. What is said in the statement is as it is; that is, that we have made some key assumptions on which this scenario has been built.
—So if you trip once it is out.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—It has not been the practice of the central forecasting group to forecast beyond the year immediately ahead. On this occasion we have forecast essentially for an 18-month period, including the 1992-93 period. Beyond that, we have a scenario which is based on a model which was built in the Treasury and has certain assumptions built into it. One of the key assumptions that has been built into it is the one about inflation and wages. That is the one which the Opposition and so many others in the community find hard to accept, apparently. What we have said is that we are basing our growth on the assumption of low inflation growth; that is, inflation which will be at or below the level of our trading partners. How, one might say, can that be achieved? It can be achieved because we have an understanding with the trade union movement on the crucial question of wages. The ACTU has said that it accepts that wage growth should be constrained such that it does not push our inflation rate above the level of our trading partners.

PARA.TAB: This is a totally new concept for Australia and for Australia's wages policy. We are not here talking about some aggregate wage outcome; we are talking about wages being constrained by inflation, and that is a very important commitment. It is a very important objective; it is an objective which puts a proper priority on jobs and industrial development. What those opposite are saying, and what they find so incomprehensible, is that we can contemplate low inflationary growth in this country. What they contemplate is high inflation and probably no growth. Their problem is that they cannot possibly contemplate a situation of low inflationary growth or wage restraint in any possible scenario that they might develop. That is why the growth estimates which they assume are so much lower than ours; that is why their productivity estimates are so much lower than ours. Our forecasts are achievable because we have the appropriate policy structure in order to support those assumptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Secretary-General of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Mr Jean Claude Paye. On behalf of the House I extend to him and to his party a very warm welcome.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister advise the House of the importance of his One Nation plan to private investment? What incentives are there for private enterprise to invest in Australia?

—The Government's One Nation statement last night established a very conducive environment for private investment, coming from the following things: low inflation and a policy of maintaining low inflation; a commitment from the trade unions that our inflation rate should not exceed the average of our trading partners, and those include the low inflation countries, which is a discipline on our labour market; workplace bargaining—we are now seeing a revolutionary change in enterprise bargaining between unions and employers to look for productivity to make businesses operate more efficiently, more cleverly, and therefore to be able to give wage increases with lower costs and lower inflation; changing the nature of training in Australia and, as a result of the Government's announcement last night, to do for technical and further education what we have done for universities in lifting the capacity of Australia to train people, to train children, to train kids leaving school for practical jobs in the economy; the change which has been taking place in infrastructure, but particularly, as we announced last night, the rebuilding of the main rail trunk routes of Australia, and also the building of new, important intercapital city highways—
—You have lost it.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party.
—The establishment of a national electricity grid for greater efficiency.

PARA.TAB: Mr Sharp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Gilmore will cease interjecting.

—And the maintenance of low interest rates which come from a lower level of inflation. On top of that, in last night's statement we established a landmark reform with a new regime for depreciation for Australian business, to give Australian business the capacity to write off plant and equipment against assessable income at rates much faster than those at which it was formerly able to be written off. This will mean that a 40-year asset or an asset which was formerly depreciable over 40 years will now be depreciable over 15 years; an asset which was formerly depreciable over 20 years will now be depreciable over 7 1/2 years, and so on. There will be a much faster rate of depreciation, something which has not even entered the minds of those opposite in terms of their own program.

PARA.TAB: As well as that, for industrial buildings we have increased the rate of depreciation from 2.5 per cent to 4 per cent. For tourist-related buildings and accommodation, short term travel and accommodation, such as hotels and tourist resorts, we have also introduced a concession to the tax system to encourage the private provision of public infrastructure, provided that the provision of the infrastructure is genuinely private and there is not some other government guarantee on the income of the facility to be constructed. There is also the prospect of a development allowance for large projects, an investment allowance beyond depreciation, for developers of large projects bringing them to fruition; pooled development funds to help raise equity for small and medium business where they cannot secure them in the economy; project facilitation; and, of course, a relaxation of foreign investment policy.

All of these changes mark a new epoch for the background to investment in Australian private investment in this country. It is a change which was totally overlooked by the Opposition. Nowhere in the Opposition documents do you find any acceleration of depreciation. What those opposite have done is increase the corporate rate they proposed from 39 per cent to 42 per cent. The real issue in Australian business is the cost of capital, and it is the issue which the Government alone has done something about.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I remind him of his constant boasting about his concern for the poor. Is it a fact—a yes or no answer will do—that the Prime Minister's tax cuts—

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.

—Is it a fact that the Prime Minister's tax cuts promise over 40 per cent of taxpayers, many of them women, absolutely nothing? How can the Prime Minister justify giving tax cuts of $47 a week to persons on $50,000 a year, but no tax cuts whatsoever to persons on $20,000 a year?

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left and on my right will cease interjecting.

—I have heard some roughies in my day, but that takes the cake. When I became Treasurer the bottom rate of tax from the threshold up to $20,000 was 30 per cent, and today it is 20 per cent. We also increased the tax free threshold from $4,900 to $5,400. You opposed those changes. When we brought in the family allowance supplement for low income families—a targeted assistance for low income families—you opposed those changes.
—No, we didn't. That is a lie.
—You did. The fact is you said it was a deal with the ACTU.

PARA.TAB: Mr Chaney interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Pearce will cease interjecting.
—You ought to be made to withdraw. That is a total misrepresentation.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.
—It was written off as a deal with the ACTU. When is a deal not a deal? You want to take credit for the changes while blackguarding us as making deals. I say this to the Leader of the Opposition—
—You are despicable.
—The honourable member for Mayo!

—I say this to the Leader of the Opposition: we thought about low income taxpayers about five years before you did. In the second stage of these vast tax changes presided over by this Government we will now focus the next major set of tax cuts on the lower to middle ranges of the tax system, between $20,000 and $40,000. The reason why Opposition members are smarting under these changes is that it is the same marginal tax rate as proposed by them, but without a 15 per cent consumption tax. That is what hurts them. It is without a 15 per cent consumption tax. The Leader of the Opposition had the gall last night to say that that promise was unfunded. The personal tax cuts to the same area which you propose come exactly from fiscal drag. Is that unfunded? Is your fiscal drag payment unfunded? Have you described yours as unfunded? What about the $4 billion discrepancy that the Department of Finance and the Treasury have allocated to your program? Is that not unfunded?

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to debate with the Leader of the Opposition any day he likes the matter of how we have treated low income taxpayers in this country, how we have treated low income families, how we have treated the children of the poor, and how we now treat middle income taxpayers without attacking their way of life with a consumption tax on every morsel they put into their mouths or every piece of cloth they put onto their backs. That is what the battle will be about. It will be about fairness and equity in the tax system.
—What did you say in 1985?
—If the honourable member for Mayo interjects again, I will name him.

—It will be about fairness and equity in the tax system and not a savage, regressive flat rate of tax levied across income groups without the appropriate compensation. That is what you have got in mind. When one is giving it to him, he always has a conference. He is always having a conference. He really has a little conference. I know we have to get used to these little foibles and habits of our friend opposite.
—Order! The honourable member for Groom!
—The point is this: do not come to us with any unctuous questions about the low pay.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Will the One Nation plan he announced last night be of assistance to Australia's tourist industry, and can he outline to the House the significance of tourism to Australia's economic future?

—Tourism was one of the industries which flourished greatly under the opening up of the economy in the 1980s by the removal of exchange controls, by the float of the exchange rate and by more open foreign investment rules. Those measures saw the Australian tourism industry flourish, so that now we have high quality, world quality tourist accommodation. The importance of tourism has always been underlined by this Government. It is one of the reasons why we believe a consumption tax at a rate of 15 per cent would be entirely deleterious to all tourist accommodation in this country.

PARA.TAB: Because of its importance, the tourism portfolio has now been included in the Cabinet as a full ministry under the honourable member for Maribyrnong. In the course of this statement he brought to the ad hoc committee of the Cabinet policies which affect the tourism industry beneficially and which we have considered. Other policies not directly related to his portfolio, but affecting it, have also been considered and adopted.

In aviation policy we have put in place the ending of the two-airline policy of the Liberals; major changes affecting both international air travel and travel within Australia; the opportunity for additional carriers by the development of infrastructure at airports, with common user terminals being built in Sydney and Melbourne and possibly at other airports and the international airports at Sydney and Melbourne being significantly upgraded.

In respect of depreciation on tourist related buildings, the allowance has just about doubled from 2.5 per cent to 4 per cent. There will be a faster rate of write-off for plant and equipment associated with tourism development and for structures, such as car parks, roads et cetera. We have increased the funds of the Australian Tourist Commission by $15m for additional promotion. Since 1983 we have increased sixfold the funds for tourism promotion, to advertise Australia abroad.

Are we taking this industry seriously? It is represented in the Cabinet by a Minister of Cabinet ranking who has brought changes to the Government to make this industry better and more competitive. Because so much of the growth in tourism is employment related with a high labour content and a great capacity to produce many thousands of jobs in the economy, we see that tourism has changed from being an important industry in the 1980s to being one of the economic stars in Australia in the 1990s.

We will not be crippling it with a 15 per cent tax on every room every morning, or 15 per cent on every restaurant meal, or 15 per cent on every service provided at an integrated tourist resort. We will not be crippling the industry. We will give it a chance. We will give it the prospects for growth without the sort of crippling tax impost which has been dreamt up by the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Minister for tourism. They must have great difficulty in explaining to members of the tourism industry how the 15 per cent GST impost will help them as it turns their competitiveness down and robs them of the sort of growth to which they are entitled. This Government has taken the opposite view. We have kicked the tourism industry along, and we are very proud of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister whether he stands by the figure of $46 per week as the tax cut for someone on average income?
—The rates scale is in the document. The Opposition Leader should get out his calculator and do his own calculations.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—Order! The honourable member for Kooyong will cease interjecting.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. I ask: is he aware of criticism concerning the growth and productivity projections contained in last night's One Nation statement by the Prime Minister? Can he assure the House that the Government stands by the projections in the statement?
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson will cease interjecting.

—Of course the Government stands by those figures. There has been some discussion about the productivity estimates which underlie the creation of the scenario which has been referred to. I think it is important to bear in mind that what we are talking about in terms of productivity of 1.5 per cent is what the Australian Bureau of Statistics has estimated for multifactor productivity during the period from the late 1960s until the late 1980s.

PARA.TAB: For the period immediately ahead we are assuming the same figure as was recorded by the ABS in the period from the late 1960s through to the late 1980s. If anything, that productivity number is likely to be somewhat on the conservative side. It is a fact that as any economy emerges from recession into recovery we are likely to see a pick-up in productivity.

As far as the question of growth is concerned—and that was the other matter to which the honourable member referred—there are a number of issues here which support the growth figures which are included in the scenario period. The first thing to bear in mind—and this might be difficult for the Opposition—is to recall that we are talking about low inflationary growth. In a sense, because one has low inflation one has greater efficiency in the economy and one is therefore able, in a sense, to raise one of the important speed limits—one of the barriers—which our economy has always run into in the past as it tried to grow during a period of growth.

In this context, inflationary expectations are now at a very low level and in fact are at about the same level as inflation itself. This is a very important achievement for Australia and one which we must hang on to if we want to see the realisation of stronger periods of growth and, therefore, reductions in unemployment.

The second point is that the profit share, as we go into this period of recovery, continues to be strong. That means that there will be greater capacity, as the economy improves, for business to invest and to grow. Lower interest rates are, of course, another factor. The fact that we have been able to bring down interest rates to a low level in Australia again means that this is an important underpinning for a stronger period of growth in the period immediately ahead.

The third point I wish to make refers to the breaking of the drought and, therefore, the better prospects for the farm sector. The fourth point I make is that ABARE—our official body in terms of advising us on the prices of commodities—has indicated that there will be an improvement in the terms of trade, as it predicts that commodity prices across the range of the commodities that we export will improve over the period immediately ahead.

The fifth point is that when this suggestion is made that we cannot grow faster than our trading partners we should bear in mind that the composition of our trading partners has changed quite dramatically in the last 10 years. We are not now trading to such an extent with the economies which have slowed down so much in Europe and North America; rather, we are trading more with the rapidly growing economies closer to home. Indeed, whilst Japan continues to be the destination for 28 per cent of our merchandise exports, we have seen, essentially, a new Japan grow as a destination for our exports amongst the ASEAN nations and the newly industrialised economies. So those south-east and north-east Asian economies—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Can you recall a point of order that I took previously when I said that an answer should be an answer, not a bedtime story?
—If the honourable member for Franklin makes any more interjections in the guise of points of order he might get down to Tasmania earlier this week than he thought.

—Of course, the Liberal and National parties have never been interested in this region or our relations with it. We have taken our important relations with this region seriously and it has paid off. Over the last 10 years we have seen that the nations of north-east and South East Asia have become the destination of 30 per cent of our merchandise exports. Those are the economies which continue to grow strongly and, therefore, provide an opportunity—a growing market—for so many of our exports.

PARA.TAB: The final point I make is that the expectations we have in this scenario are not ambitious, compared with our previous experience as we have emerged into recoveries in the past. If one looks at what happened as we emerged from the recession in the early 1960s, one can see the growth rates were 6.6 per cent, 7 per cent and 7.1 per cent in the first three years of recovery. In the last recovery in the 1980s we saw 6 per cent, 5.1 per cent and 4 per cent. What has been built into this scenario is growth rates in the first three years of 4 3/4 per cent, 4 1/2 per cent and 4 1/4 per cent.

Even the Opposition's favoured advisers on these matters were saying that the growth which we could anticipate in 1992-93 was 3 3/4 per cent, and that was before the measures that we announced last night, which will have an important additional impact on our growth rates in the forthcoming 18 months or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is it not a fact that in the Prime Minister's statement last night there are no tax cuts now and no tax cuts for the next five long years for nearly four million taxpayers who earn up to about $20,000 a year, which is about half the total number of taxpayers in Australia?
—This is quite extraordinary.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Yes or no.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—We now have this new affection for the poor on the part of the Liberal Party. This is one of the great political novelties of our time. We have taken their interests seriously, not only in reductions in marginal tax rates, but also in the contribution that we have made to those families particularly—in family payments and the improvements that have been made in other benefits that have come from Government services. These are the things which we have done.
—They are worse off.
—The honourable member for Higgins!

—Almost all of them have been opposed by those opposite. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition likes to say that the Opposition is offering a tax cut for those people earning under $20,000. The Opposition's tax cut for people earning under $20,000 is calculated to do one thing and one thing only; that is, offset the price effect, the income effect, of the introduction of the Opposition's food and clothing tax. It does nothing more.
—You have abandoned your electorate. You have kicked them in the teeth.
—Order!

—The Opposition's tax cut for people earning below $20,000 is calculated to do no more—I leave aside whether or not it is a success—than compensate for the introduction of its food and clothing tax. Members of the Opposition leave entirely to one side the fact that it is their intention to reduce Commonwealth outlays by $10 billion, which will have a savage effect on those very same people.
—Why don't you answer the question?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting. He asked the question and he should listen to the answer.
—He is quite right.
—I warn the honourable member for Kooyong.

—These expenditure cuts are not mythical, they have a real effect. Where they have the greatest real effect is amongst the poorest people in Australia. It is in that context that we ought to bear in mind all these crocodile tears and this cynical new regard for the poor coming from the other side.

PARA.TAB: The other point worth making is that in relation to families with low income earners, whether they be in the work force or outside of it, last night the Prime Minister announced an increase of $3 per week per child for those families via the family assistance scheme. This is real and immediate assistance for those lower income families. That has to be put against the fact that this has been an area of total neglect on the part of the Liberal Party. We should remember that the central features of the Liberal Party's tax cuts for the low income earners are only designed to compensate for the savage impact of the food and clothing tax, a tax which these people, mercifully, will not have to contemplate under us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training been drawn to comments alleging that the Government's intended expenditure on vocational education and training is conditional on agreement with the States? What are the Government's intentions in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen—

PARA.TAB: Mr Sharp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Gilmore will cease interjecting or I will name him.

—I have seen some comments along the lines that the honourable member for Oxley refers to in a more than unusually demented press release from the Opposition spokesman on education matters, in which he describes an undertaking by this Government to increase expenditure on vocational education in this country by $720m over three years as a damp squib. I will get on to what he particularly wants to do about it but this is definitely a novel description of such an initiative.

PARA.TAB: Apparently it is a damp squib because I have to talk to the States to arrive at agreements with them in order to spend it—in exactly the same way as we do with secondary education and in exactly the same way as we do with all the supporting programs that advantage the disadvantaged in our community in education. It is as though this is some new, difficult process that we have to go through. What the Opposition spokesman says about the Fightback package is this:

ANSWER.PARA: Further, the Fightback! commitments are part of a comprehensive strategy to create an open and flexible training market, and are made in the context where agreement with the States is facilitated by recognition of their financial problems.

As I remember the Fightback package, recognition of the Opposition's financial problems constituted cutting FAGS by about 5 per cent, or something of that order. That is the sensitive financial thing which is going to make the States warm to whatever it is that those opposite propose but neglect to support what we propose! What the Government is proposing here, of course, revolutionises vocational education in this country in the way that we have revolutionised university education and revolutionised the willingness of our young people to stay on in school and get themselves an education.

PARA.TAB: Dr Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Goldstein will cease interjecting.
—It fills a vital gap in their life chances. It fills an absolutely vital gap as far as our industry is concerned in training people for vocations that they need if our industry is to prosper.
—Do you have the agreement of the States?
—I warn the honourable member for Goldstein.

—If our industry is to prosper it is absolutely essential that this development take place. What does the Fightback package suggest? The Fightback package suggests that over seven years honourable members opposite will make a $500m contribution to vocational education; that is, $75m a year for that period. Their increases are $75m in the first instance and nought from that point. If implemented, that will not even take care of demographic change over the next seven or eight years in that section of the population utilising vocational education. What it actually amounts to is a real reduction in the capacity of TAFE to service that age bracket—some support for the educational needs of our young people and, even more important than the educational needs of our young people, the prosperity of our industries.

PARA.TAB: If the Fightback package were to be implemented over our proposals, the effect would be thus: in the first year there would be minus $30m available. That is on the best estimates because the Opposition's figuring was done before $100m was put in by us in the course of this year. It is unclear as to whether the estimate includes that amount, but if it does not include that $100m the figure is minus $130m. It moves on to being minus $175m in the second year or minus $275m; then it goes on to be minus $210m or minus $310m, depending on how one does the calculations.

The net effect of the implementation of the Fightback package on vocational education was, when it was announced, to see a real reduction in the TAFE effort. If it were pursued subsequently by the Opposition in government, its net effect would be effectively to destroy the chances of vocational education in this country providing the training for our people. The Opposition spokesman on education is comfortable with a sherry before a log fire, chatting with his old university mates after a good dinner in one of the older campuses around this place, but he has never taken seriously, or even marginally understood, what is intended by this Government—not only intended by this Government but advised to the community in general by it—in terms of providing training for our people.

We will want to know from you what your intentions are now that this One Nation package has been announced. What are your intentions with regard to the expenditure? When you have been asked what you might do about it, I have heard one or two of you folk say, `Oh no, we would not stop this project', `we would not do this' or `we would not do that', at the same time as you are trying to accuse us of putting forward unfunded proposals.

It will be interesting. If you do not make way for this you will betray a generation of young people. You saw the desperation of those young people as they struggled to get into the massive number of new university positions that we have made available, many of them unsuitable for those positions but needing an opportunity in life. You will betray that generation of young people if you cannot find your way clear to give us total and complete support on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question again is to the Prime Minister. Is it not a fact, using the average income figures in this Telegraph article today, that the tax cut for the average wage earner is only a little over $17 per week and not the $46 per week that is foreshadowed in the newspaper? Secondly, is it not a fact that, if it is done on the same basis as the Fightback! document, your tax cut for the average income earner is less than half of ours?

—The answer to the last part of the question is no. The answer to the first part of the question, Mr Speaker, is that I did not do the Telegraph calculations for them. If you want to do a back of the envelope job there, go for your life. If you expect me in Question Time to get the calculator out and work out what the tax rates are at various income levels, then you are cracking jokes.

PARA.TAB: We should bear this in mind: were the Opposition ever, God help us, to become the government of Australia, and it produced Fightback to the Department of Finance and the Treasury, they would take the Opposition's proposals and outlays and they would add on $1,355m—$365m for the change to Medicare; $349m for the GBE dividends; $261m on public debt interest; and administrative changes of $193m. Both the increased outlays and savings would fall short of the target by $2.6 billion. That is what the Department of Finance would tell you.

Then the Department of the Treasury and the Taxation Office would say that the tax measures would show that you have overstated your revenue by $1.1 billion, assuming no avoidance of the GST, assuming new collections from the black economy, which are speculative, and overstated the GST base. After adjustments are made to all figures on a comparable basis, the unfunded part of the Fightback package is $3.9 billion. So, even with a consumption tax, you could not deliver the tax cuts which we are delivering. You have got a $4 billion hole. This is not our say-so; the Department of Finance and the Treasury say so.

The fact of the matter is that you stand up and talk about a 30 per cent rate. But, to bring the rate down from 38 to 30, it costs around $7 billion to $8 billion. You talk about a 30 per cent rate, but you can deliver only half of that. You cannot even get below about 34 per cent, because 30 per cent costs about $4 billion, which you do not have. So again we will be the only people who can deliver a 30 per cent tax rate to taxpayers on low and medium incomes between $20,000 and $40,000.

How dare the Leader of the Opposition—after this Government has changed, without any cost to low income taxpayers, the tax rate from 30 per cent to 20 per cent; increased the tax free threshold; spent large amounts of money on the family allowance supplement for low income families with children, and added another quarter of a billion to it as a result of last night's announcement—then say, for the paltry compensation payments for the GST, that he is giving something to people earning under $20,000? It takes a lot of gall to put that proposition over, and a lot of gall you have, obviously.

When we inherited the tax system the top marginal rate in this country was 60 per cent. Who was the Treasurer? J. W. Howard. Take a bow! And who was his adviser? The honourable member for Wentworth. What is the top rate today? It is 47 per cent. What was the company rate then under those opposite? It was 46 per cent. What is it now? It is 39 per cent.

What was the rate of tax on distributed incomes under Messrs Howard and Hewson when they were in office? Answer: 78c in the dollar. What is the answer now? It is 47c, but if they do not distribute it, it is 39c. We have cut it in half. The Government has now approved a depreciation and now, after giving tax reform costing billions over the years, we are going to reduce the medium incomes from 38 per cent to 30 per cent, with no consumption tax. Does it not rankle you? You then have the hide to say it is unfunded when your own things are funded by fiscal drag. When your own things are funded by the impact of inflation on the tax system—fiscal drag—you say it is unfunded. What a paltry dishonest comment that was, when your own package is, by your own measure, unfunded.

Apparently the Leader of the Opposition thinks we ought to hang on to the fiscal drag, but if he thinks we should hang on to it, why should he be able to give it away? If we should hang on to it and supposedly fund it—that is, keep it—even with modest inflation the receipts in the tax system rise and the real tax burden rises, but we should keep the loot, not hand it back and not give taxpayers a break. If he does it, well, that is okay, that is part of reform.
Again the Leader of the Opposition is always engaged; he asked the question and now, as always, he has a little conference, a little conversation. He is psychologically unsuited to reply—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Well, he is going to have to change the old psychology quite a bit because he is going to get a lot of it.
—Order! The member for Dundas will cease interjecting.

—Particularly about this: the vicious tax regime you had on Australian taxpayers and the vicious one you are about to put on them by taxing the food they put in their mouths and the clothes they put on their backs for themselves and their children.
—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of recent comments suggesting—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of recent comments suggesting that the 1950s were a time of great advancement for Australia, a golden age for Australia? Can the Prime Minister tell the House whether it is the Government's intention to pursue similar outcomes?

—In the past week we have had one of those rare philosophic outbursts from the Opposition. We had some remarks from the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong at a philosophical level which could not have made the differences between the Government and the Opposition clearer than they did. They started off with the Leader of the Opposition, with his back turned as usual, talking about, `I never learned respect at school'. You see, I should never have said in front of Her Majesty the Queen of Australia that Australia was now trading with the Asia-Pacific area. I should never have said that we have independence from Britain and Europe, as Britain joined the Common Market and as Australia trades now 70 to 80 per cent of its imports and exports with the Asia-Pacific area. I should never have made that remark about independence to the Queen of this continent. I should have had more respect. How dare I even reflect modestly on the old links with Britain, on the British bootstraps stuff? Of course we then had a flurry of comment by the honourable member for Bennelong about the 1950s and what a very good period that was—he said it was a very, very good period, a golden age. That was the period when gross domestic product per head was half what it is now; when commodities occupied 85 per cent of our exports; when telephones were half what they are now; when there were half as many cars per thousand people of population; when pensions were half their real value of today and when 10 children per 1,000 went to university instead of 30 per 1,000. That was the golden age when Australia stagnated. That was the golden age when Australia was injected with a near-lethal dose of fogeyism by the conservative parties opposite, when they put the country into neutral and where we very gently ground to a halt in the nowhere land of the early 1980s, with a dependency on commodities that would not pay for our imports.

PARA.TAB: That was the golden age when vast numbers of Australians never got a look in; when women did not get a look in and had no equal rights and no equal pay; when migrants were factory fodder; when Aborigines were excluded from the system; when we had these xenophobes running around about Britain and bootstraps; and that awful cultural cringe under Menzies which held us back for nearly a generation.

I said today at the Press Club that one of my colleagues, the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, has always been at the Cabinet about the future development of the old Parliament House and about whether it ought to be a constitutional museum or museum of Australian cultural history. We thought we could basically make the changes and put some of the cultural icons of the 1950s down there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Higgins.

—The Morphy Richards toaster, the Qualcast mower, a pair of heavily protected slippers, the Astor TV, the AWA radiogram. And, of course, the honourable member for Wentworth and the honourable member for Bennelong could go there as well. When the kids come and look at them they will say, `Gee, mum, is that what it was like then?'. And the two Johns can say, `No, kids. This is the future'. Back down the time tunnel to the future—there they are. I was told that I did not learn respect at school. I learned one thing: I learned about self-respect and self-regard for Australia—not about some cultural cringe to a country which decided not to defend the Malayan peninsula, not to worry about Singapore and not to give us our troops back to keep ourselves free from Japanese domination. This was the country that you people wedded yourself to, and even as it walked out on you and joined the Common Market, you were still looking for your MBEs and your knighthoods, and all the rest of the regalia that comes with it. You would take Australia right back down the time tunnel to the cultural cringe where you have always come from. That is why your Fightback! document—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise. Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Dundas will cease interjecting. I think the honourable member for Bennelong is going to have a heart attack if his face goes any redder, so he might cease interjecting too. Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.

—These are the same old fogies who doffed their lids and tugged the forelock to the British establishment; they now try to grind down Australian kids by denying them a technical school education and want to put a tax on the back of the poor. The same old sterile ideology, the same old fogyism of the 1950s, that produced the Thatcherite policies of the late 1970s is going to produce Fightback. We will not have a bar of it. You can go back to the fifties to your nostalgia, your Menzies, the Caseys and the whole lot. They were not aggressively Australian, they were not aggressively proud of our culture, and we will have no bar of you or your sterile ideology.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.
—I see the Max Gillies speech writer is being put to good use.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Banks.
—He had to read his jokes, Mr Speaker, the Max Gillies speech writer—
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition—
—Why don't you be impartial from the chair?
—Order! The House will come to order.
—Why don't you?
—If the honourable member for Bennelong interjects again, I will deal with him. The House will come to order. Honourable members on both sides will cease interjecting.
—A bit of impartiality would help.
—I name the honourable member for Gippsland.
—Mr Speaker, I move that the honourable member for Gippsland be suspended from the service of the House.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the honourable member for Gippsland wish to withdraw the remark?
—Withdrawn.

—Is the Prime Minister aware that the 3.9 million taxpayers who earn less than $21,000 are mostly students, women, farmers, the retired, pensioners and beneficiaries? Simply, why have you abandoned these people by restricting your tax cuts to those on incomes greater than $20,700?

—He is on their back with a consumption tax, and he has the gall to ask me about their fortunes. He will hit all of those taxpayers with a consumption tax, and then barely cover the compensation with a tax cut—no discretionary additions to outlays, such as we had last night; no changes to the tax system, such as we had over the 1980s, from 30 per cent to 20 per cent; no increase in the tax-free threshold other than to compensate for the consumption tax—and he thinks he has some sort of virtue on his side. Where do you get off!

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—Is the Minister for Finance aware of criticism that the fiscal strategy in the One Nation package is inappropriate? Can the Minister inform the House of the reasons for the fiscal strategy embodied in the package?
—I am aware of criticisms that have come from the Opposition about the Government's fiscal policy, both before last night—early this week—and, of course, following the Prime Minister's statement.

PARA.TAB: Earlier this week Access Economics said that the Budget was blowing out to $9 billion before this statement, and the Opposition rushed to embrace that. Of course, the publication of figures last night shows that Access Economics—or should it be `Excess Economics'—was miles out in its forecast. Our forecast was $6.3 billion—not $9 billion—and that $6.3 billion will become $6.8 billion with the measures announced in the Prime Minister's statement, which will take the deficit to less than 2 per cent of GDP—1.7 per cent—next year. With the major impact of the measures, we will have an $8 billion deficit but that will still leave us with less than 2 per cent of GDP deficit. Those percentages compare with those in the early 1980s. In 1982-83 it was 2.6 per cent of GDP and in 1983-84 it was 4.1 per cent. So we are looking at percentages of GDP which are far less than those at the time of the previous recession.

Of course the major criticism of the Government's fiscal policy is that it is unfunded. Those opposite say that the measures announced last night by the Prime Minister are unfunded. They are really saying that they should have been offset by tax increases or by other government expenditure cuts. In effect, this means that they are saying that there should be no fiscal stimulus; that is what they are saying.

If you have an array of expenditure increases and tax cuts which are offset by other expenditure cuts and tax increases, obviously there is no fiscal stimulus. Those opposite are saying that, in the present economic circumstances, when the recovery is obviously very weak and it is not likely that we will move rapidly into substantial economic growth without some further action being taken by the Government, at the least we should have done nothing; the least thing is that we should have done absolutely nothing in terms of this statement—no stimulus whatsoever. But it is wrong in the sense that that is his basic position—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Fightback.

—Exactly—Fightback. Do you know what you do with the first year of Fightback? If you had been here last night as Prime Minister announcing your policy, instead of announcing a policy of measures of $2.3 billion to stimulate the economy, Dr Hewson would have been up here announcing a policy to cut expenditure by $3.3 billion—that is the first year of Fightback. That is what they would do in the current economic circumstances.

PARA.TAB: There is one group of people—one group only—that thinks that what we should really do now, at a time when the economy needs to get moving and when we need to get unemployment down, is slash government expenditure; have a contraction of the economy; and contract demand—cut demand at a time when demand is weak and there is a great need for an increase in demand—by $3 billion. You are a bunch of economic lunatics.

The even greater absurdity is that in the second year of Fightback—after you have contracted the economy by $3 billion in year one, when you have the impact of the GST whacking inflation up towards double digit levels again—what do you do? You ease off on fiscal policy—in the year in which you impose a big inflationary impact on the economy. What a lunatic fiscal policy it is.

Of course, in those circumstances there would have to be a massive increase in interest rates unless you were going to have that inflation permanently built in. The wages blow-out scenario, much talked about by Dr Murphy as one of the possibilities, would be an absolute certainty without that further contraction of the economy by increasing interest rates very dramatically.
The Opposition criticises us for having a fiscal policy which is unfunded, in circumstances when they themselves would pursue a policy of no stimulus and, in fact, a contraction of the economy.
Finally, let me say this about the unfunded side of things. We have just had four years of Budget surplus—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for McPherson.

—They are the only Budget surpluses that this country has ever recorded—four years of surplus—and they have amounted to $18 billion. We will now go through three or four years of deficit. It will be roughly the same amount—about $18 billion of deficit. We will then move back into a surplus.

PARA.TAB: So we are not pursuing a policy which is reckless or structurally impairing the Budget; it is a policy built on the basis of a very strong Budget position before we entered this recession. Those years of substantial Budget surplus enabled us to cut Budget sector debt from 21.6 per cent of GDP to 12 per cent of GDP. So we had substantial debt reduction. We will now go through a period of some increase in the deficit, but we will move back to Budget surplus in a few years time.

The policy being pursued by this Government is the appropriately flexible fiscal policy. It is an utterly responsible policy and it contrasts markedly with the absurd fiscal policy proposed by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—In today's Sydney Morning Herald an article quotes me in part correctly and in part incorrectly. The first quote is:

PARA.TAB: "The statement fails to provide a boost to our competitiveness; it fails to create genuine sustainable job growth because it leaves in place the horrific sales tax slug on all exporters, along with high levels of petrol and diesel fuel excise," he said.

SPEECH.PARA: In the next paragraph it states:

PARA.TAB: The lack of sales tax reform added 5 per cent to the costs of exporters, he said.
He damned the decision to re-open the prospect of mining at Coronation Hill in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the House that Coronation Hill is no thimble-full mine. It involves 600 jobs and $500m worth of export income. In fact, I have always supported this mine. It is totally incorrect for the Sydney Morning Herald to say that I would damn a decision to re-open the prospect of mining at Coronation Hill. I support the reversal of the Cabinet decision on Coronation Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—During Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) quite dishonestly—I use the word deliberately, because it is true—asserted that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), my colleagues and I had opposed the family allowance supplement. I point out to the House that when the debate on that legislation in 1987—
—No.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, the Prime Minister lied about our position.
—No.
—I will revise that, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I will say—
—The honourable member for Bennelong will withdraw.

—I will withdraw the word `lied' because it is unparliamentary; nonetheless it remains true that the Prime Minister deliberately misrepresented our position. He gets up here day after day in this Parliament—
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, with respect, I have not finished my personal explanation.
—I warn the honourable member for Bennelong.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will take a point of order.
—No.
—Why? You cannot do that.
—The honourable member for Bennelong will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker—
—Mr Deputy Speaker!
—No, I do not want to hear from the honourable member for Pearce either.
—You cannot say no. You have no right to say no.
—Resume your seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

—No. I am dealing with the honourable member for Bennelong. The honourable member for Bennelong sought the indulgence of the Chair. He has introduced new material that is not germane to his personal explanation.
—May I speak to that?
—Yes, you may.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, the Prime Minister said in Question Time that the Opposition had opposed the family allowance supplement. Surely it is germane—
—That part is. Do not argue, that part is. Continue.

—Thank you. The point I make is that not only did we not oppose it when it was introduced in 1987; it was our idea in the first place because it was introduced under the name of the family income supplement in the 1982 Budget. I brought down that Budget and it was an initiative of Senator Chaney, a former Minister for Social Security. Thank you very much.
—Order! The honourable member has concluded his personal explanation. I remind the honourable member for Bennelong that indulgence is granted by the Chair. He should not abuse that indulgence.

—I accept that admonition. I have very great respect for you, Mr Deputy Speaker, but perhaps the Prime Minister ought to understand that he should not abuse his privileges in this Parliament and completely misrepresent our position.
—There is no further personal explanation.
