PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The Government's failure to effectively deal with the economic problems facing Australia and to map out a strategy for future prosperity.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise this matter of public importance today to focus upon the issues which the nation ought to be focusing on as it endures the worst recession for 60 years. As honourable members would be aware, there have been some major statements of government policy brought down in the last few days which are occupying public debate. I met a few of my Labor colleagues around the corridors last night and, I must say, it is no wonder that they were looking so glum and so concerned about their own political future.

PARA.TAB: If they listened to 2GB this morning, when a radio poll was conducted on people's attitudes to the statement that we had last night, they would have heard that 79 per cent were opposed to the statement and said that it went nowhere far enough. I suppose that is no wonder. When members of the public got up this morning and turned on their radios or walked out in their pyjamas to get the morning paper they were met with a series of headlines which really told the story about the reactions to the Keating statement landed in our laps last night. The Sydney Morning Herald had the word `gamble' in its headline; the Canberra Times had `Keating spends, and hopes'; the Australian had the words`votes grab'; the Australian Financial Review had the words `risky play'; the headline in the Telegraph Mirror was `Who's going to pay for it?'; the Sydney Morning Herald, `A nudge, not a kick-start'; the Canberra Times, `What about when the bill's due?'; capped off by the Age with the headline, `An unashamedly political pitch for votes'.

The headlines were not a surprise because they reflected the damning commentary of so many independent commentators as they looked at Mr Keating's whiz-bang package to get himself back into the Lodge after the next election. Terry Vine said it pretty well in the Herald-Sun, when he stated:
And you might as well throw in magic, rabbit, wand and hat.

SPEECH.PARA: But this is the same man who stood before us these past five years telling us one lot of whoppers after another as this country went further and further into depression.
Alan Ramsey, no great friend of the Liberal Party, stated:

PARA.TAB: This isn't bold, it is shameless . . . Paul Keating's latest piece of political hocus-pocus is a breathtaking attempt to persuade Australians he can achieve in four years what he couldn't achieve in nine.
It's really just window-dressing, more gloss to dress up the vision splendid for the years ahead. Voter bait, if you like.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Sydney Morning Herald, under the heading `A nudge, not a kick-start', Ross Gittins stated:

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating says he has a four-year plan to fix the economy. That's rubbish.

SPEECH.PARA: He talks about the `"scenario" for the economy over the next four years to 1995-96 that no-one in his right mind would take seriously'. He continues:

PARA.TAB: The fine print of Treasury's forecast (which probably errs on the optimistic side)—

SPEECH.PARA: that is a generous comment—
is for unemployment to "drift up further". . .
the economic statement doesn't add up to much as an economic document. It's real punch is political.
Stephen Bartholomeusz wrote an article for the Age headed `A mish-mash dressed up as a strategy'. Then, even from the people who are his friends, look what Geoffrey Barker said:
. . . Mr Keating's best and fundamentally decent intentions seemed close to being overwhelmed by his inherent caution.
Mind you, that did not stop Mr Barker having a shot at the Opposition. He starts with the following incredible claim:

PARA.TAB: This proposal marks Labor's belated recognition of the problems of middle-income earners, and is more socially equitable . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I am going to destroy that in a moment. That is simply not true. Then he had the audacity to go on and say that our Fightback package gives the most benefit to higher income earners. That is simply not true. His running stablemate Tim Colebatch said that the Prime Minister basically had the guts to be a populist. That is not bad. Then, in respect of the statement, he said:
. . . it shrank back from doing something more when it could have.
Ken Davidson—`Red Ken' from the Spencer Street Soviet—said:
. . . the impact of the proposals on the macro-economy (national output, employment and inflation) will be imperceptible.

He could not even get his mates on side. Michelle, as I say, just described it as `an unashamedly political pitch for votes'. But my award for the most jargon-free, entertaining and incisive comment goes to Terry McCrann of the Herald-Sun, who starts off by saying:

PARA.TAB: Paul Keating should have been a used car salesman. Last night he gave Australia its first Arfur Daley budget—extravagant spiel, worn tyres, clapped-out engine, use-by warranty and all.
Last night's speech could go down in the salesman's manual as perhaps the ultimate spiel, cleverly recycling and reworking all the old Keating rhetoric.
"Soft landing?" No way—pin your ears back for the roaring take-off. He promises it; he guarantees it.
As for "bringing home the bacon"—the all-new Keating now promises to deliver the whole goddam pig (in a poke). To every table.
If you believed just half of what was said last night, Moses would have to stand aside in utter embarrassment for our Paul to lead us to the promised land.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not bad, Terry, your prize will be in the mail. The cartoon of the day is of the Prime Minister. He is wearing that great Mexican hat, a sombrero, and has a banana in his hand. Underneath it says `Juan Nation'—the banana republic well on its way to fulfilment in Australia.

PARA.TAB: When we read the statement the first thing that really hits us about it is that this whole sort of mirage, this edifice is just built on quicksand. It will be there one day and literally gone without trace in a few days. That is because all the numbers in this are just plain shonky. It is incredible that the Government of Australia could produce a statement based on such loopy numbers on all the principal economic parameters. It is just pie in the sky. It is just being dreamt up. The Government never said that it is actually Treasury's forecast; no. I bet these figures have all been pumped in out of the Treasurer's office and out of the Prime Minister's office.

Take their estimates of how Australia is going to grow in the next two or three years. Basically what they are saying is that when we get to 1 July he, the architect of the recession, is going to flick a switch and we are going to go from a recession to a boom. That is basically it. If we look at the figures he is projecting, we see we are going to zoom up to nearly 5 per cent GDP growth next year and stay there, and stay at an average of 4.3 per cent. We have not achieved that at any time while these guys have been in. That is nowhere near their average. In fact, their average for GDP growth 1983-84 to 1991-92, making an assumption about the last couple of months, is in fact 3.03 per cent, and they are assuming that they are going to get 4.75 per cent next year and 4.3 per cent as an average over the next three or four years. It is just not going to happen.

I guarantee the Treasurer will get up and say, `Look, this turnaround is not even as big as the turnaround that we had back in 1982-83'. That is his response. He will get up and give it to us rote. If it were true, if we were miraculously to go into this growth phase that these people are all hoping for to save their political necks, the next assumption they make is that as we grow we do not suck in any imports. Go back to 1982-83. What did we do? Sure, they pumped up the economy. We started sucking in imports and we got a massive debt that went from $23 billion to $133 billion, which is about $8,000 for every man, woman and child in the country. And these blokes want to do it again. Well, it is not going to happen. It is just undeliverable. It is pie in the sky.

Take, for example, the second of their assumptions, which is a big jump in productivity growth. The average growth rate under these people has been about 0.7 per cent. The current trend is about 0.5 per cent. What do they assume in their numbers to create this magnificent mirage on this quicksand—1 1/2 per cent, a factor of two. They see a number, double it, whack it in there and tell us, `Don't worry, we are going to have a boom, a recovery'. Well, it is not going to happen, specifically because you are not prepared to take on your trade union mates and see the sort of reforms to the way in which we run our businesses in this country and employee relations to actually capture the potential which we have—which this country certainly has, but certainly not under you people because you take your orders from people like Bill Kelty.

The third assumption which I want to knock over, and which is another one of the foundations of this mirage that is sitting on the quicksand, concerns private investment. Private investment this year has dropped by about 6 1/2 to 7 per cent, something of that order. It has actually dropped. These people are projecting that next year, 1992-93 it is going to be 4 per cent and in 1993-94 it is going to be 12 per cent and stay there. It is going backwards at the moment. They have built their house of cards on a projection that we are going to have positive investment, and the latest official statistics from the ABS say that the projections are that investment is going to continue to fall. Well, we just kick away another one of the foundations upon which you people have built this mirage.
Obviously we do not oppose everything in the package. It would be great if we could just flick a switch and save Paul's political neck and get everybody back to work. It would be great.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The honourable member should refer to honourable members by their appropriate titles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Recession.
—Mr Recession.
—No. The honourable member will withdraw that and refer to honourable members by their correct title.
—I am only provoked by my colleagues, who will refer to him as Mr Recession.
—The honourable member's colleagues should not provoke him.

—I do withdraw. Obviously there are some measures which we would support. For example, there is the power grid. That was in Fightback!, so of course we support it. We support the capital gains tax relief, the foreign banks, and some of those things—and the few dollars that are going to families just once for the Wills by-election. We support that in the sense that people have been kicked very badly by this Government.
—Conscience money.

—It is conscience money; I thank the honourable member. Obviously we would have some support for that.One of the most surprising things in the package is Labor's treatment of that part of the community which earns up to $20,000 a year. It is a stunning fact that nearly half of all taxpayers—nearly 4 million Australians—in fact earn only up to $20,700 a year. We have the latest available statistics, but it is around that figure.

PARA.TAB: If I was a Labor Party backbencher, I would be looking to see what the Government was going to do by way of tax cuts for those who have been most badly affected by this recession, those who have been kicked from pillar to post—those without education, those without the skills and those whose socioeconomic circumstances put them on a treadmill, if you like, of low economic standards.

As we flick through the pages it stands out that that group in our society, those in greatest need, get a once-off payment if they have children, which affects about 200,000 or 300,000, and the other 3 1/2 million get absolutely nothing. It is extraordinary. Not only do they get nothing, but they pay more tax over the years through bracket creep. You guys who talk about compassion, concern for the disadvantaged in our society, have kicked them in the teeth and now you abandon them, and in the next year, two years, three years, four years, five years you give them absolutely nothing. I think it is an outrage. I think you ought to be ashamed of this package. You carry on about fairness and social justice. Yet you give tax cuts to the rich, to those earning from $20,000 to $100,000 a year, and nothing to those in greatest need in our society.

This whole package is based on loopy numbers. The numbers are shonky. The commentators have canned it. The Government is borrowing more money, which we cannot afford, and putting it all on the national bankcard. Interest rates will go up, debt will go up and, lastly, it misses a chance, its last chance, to provide some sense of hope, some sense of vision for those who have borne the consequences of the recession that it engineered.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was supposed to be a debate about mapping out a strategy for the future prosperity of the country, but instead what we had from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) was a fairly shallow attempt to criticise the Government's proposals which were announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last night. The speech proceeded on the basis of a series of quotations from journalists, who are now referred to as commentators in terms of this economic debate. I suppose the one thing which I lament in the last nine years is that in a sense we taught them all too well. We taught them about the desirability of fiscal restraint. We taught them about the desirability of getting our Budget in shape. We taught them about the desirability, in the context of a period of strong economic growth, to get the Budget back into surplus. We taught them about the virtues of having a low level of debt confronting the central government. We taught them all that over the last nine years.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, we allowed those commentators to forget a few important lessons. We allowed them to forget that, in the context of a recession, there is an important role for government to play in trying to bring on an economic recovery. Essentially, that is what this debate is all about. It is about whether we want to see the Australian economy continue to languish in a recession—in the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), a decade of recession—or whether we want to see a legitimate role for government in trying to bring on a recovery, trying to do something about a more rapid return to prosperity, a more rapid generation of jobs in this country to try to get back to work the 800,000 or 900,000 people who are now looking for work. The commentators, so-called, have forgotten that there is a perfectly legitimate role for government, particularly in the context of our fiscal position.

We did not for nothing go through that period of teaching the Opposition the virtues of fiscal propriety. We did not embrace that objective. We did not go into a period of sustained Budget surplus during the good years just so that we could hang on to it. We did it because we wanted to get the Budget back into shape so that, if ever we needed to use the room that was created by that restructuring of the Budget, we could do so without threatening the structure of the Budget or the indebtedness of the nation.

It is important to recall that we probably have the lowest level of indebtedness of any country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. The average debt level of OECD countries is 60 per cent of gross domestic product. Ours is 16 per cent—60 per cent versus 16 per cent. Whether it is measured in terms of domestic debt or the Commonwealth's foreign debt, that is a very low level of indebtedness indeed. In other words, we went through the 1980s setting ourselves up so that we could have the budgetary flexibility to do precisely what we are doing today. Yet what do we hear from those opposite? We hear that we should not do it; in other words, that we should not apply some fiscal stimulus; we should only expend that which we save—which is a piece of fiscal and economic nonsense.

We now have the so-called commentators being too slow to relearn the lessons they got in the 1980s, which were that in these circumstances we can promote the economy from recession to recovery. But I have every confidence that these commentators well understand not only that there is a case for fiscal stimulus now and that we have the opportunity to exercise that fiscal stimulus, but that this particular package of measures is much more, so very much more, than just a question of trying to provide some fiscal stimulus to the Australian economy.

Most of what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition had to say was, essentially, nonsense. That bit of his speech which was of his own originality—that is, not based on quotations of others—was nonsense. As he revealed so patently today, he does not have a strategy for Australia. He does not even want to promote Australia into a recovery. He does not believe Australia can grow. He does not believe Australia can grow faster than its trading partners. Even his key adviser, his key economic oracle—Access Economics—believes that in 1992-93 Australia can expect to grow out of recession into recovery at a rate of just under 4 per cent. That estimate was made prior to the package of measures announced by the Prime Minister, which was designed quite specifically to promote that level of growth during 1992-93 and then into a more prolonged and sustained period of recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you defend your assumptions?

—The honourable member for Flinders, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, asks me to defend the key assumptions which underlie the scenarios in the Prime Minister's statement. I spent a very extensive time—indeed, members of the Opposition were complaining about the length of my answer—pointing out how different Australia is. It is no surprise that the slow-witted honourable member for Flinders either did not listen or did not comprehend what I was saying. Australia is a very different place from that which it was in 1982-83. We have been through a period of great change, of structural change—change which can now begin to bear the fruit which we all thought it would.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the Liberal Party of Australia and, most particularly, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, have no belief, no confidence, no faith in Australia. They have no belief, faith or confidence in the Australian people. They do not understand the great changes that have gone on in Australian industry to make Australia a more competitive place.

What is interesting about the debate that is going on at the moment is that, when industry and the trade unions came to see us, they were not asking for a slowdown in the levels of tariff reduction. Do honourable members opposite know why they were not? It was because they were adjusting to accommodate those tariff reductions. They were doing the hard work at the level of each individual firm in Australia. At the factory floor level workers and management were getting together, finding new and better ways of doing things in Australia, so that we could become more productive. Those people really need a pat on the back, a bit of encouragement, rather than a constant tirade of abuse and denigration which they receive from the Liberal Party and the Opposition in general.

The Liberal Party does not believe that that change has occurred and does not believe that Australians have it in them to achieve that kind of change. They want to subject Australia to a continuing recession. As I said yesterday when quoting the Leader of the Opposition, those opposite believe that Australia should be in for a decade of austerity, a decade of recession, a decade during which unemployment would continue to rise. We say, `That is not good enough for the Australian people; Australia can do better; Australia can grow at a modest 4 per cent or 4.5 per cent, or maybe a little more; we can do that because we have now made some of the changes necessary to achieve that'. Most particularly, for the first time ever we have an understanding of what should happen to wages during a period of growth.

In all of the periods of growth over which the Liberal Party presided and, most particularly, in that period leading up to the 1982-83 recession, what did we see? We simply saw an explosion in wages, leading to an explosion in inflation, leading to an explosion in the current account deficit. In other words, those opposite could not run a period of sustained growth. They could not do it because they had that big missing link, that big gaping hole in their policy structure—that total absence of an approach to wages. They did not have an idea about wages. If they did have an idea, they did not have a mechanism with which to achieve it. In 1982-83 we saw an attempt to decentralise the wages system which simply led to an increase in wages of about 18 per cent in one year. It was totally absurd and something about which the government of the day could do nothing.

On this occasion things are vastly different. We have a trade union movement which understands the primacy of getting jobs. It understands the primacy of developing a manufacturing industry. It understands the primacy of building that manufacturing industry on an export capacity. It is because it understands the primacy of competitiveness that it has decided that wage increases should be conditional upon our maintaining an inflation rate at or below that of our major trading partners. It knows the damage that inflation can do to its industries. It knows the damage that can be done to its jobs.

What does the Opposition have to say about wages policy? It has a policy which is not about constraining inflation, but giving it an almighty kick. Those opposite want to give inflation a kick by introducing a 15 per cent tax on food, on clothing and everything else—on all the goods and services provided in this country. Whatever might be the arguments of the effect of that on inflation, everyone knows that it will have a very substantial effect on inflation.

Those opposite are saying to the Australian work force, `We are going to increase your cost of living, but don't you ever expect to take that increase in wages. Don't you ever expect to maintain your standard of living through the wages system'. How on earth can working men and women be expected simply to accept that proposition when those opposite do not have a relationship with the trade union movement? In fact, when they want to embark on a policy and a process of government which will set one Australian against another, which will try to set worker against boss, and which will try to set the rich against the poor, how can they ever expect to have any agreement about anything, let alone something so centrally important as a wages strategy for this country?

The only thing those opposite can rely on in the end is that as any pressure emerges in the wages system and as workers try to compensate for the impact of the goods and services tax—or the food and clothing tax—they will simply hit the workers with an increase in interest rates in order to knock out of the system any pretence or any expectation of a wage increase. That of course is why the Opposition is interested in a no-growth economy: because it cannot have a growth economy in the context of the introduction of a consumption tax.

We, on the other hand, have another view. We have the view that Australia is a place that can compete with the world. We have seen the way in which our trade has been switched from a great reliance on Europe and north America towards a greater reliance on the burgeoning markets of north and South East Asia. We are saying that, if we want to grow along with them, we have to continue the process of structural change. That is why my colleague the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) has a plan to improve road transport. We also have a plan in his portfolio to improve the rail system so that our ports can begin to be not only competitive in themselves but also forced to compete one against each other, because for the first time they will be connected by a rail system that works and operates efficiently.

These are the kinds of things we are doing in order to lower the costs to business and to reinforce a move towards a more competitive Australia—one which can, with a great deal of confidence, face the rest of the world and compete for its markets. That is the difference between us and those opposite. We believe we can grow and we should grow, not on the basis of an artificial stimulus, but on the basis of rebuilding the infrastructure, which is so important to Australia, and of continuing the process of micro-economic reform, which will have as its great bonus the lifting of the burden of costs from the backs of Australian business, therefore providing for greater profitability, greater growth and a greater number of jobs. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith), who put forward this matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's failure to effectively deal with the economic problems facing Australia and to map out a strategy for future prosperity.

As my colleague pointed out earlier, the whole of this One Nation program is built on quicksand. He has elaborated in some detail and I will get to some specifics in a minute. But having listened to the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), I think one of the points made by my colleague was spot on. He said that basically the Government is not prepared to take on that privileged group—its mates in the ACTU.

PARA.TAB: What was even more disappointing about the Treasurer's contribution was that he failed to read the matter of public importance. In fact, he failed to read the word `failure', which is what it is all about—the Government's failure. I listened carefully to what he had to say, and I noted that there was one thing that he just could not acknowledge—the fact that it is the failure of this Government that has led this country into its worst recession in 60 years. The Treasurer could not even front the chamber and admit that his Government had in fact driven us into the worst recession in 60 years. This more than anything else tells us how much duplicity this Government is trying to engage in in wanting to mislead the Australian population not only about its intentions but also about its past failures.

It was interesting also to listen to the Treasurer make his attack on financial commentators. It seems that he does not like them any more because they will no longer be `nice guys'. It seems that, when all else has failed, he is now lecturing the commentators for actually noticing that the Government is failing. Of course, throughout all of this he completely overlooked the unemployed, those who face bankruptcy and those who face dreadful personal hardship, delivered as a direct result of what this Government has been on about.

I guess the main thrust of this statement is about one thing: public works. The Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) no doubt feels very lucky because he will now be overseeing a massive increase in spending on public works. I suppose that if the projects were funded we would say that many of them are very worth while. But with this One Nation program we are really looking at something which is aimed more at saving the neck of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and those of his mates in some of the Labor States than it is at growth in Australia.

It is much more like Whitlam revisited. Do honourable members remember the vision Whitlam had of taking over the railways and all the various things he was going to do? In fact, if one looks at the record one can see it was the Fraser Government that actually had to implement many of the reforms that were needed. It is ironic to compare the capital spending on rail put forward by the Fraser Government with what has been put forward by this Government to date. In the seven years of the Fraser Government—excluding what went into Australian National Railways—over $400m was put into railways. How much has the Hawke-Keating Government put in? TALK.START.PARA: —That's rubbish, and you know it. Even your colleagues don't believe that.

—That comes from the Minister's mates, the ARU. But let us look at Commonwealth government expenditure overall. We can see which government was really interested in capital investment and which one was not. I hold up this document for the chamber. Honourable members really ought to inspect this carefully, because what they will see is that in most of the years of the Fraser Government, capital expenditure either equalled or in most cases exceeded consumption expenditure, whereas this Labor Government, for all of its time in office up till 1990, has presided over a massive excess of consumption spending over capital expenditure. Is it any wonder that so much of our infrastructure is run down? Over those years it has been seriously and deliberately run down by this Government, which has suddenly found that maybe it would like to go on this spending spree.

PARA.TAB: But the matter is more serious than that because we now have to look at whether there has been any serious assessment of the estimates of returns for the money invested. TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not.

PARA.TAB: There are other things about these projects that are of concern because, as the Minister would know well, there is little point in spending this money without having received full agreement from the unions to get international best work practices. The questions keep rolling in. When will these projects happen? How does the Government expect to deliver them? How long will the agreements last? Who is going to pay for the redundancies? As the Minister would be well aware, the National Rail Corporation has suggested that the number of people employed will be considerably less than the number currently employed on some of these rail routes. With all this additional money being spent, will the National Rail Corporation become commercial and, if so, when? As the Minister would well know, many of the projects that have been announced in this statement have already been identified as marginal projects at best by the National Rail Corporation itself.

I turn to the Government's mates in Victoria. We have to ask this question about the Victorian railways: why is something not being done to get some real efficiency there? We have a ludicrous situation in Victoria: the railways alone are losing over $3m a day. One wonders how long the nation has to put up with the losses on the railways. Currently, according to the Industry Commission, they amount to over $4 billion a year. It is easy to say, but it is something like $11m per day—$450,000 per hour. That is what our railways are losing us. Just in the time that it takes for me to make this speech, the railways will lose more than the annual salary of a backbencher in this chamber. That is a problem that the Government has not addressed. All it wants to do is spend more money, without addressing some of these problems.

We can look at some of the things that money is wasted on. As the Minister knows full well, the National Rail Corporation is going to address only 12 per cent of the rail freight, which itself accounts for less than half of the losses of the railways. It is not micro-economic reform: it is a public works program. Last year over $1m worth of goods was stolen from the Indian Pacific train. We have an extraordinary situation in Victoria in that in the town of Dimboola, when a light globe blows—and I am sure many of my colleagues would know that Dimboola is west of Horsham—a phone call to Ararat has to be made to get an electrician to drive to Dimboola: nearly two hours drive just to change a globe. That is the sort of thing that is going on in Victoria. The Minister may laugh, but all of this is costing us dearly.

The point is that, despite the Hawke-Keating cutbacks—and I have already highlighted those very well—there is another interesting statistic worth looking at. I come back to the point that there is, no doubt, a failure in this whole package. It has been cobbled together in a great hurry. Not only is there a need for a change of government; this Government has given us this worst recession and deserves to be roundly condemned for it. (Time expired)

DEBATE.TITLE: PRODUCTION OF RECORDS OF THE HOUSE

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Baldwin, on behalf of Mr Beazley) proposed:

That this House grants leave for Arthur Robinson and Hedderwicks to produce the following records in evidence in proceedings in Western Mining Corporation v. The Commonwealth (ref. VG No. 137 of 1991) before the Federal Court
Parliamentary Debates, House of Representatives—
(a)second reading speech of Mr Griffiths, 8 May 1990, pages 68-72;
(b)continuation of speech of Mr Griffiths, 9 May 1990, page 107; and
(c)statement by Minister for External Affairs, 30 October 1970, pages 3107-3109.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I indicate our support for the motion that has been moved by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin). The most important issue that arises concerning the use of parliamentary records in courts and other tribunals is to ensure that the requirements of the law concerning parliamentary privilege is respected. In particular, there must be no attempt to impeach or question members as to what has taken place in the course of proceedings in parliament. The House relies on the wisdom of judges to ensure that the law is observed in this regard.

PARA.TAB: The present application is concerned with the subsidiary question of the House giving leave for the Hansard extracts in question to be produced in the court proceedings. If the House grants the leave sought, this is not to imply that the proceedings can be impeached or questioned in court; rather it is simply to allow the records to be produced for such limited uses as are not contrary to the provisions of article 9 of the Bill of Rights and section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987.

I understand that the British House of Commons changed its practice in this regard in October 1980 when it agreed to a resolution to the effect that leave be given on a continuing basis for reference to be made in future court proceedings to the official report of debates and to published evidence of committees; in other words, the House of Commons abandoned the practice of granting leave on a case by case basis. The Senate made a similar decision in 1988 but the House has not, to date, changed its practice.

I also note that there is some judicial opinion to the effect that as a matter of law leave is not required for the production of parliamentary records for purposes that are consistent with the constraints imposed by article 9 of the Bill of Rights. Be that as it may, the House has not changed its practice and so it is appropriate for the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), and for the Minister on his behalf, to move a motion, as has been done today. The motion is consistent with our practice in these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Article 9 of the Bill of Rights provides that the freedom of speech and debates or proceedings in parliament ought not to be impeached or questioned in any court or place out of parliament. This fundamental law became part of our law through the provisions of section 49 of the Constitution. In 1987 it was amplified by the provisions of section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987. The motion moved on behalf of the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) is, as has been said, a procedural one. If passed, it will allow records in question to be produced in court for the purposes allowed by article 9 and the 1987 Act. It will thus be possible for a party to establish as a fact, for example, that certain statements were made on certain days.

PARA.TAB: The resolution will not allow the proceedings of the House to be impeached or questioned. I understand that the case giving rise to the motion before the House is at a very preliminary stage and I wish to make no comment on the course it might take. I note, however, that the provisions of article 9 of the Bill of Rights have not always been respected. During the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies in 1983, I understand that serious concerns were held about a document issued by the Commission foreshadowing lines of questioning. It was concluded by the Presiding Officers that some of the questions would have created a risk that proceedings in parliament would be impeached or questioned before the royal commission. Counsel was engaged to argue the question of privilege on behalf of the presiding officers. Counsel's submissions were successful on this point and the documents were amended so that privilege was not infringed.

Later, in the trials of the late Mr Justice Murphy and Judge Foord, witnesses who had given evidence to Senate select committees were questioned as to their committee evidence. Submissions by counsel representing the President of the Senate were rejected on this occasion, but I acknowledge that this was a complex issue and that opinions still differ as to the questions of privilege that arose.

Since then, the Parliament has passed the Parliamentary Privileges Act. This spells out in much more detail what may not be done in courts and other tribunals in so far as parliamentary proceedings are concerned. I understand that a Federal Court decision since the Act was passed gives a very clear decision as to the meaning of section 16 of the Act. One hopes therefore that the risk of proceedings being impeached is now slight.

My concern is that, if the risk of privilege being infringed in any case emerges, the House can be faced with a substantial cost to have its position argued. I think that the Government should consider taking advice on this point as to whether it is possible to attach a condition that the Commonwealth should be indemnified as to all costs. I suppose we could then be criticised as being obstructive in proceedings. Nevertheless, it could be that the Commonwealth will be involved in extra costs because of this, and I think that question should be investigated.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will amend the child support legislation in a number of respects. The Bill will give effect to the Budget announcement that there will be an administrative review process available to all persons named in child support assessments who seek to depart from an assessment raised by the Registrar of Child Support. The grounds for departure will be the same as currently available in a formal process to the court.

PARA.TAB: A further amendment was also announced in the Budget context relating to a one-time option for a pensioner custodian to opt for the private collection of amounts assessed by the Registrar. This Bill amends the law to allow this option to be exercised. A series of amendments will enhance the powers of the Registrar to recover amounts that are due. The power of garnishee will enable debts due to be recovered directly from persons holding money on behalf of a payer who has an outstanding child support debt in satisfaction of the debt that is owed.

A facility is also to be included in the child support legislation which is modelled on a similar provision in the Family Law Act 1975 to enable the Registrar to seek an order from a court to set aside an instrument or disposition which has the effect of defeating a person's capacity to pay child support. These measures have become necessary to ensure that those persons who do not meet their responsibility at law to provide for their children cannot continue to ignore that responsibility. In addition the Bill contains a number of other amendments to the existing legislation designed to enhance the working of the scheme.

The child support scheme has brought about a substantial turnaround in the attitude to, and the payment of, child support for children in single parent families since its inception in June 1988. The outcome has been to see disposable incomes of custodial families increased for the benefit of the children.The detail of the amendments to the legislation I will now outline further assists children in single parent families.

The Bill will allow a custodian or a liable parent to have an assessment of child support reviewed by an independent person free of charge and without legal representation by a child support review officer who will be employed by the Registrar for that single purpose. The intention is that the parties be able to have an assessment reviewed in the light of their individual circumstances. This review will be a mandatory first step in the general appeal process allowable under the law. It may be exercised at any time during the currency of any assessment which is effective from and after 1 July 1992, but may be based only on the grounds that are presently set out for appeals to the courts.

If the grounds that are already prescribed exist, it will be possible for a determination to be made by the Registrar departing from the assessment in force in the same fashion as a court can order a departure from an assessment. Further rights of appeal to the court are retained against determinations that may be made.

Of major importance in this amendment is the proposal to allow and encourage the parties, in the course of this mediation and review process, to agree how the amounts of child support, either in the form of periodic or non-periodic amounts, should be paid. It has never been the intention of the assessment process or the scheme itself to limit people agreeing to arrangements for the support of their children. The most satisfactory and unobtrusive way is for the parents to agree to those arrangements themselves with, however, appropriate revenue safeguards in place for custodians who are in receipt of an income tested pension, benefit or allowance.

At present it is a mandatory requirement that pensioners register for collection by the Child Support Agency an amount of child support that arises from an administrative assessment. This Bill will end that mandatory requirement and allow a pensioner to choose to have the payments made direct. Pensioners may still choose to register the assessment for collection from the outset if that is their wish. Providing that they report to the Department of Social Security that payments are being made in full under the assessment they may continue to receive the payments due privately and directly. If they report that payments are not being made as required, the Department will then require them, as part of the reasonable action for maintenance guidelines, to register the assessment for collection, and once registered it must remain registered until the liability ceases.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Enhancement of the recovery powers of the Registrar

PARA.TAB: The methods of collection of amounts due each month to the Registrar are either by deduction at source of income for salary and wage earners or by direct payment to the Registrar from those employees for whom the agency has not been able to identify an employer or all those liable parents who are not employees for the purposes of the taxation laws.

The power to recover amounts of child support that have not been paid to the Registrar when due is presently limited to actions in the court and by intercepting refunds of tax due on assessment under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. This Bill will enhance the power to recover overdue amounts by making provision for the Registrar, by notice in writing, to require a person who is holding money on behalf of the person who has a child support related debt to pay so much of the money that is held in satisfaction of the debt that is due. The provision will also provide the scope for the Registrar to require amounts that would, in other circumstances, be deemed to be salary and wages to be garnisheed from time to time to the extent necessary to pay amounts of child support that are due to the Registrar.

There are other occasions when the Registrar must act quickly to ensure an opportunity to collect amounts due is not lost. Very often the Registrar becomes aware of amounts being held for the liable parent by a third person, that a settlement is due in which the liable parent is to receive a cash amount, or of the existence of cash in an account at a financial institution. When all efforts to collect have failed or, in the judgment of the Registrar, it would be appropriate to garnishee funds held, it will be possible to do so administratively without seeking an order of the court.

Allied to this change is a complementary change to allow the Registrar to garnishee amounts from funds held in Australia for persons who have a child support debt in Australia who, for the time being, are not in Australia. These measures should result in an improved rate of receipt of child support for the benefit of children where these opportunities are detected.

SPEECH.PARA: Consent orders to be subject to the scrutiny of the court

An appeal may be lodged with a court concerning the outcome of an assessment and, after passage of this Bill, against a determination on an administrative assessment made by the Registrar. The present legislation provides that the court must state reasons for making an order which are then required to be entered in the records of the court. This does not apply to orders made by consent and it is therefore possible that pensioners can arrange to depart from an assessment without the new arrangements being subject to the scrutiny of the court. This could undermine the thrust of the legislation in this area. A determination, if any, made by the Registrar will also have to be considered in this way for pensioner custodians.

PARA.TAB: The Bill will therefore amend the law to require consent departure orders entered into by pensioners to be subject to the scrutiny of the court as is the case when the court has itself been asked to make an order. Similar amendments are made to other parts of the law to complement this change.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Payments made outside the agency arrangements

PARA.TAB: Provisions exist to allow the Registrar to take into account payments directly between the parties against the liability to pay the Registrar. This is a popular provision and is much used by clients of the agency, even though it is the cause of problems from time to time. It is a provision which allows, in special circumstances, the payer to support the children directly as the need arises. The provision is limited in scope and this Bill will open up the range of payments that can be brought to account by the Registrar. In particular, payments to third parties from which the custodian and the children receive a benefit will, after the agreement of the parties and if the Registrar is satisfied, become allowable as credits against the liability to the Registrar.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Enforcement of child support debts when payer is not present in Australia

PARA.TAB: Child support debts registered with the Agency are debts due to the Commonwealth and this fact has caused difficulty with enforcement in some European countries. They have not been prepared to enforce debts in these circumstances. A minor machinery-type change is made to separate the concepts of who is due to be paid child support and who may receive; that is, collect the amounts that are paid in these cases. The change ensures in law the money is due to the payee, but it is to paid through the Commonwealth acting as agent for the payee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Setting aside transactions to defeat capacity to pay child support

PARA.TAB: A provision exists in the Family Law Act 1975 to enable a court to set aside transactions, whether already made or proposed to be made, the effect of which is to defeat an order of the court in a maintenance matter.

This Bill inserts a similar provision in the child support legislation to ensure that the Agency can, in any proceedings under the child support legislation before the court or, by separate application to the court, have the court set aside such transactions, the effect of which has been or will be to defeat the payer's capacity to pay child support at all or the amount due under any liability that has been established.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Elections to end a child support liability

PARA.TAB: The Bill also proposes to remove the ability of pensioners to elect to end the liability of the non-custodial parent who is required to pay child support. Because assessment of child support is now mostly an administrative process there is a need to have an administrative method of ending a liability. An example arises where a couple reconciles and it takes no more than an election under the appropriate section in a letter to the Registrar to end the liability. However, pensioners may be unduly influenced by the non-custodian to use this election to simply end their legal liability, or of their own volition pensioners might want to end the liability of the non-custodian so as to maximise their pension entitlement.

SPEECH.PARA: The ability to elect to end the liability is to be withdrawn for a pensioner under this section, but in the event that a liability should be properly ended and the custodian is a pensioner, there are separate provisions called terminating events under which the law operates automatically to end the liability in all of the likely circumstances.

PARA.TAB: This Bill will eliminate the need for the Agency to have to offset liabilities that arise, one against the other, when there is both an assessment and an order of the court or an agreement for payment of maintenance in force for the same child for the same period. The offsetting process is now believed to be unnecessary and the new provision to be inserted in its place will have the effect of terminating liabilities under any order or agreement if an assessment has been issued for the same child and for the same period.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Children subject to a child welfare law

PARA.TAB: Finally, the Bill extends eligibility for administrative assessment of child support to parents and relatives of children who are the subject of a child welfare law providing those children are in the care, custody or guardianship of the parent or relative. This amendment will take effect on a State by State basis as each State amends their referral of powers legislation; that is, Commonwealth Powers (Family Law—Children) Acts.
I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peacock) adjourned.
Bill presented by Mr Martin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to authorise a contribution of $A350m towards the Fifth Replenishment of the Asian Development Fund.

PARA.TAB: Contributions to the ADF are one of the largest single items in Australia's official development cooperation program. As such the size of payments can have a significant impact on other components in the program. A $350m contribution represents an appropriate balance that will enable Australia to continue playing a significant role in the Asian Development Bank while allowing financial flexibility in the rest of the development cooperation program.
The ADF is the concessional lending arm of the Asian Development Bank. The Bank provides roughly one-third of its loans on concessional terms.

The Asian Development Bank is a major international development agency. It is owned by the governments of 36 countries from the Asia Pacific region and 16 countries from Europe and North America. The Bank provides financial support for development activities in its medium and low income developing member countries in the Asia Pacific region. Access to the ADF is confined to the poorest developing member countries.

In 26 years of operations, the ADB has become a major catalyst in promoting the development of the most populous and fast-growing region in the world today. The ADB's operations cover almost the entire spectrum of economic development, with particular emphasis on agriculture, energy, capital market development, transport and communications and social infrastructure.

The ADF was established in 1974 and Australia has participated in the previous four replenishments of the ADF. Participation in the ADF has been an efficient means of achieving aid delivery to the poorest countries of the Asia Pacific region. ADB activities also complement our bilateral aid to Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific.
Traditionally, the terms on which ADF loans are made are very favourable:

SPEECH.PARA: Loans are repaid over a period of up to 40 years
repayment begins only after a period of 10 years
borrowing countries pay a service charge of one per cent on their loans.

In general, only countries below a per capita gross national product of $US860, in 1990 dollars, may be considered as eligible for ADF resources. ADF borrowers are thus among the poorest countries in the world. They face serious constraints in building their economies and alleviating poverty.

PARA.TAB: Australia is currently the second largest regional donor to the ADF, after Japan, and the fourth largest overall. Since the inception of the ADF, Australia has pledged an average 6.1 per cent of total funds. As a major shareholder of the Bank and contributor to the ADF, Australia plays a significant role in formulating the Bank's policies.

During the replenishment negotiations, the donors to the ADF set policy guidelines for the Bank on the use of ADF-6 funds. These policies include focusing on poverty alleviation, the role of women in development, cooperation with non-government organisations and the environment. Development of the private sector is also a major policy aim of the Bank and the ADF.

We have come to regard the achievement of economic growth without corresponding poverty alleviation as unbalanced. In the ADB, poverty issues are now systematically considered when designing development strategies for member countries. An increasing number of projects and programs is aimed at meeting specific poverty alleviation goals. An example of a successful ADF poverty alleviation project is provided by the `NGO-Microcredit Project' in the Philippines. In the initial phase a loan of $US8m was made available to the rural poor by using NGOs as intermediaries. The NGOs lend the money for small scale projects that will increase farmers' incomes and enable others to become self employed.

One of the major objectives of the ADB's policy on the role of women in development is to fund projects which enhance women's status in society and improve their quality of life by providing education, employment, training and income generating opportunities. For example, the ADF `Rural Women Employment Creation Project' in Bangladesh involves collaboration with local NGOs to mobilise women in rural areas and facilitate their access to credit.

During the 1980s, the ADB became increasingly concerned about the impact of development on ecological balance. A framework has now been established for incorporating environmental concerns into the overall objectives and strategies of loans for socioeconomic development in the Bank's developing member countries.

Australia's representatives on the boards of the multilateral development banks are required to examine environmental issues. The Bank is responding to our concerns and other donors on this issue. For projects that have a significant impact on the environment, the ADB releases environmental impact assessment statements at least four months before the project goes before the executive board for consideration. This enables concerned groups to examine the proposals in detail and raise any concerns.

Contributions to the ADF are a significant conduit for achieving the objectives of Australia's development cooperation program. About 60 per cent of ADF funds has been committed to projects in Bangladesh and Pakistan, where the average per capita income in 1989 was $US180 and $US360 respectively. Australia's bilateral aid programs in these countries are relatively small in terms of their total development needs. Thus, channelling funds through the ADF is a significant means of achieving the humanitarian objective of providing assistance to the poorest countries.

Australia, along with most other donors, argued for access for China and India to ADF resources during the fifth replenishment of the ADF. Unfortunately, a consensus amongst donors could not be reached on access by China and India. The ADF-6 negotiations concluded, to our regret, on the basis of no access by China and India, but our policy stance is unchanged.

Indonesia and the Philippines were granted renewed access to ADF resources during the previous replenishment period. These funds were made available on a temporary basis to assist in their major economic restructuring efforts. These countries' economic shocks are not as yet fully overcome, and in each there are significantly large numbers of very poor people. Australia and several other donors successfully argued for continued support for them over the ADF-6 period. Asian Development Fund activities complement our considerable bilateral programs in Indonesia and the Philippines.

In introducing this piece of legislation, the Government takes this opportunity to express the hope that the international community will see the importance of working together to overcome the very significant developmental challenges confronting Vietnam and Cambodia.

Australia, in the negotiations, argued strongly for a resumption of ADF lending to eligible countries in Indo-China, including Vietnam and Cambodia. Donors have agreed that these countries should have access to ADF funds as soon as conditions become appropriate for the Bank to resume lending to these countries.

Australia has been successful in getting the ADB to provide more assistance to the small Pacific Island developing member countries as well as to Papua New Guinea. The ADB is now a major participant in policy dialogue in South Pacific countries in cooperation with the World Bank. Australia has played a major role in encouraging the ADB to strengthen the bank's resources in its South Pacific regional office in Vanuatu. As a consequence, the ADB will be better placed to undertake detailed country economic assessments for its seven Pacific island member states.

In Papua New Guinea, the ADB is taking a lead agency role in the agricultural, ports, roads and health sectors and the bank is implementing a number of major projects in these sectors. ADB involvement has broadened the base of assistance available to Papua New Guinea, at a time when there has been a reduction in budgetary support under the Australian bilateral development cooperation program. The ADB is the only major multilateral development bank providing concessional credit to Papua New Guinea for new loans. Overall, ADB lending to Papua New Guinea is expected to be in the region of $US100m annually.

The ADB provides a significant source of procurement for Australian business. In 1990, the total value of procurement by Australian businesses from ADB projects was at least $US77.6m; $US21.9m of this total was from the ADF. I am keen to maximise Australian business opportunities with the bank. At present an interdepartmental task force is examining the issue and will be reporting to me soon on what action can be taken to improve on this performance. As a result, I hope that we will be able to see a significant increase in procurement from Australia for ADB projects.

The ADB is seeking to improve the quality of its projects. Emphasis is placed on post evaluation work to improve the quality and sustainability of projects. According to the ADB's latest assessment of the success of its ADF projects, on average, 52 per cent were assessed to be generally successful and 43 per cent were assessed to be partially successful. While these figures are somewhat skewed because they are based on sampling mainly poor projects, bank staff argue that valuable lessons have been learned. The bank is incorporating these lessons of experience in current operations. We will continue to monitor ADB performance in this area very carefully. In my opinion, it is highly desirable that evaluation of projects should be as open and independent as possible.

Australia's Executive Director on the board of the ADB has an important role in encouraging the adoption of better management procedures to improve the administration of the bank. Australia, with strong support from other members, was instrumental in getting the ADB to establish an external tribunal to handle staff grievances. In other administrative changes, the ADB has adopted much more transparent processes in staff selection and promotion procedures. It has also improved its program operations through the preparation of a medium term strategic plan.

Another key achievement—which Australia has supported—has been to reduce the share of the ADF replenishment that could be allocated to program as opposed to project loans. Program or sector loans are relatively new and there is insufficient evidence at present to assess their long-term success rate. Australia argued that there should be a cap specifically for ADF program loans. A 22.5 per cent limit has now been agreed.

Against this background of increasingly satisfactory performance of the ADB in Asian Pacific development, we have to consider our capacity to contribute in future. We are conscious of financial pressures on the development cooperation budget in general, and in particular on the bilateral programs.

Under the last replenishment—ADF-5—Australia contributed 7.98 per cent of the total replenishment value. To maintain a 7.98 per cent share of the replenishment would have required a contribution of $431m.

In the course of the negotiations, several other donors appealed to Australia to maintain its ADF-5 share. We explained to them that the reduction from our last share was necessitated by our difficult economic and budgetary situation, and our wish to maintain flexibility in the aid budget. While a share of 6.5 per cent represents a significant drop in Australia's share from the last replenishment, it is still higher than the 6.1 per cent average of Australia's previous contributions to the ADF, and we remain the second largest regional donor in the fund, after Japan.

Unlike other commitments under the development cooperation program, payments to the concessional arms of the multilateral development banks are made over a period as long as 10 years. We now face a situation where, to fulfil past commitments, the share of the development cooperation program allocated to the multilateral development banks could rise to over 18 per cent in 1994-95. This compares with a share of 8 per cent in the mid-1980s.

The move to limit the growth of the share of ADF in the overall development cooperation budget reflects the need to maintain flexibility in the program, given budgetary constraints on the overall development cooperation budget.

While this Bill is concerned with contributions to the ADF, I have already indicated to the World Bank that our contributions to their concessional lending fund, the International Development Association will be similarly constrained. With a similar approach to reducing Australia's share in IDA, the $350m contribution to ADF-6 could eventually stabilise the multilateral development banks' share of the aid budget at around 12 to 14 per cent.

I would like to conclude by outlining briefly the payment arrangements for ADF-6. In accordance with previous practice, payment will be made in the form of non-negotiable, non-interest bearing promissory notes. The promissory notes will contribute to the ADF-6 lending authority for the period 1992-95. It is expected that the promissory notes will be encashed over a period of eight to 10 years beginning in 1992-93. These funds will be included in the annual development cooperation budgets.

Estimates of drawdowns for ADF-6 are $1.8m per year over the period 1992-93 to 1995-96, $9.6m in 1996-97 and approximately $83m per year in the following four years. These estimates of drawdowns are subject to change, as they are dependent upon exchange rates and the actual rate of disbursements by the fund.

In summary, the Asian Development Bank and its Asian Development Fund have an important role to play in continuing to foster economic and social development in the region of immediate interest to Australia. Our contribution to the fifth replenishment will confirm our support for the poorest developing countries in our region by providing highly concessional assistance.
I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum.

Debate resumed from 28 November 1991, on motion by Mr Griffiths:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to resume the debate on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991 by moving the following amendment:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "the Bill be withdrawn and introduced in an amended form so that it offers genuine resource security to forest development projects that encourage investment, no matter how small, in enterprises that add value to Australian timber by:
(1)providing legislative backing to State or regional forest strategies drawn up according to Commonwealth-approved procedures;

PARA.TAB: (2)providing project-specific legislative backing for agreements between a State and proponents of large scale projects such as pulp mills which satisfy Commonwealth environmental and other requirements; and
(3)minimising duplication of Commonwealth and State administration".

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition parties, after very detailed consideration of the legislation and consultation with all aspects of the industry, believe that the legislation we have before us will not provide genuine resource security and therefore in its present form cannot be supported. Hence the amendment and the appeal once again to the Government to take note of what we are saying, to amend the Bill to take into account those particular concerns that we have.

PARA.TAB: To make it very clear to all the participants in this debate, both in parliament and out of parliament, that we have adopted a consistent policy all the way through on this issue, I am going to read a number of statements because I want to make very clear to those who are following this debate our position and the statements of others in relation to this debate. A statement made on 20 December when the Bill was introduced into the Parliament reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition asks Keating to review resource security legislation.
The Federal Coalition had decided to oppose the Forest Conservation Development Bill that was due to be debated last night in the House of Representatives.

The Coalition is seriously concerned that the Bill, as it is currently framed, will not offer genuine resource security to the industry. The Government has repeatedly rejected approaches from industry to amend the Bill on the matters of concern to the Coalition.
Now that the Bill has been deferred, it is to be hoped the Keating Government will take account of the concerns of industry and the Coalition and be prepared to draft new legislation.
The Coalition will judge any new Bill on its merits.

Over the summer recess the Coalition will continue to work with the industry and the Government in an endeavour to produce a Bill which will facilitate investment in the forest industries, including timber mills, and the construction of world-class pulp mill facilities.

To further reinforce the point of consistency, I want to read from a joint statement made by my colleague the shadow Minister for the environment, the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), and me. I want to highlight the point that, unlike the Government, we have like views on the question of balance of development and sensible environmental protection. This also follows through into a united view within the shadow Ministry, which of course is in considerable contrast to the Government and the particular Ministers involved on its side of the House, namely, the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly). The statement reads as follows:
Opposition suggest alternatives on resource security . . .
This is dated 5 November, so no-one can say that there has not been plenty of notice about our position on this issue. To continue:
The government should re-examine its whole approach to the resource security issue contained in the Forest Conservation and Development Bill.
It is an approach which is both fundamentally flawed and which does not satisfy either the forest products industry or conservationists.

The basic flaw is that both the Commonwealth and State are required to assess environmental, cultural, heritage, social and economic issues that might arise from a given wood processing project. This involves the Commonwealth in detailed planning in areas where it has no special expertise and creates undesirable and time consuming duplication of approval processes.

In addition, provisions in the draft legislation released last month allow a range of exceptions which could disturb the security that is supposed to be provided by the Bill. Those provisions effectively provide a charter for virtually unlimited intervention by the Commonwealth at any stage in the life of a project.

There would, of course, be no need for such a legislative approach if the Hawke government had not destroyed public trust in its decision-making process. It is this lack of faith in the Government that has produced a demand for a legally-enforceable guarantee of resource security to attract investment.
Given that no amount of tinkering with the draft Bill is likely to produce an acceptable outcome, the Opposition urges the government to consider alternative approaches.

For very large projects like pulp mills, Commonwealth, environmental and other requirements should be specified at the outset of detailed negotiations between the State concerned and the proponents. Provided those standards are met, the Commonwealth should be prepared to legislate to endorse the State/proponent agreement. This would provide greater certainty that the massive investment required will not be put in jeopardy by the politically opportunistic intervention that has become so much a trademark of this Government.

To cover the multiplicity of small projects such as timber mills, which are not helped at all by the present draft legislation, the Commonwealth should be able to give legislative backing to State or regional forest strategies that are drawn up according to Commonwealth-approved procedures.

The forest industries have themselves acknowledged the need for detailed planning and assessment to meet proper environmental requirements. It ought to be within the whit of even this government to agree on processes which can be undertaken by State authorities to meet Commonwealth standards without the need for duplicate administration.
Where there are Commonwealth decisions, such as under the provisions of the Australian Heritage Commission Act, cooperative action could remove the conflicts of the past.

For example, the five-stage proposal put to the Prime Minister 11 months ago by the National Association of Forest Industries envisaged involvement of the Australian Heritage Commission (AHC) to advise the government on conservation values in deciding which parts of a forest area should be reserved and which parts could be designated for multiple use. The current cooperation between the Australian Heritage Commission and State authorities in Western Australia with respect to the South West forests is an encouraging example of what could be achieved elsewhere.
The present Bill is an attempt to please everyone which has succeeded in pleasing no one.

We will reserve final judgment until we see the final form of the legislation. But the government should stop and think again about its approach to an issue which is of vital importance in terms of both the environment and employment creating industry expansion in regional Australia.

The point I want to make again is that our position has been quite consistent and on the record for quite some time. We offered to work with the Government in that period since 20 December. We have had further detailed discussions with industry and we considered the situation again in the shadow Ministry on Monday and in the joint party meetings on Tuesday of this week and determined that nothing had changed, that the Government had not proposed any amendments or even really had any detailed discussions with us. I will detail later the degree of those discussions that did occur.

PARA.TAB: In fact, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his statement last night confirmed really the rightness of our approach rather than the current Government legislation. Under `Forest Resources', the Prime Minister's statement of last night reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government remains committed to facilitating major investment in the forest industry by providing security for industry while at the same time ensuring that environmental standards are not compromised.

In a bid to provide greater certainty over resource availability, the Australian Heritage Commission (AHC), working in close association with relevant State Government bodies, has developed a regional approach to identify significant forests for the Register of the national estate. The first of three regional surveys was undertaken in the Southern Forest Region of WA. This culminated in the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) which provides an agreed basis for the conservation and management of the region's forests.

The provision of security of access to resources will be greatly assisted by such thorough assessments being carried out prior to considering development proposals either for a region or a major project.

. accordingly, the Commonwealth—in co-operation with the States—commits itself to an accelerated and expanded program of joint regional assessments of national estate forest values based on the WA model.

That is basically a rejection of the legislation that the Government itself has put before this Parliament, saying that the confirmation of an agreed regional plan between the State Government and the industry of that State is the preferred way to go. That is what we have consistently said. That is why we once again have confirmed our position as stated in the amendment.

PARA.TAB: We really do have a tragic situation regarding the forest industry in Australia. It is tragic that we need to be considering any sort of legislation at all. But if one looks at the situation, one sees that there is no development taking place and there is no investment. Potential investment of up to $8m has been claimed, but none of it is occurring. The sawmill industry sector of this great regional industry is actually winding back, or being forced to wind back, whether it is in Victoria, Queensland or particularly now in New South Wales with the threats of standing down thousands of sawmill workers because of the uncertainty of a resource for those people in that industry.

We have an import imbalance of $2 billion. That is, we are importing $2 billion worth of forest products more than we are exporting or, for that matter, are not providing for our own market. Some of those imports are coming from countries which have far lower standards of environmental safeguards than Australia has for its forests.

In Victoria we also have forest material that is not fully utilised. Once the sawlogs are taken from the sections of the forest that are so designated, all of the waste material is basically left to rot on the forest floor. It is not allowed to be used for chips. I know there have been some slight amendments by using the oddly termed e-logs to allow a little more to be used, but there is 1 1/2 million tonnes of material not being utilised, which by itself is basically enough for a pulp mill. Leaving that material there certainly does not help the regeneration of the forest in that area. Because of this stupid attitude, somehow or other woodchips are considered bad. Until enough material builds up to have a pulp mill, obviously it is sensible for woodchips to be not only made but exported. Obviously it is sensible, once the resources can be put together for a mill, to have a mill turn that material into pulp, paper, et cetera, of far greater value.

In addition, there is a great opportunity in this country to develop a mix of native forest and plantation or private forestry for pulp mills. We have the ability, with our eucalypts and some good technology, to produce timber for pulp purposes as fast as or faster than anywhere else in the world. In fact, some of our own technology and varieties of eucalypts are being utilised far more extensively in other countries for pulp and paper manufacture than is happening in Australia because we have no genuine security to induce people to go out and invest.

Last year the honourable member for Pearce and I were in Kalimantan. Two out of three plantation varieties of trees growing there as part of a huge project in that area of Indonesia to have a number of pulp mills by the turn of the century are from Australia. Of course, Brazil has a huge area of eucalypts. We are now in the farcical situation in which some imports are coming in from Brazil made from Australian eucalypts grown in Brazil.

If we look beyond that to the timber mill section of the industry, we see that there is a desire to invest in value adding, that is, instead of just turning out green framework timber, we would be turning out quality flooring or joinery and so forth. But before that investment takes place it needs the guarantee that the resource will continue to be available.
