It is tragic that in this great industry, with the potential for regional employment and for Australia's balance of payments, nothing is happening and it is going the wrong way at the present time.I can understand the frustration of the industry and why it will not invest until it has something firm in legislation, something that is far firmer than what the industry has learned to expect, to its bitterness and regret, under Federal and State Labor governments and, I would add, some extreme elements in the conservation movement. But forestry has been cynically used by Federal and State Labor governments for votes. They have been checking out the gallup poll to see which way the balance lies. It has been called the Richardson factor: do not have a policy that is of value to this country or is secure and consistent; have a policy that is determined by the gallup polls, one that will pick up the most votes in the short term.

I also understand that the industry no longer has any trust in the informal agreements by governments, inter-governmental agreements, et cetera, because they have been broken too many times. There is quite a record of them, and I have not got time to go into that detail today.

Today's legislation is the result of that cynical approach to a very important industry and to this continuing battle within the Federal Government between resources on the one hand and environment on the other. The result, of course, is a mess, which is usual in that sort of situation. Honourable members do not have to take my word that the industry will not achieve genuine resource security; let us hear what Senator Peter Walsh, a former senior member of the Government, had to say in his Cassandra column in the Australian Financial Review of 12 November 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: More Political Grist for the Pulp Mill.

PARA.TAB: Apart from the $100 million proposed trigger and its project instead of area focus, the timber industry must be alarmed by at least two specific provisions.
The definitions extend (endangered) "species" to "sub-species", further defined to be a "geographically separate population".

One can never be too confident about court interpretations of legislation, but common sense suggests this could be used to stop logging in any specific patch of forest with (say) 25 koalas in it, even if there were a million koalas elsewhere.

Section 16(2) overrides section 15(2)—the bit that prevents the use of federal law to close down projects which have already been approved—if "designated ministers are satisfied that after completion of the assessment process. . . it has been discovered that conducting the project would cause" a species (which includes sub-species) of flora or fauna to become threatened or more threatened.
If words mean what they say, this seems to permit closing down a project at any time by ministerial fiat. "Resource security" takes on a distinctly Orwellian flavour.

SPEECH.PARA: When one talks about not satisfying anybody, of course, one means it does not satisfy the environmental movement either, for which the Government has bent over so far to try to please.

PARA.TAB: Returning to that 20 December statement we made, I put on the record that on a number of occasions we did indicate our willingness to the Government to meet with it in mid-January and again later at the agricultural outlook conference. Finally, there was a meeting to take place between myself and the Minister for Resources on 19 February. However, on Thursday, 17 February, the Minister wanted to have a more immediate discussion, so there was a telephone hook-up between him, the honourable member for Pearce and me. I will now read his record of the discussion:

SPEECH.PARA: The upshot of the discussions is that the opposition supports the concept of a legislative level of resource security as a firm foundation for investment in major wood processing projects, however, their concerns with the current Bill are more fundamental than merely the compensation issue. In short, the Opposition believes
(i)the umbrella legislation should be amended to project specific legislation for major projects only.

(ii)the legislation should be tightened up in the sense that once the resource area for projects has been assessed and considered by Government, there should be very limited opportunity for Government to revisit the resource area in the case of unforeseen circumstances. Their view is that the provisions in the Bill are unnecessarily wide allowing the Government of the day to act in a capricious manner should it wish to do so.
(iii)the compensation provision should be removed from the Bill altogether and wood compensation provided through Commonwealth/State Agreements.

(iv)that a legislative level of resource security should be available for programs which draw resource from a common area but importantly, the level of investment does not meet the $100m eligibility criteria provisions of the Bill. Rather, their view is that the Bill should be amended to include investment programs on a regional basis such as areas recently agreed by governments and which have bipartisan support such as the South East Forests, the Tasmanian Forest and Forest Industry Strategy and the CALM/AHC Agreement in Western Australia.

On the following day there was a further discussion between the Minister's staff and staff from the Opposition, and the honourable member for Pearce and I offered also to set aside the following Monday to have further detailed discussions if that was the wish of the Government. The point I want to make is that we certainly made these offers time and time again to work with the Government to get it to reconsider its position.

PARA.TAB: The next point I want to make is that it is up to the Government to make those amendments, and that has been made very clear all the way through. The Opposition does not have the ability to do that with complex legislation drafting necessary for amendments. More importantly, unless the Government itself agrees to amendments, there is no guarantee that amendments will be passed. That point has been made time and time again.
No-one in the industry really likes this legislation. I want to quote now from the National Association of Forest Industries Ltd press release of 18 December 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: Industry Seeks Changes in Resources Bill

"The Government's Forest Conservation and Development Bill requires significant changes if it is to achieve its conservation goals, encourage investment and protect jobs, the Executive Director of the National Association of Forest Industries", Dr Robert Bain, said today.

"The legislation is due back in the House of Representatives tomorrow and we hope that it contains some substantial amendments. The $100m eligibility criterion in the original legislation would split the industry and make the sawmillers and smaller operations second class citizens.

These firms represent some 80,000 jobs spread right across much of rural and provincial Australia. There is no logical reason—environmental or economic—for not giving this group the same framework for investment and employment as the large pulp and paper companies.
"With the current devastation of the rural economy the industry cannot understand the Government's reluctance to support the backbone of so many country communities".
"In many cases the smaller firms will be able to invest faster and protect jobs more quickly, because of the long lead times for the $100m plus pulpmill projects", Dr Bain said.
"The other essential change to the legislation is the removal of the clauses which try to absolve the Government from the consequences of its actions.

"The Government must be prepared to compensate communities and firms if it decides to close them down. Ideally alternative resources should be found or developed to substitute for forest closures. Financial payments are a last resort", Dr Bain said.

"Our financial advisers, including a major international banking firm which specialises in forest industry investment, tell us that legislation which specifically rules out compensation is not satisfactory for investment security".
"The industry wants these "non compensation" clauses dropped and appropriate arrangements negotiated, when specific proposals are put forward", Dr Bain said.
"Compensation arrangements relevant for one development might be quite inappropriate in different circumstances.

"NAFI recognises that there may be special circumstances that mean that the original legislation could provide a basis for a northern Tasmanian pulpmill. However, our duty is to the industry as a whole, and tens of thousands of employees throughout Australia. Therefore, we could not support legislation which does not provide for the sawmill sector and seeks to absolve Governments from all forms of compensation.

That was a very significant release from the industry, coming the day before our shadow Ministry decision. It was a major factor in our decision and it goes somewhat to the core of the argument with regard to North Broken Hill and whether or not this legislation is bankable. Being fair to North Broken Hill, it disputes that it is bankable, but it is also a question of timber mills, and timber mills for the rest of Australia, not just Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: On that aspect of whether it is only this legislation that will determine whether or not there is such a pulp mill built by North Broken Hill in northern Tasmania, I now quote from a letter dated 25 February from Bill Paisley of North Broken Hill to the Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Prime Minister,
I would like to confirm with you this Company's position in relation to Resource Security Legislation and the development of an internationally competitive export pulpmill in northern Tasmania.

As you are aware, in recent times we have had discussions with members of your staff and with the Honourable Alan Griffiths in relation to these matters, and the following is a summary of the position that we have put to them:
1.It has always been the contention of North that Resource Security Legislation at a Federal level is a pre-requisite for the assessments needed that would lead to the development of a mill.

2.In addition to Resource Security Legislation, we have also stated that we believe that an Environmental Impact Statement is not required on the Tasmanian Forests as this work has been comprehensively undertaken over recent years. Following this point we have also stated that all work needed to be completed by the Commonwealth in relation to accrediting studies already undertaken in Tasmania, should be finalised as a matter or urgency.
3.For the project to be considered viable it will be necessary that the mill can be depreciated at a rate of 20% per annum.

Subject to the above points being satisfactorily completed, and subject to our ability to attract a partner to the project, then North, together with its partner, will be prepared to enter the assessment phase of the project.

In relation to the proposed Resource Security Legislation currently before the House, we would urge that this Legislation progress as rapidly as possible as it is our opinion that this will provide an immediate signal to potential partners of the willingness of the Federal Government to create the necessary environment to allow the development of this nationally important project.

I quote that last part also to make the point that I am quoting him fairly. The point I want to make is that even if this legislation is passed, that does not mean that North Broken Hill would build a pulp mill in northern Tasmania, because it would still require this environmental assessment, which the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) claims could take up to two years, and a 20 per cent return on its investment as well as obtaining a partner.

PARA.TAB: When the Prime Minister tried to get North Broken Hill to say that it would build the pulp mill so he could include it in his statement of last night, North Broken Hill quite correctly said—and this has been freely quoted in the papers—that it could not give that guarantee because it would not know what the result of that environmental assessment was, and it would not undertake any feasibility studies at this time even though the Prime Minister promised to repay the cost of those feasibility studies if the project did not go ahead. That further makes the point that this legislation does not provide resource security, because it does not stop other elements of the Federal Government bogging things down and making them impossible to proceed.
Finally, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), in a reply to Mr Paisley, also of 25 February, made the following points:

SPEECH.PARA: I note your press statement of last night calling on the Opposition to support the Forest Conservation and Development Bill currently before the Parliament, even though you have admitted to me that there are a number of quite fundamental problems as drafted.

The Opposition has consistently stated that the Bill before the Parliament is flawed in that it does not offer genuine resource security and is thus of no value whatsoever to the majority of the forestry industry.

However, we remain strongly in support of a northern Tasmanian pulp mill and of resource security. We have said that we will support project-specific resource security legislation to facilitate the mill or legislation to endorse regional forest plans prepared to Commonwealth-approved standards.

In our previous discussion, I made the point that the Opposition is not in a position to force amendment of the current legislation to overcome industry and the Opposition's concerns since the Government controls the House and we would not get the Australia Democrats' support in the Senate. I therefore urged you to seek to persuade the Government to amend the legislation so that it offers real protection of the industry's access to forestry resources. I would be interested to hear what you have done and achieved in this respect.

He goes on to other points which had been discussed with the industry from time to time. Once again, that would not provide that security. I have another example here of a potential investor from Singapore.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. M.J.R. MacKellar)—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want first to expose what I feel is evasion and perhaps duplicity by members of the Opposition on the Forest Conservation and Development Bill. They seemed to leave a little chink, a little opening, for themselves to support this legislation when it comes back from the Senate. Secondly, I want to expose an error in a RAC research paper. I want to show that that RAC research paper is wrong on a number of counts. Thirdly, I want to reveal how those errors have been misused by environmental organisations in discussions with the New South Wales Opposition, and I also want to deal with the Opposition's amendment to the legislation.

PARA.TAB: If the Opposition finally opposes this legislation, that is tantamount to duplicity in the formulation of public policy which is clearly in the national interest. I believe that, if it opposes the legislation, its duplicitous behaviour will warrant condemnation by the timber industry. It is well known that the Opposition has repeatedly said that, in relation to resource projects, it would build the Wesley Vale pulp mill in Tasmania. The Opposition has said it would build at Wesley Vale, but it is opposing the very legislation that will enable that pulp mill to be built.

I agree with the Opposition: the legislation does not go far enough. But why is the Opposition doing this? Why is it prepared to wipe out any possible support through resource security just because it thinks that the legislation ought to be broader? I think it should be broader, too, but I will vote for it because it gives us a much greater chance of having the Wesley Vale mill. It also gives us a much greater chance of having another pulp mill in Australia. Only a couple of nights ago, a meeting of 900 people from the Eden, Bombala and Nimmitabel areas resolved to work for a pulp mill in the south-eastern region of New South Wales and Victoria by the year 2000.

Why is the Opposition doing this? Is it for short term political gain? I believe that if the Opposition opposes this legislation it is prepared to forsake the national interest, at least, for short term political gain. The Opposition is prepared to sacrifice at least two possible large developments in Australia for short term political gain. Let me explain why this is so. North Broken Hill, the company which would build the Wesley Vale mill, issued a press statement two days ago urging the Opposition to support the passage of this legislation through the Parliament. The press release stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this would be a significant step forward in the advancement of this nationally important project.

That is, it would be a step forward to build the Wesley Vale mill. North Broken Hill goes on to say that the industry is totally unified and that, if there is to be a pulp mill in Tasmania, both the Government and the Opposition must support the current legislation. So there we have it.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has read out correspondence from North Broken Hill to the Government. I have to reiterate the point—I will not quote again from all the material that he has quoted from—that North Broken Hill has said that both the Government and the Opposition must support the current legislation. Will the Opposition block the legislation so necessary for the Wesley Vale pulp mill to be built for short term political gain, to try to be different from the Government? In so doing, is the Opposition prepared to forsake the national interest?

I believe that the Opposition is out of step with the industry and with the Australian community. The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia quoted the National Association of Forest Industries Ltd. It is great to see the Opposition taking an interest in the timber industry. I have been in this Parliament for nine years. In that nine years the Opposition has made very little in the way of constructive suggestions about the timber industry and its future, but it has been dragged into this debate because we have forestry legislation before us. That is about the only time the Opposition is prepared to raise important forestry issues. In March last year, the National Association of Forest Industries said, `the role of the Federal Opposition in this debate has been a bit ambivalent'—and it certainly was. NAFI went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has been very quick to castigate the Government for the things it has done to the industry in the past but has been slow in putting their own cards on the table.

NAFI also said that it had met with the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and had numerous discussions with Opposition parliamentarians, and that it was considered most unlikely that the Opposition would oppose the legislation when it was put forward by the Government in this House. I do not know who has it wrong. It is probably the Opposition, because it is now no longer prepared to support the legislation as it is. I agree with some of the Opposition's ideas, but I will certainly support the legislation in the end.

PARA.TAB: But there is more. In December last year North Broken Hill, the company intending to build the Wesley Vale mill, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to express our appreciation at the considerable effort of the Government in achieving significant progress towards ensuring the future of this vitally important industry.

Again, in opposing this legislation the Opposition is prepared to forsake the national interest. There is more yet. On 23 December last year Australian Paper Manufacturers, the company intending to invest in an $850m expansion of its Maryvale plant, said:

We accept the involvement of the Federal Government in the concept of resource security and will work with the Victorian and Federal Governments and the National Association of Forest Industries to reach appropriate guarantees through legislation.

If the Federal Opposition opposes this legislation—and I am not sure of that yet—it is prepared to forsake the national interest. The honourable member for Murray has quoted from another letter, dated 25 February from North Broken Hill to the Government. I want to repeat just one paragraph—the honourable member was good enough to quote the whole letter—to emphasise the point he made at the end of reading that letter. It states:

In relation to the proposed resource security legislation currently before the House, we would urge that this legislation progress as rapidly as possible as it is our opinion that this will provide an immediate signal to potential partners of the willingness of the Federal Government to create the necessary environment to allow development of this nationally important project.
Yet we have the Leader of the Opposition instructing his troops to oppose this legislation. In doing so, he now appears to be opposing the Wesley Vale pulp mill—the pulp mill he said he would build.

PARA.TAB: Why is a conservative opposition, a political party that acts as a mouthpiece for industry in very many ways, opposing investment and employment generating legislation? Is it because it just wants to look different from Labor? It is looking for product differentiation at the expense of the national interest, at the expense of a world-scale Wesley Vale pulp mill. I wonder how the new Tasmanian Premier, Ray Groom, feels about having his main election pledge possibly blown out of the water by the Leader of the Opposition. He committed himself to Wesley Vale. Without this legislation there is much less likelihood of a Wesley Vale pulp mill coming about.

The Opposition has had trouble coming to an understanding of the timber industry; it has had trouble in coming to an understanding of the Tasmanian forests; and it has had trouble coming to an understanding of the south-eastern forests. That is a problem because there is such strong rural representation on this side of the House. As has been said, the real debate has been on this side of the House. If the Opposition is not heavily involved throughout, then we have to have the debates in our policy committees. There has been a debate about the forestry industry on this side of the House and that is because we have very strong rural representation. Some of my colleagues who will speak after me will give evidence of that.

The Federal Opposition is a bit like the Labor Opposition in New South Wales in that it does not have people who know the industry. When the New South Wales Labor Party lost people such as John Akister and Jack Hallam and when it hardly had a country member—it had no country members for a time—it was obvious that it would be out of touch with the timber industry. Now we find that the New South Wales Opposition has been lobbied heavily by environmental groups which have been using as their basis research paper No. 5 of the Resource Assessment Commission.

Two people, Hamilton and Streeting, wrote that research paper. I realise that it is a research paper prepared for, not by, the RAC. This paper has been used to convince people, including the New South Wales Opposition, that the placement of National Estate areas into a national park would mean a direct loss of only 61 jobs: 50 in the sawmill industry and 11 from the chip-mill industry. It said that there would be a direct loss in sawmill jobs of 40 people. Page 69 of the research paper states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the model of resource availability suggests that the cessation of logging in the National Estate would reduce the annual availability to industry of sawlogs by 16 000 cubic metres and pulpwood by 29 000 tonnes to the year 2012.
It then quotes an economic consultant, Diana M.H. Gibbs. Quoting her, it states:
. . . around 40 sawmill jobs would be lost directly if logging were discontinued in National Estate forests.
In summary, it states:

. . . the estimated total direct job loss in the Eden area forest industry is 61 jobs, comprising 50 jobs linked directly with the sawmilling industry and 11 jobs linked with Harris-Daishowa's operation.

That, of course, is the woodchip operation. That paper, predicting a loss of a total of 61 jobs, used that report by consultant Diana Gibbs to justify its figures. I have obtained some information from Diana Gibbs which directly criticises and contradicts the quotations from her report which were used by the RAC researchers. She said:
. . . not only is this figure incorrect, but nowhere in the report—
that is, her report of 1990—
is a single estimate for sawmill job losses alone presented.
The 1990 Gibbs report contains the following data relevant to those sought by the authors of the RAC paper:

PARA.TAB: Total mill workforce (1990)239
Total industry employment599
Total regional job loss431

SPEECH.PARA: This last data item represented all jobs lost in the region, i.e. including direct and indirect job losses, resulting from loss of National Estate areas.

In addition, a figure was presented in the report . . . which illustrated the jobs existing in each sector (sawmills, chipmill, forest contractors, Forestry Commission) under different alternatives—i.e., current, after loss of listed National Estate areas, and after loss of all nominated National Estate areas. No actual data were listed to accompany this figure.
She continues:

Neither of the authors of this paper contacted me in the course of preparing their analysis, so I do not know the basis on which they concluded that my report "estimates that around 40 sawmill jobs would be lost directly if logging were discontinued in National Estate forests".
Had the authors contacted me, I could have provided them with the raw data on which this Figure 10 was based, viz.

PARA.TAB: sawmill job losses60
chipmill job losses35
others (contractors and FC)108
Total job losses in Eden203

SPEECH.PARA: That is vastly different from the total of 61 jobs predicted in the report on the basis of Diana Gibbs's report. She estimates an output loss of $21m a year.

PARA.TAB: The RAC report also lists another report, dating back to 1986, as a source of its estimate of chip-mill job loss; but it makes its assessment of contractor and Forestry Commission job losses without providing any basis for that assessment. That would lead one to question the validity of the references given in the RAC report.

The RAC report has been used by the South East Alliance in representations to the New South Wales Opposition. Fortunately, we have an industry and a trade union movement which are prepared to go into the New South Wales Parliament and go before the Independents—I say this for the benefit of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) who will speak later in the debate—to correct their view and that of the Opposition. I hope they get their point across, because a lot of misleading information is coming from that research paper.
The RAC research paper has made another incorrect remark and I believe this is the basis of its error. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the model suggests that 59000 tonnes of pulpwood will be generated annually under integrated harvesting operations. This is well above the 504 000 tonne long-term annual commitment to Harris-Daishowa.

I have done all the work I can to try to find out what that figure should be. It is quite obvious that only 504,000 tonnes, not 590,000 tonnes, can be confirmed if we are to have a sustainable yield industry. I believe the Forestry Commission ought to make that point to the Resource Assessment Commission. It is particularly important that it makes that point because its figure is blatantly wrong and that ought to be corrected.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that not 29,000 tonnes of pulpwood per year, as quoted by the Commission, would be lost; but, rather, four times that amount: 115,000 tonnes per year. It is also clear that Gibbs has been misquoted and that parts of her report which should have been used have not been used. It was quoted as a partial source of data, but none of the estimates provided appear to have been used.

The south-eastern forests have been done over by governments of the State of New South Wales and the Commonwealth—they have been done over by government more often than by the loggers themselves over many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they leave a bigger mess.
—It is a much bigger mess and I believe that is partially due to the complex system of government in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has come up with a number of amendments. I agree with the Opposition on the first point, particularly if it means that we will have more access for the sawmill industry. That is great, because I believe the sawmill industry ought to have more access. It is true that both the Federal and State governments have a range of legislation and requirements which impinge on the south-eastern forests and, therefore, both are involved in sawmill access. The point made by the Federal Government is that there can be intergovernmental agreements, and with New South Wales, Victoria and the Federal Government coming to agreement we can give the industry a guarantee and make the agreements legally binding.

Contrary to what the honourable member for Murray says, I believe that compensation can be incorporated into those agreements if the State government so wants. The State government can make a contract with the Federal Government that can be legally binding at common law or taken to judicial review. They are important matters to note.

I believe that the amendments and discussions that emanate between now and when the Senate considers the matter ought to involve full consultation between industry, government and unions so that, if the Bill has to come back here, we will have legislation which will protect the forests for all industries. I believe that is important. It is also important that the Opposition and the Independents in New South Wales do not undermine the implementation of Federal policy via this legislation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My own electorate of Forrest illustrates the complexities of the issues before us. It also demonstrates the importance of the timber industry for the future prosperity of the south-west of Western Australia and, indeed, Australia as a whole. Approximately 90 per cent of Western Australia's forest production is from the south-west. This industry pumps between $400m and $500m a year from the region into the economy, employs some 3,000 people directly and provides one in four of the region's manufacturing jobs. In addition, there are many farmers in my electorate who supplement their income by either full time or part time employment in the forest products industry.

PARA.TAB: Hardwood and softwood sharefarming schemes have been instrumental in many cases in helping to rehabilitate degraded water catchment areas and in keeping the financial wolves from many people's door. The timber industry provides the Government of Western Australia with $35m a year in royalties, plus various charges for power, water, rail services and taxes. The potential for expansion of the timber market, both at home and overseas, is enormous.

The region has an estimated 1.8 million hectares of hardwood forest, 1.5 million hectares of which is on public forest land. Half a million hectares are preserved for conservation. This leaves one million hectares for multiple use, including timber production. There are 52,000 hectares of publicly owned pine plantations and perhaps 12,000 hectares of private pine plantations. We also have around 12,000 hectares of short rotation eucalypt plantations, half privately and half publicly owned. I understand that there is potential for further plantation investments to the tune of $100m over the next 10 years to establish an extra 100,000 hectares of plantations.

In the south-west we already have the potential to produce more than the State-wide demand for forest products. The region can sustain, on current resources, an output of 1.8 million cubic metres of wood, but it can do far better than that. The volume of woodchip exports from Western Australia is almost equivalent to the volume of wood required to furnish our total paper consumption. It is easy to see, therefore, that our biggest imbalance is value. We export low value products and import high value products.

In recent years investment in the timber industry has stalled. Growth is at a standstill and the industry has contracted by at least 15 per cent. I am given to understand that the recession may not be totally to blame. Industry sources say that they cannot clearly separate the effect of long term resource insecurity from the general effects of the recession. The fact remains, however, that timber mills have closed and workers have been retrenched or placed on shorter working weeks, while felling and milling operations throughout the region have been cut to the bone.

What has gone wrong? Why has an industry of such immense importance been allowed to degenerate to a stage where it is begging for survival? The figures I have quoted today are ample proof that in the main the timber industry in Western Australia is being well-managed. It has used foresight in the development of its softwood and eucalypt operations, anticipating the decline in supply of old growth forest and sawlog production from native forest. As a result, the south-west has a sustainable resource that was, until the decline, undergoing careful and reasonable expansion. Our workers are amongst the best to be found, and investors were ready and able to put their money into the growth of the industry.

It is obvious that the blame for the recent downturn does not lie with the industry. We should be looking instead at the sorry behaviour of the members of this Government, which pandered to environmental lobby groups to prevent its political demise, while at the same time doing enormous damage to the nation's credibility. This is in spite of a pressing need for new investment in Australia's industries, particularly to help reverse the nation's chronic unemployment situation. Bear in mind that unemployment is already the highest it has been since the war. Over the past year the number of people receiving social security benefits in the south-west, for example, has risen by more than 1,000 and now stands at 4,083 people.

The Forest and Conservation Development Bill is the Government's way of trying to convince the community that it now recognises the need to support resource-based industries. In fact, it is a graphic illustration of how not to legislate and how not to govern. In particular, the Government's legislation is too narrow in its scope.

A resolution unanimously passed at a meeting last year organised by the Forest Protection Society in Bunbury in Western Australia recognised that this Government's draft forest conservation Bill did not remove the threat to existing industry operations, because it applied only to new investments of $100m or more. Put bluntly, my local timber industry wants this Government either to support the timber industry fairly and squarely or to get right out of the way. Offering security only to projects which reach the $100m mark is a cheap attempt to pick the big dollar winners, to the total neglect of smaller operators and the timber industry as a whole. It is quite apparent that this legislation does not even offer proper security for major resource projects. My understanding of the concept of resource security is that it maintains the viability of all operations in the industry, regardless of the size and age of its investment. The Bill before us falls well short of that mark. It is for that reason that we have proposed our amendments to this Bill.

Two of Western Australia's largest timber producers, Bunnings Forest Products and Cullity Timbers, recently announced that they were about to launch a joint timber venture in my electorate that would entail a total investment of $50m over the next 10 years. That is a considerable project by any timber industry standard, yet it falls well short of the $100m benchmark. There would be no resource security for them in that situation.

The complete ineffectiveness of the proposed legislation was amply illustrated by Western Australia's Minister for the Environment. The Minister, who attended the same meeting I have referred to, was emphatic in his belief that very few projects would reach the $100m target. In fact, he raised concerns regarding this legislation at the original State Ministers conference on the issue. Further, he expressed a pessimistic view that he did not think Western Australia would have a major project such as a pulp mill for at least 10 years. The Minister said that Western Australia's 1987 timber strategy was sufficient to protect resources in the State in future years. All Western Australia wanted was Commonwealth legislation which supported the Western Australian timber strategy. Like everybody else involved in the issue, it appears that he has been disappointed. In fact, it appears that he will be completely ignored.

The approval process under this legislation is unwieldy and unmanageable. It is expected that the whole approval process could take up to two years to complete. At a time when Australia needs a fast track approval process for new investment projects, the legislation proposed by the Government is not good enough. This problem is compounded by the fact that two tiers of government are involved in the approval process.

More importantly, the whole approval and monitoring process set out under this legislation casts serious doubts about the extent to which the Federal Government would be prevented from interfering in resource projects for purely political reasons. In other words, this legislation does not offer resource security in the true sense. For example, there is nothing to prevent the Federal Government acting in a political fashion and imposing a range of provisions during the approval process. After all, the Government's legislation provides that the designated Minister must be satisfied that the Commonwealth has completed an appropriate assessment process in regard to the cultural, environmental, heritage, social and economic aspects of each proposed resource project. This leaves plenty of scope for political intervention and unnecessary delays. Even when a project is up and running, there are five reasons why the Government can intervene and, in effect, remove or erode the resource security that has been approved earlier. It is hardly the way to safeguard long term major projects.

Certainly there is real interest at present in investing in the timber industry in Australia and, especially in the case of North Broken Hill, this new investment would be facilitated by the existence of genuine resource security. Unfortunately, the Government's Bill does nothing to foster long term confidence in the industry, and without business confidence new investments will be few and far between. Indeed, the Federal Government has come under fire in recent times because of its failure to attract new business investment. New capital expenditure, for example, plummeted by a massive 7 per cent in the last financial year. The first quarter of 1991-92 saw a further 12.2 percentage point decline compared with the previous 12 months.

Lack of business confidence, a heavy-handed tax system, high interest rates and depressed markets have all given our business sector cold feet. Nowhere is this lack of confidence more evident than in the resources sector. Coronation Hill, Wesley Vale and Marandoo have all become synonymous with the State and Federal governments' failure to come to terms with the importance of our resources sector and the damage that such poor decision making can have on the nation's reputation.

Recently, a colleague handed me a copy of an article in a Singaporean newspaper which carried a detailed analysis of Australia's economic problems. Its published comments were a severe warning to would-be investors because of the lack of security given to our resources sector. The article stated:

The mining sector—which is currently the only thing standing in Australia between recession and economic catastrophe—was obstructed at every turn by ideologically driven `conservationists', Aboriginal lobby groups which wielded power far in excess of the numbers they represented, and mindless urban-based anti-developmentalists.

The supreme irony was that anti-mining and anti-logging policies were often driven by people in the least productive areas of the economy. These were people who depended on the industries they so despised to sustain their jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: It went on to say:

PARA.TAB: In the middle of the recession, minority Aboriginal groups managed to persuade former Prime Minister Bob Hawke to block a major mining project at Coronation Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether we like it or not, this is how our Government's resource management policies are being reported overseas. This type of message has the potential to drive investors further from our doors.

PARA.TAB: It is all very well to talk about the need for more favourable depreciation allowances and sustained lower interest rates to attract large-scale investors. But where is the incentive to spend well in excess of $1 billion on a state-of-the-art pulp mill if there is no certainty that raw materials of the requisite quality and quantity will be available in years to come?

As I explained earlier, this legislation will not promote anything more than superficial confidence in our resources sector. Indeed, it could lead to far greater uncertainty. For example, if the Government's legislation were passed through the Parliament, the forestry industry would be entitled to believe that it had cast-iron guarantees of resource security for major investment projects. Imagine the shock waves that would be caused if, despite this so-called resource security legislation being in place, a major investment proposal were rejected in accordance with one of the loopholes I mentioned earlier. Without doubt, the damage to our reputation would be immense and would crucify any perception that Australia was a reliable manager of economic resources.

Alternatively, consider the potential for disruption in our forestry industry if a major new $100m-plus project was granted resource security at the expense of existing operators in the industry. With no security under this legislation for those already in the industry, it is not too far-fetched to imagine an opportunist government sacrificing the livelihoods of existing mill operators to ensure an adequate supply of timber resources to a new $100m plus venture.

This is of particular concern in my electorate of Forrest, as there have been suggestions that a new pulp mill there may be viable. While I would welcome such a large-scale investment, I would not want to see it take place in a way that would unduly disrupt the existing timber operation. Again, this points to the need for total regional resource security; that is, protecting everyone in the forestry industry, not just a chosen few.

The whole question of resource security needs a completely fresh approach. To start with, the $100m limit must go. The Government must consider a full range of alternatives to encourage smaller mills to value add and to diversify to assist the entire industry to get back on its feet. Again, the need for improvements in Australia's value adding industries cannot be stressed too strongly. For example, last financial year Australia exported $36.6m worth of wood manufactured products, but we imported $214.2m worth of the same products. We imported nearly six times the value of our exports in this area. We imported a staggering $1,155m worth of paper products. The value of our exports, at $187.7m, was equal to barely 16 per cent of this figure.

Even in the area of raw timber product, where most people would think we have an overwhelming trade advantage, we actually imported more than 90 per cent of the value of our exports. If the Government is serious about trying to contain the blow-out in Australia's balance of payments and foreign debt, this one industry must be encouraged to value add. This requires solid legislative support from this Government.

Even the non-legislative resource security provided for in this Bill is far too loose and involves a system of agreements between the Commonwealth and the State concerned in each case. Again, it will not provide true resource security for our timber industry.

The coalition's view is much simpler. Let us get the Commonwealth out of the business of directly interfering in resources issues and leave the broad administration of timber resource management to the States. Let us give firm legislative backing to individual major resource projects, such as pulp mills, so that the companies concerned in each venture can impress their bankers and investors with the extent of resource security available to them.

But let us not forget the rest of the industry. In fact, the coalition's amendments propose to give legislative backing to endorse the State or regional forestry plans drawn up in accordance with approved Commonwealth guidelines. In this way, the whole industry would know precisely where it stands. It could plan for the future, secure in the knowledge that political interference, which has become a hallmark of the present Government, would be a thing of the past.

Only recently, Western Australia's Department of Conservation and Land Management, CALM, and the Australian Heritage Commission put forward proposals for a comprehensive forestry management plan. While I have concerns about some aspects of the plan concerning areas to be put aside for possible National Estate listing, it must be recognised that all parties concerned now have the opportunity to voice their concerns and make their suggestions before the whole strategy is finalised.

This plan sets out to balance conservation needs with the objective of a strong forestry industry based on sustainable timber production. Already, the process used to arrive at this management strategy proposal is being touted as a model for the forestry industry throughout Australia.

The key is that it is not limited to projects of a certain value and does not identify areas of environmental significance on an ad hoc basis; instead, it is a broad plan which identifies conservation priorities regionally. The draft report detailing the whole strategy sums up the advantages of the approach in these terms:

The assessment of management of national estate values at a regional level has many advantages. Because the major values and their occurrences are all identified and described in detail, it is possible to identify the particular areas where there is direct conflict between the particular value and a proposed practice, having firstly assessed the representation of the value in the region and its protection in the reserve system.

It is then possible for CALM to concentrate on conservation of a particular value and on the mitigation of adverse effect on it. In turn, because a regional perspective is available, it is easier for CALM to manage for the conservation of values at a regional level.

SPEECH.PARA: This means that access to resources is not automatically blocked because an area has a particular feature of environmental value. Instead, those features are assessed to determine their overall value within a region.

PARA.TAB: I am of the view that the draft management strategy formulated by CALM should form the basis for genuine resource security. Certainly, this is the approach the coalition has favoured. The only way to secure the future for our existing forestry industry and to encourage investment in new timber projects is to adopt this regional approach. Furthermore, there is no earthly reason why this could not be done in conjunction with project-specific agreements.

I envisage a policy based on long term regional management plans developed by each State in accordance with Commonwealth objectives. These would be cemented into legislation and, where necessary, supplemented by project-specific legislation. In turn, these measures would enable agreements on wood supply for longer terms than has generally been the case to date. In some cases, companies have been expected to operate on the basis of agreements renewed annually, which is hardly likely to inspire long term investment.

The coalition is opposed to the Government's legislation because we do not believe it will promote resource security, and for this reason we have moved our amendment. It is widely acknowledged that, if the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was not intent on playing politics with such an important issue, he would openly admit that he was not a supporter of this legislation either.

A number of people I have consulted in the forestry industry agree that the Government legislation will not provide long term resource security. Some will be disappointed that the coalition has not supported this Bill in its present form. Politically we could have taken the easy path and supported the Government's Bill, but the Government's legislation is bad legislation and, far from achieving resource security, it could have the opposite effect, particularly for those already operating in the industry.

In my own electorate, which always must be of priority, I have grave concerns about this legislation. Indeed, it is quite possible that the existing timber operators could be disadvantaged if the needs of major projects were put ahead of their own. For these reasons I call on the Government to support the amendment we have moved. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Forest Conservation and Development Bill and oppose the amendment. I really have to ask the Opposition: does it want the Wesley Vale pulp mill to go ahead? Does the Opposition really want it? In the past it has argued that it should go ahead, but here today honourable members opposite are refusing to support the very legislation that will give security to that pulp mill and allow it to go ahead.

PARA.TAB: I might say that the Opposition's change on this issue is of very recent origin, because until some months ago the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) not only supported the Wesley Vale pulp mill but were okay on what we then called resource security legislation because honourable members opposite understood the need for security, the relationship between a major investment in a value added pulp mill in this country, specifically at Wesley Vale in Tasmania, and the need for some legislation.

We responded by giving the Opposition some legislation tantamount to giving security to the investor as well as protection to the environment; but now the Opposition turns us down, now it does not want to be in the game. I have no idea why, but I guess it is for the Opposition's own short term political interests. It has been clear to us, as it has been clear from the comments of the industry, the National Association of Forest Industries Ltd, that the Opposition should be supporting this Bill. The industry wants the Opposition to support this Bill.

I know the Opposition wants to make some amendments to the Bill; I will detail those in a moment. We will argue them out. None of them stand. But I really cannot understand why the Opposition in the Senate will seek to knock off this Bill, the very Bill that is required if this country, in the national interest, is to have the Wesley Vale pulp mill. That sits on the heads of honourable members opposite.

We have done the negotiations; we have worked out the legislation. It is now in place. It is decent; it will work. It will suit the interests of both foresters and conservationists, and it will get a pulp mill up. But honourable members opposite do not want to be in it. For his own purposes the Leader of the Opposition does not want the Wesley Vale pulp mill; he does not want the immense wealth that that pulp mill will bring. I guess the only reason he does not want it is that he does not want us to have the success of getting a pulp mill in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —That may not be the view of the honourable member for Forrest, but it seems to be the view of the industry.

PARA.TAB: North Broken Hill, the company which will build the Wesley Vale pulp mill should we get this legislation through, issued a press statement just two days ago urging the Opposition to support the passage of this legislation. Let me quote from that statement:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this would be a significant step forward in the advancement of this nationally important project—

That is pretty straightforward, pretty decent, pretty obvious. The company which wants to build the pulp mill wants this legislation. Why is the Opposition opposing this decent legislation? Why is it opposing something that is clearly in the national interest? If we cannot argue it out here, then I guess the Opposition will do its business in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: North Broken Hill goes on to say that the industry is totally unified; that if there is to be a pulp mill in Tasmania, both the Government and the Opposition must support the current legislation. So the Opposition has to decide. It is on its head. It is our legislation that will bring to Tasmania, and to the nation, a pulp mill and the wealth that that pulp mill will bring. The Opposition wants to stop it, and I really do not understand why.
There is more to it, of course. In terms of the industry's own view, in March of last year the National Association of Forest Industries said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the role of the Federal Opposition in this debate has been a bit ambivalent . . .
I think the Association has been far too mild there; the Opposition has been entirely ambivalent. NAFI goes on to say:
The Opposition has been very quick to castigate the Government for the things it has done to the industry in the past but has been slow in putting their own cards on the table.

We know why it has not put its cards on the table; the Opposition spokesman on the environment, the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), has been in a total dither on this question, not knowing whether to canvass our views on the environment or to stick with Opposition members who think they represent the interests of the forestry industry in this country but in fact are damning its interests by stopping the legislation. Better than that, NAFI goes on to say:

NAFI met with Dr Hewson and had numerous discussions with Opposition Parliamentarians. It is considered most unlikely that they would oppose legislation when it is put forward by the Government in the House.

Well, NAFI was wrong. I would not blame NAFI; I would say that the Opposition is wrong. It has been sitting on the fence on this one, unsure which way to move, only wanting to achieve one thing—opposition. It really does not want to debate this in terms of the national interest; it simply wants to oppose. And so we go on.

PARA.TAB: In December last year North Broken Hill, the company that intends to build Wesley Vale, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to express our appreciation at the considerable effort of the Government in achieving significant progress towards ensuring the future of this vitally important industry.
I say to North Broken Hill that I hope the Opposition has sufficient sense to allow the passage of this Bill so that we as a government can allow North Broken Hill to build the mill.

PARA.TAB: On 23 December last year, in another case, Australian Paper Manufacturers, which intends to build a Maryvale plant worth some $850m, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We accept the involvement of the Federal Government in the concept of resource security and will work with the Victorian and Federal Governments and the National Association of Forest Industries to reach appropriate guarantees through legislation.

For some time that is what these people have been asking for—guarantees through legislation. We seek to give those guarantees to them through this Bill. The Opposition is denying that security that the legislation will bring.

PARA.TAB: The Federal Opposition, in opposing this legislation, is again prepared to forsake the national interests for its own short term political gains. To cap it all, North Broken Hill wrote to the Government on 25 February this year, again saying:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the proposed resource security legislation currently before the House, we would urge that this legislation progress as rapidly as possible as it is our opinion that this will provide an immediate signal to potential partners of the willingness of the Federal Government to create the necessary environment to allow the development of this nationally important project.

North Broken Hill is pleading with the Opposition to do the decent thing. I do not know why it is that the Leader of the Opposition has turned his back on this decent legislation; why it is that a conservative Opposition which purports or, let me say, pretends to be the mouthpiece of industry—which patently it is not in these circumstances—would shut out and deny the possibility of a pulp mill in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the Opposition has a number of concerns with the legislation, so let me detail them, put them aside, and then return to the initial proposition, which is that the Opposition wants to stop a decent pulp mill in Tasmania. As I understand it, there are four concerns from the Opposition: firstly, the legislation should be project specific rather than umbrella in nature; secondly, that the legislation should be tightened up to further limit the opportunity for governments to revisit resource access issues in the case of unforeseen circumstances; thirdly, the compensation provision should be removed from the Bill and wood compensation arrangements provided through intergovernmental agreements; and, fourthly, legislative resource security should be available for regionally based investment programs which do not meet the $100m eligibility threshold.

Let us take the first case of project specific or current umbrella legislation. This Bill—the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1991—is umbrella legislation which will set a consistent and comprehensive framework for considering resource security for all major forest based investment projects. In fact it will act as a trigger to relevant projects and proposals as they are put to us. It avoids the need to have separate legislation for each project; rather the detailed terms and conditions of each project will be contained in separate agreements between the Commonwealth and respective State governments, and these will have the backing of the legislation.

In a practical sense project specific legislation would result in a similar outcome, but, importantly, this would result in additional time delays while legislation was prepared and debated in the Parliament for each new investment project, which we would propose could take up to 12 months in each case. Clearly that is not an option. The Opposition's first objection fails.

In terms of unforeseen circumstances, once resource security has been granted to a project the conditions under which resource security could be revisited are strictly defined in this Bill. It can only occur in specified exceptional circumstances, such as the discovery of an endangered species, and the legislation requires all parties to undertake extensive consultations before any decision is made which could affect the availability of resources.

In other words, access to resources would only be withdrawn as a last resort after all other avenues had been exhausted. It is difficult to see how the Opposition could tighten these provisions, short of ruling out unforseen circumstances for the life of each project. Clearly no government could responsibly make such a commitment.

In respect to compensation, the Government believes that there are adequate provisions in the approaches outlined in the Bill to ensure that, even in the unlikely event of resource withdrawal, security of resources available to projects could be maintained. For instance, the catchment area for a project should be defined to include a margin for the protection of environmental values and this would be specified in the agreement between Commonwealth and the State.

While the Bill explicitly rules out liability by the Commonwealth or a State to pay financial compensation, it does not prevent the provision of structural adjustment assistance such as the Government has provided in the past in cases involving World Heritage listings of the forests of south-west Tasmania, the north Queensland rainforests and, closer to my home, the most recent response to the cessation of logging on Fraser Island. There is nothing in the legislation which would preclude a State agreeing to make available alternative resources of equivalent quantity, quality and price in the event of the withdrawal of resources due to unforeseen circumstances.

I had some discussions some weeks ago with NAFI where I debated the question of a letter from the Toronto Dominion Bank to the National Association of Forest Industries. That letter was dated 13 November 1991, and in it that bank stated that the legislation has done little to improve the risks associated with investment in the forest industry and is unlikely to commit funds for forestry investments. I asked NAFI in those discussions weeks ago to give me some proof from other banks who held a similar view because I felt that their view would be considerably strengthened if they could supply information from other banks.

However, the Minister has had discussions with the Australian Bankers Association, which has advised the Government that it has a different view about lending for forestry investment and that the Australian Bankers Association has no generic policy against lending to the forest industries. So I would argue, and I suspect, that the single document from the Toronto Dominion Bank to NAFI holds no weight in this debate.

On the question of regional resource security, the Government fully appreciates the important role which the sawmilling sector plays in the industry and its concerns to have secure access to forest resources. The Commonwealth will provide a legislative level of resource security for the sawmilling sector provided it can form an enterprise to meet the eligibility criteria specified in this Bill. In addition to the legislation for the sawmilling sector, the Government intends to provide non-legislative resource security for investments which do not meet that $100m threshold.

These arrangements will involve enhanced intergovernmental agreements between the Commonwealth and the relevant States on a regional basis, and are designed to encourage value adding and restructuring in the hardwood sawmilling sector.

I remind the House that the Bill and the non-legislated policy initiative for the hardwood sawmilling sector are concerned with achieving the following objectives: first, ensuring that forest environment and heritage, and cultural values, are adequately considered in a transparent and predictable framework prior to a development proceeding; secondly, facilitating much needed value adding investments in the forest sector, including commercial plantations; and, thirdly, creating more and better jobs for Australians who earn an honest living from this industry.

Provided the forest industries hold to their commitments to invest, as the public is entitled to expect, Australia will benefit from world scale value adding investments before the year 2000—that is, if the Opposition is sensible enough to allow this legislation through both Houses. The legislation has the capacity to pave the way for a pulp mill proposal in northern Tasmania and for the expansion of an existing mill in Maryvale in Victoria. Other major investments are envisaged for later in the decade in Western Australia and in Gippsland in Victoria.

Of particular importance is the role of commercial plantations in providing the necessary feed stock to sustain these developments. The Government believes it is steering a path consistent with its environmental objectives to create a better and more productive industry, which can become the base for a sophisticated paper-making industry in the future, providing more jobs for Australians and more prosperity for our nation.

In this debate I speak as the chairman of the caucus environment committee so I, of all people, might have some objections to this legislation. I do not. I regard it as giving full and decent protection in a transparent exercise whereby the conservationists can be satisfied that the decent values in native forests will be protected for all time, while at the same time the investors are given security of investment; that is, security over a resource. Whether or not their investment works because of other failures is their business. Nobody is going to compensate them for that. All this Bill is about is the security over a resource that we can guarantee to the satisfaction of both the investors—we would argue—and the conservationists in so far as they too have reason to argue about the security of the wider concept of our forestry resources.

I asked the Opposition and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to rethink their views on this Bill: they are wrong; they are in error, and they are in danger of stopping some of the most important investment in this country in the next couple of years—a pulp mill in Tasmania, the extension of a mill in Maryvale and some other works later down the track in east Gippsland. If the Opposition wants that sort of paucity of policy making on its head, so be it, but please do not return to the Government and suggest it is beholden to greenies. I am in the Greens camp; I am happy with the legislation; I want to know why the Opposition will not give us the legislation. The Opposition has to answer that.

I do not know why I can come to this table representing the Government's conservation interests, but I cannot convince the Opposition, which seeks to represent business interests and—as much as members opposite like to make speeches in this place—environmental interests, to do what the industry pleads for it to do. The industry and companies like North Broken Hill want the Opposition, with the Government, to push this legislation through both Houses so that we can get some investment off the ground. This thing is so important it can sit hand in hand with the statement of the Prime Minister last night, whereby we have a resurgence of investment in this country. Please do not stop decent investment in this industry.
Debate (on motion by Mr McLachlan) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the House take note of the papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night's economic statement delivered by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had two principal purposes: an economic purpose and a political purpose. Politically, it was billed as a test of the Prime Minister's fitness for the job. It also had to provide a response to our Fightback package and, of course, to improve the Government's very low electoral standing.

PARA.TAB: As an economic document, well, it should have been designed to give hope to the people of Australia during the worst recession since the Great Depression—give a sense of direction, a sense of vision for their future—and, of course, to be fiscally responsible in the way it went about creating jobs.

It failed on all counts—a total failure. It offers no real hope to Australians, its only sense of vision runs through to the next election and it is designed to boost the popularity of the Prime Minister and push the problem out beyond the next election.

Of course, as far as Fightback goes, it highlights the strengths of Fightback as well as picking out a few features of Fightback. It highlights the strengths of Fightback and its basic thrust towards genuine structural reform, which is the only way to rebuild the Australian economy and the lives of average Australians. It does not deliver sustainable job growth, as I will show in my remarks later.

Indeed, when we look at it as an economic document, it is fiscally irresponsible. It has about $18 billion which is unfunded, which will have significant effects down the track on interest rates, debt and the balance of payments and cause major economic hardship for average Australians.

But, most importantly, I guess, as a test of the Prime Minister's fitness for office—a man who has barely got the majority of his Party behind him—it revealed his capacity for shameless pork-barrelling, the fact that he will do anything or say anything to get himself re-elected and the extent to which he is tied, held and throttled by factions. So the Prime Minister failed himself, he failed his Party and he failed the people of Australia.

The first test of this statement should have been to give an honest and open assessment of where this economy is at the present time. It should have been to give us a statement on the nature of our economic circumstances in the worst recession in 60 years. But it did not do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a word.

—Not a word. Of course, it is not for me tonight to remind the people of Australia as to the magnitude of the problem. But it is worth putting some of the more important features on the record as a background to what I have to say. GDP has fallen in this recession by 3.2 per cent, which is about 7 per cent below where it otherwise would have been in normal circumstances. Bankruptcies are up 144 per cent since March 1989. There has been a 21 per cent fall in private sector investment. The number of people in employment has fallen by 192,000 since July 1990.

PARA.TAB: The number of people unemployed in this recession has gone up by 418,000 since October 1989. There are now 920,000 Australians who are officially unemployed, 760,000 on the dole and 1 1/2 million who have not got a job or who cannot get the hours of work that they want.

But among those unemployment numbers are some very real examples of hardship. There are 262,000 families in which the chief breadwinner is unemployed, which is up 40 per cent in just the last year. There are 218,000 Australian children living in a family in which no-one has a job, which is up 40 per cent in the last year. There are 248,000 Australians that have been unemployed for more than a year, which is an 88 per cent increase in just the last 12 months. There are 500,000 children living in poverty and 75,000 homeless—and an extra 140,000 families a year have been plunged into extended poverty because of this recession.

Youth unemployment in Australia is around 30 per cent, but in some of the regional areas outside Sydney and Melbourne it is as high as 40 or 50 per cent. There are 60,000 young Australians who could not get into university this year and nearly 100,000 young Australians who could not get into TAFE or technical colleges.

There are 60,000 Australians currently on the public hospital waiting lists. Juvenile crime is up fivefold. Last night and every night the Salvation Army has cared for 1,000 homeless persons, given away 300 food parcels or vouchers and provided 2,000 meals. Over the past year the St Vincent de Paul Society has experienced an increase of 30 per cent in the number of people wanting help.
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Those opposite do not like it, but they have to hear it because that is the background of the economy that they have created. That is the background against which this statement has to be brought down.

PARA.TAB: Can honourable members imagine, against that background, that this man did not go to the heart of our problems. He did not try to make substantial change to our economic circumstances and our economic policies.

Let us hope that out of all this economic damage this nation—and, hopefully, in the end, this Prime Minister—has learned something from the worst recession in 60 years. We now know that we must act together to make sure that we do not repeat the same mistakes—and some very real mistakes, some very tragic mistakes were made in the course of the 1980s that plunged this country into recession.

We must learn in particular what this man has not yet learned—that governments cannot spend what they do not have. He went into this package on a spending spree unequalled in this country—a spending spree which shows total disregard for the fact that he is unable to raise the money to pay for that.

We as a nation have to turn our back on the quick fix, the political bribe or the attempted short term job creation—the wild boom-bust mentality of the 1980s. We have to put those sorts of experiences behind us and learn from them as we come to address the basic problems that confront this country. If we do not, we will not have to worry about just the prospects over the next two or three years; we will have to worry about the prospects for our children and our grandchildren. Right now, for the first time in our history, this current generation is about to leave to its children and its grandchildren a lower standard of living than it enjoyed itself.

Of course, the tragedy is that Australia is a very wealthy country and a well located country with an abundance of natural resources, a well educated and articulate work force and an enormous amount of opportunity. What that should tell the Prime Minister is that things do not have to be the way they are at present. We can have a different country and a better kind of country. We can be a major player, for example, in the Asia-Pacific region in the course of this decade if we set about putting our house in order. We can be looked up to by the region, rather than looked down on by the region as we are at present.

We can become one of the region's major exporters of agricultural products, minerals and value added products in both those areas. We can become a very successful manufacturing base for the region and a major exporter of tourism, education and other services to the region. For some specific examples, we can become the second most important financial centre after Tokyo in the Asia-Pacific region and a major exporter of education, medical and legal services. We can develop even a dynamic car industry among the manufacturing industry if we get right the attitude to manufacturing, which is not embodied in this package. Of course we can also, finally, become a centre of excellence in research and development, using the talents of Australians as a backup for that industrial base.

Finally, I guess we can become a major tourist destination for the region. By the year 2000 we can quadruple the number of tourists we take in Australia—that would be 10 million—if we get on and do what is required to turn this country around.

But there is only one way to achieve that sort of vision for this country—and it is not by throwing money at it. It is not by pork-barrelling. It is not by short term dashes for growth. It is by facing the very fundamental fact that this country is not matching the best in the world. It has major inefficiencies, major disadvantages and major cost disadvantages which have to be eliminated in order to turn our circumstances around. There are no quick fixes. There are no easy ways to stimulate the economy to solve the problem. There is just a very hard, difficult, thorough process of structural reform which has been rejected by this Government.

The comparison that can be drawn between us and this Government is that the Fightback package that I have brought down does that. The Liberal-National coalition's Fightback package can deliver that sort of vision in this country in the course of this decade if we are prepared to work together to solve those problems.

There are a lot of reasons why this statement fails. But perhaps the principal reason, its single greatest failing, is that there is no mention of structural reform. Hence there will be no sustainable job growth as a result of the statement that was brought down last night. Let me use a few examples just to make the point. Let us look at one of the central features of structural reform in this country that this statement does nothing about, that is, labour market reform. There is a section on labour market reform where those opposite try to neutralise the differences between us and them by referring to enterprise bargaining. They say, `We are going to embrace enterprise bargaining'. That is all we are told. They have been saying that now for several years with no substance.

What about doing something fundamental about some of the other basic problems of our labour market, some of the atrocious work and management practices? Why did those opposite not mention something about penalty rates or leave loadings? Why did they not create the circumstances where there could be direct negotiation between employees and employers at the work place? Why did they not outlaw closed shops? Why did they not outlaw compulsory unionism? Why did they not get rid of the `no ticket, no start' practice? Why did they not get rid of hosts of those other sorts of allowances that we have heard about—heat allowances, hot weather allowances, cold weather allowances, even dim sim allowances? Why did those opposite not foreshadow some of those fundamental changes, which make us structurally inefficient in terms of our labour market relative to the rest of the world?

Secondly, of course, the statement does nothing fundamentally to reform the tax system. There is a bit of tinkering with the tax system; this is a very strange effort for a Labor Government to hit the poor as a result of the tax changes relative to the rich. But there is no substantial change in the tax system under this Government. In fact, there is a very important group of people, nearly four million Australians—nearly 50 per cent of taxpayers—who earn less than about $21,000 a year. Women, farmers, the aged, pensioners, retirees, students, and other beneficiaries make up the four million forgotten people who earn less than $21,000 and who do not get any tax cuts in this statement.

There is no attempt to abolish sales tax; there is no attempt to abolish payroll tax; there is no attempt to abolish petrol excise tax; there is no attempt to abolish lump sum superannuation tax—there is no genuine taxation reform in this statement. There is no attempt to lower real interest rates; there is no attempt to produce a more competitive situation. Indeed, those opposite risk the possibility that real interest rates will go up as a result of their statement. The exchange rate will further appreciate and this country will go even further into recession. That is the sort of economic risk those opposite have taken.

Let us look at the waterfront. Does this statement mention reform of the waterfront and some of the notorious practices we have seen over the years? Let us be frank.
