The Government says it is proud of its waterfront reforms. In September last year, after its much vaunted enterprise agreements were put in place, Australian wharfies earned $47,000 a year for an average of 21 hours per week. In the Port of Sydney, the flagship of reform, idle time—that is, the time that wharfies either spend going home, playing cards or, if they like the activity, fishing off the wharf—has increased from 11 per cent to 30 per cent thanks to two years of the waterfront reform process. The Government is going backwards under its so-called waterfront reform agenda.

Let us take an example where the Government claims to do something—rail transport. It claims in this package that it will make some headway with rail transport. The Government says that it is going to do this by building a nice, new glossy train line from Brisbane all the way to Perth. It understates the cost of that, by the way, in the package. But the building of a nice, effective railway line from Brisbane to Perth is not going to make much difference if the Government does not do anything about the fundamental inefficiencies in the rail industry. The rail industry has lost about $20 billion in the last 10 years. What is a glossy new train line going to do? Give the industry the chance to lose even more money on the basis of a glossy new rail line?

The Government has got to go to the heart of work and management practices if it is going to deal with problems in the railways. I am told, for example, that in Victoria it is cheaper to close down the rail system and give every commuter a small car than it is to try to run the railway. What do those opposite do about those basic inefficiencies? We have seen examples of train stations where, although trains do not stop, as many as 26 people man them. We have seen examples of firemen on electric trains and hosts of other work and management practices which make the railways grossly inefficient.

So we can go to any other area of reform and see no significant improvement, whether the Government has addressed it in the statement or not. Look at telecommunications, for example. In the last 12 months the Government scrapped the two-airline policy, but moved onto a two-telephone policy. There is still one union, but two players in the system. There will be no genuine reform in telecommunications. The Prime Minister, more than anyone else, knows that because he, after all, advocated an outcome different from that being pursued by the Government at this time.

Look at coastal shipping and trans-Tasman shipping. For example, New Zealand has imported gypsum from Mexico rather than Australia and sugar from Thailand rather than Australia because of the expense of the trans-Tasman shipping lines. Just last year an Australian farmer sought to send a container of peas from Tasmania to Fremantle. The lowest quote he received was almost twice as high as the quote for taking the same container from Tasmania to either Europe or Japan. They are the sorts of massive inefficiencies that exist in this system. There are work and management practices all over the place that desperately need to be addressed if we are going to turn our circumstances around.

What about privatisation? The Government says it has started to embrace privatisation. Selling 49 per cent of Qantas is a waste of time. Why not sell 100 per cent of Qantas and put it into place and go on to sell the rest of the Commonwealth Bank? Governments should not be running banks and airlines, particularly the way those opposite have been running them with massive losses, massive debts and massive inefficiencies. This statement is a massive failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only airlines making money are the government ones.

—Just to be clear, and the Leader of the House might like to pay attention, the statement is a massive failure of courage and nerve on the part of the new Prime Minister. Without structural reform it does not matter about the Government's capital works because they are not going to work. Without structural reform, the Government is not going to be able to get ahead. By comparison, Fightback does it all. Fightback actually addresses all these problems. Fightback has an integrated package of 20 separate policy initiatives to deal with labour market reform, tax reform and genuine commitments to major reform.
—Order! The honourable member for Calwell!

—There is the abolition of sales tax and the abolition of payroll tax. Those opposite want to create jobs. Even the Prime Minister, back in 1977, when talking about the abolition of payroll tax, said that it was a good idea as it could create as many as 200,000 jobs. Why did he not do it? Why does he support a system that taxes employment? We are offering the largest personal income tax cuts in history. We are offering to eliminate the 20 per cent to 50 per cent cost disadvantages that I just referred to that flow into all those infrastructure areas as a result of the massively inefficient work and management practices, the lack of competition, and the other reasons in each of those infrastructure areas that I cited.

PARA.TAB: We spell out a coordinated, anti-inflationary strategy. We reduce and eliminate wasteful and unnecessary government expenditure by $10 billion. The only way to give genuine tax reform, as those opposite know, is to cut government expenditure. We have a major program of privatising Commonwealth authorities, a major national savings strategy for both short term savings and superannuation, new programs in education and training that will cost as much as $3 billion over the decade, a new range of initiatives for the unemployed, a new private health insurance tax credit system, new superannuation tax rebates, cuts in short term migration and reform of Commonwealth-State financial relations. We do it all. Those opposite can go through their package and see what they have not done. One of the real tragedies for this Prime Minister is that in the past he has advocated many of the measures to which I just referred.

For example, there was the introduction of a broad-based goods and services tax in 1985. He still has on record the best case for a broad-based goods and services tax. In relation to telecommunications reform, he did not support the two-telephone policy of this Government. He used to believe that Coronation Hill should be mined. He did deals on Coronation Hill in order to get the leadership—and doublecrossed. He has done deals on immigration cuts, but he has not done anything about that in the package either. He lectured the mining industry about how the resource security legislation was a hopeless piece of legislation. What is he doing? He is pursuing it in the package. There was also the three-mine uranium policy—and I can go on. This man will say or do anything for short term political support. This document, therefore, fails dramatically as a political exercise on behalf of this man trying to rebuild his credibility with the Australian electorate and trying to develop an effective competitor to Fightback, which it is not. It is a sad and failed alternative approach at the very best.

Let us just look at the economics of the statement. Remember the lectures we have had from this Prime Minister over the last three years when he was Treasurer, and from the ex-Prime Minister, about what our basic problems were in Australia? I was told that one of our basic problems is that we spend too much relative to what we produce. Too much spending, too little saving, too much debt, too little production. What does the Prime Minister's package promise? Even more spending, even less saving, even more debt and little improvement in our productive capacity, if any at all.

Just to make this point very clearly for the new Prime Minister, we took the Murphy model—honourable members will all know Dr Murphy because this Prime Minister has been parading Dr Murphy around as an accepted domestic and international expert for the best part of the last week or so; he came out of the Treasury under this ex-Treasurer—and ran the Government's package through it; we put the Government's expenditure in it. We said, `We can't believe your forecasts because they are not forecasts; we are told they are projections'. Treasury have disowned them. The Treasury people have put some qualifications in the text to tell us that these are not forecasts, they are projections—and, by the way, the projections will only come good if a whole host of things happen, which they do not believe are going to happen. They have washed their hands of it. The work was done in the Treasury office and you know it.

Anyway, we ran the package through the Murphy model just to see how the Prime Minister's grand claims stack up—what he said about inflation, what he said about growth and what he said about the current account deficit. It would pay you, Prime Minister, to listen to the outcome of this study, because this is a very significant criticism of his package.

If we are going to have a sensible debate, I am prepared to put the detail of the calculation on the record and I am happy for the Prime Minister to make his comments on the other side. Maybe one day we will have a proper debate when he stops running for cover. He does not front up on television; he does not front up on the radio.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stick to it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Last night and this morning he and I did dozens of radio and television interviews. We passed each other in the corridor, but he would not debate me under any circumstances. Well, debate this lot.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the statement shows that GDP growth is much lower, economic growth is going to be much lower—an average of 3.3 per cent, not 4.3 per cent as was assumed. Secondly, inflation blows out. It does not stay at 3 1/2 to 3 3/4; it blows out to over 6 per cent. The current account deficit does not just stick around $20 billion, which ought to be alarming enough in itself; it goes as high as $27 billion. This is the bottom line: foreign debt increases by nearly $100 billion over the four years. Foreign debt will rise to $225 billion under that package according to those simulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —No way.

—The Prime Minister says, `No way'. I reckon our creditors will be in here first. I reckon we will have a major exchange rate crisis if this policy is going to run. I have to say that it will never be delivered.

PARA.TAB: Just to let honourable members see how this man thinks, he said he was going to go back to what he did best in the early part of the 1980s: to create growth and jobs. He forgets to say that the way he does that is by more debt, more debt and more debt.

I went back and I did a calculation. I looked at the period through to 1990-91. I was generous—I counted 1.4 million jobs he says he created through that period. Do honourable members know what it cost per job in debt? It cost $73,000 in international debt per job. But I tell you what, he is even becoming inefficient at putting it on the international Bankcard because this time the jobs he claims to create in the course of the next four years will cost $109,000 in foreign debt per job. That is grossly irresponsible.

No wonder his old mate Max Walsh called it reckless; no wonder every informed commentator in the country has canned his approach to this particular package. They see it as a short-sighted, politically expedient document designed to get him back into government at the next election and to push the problems out way beyond the next election. On those numbers that is not going to happen. Simon Crean, you had better get ready, mate. You had better get your alternative ready. I think you are going to get a run in the course of the next few months when this package and this man fall over. It is undeliverable.

In conclusion—I have to be honest about this—the Prime Minister and I do agree on one thing: the people of Australia ought to be given a clear choice at the next election. You can bet your bottom dollar that we are going to give them a clear choice at the next election. You run on this package and this disaster that is in prospect, and we will run on Fightback. Why not start with a particular challenge? A Wills by-election will be coming up some time in the next couple of months. Why not turn the Wills by-election into a general election to give the Australian people a chance to fight back?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We just listened to a speech from a man who would be Prime Minister.
—Would be? Will be.

—That is all he will ever be—a would-be Prime Minister. Quite clearly from what he said tonight he has nothing more to offer than he has produced in Fightback, which has already been shown to be a totally irrelevant solution to our problems.
—The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.
—Quite clearly, Fightback has already been shown to be utterly irrelevant to the needs of the Australian economy at present.
—If the honourable member for McPherson continues to interject I will name him.

—At the outset let me draw the attention of those opposite to one interesting point, a key devastating demolition point that was made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) about One Nation, the Government's proposals put forward by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last night. When the Leader of the Opposition ran them through the Murphy model he said that they would produce a foreign debt in 1995-96 of $225 billion. That is what we were told. But if we look at Fightback, the foreign debt in scenario C is $245 billion in 1995-96. The Opposition scenario gives a higher foreign debt than the Murphy model does for One Nation. That will do us for starters.

PARA.TAB: If that is the Opposition's demolition point, the central point by which it destroys our proposal, it destroys its own even more by the same point. It is an absurd position to say that something can be run through the Murphy model and then claim anything for that. It is as though it would capture all of the things which are built into our proposals for the future; in particular, the fact that inflation will be kept down by something which the Murphy model simply cannot capture. It works off the past, it works off things going way back; it does not capture the fact that there is now a trade union movement saying that we will agree that wages outcomes shall be conducive to an inflation outcome, which gives us inflation no higher than that of our major trading partners.

That is something we have never had before. It is something which means that if we have that kind of inflation containment built into our wages policy, we are much more likely to be able to have growth with low inflation than was possible in the past. Of course, the accord itself has been a major break with the past and has meant we have been able to get growth with much different inflation outcomes than would have been the case in previous decades. But in the future with this very low inflation, which is less than that of our major trading partners, we have the capacity to maintain that, and the Murphy model can never capture that. So to claim that the Murphy model means we will get less growth or less employment, or whatever, when it does not capture that central point on inflation, is to make the whole analysis utterly ludicrous and irrelevant.

The Murphy model, of course, cannot capture things like the change in our export pattern, because we have had dramatic change in our exports. The Leader of the Opposition says we can be a nation which relates to the Asian region, we can be a great leader in the Asian region and we can trade massively with the Asian region. What does he think is happening? What does he think is going on out there? Manufactured exports have been increasing over the last decade in real terms by 10 per cent per annum, and in the last two years by 20 per cent. We have an explosion in manufactured exports. He is standing here saying that nothing is happening; that we are not getting this kind of dramatic change or this structural change. He is saying that there is no structural change in One Nation, but he forgets absolutely that the fundamental structural change, that of low inflation, has now been achieved by us and, I believe, will be maintained through the process that I have just referred to.

So that is a structural change of enormous magnitude. Australia has never been constantly a low inflation country, and we now have that capacity to be a low inflation country—not with the Opposition's policies, which would give us the GST and push inflation back to double digit levels, but with our policy, which contains wages to a level that ensures that we will have the outcome on inflation which we all want to maintain, not just for one year or two years or three years, but for decades. That can be done with the kind of arrangements which are now in place. That is an enormously important structural change. To say that there is no structural change in this document is just an absurdity.

Of course, the Leader of the Opposition made a great point of saying that there is no structural change in things like the waterfront. He said, `You have not got efficiency improvements there'. He simply does not know what is going on. This comes through in so many things that he says. He simply has no idea what is going on on the waterfront and in shipping.

Let me just refer to the facts rather than this ludicrous anecdotal evidence that we got from the Leader of the Opposition. The fact is that with the reform process that is going on on the waterfront at the present time, major ports have moved completely to enterprise employment and regional ports are introducing new arrangements to eliminate cross-subsidisation. The total work force since the process started in 1989 has downsized by 40 per cent from 8,800 to 5,400, and will be halved by October 1992. Stevedores now report productivity improvements of up to 80 per cent in container handling rates, with some terminals recording average container crane rates rising by 60 per cent from 12 to 20 standard containers per hour. That is a crane rate which is equal to, and in some cases higher than, those in overseas ports with which Australia trades. They are aiming for further improvement to match international best practice.

Furthermore, and most importantly, these productivity improvements are leading to reduced prices for stevedores; that is, stevedoring rates are coming down. They have dropped by 20 to 25 per cent in the case of NTAL in the last 12 months. I have here a letter from David Boyd, the Managing Director of National Terminals (Australia) Ltd, the second largest operator of container terminals in this country. Actually, this is a letter written to Paul Lyneham after he made some comments in a telecast recently. He says in this letter:

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure you that benefits are being passed on in that new business and contract renewals negotiated in recent months are reflecting reductions in tariffs of an average of 20-25 per cent compared with those for business written in 1990.

He is saying that new business that is being written is cutting stevedoring rates, because of the enormous productivity improvements which are being attained through enterprise bargaining, by 20 to 25 per cent. I understand from the Minister for Shipping and Aviation (Senator Collins) that in some other companies the rates have been cut by 30 per cent. So there are dramatic cuts in stevedoring rates. We are becoming much more efficient on the waterfront, and the absurd statements by the Leader of the Opposition, who is either totally ignorant of what is really going on or trying to mislead the Australian nation, are just incredibly irresponsible statements and are no indication whatever of what is really happening in this country. To use his own language, why does he not tell the truth.

PARA.TAB: In respect of rail transport the Leader of the Opposition said there was no improvement, and asked what is the use of a shiny new railway line if the work practices are not changed. The statement in One Nation makes it absolutely clear that there is to be no major injection of funding into the railway system unless we get the greenfield agreement for best practice industrial relations and work practices. Without that, there is not going to be this injection. We will have a very substantial lever on the National Rail Corporation and the unions involved to bring about that kind of improvement in productivity and efficiency. I am very confident in those circumstances that it will be obtained.

We are not just simply throwing money at the problem. We are facing up to the fact that what is needed is a major investment of capital and also a dramatic improvement in work practices and efficiency. Both of those things are being aimed at and will be obtained by this process. It is utterly wrong for the Leader of the Opposition to say that we have ignored the need to improve efficiency.

These are just some examples of the kind of absurdities that we heard from the Leader of the Opposition. He says that because people who earn under $20,700 a year have not got any tax cuts, we do not care about them. Let me say to the Leader of the Opposition and to those behind him that no government in our history has put so much effort into looking after people on low incomes as this Government has. For instance, it has introduced the family allowance supplement, which provides very substantial assistance to people who earn under $20,700 a year. Those payments have increased in real terms between March 1983 and September 1991 by 53 per cent for a child under 13 and 123 per cent for teenage children.

We have increased rent assistance and made it available to low wage families. They can get rent assistance now as well as FAS. These are dramatic improvements in their situation. Not only are they at work with a wage, but also they are getting the family allowance and rent assistance. On incomes below $20,700 a year they can qualify for all of those things. So do not tell us that we do not care about these people. We have focused major direct programs on them. In those circumstances it is just idiocy to declare that because the tax cuts at this stage do not focus on such people, this Government has no concern for them. Of course, in the past the tax cuts have focused on them. The tax cuts have been heavily biased towards lower income earners in the various wage-tax agreements that have been made in the past.

Every attempt has been made to look after people on lower incomes in this way, including such programs as child care places with the fee relief system focused on such people. The full cut-off point for Austudy is $20,700. There are dramatic increases in assistance to low income families to enable them to put their children through higher education. There have been major improvements in the real level of pensions and benefits, and the real level of unemployment benefits has increased substantially. Pensions have gone up by 12.9 per cent in real terms while we have been in office and they are now worth over 26 per cent of average weekly earnings. The income for an unemployed married couple with two children living in private rental accommodation has increased by 26 per cent. Single adults are 25 per cent better off, or 53 per cent better off if they are in the private rental market. Do not tell us we do not care about people on lower incomes. There has been every effort made to look after them.

Finally, may I say that the fundamental flaw in the Opposition's position is that Opposition members stand up here saying that Fightback has all the answers. Fightback, as I have said, has none of the answers, and nothing proves it more than the point I was making in Question Time, which is that its fiscal policy is fundamentally crazy.

In its first year, the Opposition aims to contract fiscal policy by $3 billion. In fact, we showed that its funding was wrong and that the $3 billion was only $1.7 billion in the first year. But, if Opposition members were in government now, that is what they would be saying. They would be producing a statement which gave us a $1.7 billion cut, or maybe they would throw in some more expenditure cuts and make it $3 billion. But there would be a large contraction of demand at a time when demand was slack. Of course, that would contract the economy and make the rate of unemployment higher.

In the second year, when the GST was introduced, the fiscal policy would be relaxed. Using the correct costings, it would turn around by almost $5 billion—a $5 billion relaxation in a year in which the Opposition, if in government, would introduce a major inflationary impact. Of course, that would mean that interest rates would have to be jacked up to a very high level or have the inflation level blown through the roof. Either way, the economy would be put into diabolical shape.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or both.

—Or both, as the honourable member for Chifley says. As occurred in 1981-82 with double digit inflation and double digit unemployment, the coalition would do it all again with its package, a package which offers nothing to the people of Australia except the promise of large blow-outs in foreign debt if we look at the scenario which it says is the desired path for the future. It is a scenario which does not even include the GST.

PARA.TAB: When the Opposition told us that it could produce two million jobs by the year 2000, it used a scenario that did not even include the goods and services tax. What an incredible hoax! Those opposite stood up and told the people of Australia, `Here is our big package, GST, which produces two million jobs by the end of the century'. They said, `The evidence of that is in Murphy's scenario C'. When we look at that, we find that it does not even include the goods and services tax. What a ludicrous proposal. What a joke.

The fact is that this Government has faced up to its responsibilities and, like other governments around the world, including the United States Government, has recognised that there is a need in the current circumstances to do more than simply cut interest rates. We have gone through a whole period of cutting interest rates. It has not been enough. To get the economy going, we have to give it a kick start with the kind of responsible package which is here, a package which is funded in the sense that it will mean deficits of about $18 billion over four years, compared with a surplus of $18 billion in the previous four years, and going back into structural surplus after that. This is a totally responsible package and one which the Australian people will benefit from greatly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to focus on the real challenge facing Australia and to respond to the remarks of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), particularly with regard to the hoax the Government is perpetrating on all exporters and to build on the excellent remarks made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) earlier tonight. The challenge facing this nation is to bring about the fundamental requirements necessary to allow all Australians to enjoy the benefits of economic growth and job creation through boosting our export performance and our productivity generally. The need exists to test this statement against that challenge.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his speech commented under the title of `Exporting' that all of the initiatives in the One Nation statement will help build a productive base for Australian exports. He went on to speak of the potential increase in exports to Asia being some $13 billion by 1994. I would like to address this aspect in some detail in relation to Australian agriculture, Australian energy and mining resources and Australian manufacturing industries.

The key to truly boosting our export performance is to ensure a tax structure which will help facilitate exports rather than create a disadvantage for exports and our export performance. In the weeks leading up to the Prime Minister's statement there were some suggestions that the Federal Government at long last would look at the sales tax regime in particular and its impact on exports and export performance.

In a paper last year Dr John Bell, Deputy Secretary to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, confirmed that the current sales tax regime perpetrated by this Government creates a 5 per cent disadvantage on all exports. They are not my figures; they are not the coalition's figures; they are the figures from a Federal public servant, a senior public servant of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. Dr Bell said that it is a 5 per cent disadvantage factor on all our exports.

This is because $1 billion to $2 billion, around $1.7 billion, of sales tax is descending directly on our export industries as a tax on inputs contributing to the creation of exports. In layman's terms it means that the Australian wheat grower, the Australian briquette exporter, the Australian gold and mineral sands exporter and the Australian forestry machinery exporter who send their products from a place such as Rockhampton to Sumatra face a $5 surcharge on every $100 of exports. That is a 5 per cent uphill tilt of the playing field against the exporter.

I want to declare in absolute terms that there is no such thing as an international level playing field. The international trading place at this time is a particularly competitive and corrupt trading place, but the Australian Government adds to the burden of the situation by maintaining a $1 billion to $2 billion sales tax slug on all exporters.

TALK.START.PARA: —At last you've got that right.

—It is interesting that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie should interject. He is a man who is furious, because last night the Prime Minister doublecrossed him on the matter of Coronation Hill. The Prime Minister won over the vote of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. The Prime Minister gave him certain assurances that he would review Coronation Hill. Of course, there was no mention of Coronation Hill, which the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has publicly supported, in the economic statement. The Government wimped out on Coronation Hill.
—Coronation Hill will be mined.

—Of course it should be mined. I agree with the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. It will be mined. How embarrassing is that to the Minister for Finance, who is at the table? How embarrassing is that to the Prime Minister? The honourable member for Kalgoorlie, along with Senator Peter Walsh, has got it right: Coronation Hill should be mined and will be mined. It will be mined when the coalition is in government and provides the proper policy basis to mine it.

PARA.TAB: It is an absolute commitment of the coalition's Fightback package that all sales tax will be abolished and all exports will be zero rated as far as the goods and services tax is concerned. A related commitment is that fair trade objectives will be pursued, including fair dinkum anti-dumping laws, no compromise on quarantine, and truly adequate labelling laws. The House is entitled to ask: why did the Prime Minister wimp out on fixing the sales tax slug by removing that slug on Australian exports? The truth of the matter is that the Government could not devise a scheme which could isolate sales tax on business inputs, which create exports, in a satisfactory way because of the complexities and the implications associated with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

I repeat: there is only one solution to this sales tax phenomenon on our export industries, a 5 per cent disadvantage for all our exporters. That is to abolish sales tax totally and to zero rate all exports under a goods and services tax. Interestingly enough, that is the one point that Senator Peter Walsh has focused on in many of his articles in the Australian Financial Review, saying that it is a truly relevant argument associated with the Fightback package.

We have it right. We have exposed the argument and we will fix it up. Mr Deputy Speaker, you might well ask why most Asian economic tigers have no sales tax, no payroll tax, no fuel excise tax as such, and a GST or VAT regime which tilts the taxation system in favour of the productive sector and export performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Corio refers to population circumstances. Let us look at an Asian country, an economic tiger, with a similar population to that of Australia. Try Taiwan. It is a country with one of the largest gold reserves in Australia. Smaller than Tasmania, Taiwan generates more exports in a full year than Australia does and has a fair dinkum tax regime associated with its export performance. Most Asian countries, the economic tigers, are in positive economic growth. Most of the larger Asian economic tigers have close to full employment and have fixed up their tax systems. Australia is dragging the chain and paying an awful price.

PARA.TAB: The One Nation economic statement of the Prime Minister has failed the first test: it does not provide a basis for boosting our export performance and, as such, it is a dismal failure in maintaining that sales tax regime. Let me turn to a second test, not unrelated, which relates to the important area of micro-economic reform which the Leader of the Opposition touched on tonight, as did the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) earlier today. Quite frankly, I am pleased that at long last, after years of advocacy—before it became fashionable, I remember being attacked for mentioning railways at the Federal level—the micro-economic reform of rail has arrived on the national agenda.

Indeed, in 1989 I drafted two paragraphs of the report of the then House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled Rail: Five Systems—One Solution. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.1An indication of the problems which face customers who wish to move freight Sydney-Perth by rail can be illustrated by outlining the likely plight of a typical container. . . As it crosses Australia, it will . . . pass through:
.3 non-integrated rail systems;
.4 changes of locomotives;
.5 different safe working systems;
.6 different sizes of loading gauge;
.10 different engineering standards of the basic standard gauge rail track; and
.12 or more hours at sidings/junctions for crew changes, refuelling, inspections, etc.
What a disgrace in one nation!

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you do about it?

—We standardised it. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie came in hook, line and sinker. I happen to recall that it was Prime Minister Gorton who opened the standardised Sydney-Broken Hill-Port Augusta-Kalgoorlie-Perth railway line when the coalition was in government. The coalition built that line and also the standard gauge line to Alice Springs. I have to tell the honourable member that we made a mistake. When that standardisation was complete we did not insist at that time that there be a national rail corporation—one organisation set up to operate that rail system. That has now come into being.

PARA.TAB: Well might that be, but rail still has to work hard to earn its place in the sun. It has a role to play, but it is not a role which will be given to it automatically. It has to boost its efficiency and productivity as well as improve its physical infrastructure. In this regard, the economic statement proposes the Melbourne-Adelaide line, which will go through the electorate of my colleague the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), and it allocates $115m just for that project.

Let us get down to the basics. The Government did not really do much homework on this matter. If it had gone to the Booz Allen and Hamilton report it would have seen that the official estimate for that particular project is not $115m, but in fact $154m. So there is a $40m hole in that particular project estimate which has been revealed against the Government's own report. If the Government were going to consider diverting the line around the Adelaide Hills, it would cost, according to that same official report, an additional $185m. So the Government's figures are wrong, wrong, wrong so far as the standardisation of that Melbourne-Adelaide line is concerned.

As the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) and the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) correctly point out, there is a perfectly adequate rail system, which is already standardised, operating between Sydney, Parkes, Broken Hill and Adelaide. The future of that line is critical to the economic infrastructure of Australia. Of course we need to standardise the Melbourne-Adelaide line, but it needs to be done properly. It needs to be done by upgrading to concrete sleepers; it needs to address the Bacchus Marsh problem, the Horsham devi-

SPEECH.PARA: ation problem and, indeed, the Adelaide Hills/Mount Lofty problem to ensure that we do not get a second-best outcome with the rail infrastructure in this statement. I have sought the permission of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Price), who is at the table, to incorporate a table which relates to the fuel excise and payroll tax paid by the rail systems in 1990-91. I seek leave to incorporate that table.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows the amount of fuel excise tax and payroll tax paid by rail in Australia in the year 1990-91. The figures add up to a very interesting total. For example, the New South Wales railway system had to fork out $48m in diesel fuel excise—little of which it gets back—and it paid $62m in payroll tax. In total, the rail systems of Australia pay $258m.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's Fightback package will help rail. It will abolish all diesel fuel excise tax on-road and off-road. It will abolish all petrol fuel excise tax on-road and off-road and it will put the capital `d' back into `decentralisation'. The Government's economic statement failed to address fuel taxation in any way, shape or form and the Government will pay a price for that in the marginal country electorates which we will rip off it at the next Federal election. Kennedy, Leichhardt, Herbert, Hinkler, Rankin, Hunter, Calare and many others will be won—Page and Richmond, especially, after the total failure of the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) and the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell) to do anything for the Pacific Highway in this economic statement.

The House has been presented with an economic statement which does not add up. It is an economic statement which is a whole lot of rhetoric and a whole lot of bravado from a nervous Prime Minister, who is yet to get on top of his job as Prime Minister and who seems to enjoy going around insulting, indirectly, Her Majesty the Queen of Australia and the traditional historic links of this country. That has nothing to do with the debate on where this country should head in the future. On this side of the House there is the very clear commitment to building our economic and export links with Asia as the correct future direction. Some of us do not just talk about that; we act upon it. Indeed, we have helped to bring about an attitudinal change to ensure that Australia does focus especially on north-east Asia, South East Asia and south Asia.

I challenge any Minister of the Crown and any Prime Minister current to put their record of effort in Asia and their working days in Asia against my own record of working days in Asia and countries visited in Asia. Few members of parliament can claim that they have been to each and every ASEAN country—all six of them—let alone to places such as Bhutan, Bangladesh, Burma and up-country Thailand, which is a long way from Patpong Road, Bangkok, to see the real economic infrastructure of Thailand and the implications of Thailand, as one Asian economic tiger, for the future standard of living of all Australians.

I put it to the House that we in the coalition have the real alternative for this country. The statement presented by the Government does not add up for the one million people who are unemployed. It does not add up for the people in Albury-Wodonga who tonight attended the community soup kitchens—all four of them—which are all doing record business 60 years after the Great Depression. Our statement—by abolishing sales tax, by abolishing all payroll tax, by abolishing all Federal fuel taxation and by abolishing four other taxes, with a record income tax reduction of $13 billion; by reducing fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax; and by bringing about less taxation, less government, more productivity, more incentive and more jobs—is clearly the way ahead for Australia. The sooner Prime Minister Keating is thrown out of office, the better; and the sooner Labor pays the price for its political crime of destroying the Australian economy, the better. Enough is enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it quite incredible that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) can stand up in this House and make a statement such as, `You can't spend what you don't have'. Of the last 30 Budgets overseen by Liberal governments in this country, none were balanced. In the 30 Budgets brought into this Parliament for the last 30 years during which Liberal governments were in power in this country, there was not one surplus Budget. There was not one surplus Budget year in 30. And the Leader of the Opposition says, `You can't spend what you don't have'. Those opposite did, and it was spent on the national debt, not on private debt.

PARA.TAB: Since this Government came to power it has eliminated all Commonwealth government debt and we now have net foreign assets. The country does have substantial State debts and substantial private debt overseas—some of which money never ever came to Australia, as honourable members well know.

One other thing we heard about was the record of some people or the fact that the rail system should have been dealt with a long time ago. Gough Whitlam offered to take over all of the State rail systems in Australia; in fact, he took over the South Australian and the Tasmanian systems. There were Liberal governments in Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia—the other mainland States. The Liberal governments—there was a National Party government in one State—all refused, because of States' rights issues and a lack of national vision, to be party to any such arrangement.

People who stand up in this House and say, `It's about time' with respect to reform of the rail system should have a look at their own record, because on the only other occasion on which it was brought forward, it was the Liberal and National parties that rejected it—not the Labor Party; it initiated it. The rail system in Victoria was practically destroyed under the Bolte and Hamer governments. They spent nothing. There was a lack of maintenance and unsafe situations developed. In Victoria, cars that had been introduced into the system before the First World War were still in operation carrying passengers. That was after 20-odd years of Liberal governments without a break.

The package brought in by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is designed to help Australians, to help Australia get out of a rut, to do what was not done during the Depression because of the operations of a conservative Senate and a conservative bank board, to do what is necessary to assist Australians get jobs and to assist those Australians who have suffered most.

I will use my electorate as an example. On 2 April this year all families who qualify for family allowance will receive collectively $4m to assist them. Those who qualify for FAS will receive an increase of $3. They are the lowest income earners in the country. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) cries crocodile tears about low income earners. The Liberal Party has never been interested in low income earners. Conservative politicians around the world have shown that. Has no-one been listening to what is being said in the primaries in the United States? For 10 years there have been conservative presidents in the United States. There have been conservative presidents for 28 of the last 40 years. One per cent of Americans have improved their standing—the top one per cent—and they have doubled their income. The bottom 90 per cent are worse off.

A goods and services tax is really going to help those low income earners that we hear about in this House! When they buy fruit they will pay 15 per cent tax on it. They will pay 15 per cent on meat, eggs and vegetables—the things that they spend most of their money on. If they have to get an electrician or a plumber in, they will pay 15 per cent tax. If they buy a second-hand car because they cannot afford a Mercedes to get the big tax cut the Opposition is going to hand out—

TALK.START.PARA: —A Ferrari.
—A Mercedes will do. The tax cut is worth $6,000 to the people who can afford one. If they buy a second-hand car, which carries no sales tax now, they will pay a sales tax of 15 per cent.
—No, they won't.
—Yes, they will. Read your document.
—Not on second-hand goods.

—They will pay a sales tax on a second-hand car, according to the Fightback! document, which the honourable member for Fadden obviously has not read. The people who can least afford it will pay more and those who can most afford it will pay less. Where are the tax cuts in the Fightback package? It proposes some tax cuts for those at the lower end, but not as much as the 15 per cent it will cost them. It is not a compensation package. Those at the bottom end will pay more tax. In fact, 70 per cent of Australians will pay more tax. The top 20 per cent will have massive tax savings. They will save in every area of their expenditure because they spend more money on high sales tax items. They will have a 20 per cent drop in personal income tax.

PARA.TAB: Remember the crocodile tears about payroll tax we just had. The Opposition is going to put up company tax. Who is going to pay that? The same small businesses who do not now pay payroll tax. They are going to be worse off, so do not let us have those crocodile tears. I just heard one honourable member talking about how payroll tax cripples railways and how the New South Wales railways pay large amounts of payroll tax. Who collects that payroll tax? Greiner does—the person who owns the New South Wales railways. If he wants to exempt them, he can. It is not collected by the Commonwealth.

If the Opposition cuts out payroll tax, it will do so by increasing personal taxes by $27 billion and giving $5 billion back. Will the States get the money back? It was given to the States by Gorton and trebled by Liberal governments in the three years after it was given to them. In 1977, the Liberals opposed its abolition for personal income tax—the same sort of thing it is promising now—which it legislated out as soon as the election was over. Do not let us have crocodile tears.

The most important thing from my electorate's point of view is that private enterprise start employing people. This package provides very large incentives for investment. The depreciation allowances in this package will put Australia at the forefront of the world for write-off provisions for investment in new plant and equipment. One of the few countries in the world that would have a lower level is Germany, where company tax is in the order of 65c—about where the personal income tax top rate was when the Liberals went out of office.

The sales tax deduction on cars will apply to those cars which are made in Australia and are under $44,000. It is a wholesale sales tax. Some radio commentators do not seem to read anything. This morning on radio some of them were stupid enough to say that it was the same as the 15 per cent tax in the Fightback package. They ought to find out the difference between a wholesale and a retail tax. There is about $800 difference between a 15 per cent wholesale tax and a 15 per cent retail tax. That will assist Australia's car industry. There may be arguments against selling cars, but at this stage Australians drive motor cars and those in the lowest income groups are more likely to drive the cars under $44,000 than the people who would benefit from big hand-outs under the coalition's Fightback! document—those who drive Ferraris, Mercedes and BMWs.

The Bellarine Peninsula, in my electorate, one of the most popular tourist areas in Australia, has a road no-one can drive on. It will now have its duplication completed. That is built into the package. It is important for all of those people who live on the Bellarine Peninsula. We have been fighting for that for some time and I am very pleased it has been achieved in this statement.

There are a number of other important aspects to this document. It provides equity. It looks after those Australians most in need. It provides education and training to enhance job opportunities for some unemployed. It contains some incentives to provide employment for the young. It takes away the waiting period for school leavers. They will not have to sit at home for six weeks without money. It provides money for those families most in need. To some extent, that money will flow into the general economy, where it will generate economic activity and assist many of the businesses, especially retailers, who are having great difficulty in carrying on.

During this debate the Leader of the Opposition mentioned waterfront reform, which is one of the things I would have thought the Liberal Party would have run away from in shame. He mentioned the way in which the Opposition will manage industrial relations policies in this country—something it has never shown itself to be able to do in the past. He said that we have to privatise free enterprise. Anyone who has read the Costigan report will see some very spectacular examples of privatising government enterprises, such as privatising the tax system with the bottom of the harbour scheme. The Liberal Party in opposition, having done nothing in government, voted against the elimination of that scheme. Every Bill to reform the tax system to make people who should pay tax do so was voted against by the Opposition in this House.

Members of the Opposition talk about reforming the tax system: restoring the rorts is what they are about—nothing to do with tax. One of their successful ventures in private enterprise took place in the Perth office of the Attorney-General's Department. One can read about it in the third Costigan report. The person responsible for prosecuting tax dodgers in Western Australia had so much to do that he ran an escort agency out of the Commonwealth Attorney-General's office in Perth! At the same time, a prosecution notice which had been issued by Bill Hayden in 1975 was found in 1980 in the bottom of a drawer, never serviced. That is how those opposite ran the country. A billion dollars—nearly half the amount needed at that stage to eliminate payroll tax—was flowing out the door of the Taxation Office to the Opposition's friends, whom those opposite were protecting by refusing to act or legislate.

So do not let us talk about fairness. What are honourable members opposite going to do? I have said it before. They are going to collect a 15 per cent tax on the food that people eat: eggs, fruit and vegetables. The National Party says, `Look, if people buy farmers' products we will put the price up so that they won't buy as many.' The Fightback package states clearly that people's income is going to decline; that they will have less money to spend. Honourable members opposite say that, with less money to spend but more being charged for the product of the Australian farmers, the farmers will be better off. They must be joking! But there are benefits. I have just said that there is a benefit of $6,000 for the person who can buy a Mercedes, but the struggling home owner trying to furnish a house will pay more on all those things which do not currently attract tax.

What we have seen tonight is a desperate attempt to prop up a collapsing document which has not been thought through and which has about the same standards of work, intellect and academic input as the 12 health policies that the Opposition has had in the last 10 years. One of those policies did not even hit the light of the day. Its author stood up in an election campaign and said, `Help us. It is hopeless.' Six of those policies put up when those opposite were in government failed. There is another one now and the Leader of the Opposition is saying exactly the same about it as the Opposition's previous leaders and health Ministers said about its health policies. What it will do is price the low income people in this country out of decent medicine and return us to the 1950s policies—which those opposite gloried in—of having charity beds in hospitals for those who were poor enough to qualify but at the same time building private wards and giving tax deductions on health insurance for those with money. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is simply another attempt to create an illusion of economic prosperity in Australia while at the same time making a blatant and cynical grab for votes. I think we would agree that that is a sad commentary on the Prime Minister of this country. However, the saddest feature of the statement is that it reinforces the fact that neither the Prime Minister nor any of his advisers understand the true nature of the problems facing Australia. They seem to assume that if we could have better economic numbers all the other problems would automatically be fixed. Clearly, they are wrong.

PARA.TAB: The major problems facing Australia are not economic, but cultural and social. In economic terms, Australia is a very wealthy and resource rich country. The Australian people enjoy an affluent and high standard of living. It is a misconception to believe that greater affluence will provide a more enjoyable or wholesome lifestyle for the Australian people. It seems to me that our national planners have a mistaken understanding of human values if they assume that the only objective in life is to accumulate material wealth.

There is no doubt that the production of economic resources is essential to meet the physical needs met of people. People must have food, clothing, housing, education and a variety of other physical needs met if they are to live in reasonable dignity. But the mere provision of those physical or material needs will not provide true happiness and satisfaction for human beings.

Human beings are more complex than mere physical beings. Each individual harbours emotions, ambitions, ego and a variety of other psychological and spiritual needs. There is very strong evidence that to provide merely for physical needs while ignoring psychological and spiritual needs will lead to frustration and anger, which usually manifests itself in anti-social behaviour.

The Prime Minister purports to improve Australia's economic performance, which in itself is a commendable objective. But to ignore all the other values and aspirations of human nature is sheer folly. It seems to me that some politicians have concluded it is good politics to focus on the economy, and their task has been ably assisted by the media, which is more concerned with instant sensationalism than with responsible and balanced reporting.

By ignoring the privileges the Australian people already enjoy and also ignoring the psychological and spiritual needs of human beings, an attempt has been made to convince the Australian people that they are deprived individuals if they do not have as much as someone else has. In other words, the politicians and the media are appealing to the worst aspects of human nature in greed and selfishness in the hope of winning a few votes. Then they seem perplexed because Australian society is becoming more unstable.

In this country, greed and selfishness are creating an alarming disproportion between the overprivileged and the underprivileged. Those factors are also causing an increasing number of people to manipulate their affairs to gain personal advantage, regardless of the effect on the community. How often do we hear of people refusing work in order to stay on the dole? How often do we hear of personal affairs being manipulated in order to make welfare claims? How often do we hear of business people or executives manipulating their affairs in order to avoid paying legitimate taxes? How often do we hear of entrepreneurs who use smart alec tactics in order to rip off investors?

Such events are widely known and talked about in the community and, while they are promoted by greed and selfishness, they are practised with seeming immunity. Is it any wonder that a society that has lost touch with deeper spiritual and human values, but instead has given prominence to the worst aspects of human nature, should have social and cultural problems of alarming proportions? Do we think more police or harsher laws will reverse the trend of violent crime? Are we so naive as to think that making drugs illegal will stop people using them? Do we think that the alarming spread of sexually related diseases will be stopped by better sex education? Is it assumed that we can achieve higher productivity simply by offering more money?

Before Australia can improve its social, cultural or economic standing, there must be a revolution in thinking. The first profound realisation must be to accept that cultural attitudes and economic outcomes are totally interlinked. We cannot have a stable economy without a stable society, and we cannot have a stable society without a stable economy.

The Fightback package announced by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) is a genuine attempt to plan the Australian economy over an extended period. In my view, the Hewson package is the most decisive economic contribution Australia has seen since the Second World War, because it looks beyond the next election and is not primarily aimed at winning votes. However, the Hewson package is limited by the outmoded concept that economic prosperity can be driven by human greed and selfishness.

Greed and selfishness are at the very heart of our foreign debt, which is central to all other problems facing the economy of this country. During the 1970s and 1980s Australia developed a debt culture. The heavy use of debt was not limited to governments, business tycoons or corporate cowboys; personal debt in the form of credit cards, personal loans, hire purchase, et cetera exploded during the 1970s and 1980s and became the normal method of transacting personal business.

However, it is simply not possible for any society to maintain order and stability if it consistently spends more than it earns. As a national society, Australia must either reduce the level of spending or increase the level of earnings. More important, however, is the need for the Australian people to change their aspirations and culture so that we live within our means. We can no longer live with the fantasy that we are entitled to everything that opens and shuts, but that someone else should pay for it. The present recession simply means that reality has caught up with us.

To be successful, future planning must give as much attention to social and cultural values as to economic objectives. Our national plans must also take account of the changing structure of the world and of Australia's role in that changing world. For instance, how can we realistically consider reducing our immigration program while the world's population is exploding? Do we think that all the resources of Australia should be selfishly set aside for 17 million people while the population of India alone increases by more than that number each year?

Politicians from all sides keep talking about the social scourge of unemployment, which is fair enough, but then they project the impression that they can create jobs for everyone who wants to work. However, if more vision is used it will be admitted that we will never again see so-called full employment. Advanced technology means we can achieve enormous increases in productive output at considerably less cost and by using far fewer people. So we have the combined effect of an exploding world population and sophisticated technology which replaces people in the production of goods.

It is accepted that the production of goods in Australia must be cost competitive with the rest of the world. Therefore we must continue to use the latest cost saving technology. However, the harsh reality that must be incorporated into our national planning is that the more technology we use the less jobs will be available. It is therefore essential that our planning focus on the psychological needs of human beings. If full time work is simply not available for a growing number of Australians, we must plan other means to provide psychological satisfaction.

The notion that the only way to achieve personal satisfaction and also make a valuable and worthwhile contribution to the community is by being in the paid work force is outdated, and such thinking must change. However, concepts and aspirations in the community will only change when programs and structures are in place to allow individual citizens to make a worthwhile contribution to the community without being in the paid work force.

At present we provide unemployment benefits as a stopgap measure while people look for jobs. But if the reality is that jobs are not available for an increasing number of people, we must change our thinking about unemployment and also about the means of remunerating people who are not in the paid work force. At present we have a huge unused resource in the form of over 900,000 unemployed people. At the same time, the cost of caring for our rapidly ageing population is becoming a major problem. Surely it is not beyond the wit of mankind to bring the need and the resource together.

Unemployed people could be used to provide support services which would allow many older people to live in their own homes and not in institutional care. By doing so, it will give greater dignity to many older people, it will substantially reduce our aged and health care costs and it will give many of our unemployed people a fulfilling role in the community.

Quite correctly, the major problem confronting this country has been identified as unemployment. But, sadly, the only solution that seems to occupy the media and the politicians is to create full time jobs for everyone who wants to work. In my view, such a solution is a myth that must be left in the past. The challenge facing Australia over the next 10 to 20 years is how to occupy an increasing and more skilled population while the ratio of jobs continues to fall. I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to the Parliament, that we will need a very strong cultural foundation if we hope to maintain a stable society in this country while meeting that challenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a package for the times. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said yesterday evening, this statement is very much about making this nation strong. I believe that it behoves every member in this chamber to support the goals outlined in the Keating four-year plan because it is the best chance Australia has of breaking from the economic malaise which has brought in its wake an unacceptable level of unemployment to so many nations, including Australia. We have heard quite a bit about the problems facing George Bush domestically, which I think is indicative of the situation in which we in the Western world have found ourselves; in fact, it is one of the consequences of the boom or bust phenomenon which is the albatross of the system which governs our lifestyle in the west.

PARA.TAB: I believe we need to seriously question the economic effectiveness, let alone the social equity, of that system where dollars accumulated is rewarded over and above hours worked and which has delivered such results as national debts leading to famine and poverty in the developing world.

The effects of colonial rape have been very well documented. I think it is worth considering the system that allowed this rape. It was a system whereby empire building nations with power came and took over vast portions of so-called uncivilised, but actually unwesternised, nations, and I think particularly of the crying heart of Africa and what has happened there. Having taken the resources that they needed for their own use, at the stage when those different states were allowed the privilege to govern for themselves and become independent, they were suddenly thrust without training or preparation into a highly sophisticated world scene, a global trading scene.

At that stage it was the Western banks, of course, which lent money following the oil shocks in the 1960s, and they lent it without proper precautions regarding pay back. Of course, given the famine, the poverty, the numbers and the lack of infrastructure within those nations, they could not pay it back. So what did we do in the West? It was easy: we just gave them more time. We rescheduled the loans; we allowed the interest to burgeon. The results of that are a major problem in our world today. Where is the sense and where is the decency that allows money to make money and interest to burgeon to an unacceptable level and without a proper ceiling?

But in the halls of privilege the capitalist system is sacrosanct. One element which retards the ability for people, even in democracies, to effect necessary changes to the system under which they live is the stigmatising of those who question its effectiveness. For instance, it would not stun me at all in some areas, or in some circles, were my criticisms of capitalism to ignite a flurry of comparisons with communism, and of course the Eastern bloc has collapsed because of its deficiencies. I can only hope that the end of the Cold War will diminish the confrontationist attitude which has prevailed from the period of McCarthyism, opening the way for clear-sighted, objective evaluation of the merits and demerits of all socioeconomic and political systems.

It is well past time that we did so, so that the very basis of what we are doing is correct and stable. Meanwhile, it behoves democratic governments seeking social justice to work within the parameters of the Westminster system and to adapt policies and strategies to ensure that people who pay the price of economic breakdown are not ground down by unemployment and its attendant social ills. There are many reasons for recession, including changing trading patterns and the resultant loss of markets, which have affected Australia and would have done so whoever had been in government. That is another reality, but for us as a government the bottom line is that people are hurting.

It is against that background that the economic statement delivered this week is strongly and unashamedly interventionist. While there cannot be one strategy to meet all a nation's diverse needs, as pointed out by the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), this statement of necessity focuses on addressing major symptoms of hurt within the community. It has to be done. That means jobs, training, incentives for small business and support for families. It is Labor's plan over the next four years to create 800,000 jobs, without increasing the current account deficit and by keeping inflation down.

We have given incentives to employers to take on more apprentices and there should be an extra 9,000 places this year alone. In addition we have provided help to those employers and apprentices already in the system to stay on. The unemployed will receive an additional $100m between now and June next year in wages subsidies for 44,000 extra long term unemployed under the Jobstart program. Another $30m will go to provide six months work experience for those who are eligible for the Jobskills program. We will take over the funding of the TAFE system to the tune of $720m extra over the next three years. This will enable our young people in particular to acquire skills that will help them with jobs in the future. The jobs will be there, even given the problems acknowledged and outlined in this chamber tonight.

Overall the Western system is not workable and effective, but with that background we have to work with enthusiasm and in a thoughtful manner to provide within our framework of government measures that will meet both short term need and lead to longer term restructuring so the Government is building railways, upgrading roads, implementing workplace reforms and still finds it important to deliver tax cuts.

In Queensland tourism is an important source of jobs. Between 12 and 16 per cent of all jobs created in Australia in the 1990s will be in the tourism industry. That is about 200,000 jobs. The Government has recognised the potential of tourism for economic growth, job creation and increased prosperity by giving it a kick-start through this Keating plan. The growth in tourism will be achieved in four major areas: increased funding for overseas markets and promotion, $5m extra in this current financial year and a further $10m in 1992-93; sweeping reforms to the aviation industry that will result in cheaper air fares and more flexible travel arrangements; the introduction of a more competitive taxation regime for the tourism industry, which has been designed to encourage infrastructure development, while increased funding for tourism development will occur through the Department of Tourism.

However, the crux of the package to stimulate the economy, providing jobs and services, is the huge infrastructure program which will revolutionise the travel habits of Australia, bringing us into the twenty-first century. The package is a credit to its authors and to the Ministers involved and I think it is appropriate on behalf of many backbench members and their constituents to pay tribute to the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), who has been involved in major changes to land transport since 1987.

Queensland, my home State, will benefit from these changes, both in revolutionising and in facilitating easier travel for more people and in promoting road safety and creating jobs in the actual construction and in the infrastructure that will result as we are linked to new areas. Queensland motorists and travellers from southern States will travel more safely due to two major initiatives in the Labor Government's economic statement announced by the Prime Minister yesterday. The highway to Cairns will be upgraded at a cost of $43.4m and the highway from Brisbane through Sydney to Melbourne—the Newell Highway—the Port of Brisbane link, other national roads in Queensland and the $10.2m black spot program will make road travel safer.

In total, approximately $200.2m will be allocated to roads that will directly affect motoring Australians wanting to take advantage of the sun and the unique hospitality of Queensland. By upgrading the railway system in Queensland to a standard gauge linking Cairns with Perth, more people will decide that travelling by rail is a viable and relaxing alternative, particularly for the growing senior members of the Australian community.

Rail is a popular way of really seeing the vast and beautiful expanses of Australia while enjoying a motel style living. However, rail is not only used for recreational travel; a fast and efficient rail service means our primary producers and manufacturers can more effectively and competitively move their produce from one area to another.

All these measures will provide safe travel throughout Australia. Road authorities agree that the condition of this nation's roads is one of the factors affecting road safety, although the human factor is always there. In particular, the special allocation of $25m this financial year and a further $45m in 1992-93 to the black spot program is welcome. This money will be spent on known crash sites and hopefully will prevent further horrific accidents such as those we have seen in recent times in which dozens of coach passengers have lost their lives. I welcome that particular initiative.

The measures to assist families, built as they are on a number of reforms such as upgrading child endowment, the family allowance and the addition of the family allowance supplement with cash payments for the first time in Australia's history will ensure that the families in the greatest need will not be harmed to the extent that they cannot enjoy decent week-to-week living. All these reforms are welcome. The cash payout in April, which some people have criticised as being small, is not small to a number of people who need shoes for their kids and other items and have no cash to hand.

In conclusion, this statement is not a blueprint for meeting the variety of needs reflected in annual Budget allocations. However, it is a blueprint for economic recovery and a measure that will stimulate jobs. It is a recognition that the success of our social justice policies relies on a stable income, and that when people are out of work and struggling to balance their domestic budgets, it is a social injustice that cannot wait for the accomplishment of long term restructuring, essential as that may be; those people must be assisted now and with this package I believe they will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —The unfunded package from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was designed to make amends for great neglect of the Australian economy over the last few years. This misdesign of our economy has lasted for at least five to six years during which time, as we all know, commercial interest rates at 19 to 20 per cent—in fact over the five years leading up to 1991—have broken hundreds of thousands of Australians and hundreds of thousands of Australian businesses and business men and women, put them out of town or under water and, consequently, put many Australians out of work.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this package was threefold: first of all, to establish the new Prime Minister; secondly, to respond to Fightback; and, thirdly, to address the parlous circumstances of the economy. Honourable members can take those items in whichever order. I am sure that concerned backbenchers in the Australian Labor Party would reverse that order. I am equally sure that the Prime Minister did it in the order that I have just spelt out.

Why is it that we had to have our fourth economic statement in a year? There was a time when two was the exception; one was the norm and two was the exception. Perhaps it is because we have had two Prime Ministers and four Treasurers. Nevertheless, we had a statement on 12 March and a Budget last year, a jobs statement and now this ruination statement. It is because this nation was first into the recession. It did not lead the world, but it was first into the recession, which is now all around this globe. It is also because it is built on the back of bad government and massive debt.

It would be churlish of me not to agree that some of the measures in this statement are positive. Accelerated depreciation measures, infrastructure changes, road spending, rail spending, aviation changes—though not far enough—and the `stolen straight from the Fightback package electricity grid' are all positive measures.

I might say, however, that if, for example, the Government had addressed the inefficiency on the railroads; if, for example, the Government had managed to produce half as inefficient a railroad as we have in this country today by one means or another; the Government could nearly have funded the first 18 months of its package. But, obviously, that is not the objective.

We have had a good look at the figures in this package and we note that, of course, depreciation builds up over the years. We will give the Government the benefit of the doubt because in its very best year, the 1995-96 year, when it would take from business less than it does currently, its tax measures, dollars to business forgone, would total $900m.

We ought to compare the Government's figures with ours in such a year. I will start with payroll tax. Let us not forget that this is the Government's biggest year. I have left out the forgoing of customs duties, which are diminishing over time, because in that year revenue forgone in both of our circumstances would be about the same. The Government in that year would forgo nothing in payroll tax. The States forgo none; therefore the Government would not compensate the States. But we would forgo $5.8 billion.

The wholesale sales tax on passenger vehicles is down to 15 per cent. We are assuming that business uses a little over half of the motor cars in that category, so we will calculate $150m under the Government's package in that year, 1995-96. With wholesale sales tax on business, on last year's figures, out of $9.3 billion, we would forgo about $7 billion—if those figures were to go forward; goodness knows, by the year 1995-96 it might be more.

On fuel excise the Government would forgo not a cent. We would forgo about $3.6 billion on a figure of $6.6 billion last year. Under the Keating package, the figure would be $10m from the capital gains tax exemption increase, whereas we would forgo $200m under the improved capital gains tax roll-over provisions. The figures for the coal export levy would be the same in both cases.

Under the Government's package the figure for accelerated depreciation would be $490m; accelerated write-off for income producing buildings, $30m; infrastructure bonds, $100m; development allowance for large projects, $70m; and pool development funds, $5m. As I have said, I have left out customs duties because they are the same in both cases. That makes a total of roughly $900m under the Government's package and in our case a total approaching $20 billion.

That is the measure of the difference. We have had comments by some that we will have a contraction in the economy in our first year. What we ought to do is to add up all of those measures that the Government is forgoing, and the stimulus, if you like, to the economy. In the whole of the life of the Government's package those measures that I have just read out will amount to $2.7 billion. I am then going to add in the infrastructure measures, which come to another $1.1 billion. So let us say that it will be $3.8 billion in the whole of the life of the package from 27 February 1992 to the end of the financial year 1995-96. That is adding it all together, cumulatively—budgetary assistance, all the tax measures and all the infrastructure spending. It comes to $3.8 billion: big deal!

If we were in power for that period of time with our goods and services tax and the tax measures started a year earlier than otherwise, we could compare that $3.8 billion with tax revenue forgone by business of $60 billion. We can call it $55 billion, if you like, but it is three years of nearly $20 billion forgone in each year—and that is without including the cumulative effects of reducing that greater amount of tax. That is the way we can compare like with like. Were this country fortunate enough to have a change in government, we would start those tax reductions a year earlier.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) has said that we would contract this economy.
