He has based this on the fact that he seems to think that the only stimulus with which one can provide an economy when one is in government is fiscal stimulus; it has to come from the font of all power. But let us just take the example of a major textile company that has given us its figures under the Fightback package. It would get back—or we would forgo, if you like—$1.25m of payroll tax. Surely that would be a stimulus to that company. There has to be a stimulus. What else could it be?

Let us take a major construction company in New South Wales which pays $11.5m in payroll tax. It tells us that it would be a marvellous stimulation for it. It would stop that company having to make some rearrangements about jobs that it is making at present. It tells us that the $8.8m on fuel excise that it would not be paying—that is the direct cost of fuel excise; it cannot calculate the indirect benefits of all the contractors and other people—would be a marvellous stimulus. The $3.2m in wholesale sales tax that it would not be paying would also be a magnificent stimulus.

The interest savings on the abolition of those taxes amount to another $2.1m. That company's total savings, therefore, will be $25.6m. Getting rid of the burden of that tax of $25.6m has to be an enormous stimulus to it. So it is not true, as the Minister says, and seemed to imply both on a radio station program today and in answer to a question, that the stimulus has to come from the benevolence of the Government. Stimulus can come just as easily—in fact, much more easily because one does not have government departments interfering with it and creating unnecessary jobs—from revenue forgone to the Government that is left in the hands of business. I would have thought that that national economic stimulus was exactly the sort of stimulus that we need in this country rather than having everything designed by the hand of government.

That essentially is the difference between the Government on the one hand and the coalition on the other. What we wish to do in this country is allow people the right to make their own decisions, not to have their hands held by the all-powerful Government. This runs all the way through the economy, all the way through the work and the labour force. We want people on both sides to become responsible for their own decisions in the workplace with all the people involved. We want them to become responsible for their own decisions in education, in health and in business. We do not want—as those opposite seem to think is a necessity—a situation in which government takes all the money away and then dispenses the largess. I have absolutely no doubt that it makes government feel good, and when a polyglot of measures is put around, such as the Prime Minister has done in this package, those opposite can go out and say, `Look what we have given you and what we have given you'.

Before I came to this place, I always thought it an odd thing that people in government talked about the cost to government, the cost to the nation, when revenue was talked about as being forgone. It is not a cost; it is a benefit. It is an efficiency if one can dispense the services that are absolutely necessary in this country without having to interpose between the collection of those services a whole department of people to interfere with them. What we can have, and must have, is national economic stimulus which can come, and will come, from taxation forgone, not only at the rate of $20 billion a year from business but from private citizens—which will be a great part of the stimulation of the Fightback package. It will come not only from taxation forgone on the business side of fuel consumption but also, in a land as big as North America, with the distances and the remoteness but without the population, without the infrastructure, from taxation forgone from an excise on fuel. The Government takes it and then gives it back, and it calls that industry policy. We do not take it; what we want to do is to let the self-starters start and then provide the national economic stimulus for them to self-start Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The One Nation statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last night represented a plan, a four-year strategy for this nation. It represented a strategy for recovery, a strategy to generate economic growth, and a strategy to ensure that the difficulties of the recession are put behind us and the nation has the confidence to go forward into the 1990s with a forward looking, visionary package that ensures our future both in this part of the world and, indeed, as an internationally competitive nation.

PARA.TAB: In listening to the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), one is clearly able to draw the distinction between the policies of the Opposition and those of the Government. Since February 1990 we have progressively cut interest rates by half. According to the ideology espoused by the honourable member for Barker, he would leave the situation to business because it would generate its own recovery.

We have established clearly in the last 18 months that the worldwide recession is deeper and the structural problems are more difficult than in the past. It needs more than just the wishful thinking approach that the Opposition's strategy would suggest; it needs the sort of partnership approach that the Government has generated in the One Nation strategy. What gets the Opposition's goat in this discussion is the fact that the Prime Minister, on assuming the position, decided to go out and consult the community at large—the business community, the trade union movement, the broader community organisations, and the State governments—to develop a strategy and structure so that each player in the partnership could participate fully as an equal partner.

The package introduced last night goes very clearly to the heart of those issues. It recognises that business has needs and that government can play a part in working with it. It recognises that the trade union movement has a very important place in economic recovery, something that the Opposition's Fightback strategy completely ignores and suggests does not exist. Indeed, if those opposite had their way, trade unions would not be allowed to exist. The package also recognises the fact that, with different State governments and manufacturing and structural change going on in particular regions, governments have to be responsive to help get the setting right so that recovery in those areas can take place.

That is what the One Nation statement by the Prime Minister last night is all about. It is about generating that activity and confidence. In all the discussions that members of parliament have with people in the community—and my electorate would not be much different from most others—people say to me, `It needs the Government to show us direction and leadership, to give us the confidence'. It is not just a case of saying to business, `You go and do it'; the Government needs to help create the environment for that to take place. That is what last night's statement is all about. It is about setting that strategy in place, about recognising that we can make ourselves more competitive. It is about recognising that we can have a real anti-inflation strategy, something that the Fightback package does not have and cannot have. If the wages element is left out, one cannot simply expect the inflation strategy to work on its own.

We certainly cannot assume anything other than that, with a 15 per cent consumption tax, there will automatically be a doubling of the inflation rate, and there is no effective strategy to deal with that. On the contrary, the Government's policy has ensured that we have a low inflation rate; that we have the base to build on to create the recovery and to sustain low inflation, and to ensure that our wages outcomes are linked to that low inflation rate. The Government, with its partnership with the trade union movement, has the capacity to ensure that that takes place. It is something that the Opposition could never hope to deliver and cannot deliver. The Opposition suggests that it is not important. We saw the way those opposite operated when they were in government, when they did not have a wages strategy, and we saw the results of that.

The Prime Minister's statement is also about ensuring that we create jobs and that we recognise the real issues in Australia—that we recognise the inadequate infrastructure we have. It is interesting that Opposition speakers from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) down have all said, `Yes, there are some things in the statement that we think are all right in the infrastructure area'. But they say, `That is all unfunded'. To adopt their strategy, they would basically have to say, `We would cut back on all those things'. That is the approach they have. They do not believe in effective rail systems such as will be developed through the One Nation strategy. They do not believe in the upgrading of the national road system to ensure that it is competitive and is capable of solving our great distance problems; they do not accept that those sorts of things are necessary or justified.

When we develop arrangements with the States in this regard, they say, as even Premier Greiner has said, `We will take that money. We will be prepared to do those things'. But at the same time he is saying, `It is a bit of unfair economics that this is happening'. But they all put in their proposals because they know infrastructure does need upgrading. How is it going to be done? The One Nation package ensures that it is done in two ways. First, it ensures that we give the kick-start with the commitment to public infrastructure development in the initial stages. We also create the tax environment to encourage private infrastructure participation over the time of the package. They are positive initiatives; they are things that should be done. One of the great needs we have in this country if we are to ensure we are the export and outward looking country that we want to be is surely to ensure that our ports and the linkage to our ports are adequate, to ensure that our rail system is adequate, and to ensure that the National Rail Freight Corporation that we set up—it was not the Opposition—is adequate.

The Opposition might have talked about rail but it never did anything about it. We have actually ensured that the Rail Freight Corporation is put in place. The measures outlined last night take that a step further; standard gauge rail links around the country will ensure that we are able to compete. Of course, businesses will get the benefits of that, as many of them have readily acknowledged in the last 24 hours. All those things will be taken into account.

Our package gives a real commitment to Australian tourism, an industry created in the 1980s by the Labor Government. We are going to ensure that it grows in the 1990s. The Government is committed to ensuring that our aviation policy is competitive, dynamic and able to cope with the changes that are involved in that area. The Government is particularly committed to ensuring that tourism, which has the potential to be our great growth industry of the 1990s, is given a chance.

What is the alternative from the Opposition? We have only to listen to tourism groups around Australia to see what they think about the goods and services tax and the impact it will have on the tourism industry. They have certainly been ready to acknowledge that the impact of the GST package on their industry, one of our great growth industries, will be very detrimental indeed. Let us compare that with the setting that we created in last night's statement. It is certainly the right sort of confidence booster, the right sort of kick-start that the tourism industry in so many of the important regional areas of Australia needs. In the major cities also, the industry needs airports and free movement to and from cities and the regions.

The next important element of our package is training. We recognise that the educating and skilling of our work force is important. It is really important when coming out of recession. All too often past experience has shown that in recession we lose much of that skills base. We already had a great commitment to higher education. That, with the massive commitment that was given last night, will ensure that the tier that has not received the attention it should have in the postwar period is given that attention—the TAFE sector.

Vocational training and skills training are to be given the impetus they deserve as we lead into the 1990s. That is being done because a Labor Government at the Federal level is saying, `We are prepared to make a massive national commitment to TAFE training; we are prepared to ensure that the States, which so often have fallen short in providing TAFE resourcing at the level that is required to ensure that area is properly able to grow and develop to provide the opportunities for our young people, provide that training'. That is precisely the sort of message that needs to be given as we seek to move out of the recession into this important recovery.

In the process, we are maintaining our commitment to the school education system. It has not received as much publicity, but in last night's package there was further funding for the school education area. We know that the continuing demand and need in that area is one that governments have to address. Labor governments at the national level have always given priority to addressing the problems in school education.

We move on from those initiatives to the fact that we believe in fairness and equity. We have heard a lot today about taxation issues. The tax reform measures taken over the period of this Government and the measures announced last night ensure that a spirit of fairness and equity is maintained. The assistance package for families announced last night—and the special payment to be received next month—is just the sort of stimulus to confidence that is needed. From the response I have had to that measure, I can certainly say that families in need really appreciate and welcome it. Those families know that the alternative—a 15 per cent consumption tax on everything that they purchase in the way of food and clothing—is going to slug those in need very severely indeed. That is something that cannot be tolerated. The people of Australia, who care about equity and fairness, will not let that happen. The Labor Government, which cares about social justice in that area, will not let that happen either.

The statement contains important initiatives for the cities, for areas such as those I represent in western Sydney, growth areas so long neglected by conservative governments who did not really understand the needs in those areas. The problems we have with our roads, our education, the lack of resources we have for those sorts of facilities, are addressed in the statement. I welcome that very much. I think the Prime Minister deserves congratulations on the initiatives that have been undertaken in that area.

I refer briefly to a few of those matters. In western Sydney, the north-south road link is being given a massive contribution of $25m to help accelerate construction of that Sydney by-pass so that commercial freight traffic and so forth can get around the city. It improves commercial competitiveness and economic efficiency and at the same time ensures safer conditions for the people in the western Sydney region. Likewise, the Government has given a commitment with respect to the major road construction at James Ruse Drive and Victoria Road, one of the major roads in the Sydney metropolitan area. It is a very positive initiative, a very tangible way for the Government to show that it is determined to ensure that commercial operations in that part of Sydney do have ready access to and from their workplaces, ports and railheads. Those are all very worthwhile, very positive initiatives that help to set the scene for economic recovery. So much of that process is going to be built around the confidence that the environment is right for business to get out and participate once again.

The package does that. It leads the way. The Government is not standing back, as the Opposition would have us do, and saying, `Well, you go and do it; we will sit back and watch you do things'. The Government is leading the way, showing the direction and providing the leadership that the country needs to generate recovery, to create the 800,000 jobs that the Prime Minister spoke of last night.

It cannot be suggested, on any reading of the Fightback! document, that it does anything other than contract the total economy. Our fiscal stimulus to help kick-start the economy stands in stark contrast to the Opposition's contraction of the economy. The Opposition's proposal would ensure that inflation doubles. The Opposition's proposal would ensure that the basic needs of people are not given the attention they deserve. We will not let that happen. In fact, our package of measures seeks to open up the economy further. It seeks to ensure that our role, both in financial circles and in exports, is opened up more—a very positive move indeed, something that we should encourage.

I think it is very important in that context to note that we have ensured that business, small or large, has that environment within which to move forward. Measures in the statement cater for those various groups. Each of those groups can look forward, based on the strategy that has been developed in the One Nation package, to a period when they can seek to develop and expand their businesses, when the national economy will grow, because economic growth is what this package is all about.

The world economy and countries around the world face enormous challenges. The United States and other countries face huge challenges because of the depth of the economic difficulties they have. We certainly have a major challenge from this nation's point of view. The One Nation strategy takes up that challenge. It recognises the need for a sort of kick-start, for a responsible stimulus to activity. That is very much part and parcel of the Labor Government's ethos. For that reason, I believe it is a statement that the people of Australia will welcome. They will see it as providing the inspiration and direction the country needs. I firmly recommend the package to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say briefly to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), who says that he comes from the rapidly growing western suburbs of Sydney and Parramatta and that this package does a lot for him: I come from the rapidly growing eastern suburbs of Melbourne—in fact I have the demographic centre of Melbourne in my electorate—and this package does almost nothing for the people in my electorate. Equally, let me say to him when he boasts about the six weeks of consultation by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating): before we put together the Fightback package we spent 18 months on our Australia 2000 program consulting far more widely than the Prime Minister did in his six weeks.

PARA.TAB: This is, of course, a much publicised statement. The Prime Minister did make a great show about consulting and promising to take ideas on board. This was the opportunity for the Government to actually do something for the people of Australia on a sound long term basis. Of course, the Government had the advantage—Fightback had actually blazed the trail. We had shown the Government what could be done.

But I will have to report to the people in my electorate that last night the Prime Minister failed his big test. Why did he fail his big test? The answer is, as the Leader of the Opposition so effectively said earlier tonight, that the Prime Minister did not say how the Government is going to fund its multibillion dollar program. As every family in this country knows, one can only spend what one has got. The Government wants us all to go deeper in debt so that the Prime Minister can try to win the next election.

Let me say up front that there are some good bits in the package. For example, Australia and New Zealand as one air market is an excellent idea, on page 58 of Fightback!; the national power grid, on page 59 of Fightback!; capital gains tax relief for business, on page 37 of Fightback!; one stop development approvals, on page 63 of Fightback!; emergency relief for voluntary agencies, on page 62 of Fightback!; training packages for long term unemployed, on page 213 of Fightback!; assistance to non-government schools, on page 24 of supplementary paper No. 4; accelerated depreciation for business, on page 49 of Fightback!; more TAFE funding, on page 37 of supplementary paper No. 4—and so on.

But having said that, let us look at some of the other measures. When I go back tomorrow, what do I tell my constituents? I live in the real world. I actually get out and visit my electorate and, even more, I live in my electorate, unlike the previous Prime Minister and the current Prime Minister. What I am going to do is tell them about the infrastructure reform that is supposed to be the centrepiece of this One Nation document. The Prime Minister said on television last night, `Spending should have been done years ago'. He said it on television for everybody to see and hear. I say to the Prime Minister of this country that he has boasted frequently, loud and long that he had his hands on the levers, so why did he not do it?

Let us look at land transport. Rail reform, of course, is a key priority in Australia's micro-economic rehabilitation. But sinking $454m into a rail system that loses over $5 billion each year is a measure purely for short term political gain. Pouring money into railways means supporting the most inefficient, union dominated sector of our transport industry. For goodness sake, let us get the existing railways working properly, and then that is the appropriate time when we should start thinking about spending vast amounts on new lines.

Where are the proposals in this package for waterfront reform? Show me the proposals in here for waterfront reform. There is not one. Yet the Government surely cannot be satisfied with what it has done on the waterfront so far. The waterfront is a key element in our export effort, and there is not a single thing in this document about it.

Where are the proposals on telecommunications? One of the problems in this country is that we suffer from the tyranny of distance. A fundamental need in this country is telecommunications. The issue is not addressed in this document at all.

Let us look at aviation. The Government has taken up the Fightback idea of one air market. That is good, but the Government does not go far enough. Aviation reform is not about just letting airlines fly and letting more airlines fly and letting the international airlines take domestic passengers, and so on, which is important; it is also about running the terminals properly and commercially and providing good services so that we encourage business and tourism. Why not privatise the Civil Aviation Authority and let us start to run the place properly.

Do I go back to members of my electorate and tell them about the Government's measures for industry and small business? There are many businesses in Victoria, of course, the heartland of the manufacturing sector in this country. It is in a pretty sorry state at the moment because of the recession generated by the Prime Minister when he was Treasurer. It is business confidence which is most in need of restoration in this country. If we have the confidence, then we can overcome almost anything. We have to encourage business because it can make the biggest direct impact on turning the jobs crisis around. But what business wants is, of course, incentives to perform. So it needs lower costs. Where is that in the package? It needs better returns. Where is that in the package? It needs to be internationally competitive.

I ask the Prime Minister: are his big business consultees, those he went and talked to a couple of weeks ago in Melbourne and Sydney and so on, actually committed to invest in the package he has now announced? I very much doubt it. The Prime Minister has given them what they want. Why will they not give him the quid pro quo? They are just milking the Prime Minister because there are no clear measures in his statement to get business off its very comfortable backside. It has to get out there and compete and be competitive.

The Government should have brought in stronger anti-dumping measures, and I see no mention of that in this document. There are imports coming into this country and there is nothing in here about anti-dumping. We are destroying small businesses, farmers and all sorts of other companies because we are slack in that area.

There is nothing in this document about abolishing regulation; there is nothing about lessening government interference. When is the Government going to lighten the load on business? When is the Government going to take off some of that regulation? When is the Government going to streamline some of the duplications, triplications and all the rest of it between the States if we want to operate in business in this country? Why has the Government not abolished payroll tax, the tax on jobs? That not only impacts on big firms; it also has a trickle down effect. Why did the Government not abolish the fuel tax, the tax that applies to every business in this country and every leisure activity?

In this document the Government talks about assistance to exporters. Australia already spends around $550m per year on assistance to exporters. That is $10.40 for every $1,000 worth of exports, more than twice what is spent by most of our competitors overseas. But throwing money at exporters in the past has done very little good in terms of actually boosting exports, and throwing extra money, as proposed in this document, in large dollops to Austrade and so on is hardly the solution to increased competitiveness.

Am I going to tell my constituents about superannuation, including the small businesses that cannot afford to pay the compulsory superannuation? If the Government persists with that compulsory superannuation, it will destroy thousands more jobs.

I take a special interest in science and technology in this place. Whilst the tax and the micro-economic reforms are, of course, critical, I suggest that technological diffusion across our economic base is probably as important as any other single measure. We need to take up technology and innovation in all that we do in large dollops. We do not just want one or two clever little ideas and then whinge if they go overseas because nobody will invest in them. It is the application of technology across the board that is as critical as any other single factor in our recovery.

What action have we had from the Government to achieve that? We have a number of world class companies in this country, but it is only a handful, and we need more. We need to do a number of things to try to encourage those companies and grow more of those companies. We have to educate our scientists and our engineers, frankly, to be more commercially aware. But even more importantly, we have to educate our business managers to be even more technically aware, and when they have a problem they must instinctively turn to their R&D departments and look for solutions to their problems. We have to get more commercial output from public sector R&D expenditure, and to do this we must do it by establishing a more effective network between public and private partnerships, not contrived schemes. We must persuade more chief executives to show greater vision towards product innovation and to global markets. By `persuade' I mean we have to give them incentive, and incentive means profit and lowering their cost base.

We have to develop more international partnerships. Where in this statement are any measures to achieve any of this? We talk about the ATG in this document. Do I detect a hint of the VEDC, picking winners? History does not show that that works.

I would like to refer to a brief extract from the Sydney Morning Herald of last Monday. The Industry Commission's draft report on the national procurement development program said, `The program has so far provided $25m in grants for the development of new products'. The Commission reported that the scheme has been `driven by industry interests' and that `most of the money has been spent on projects that would have been developed anyway'. The report highlighted that, `only 10 of the 42 grant recipients have so far sold products developed under the scheme'. It mentions that `the administrative costs have been high' and that the `Commission is almost certain to recommend that the program be wound up at the end of this financial year'. Here is the interesting bit:

SPEECH.PARA: The politicians and the bureaucrats who designed and administered the program have not been using their own money; they have faced no penalty for poor commercial judgment. They have not been subject to the most basic discipline of the market.

Here we go again, perhaps. Let me be parochial; let me talk about my own patch. In my electorate of Aston we have had a 572 per cent increase in unemployment under this Government. Youth unemployment is running at nearly 40 per cent. People can witness the bankruptcies as they walk around and see the `For sale' and the `For lease' signs on factories, offices and shops. What do I tell my constituents about the special payment of $125 if they have one child or $250 if they have five children? If they want to buy a pair of school shoes for the kids, they will cost about $50 or $60. The special payment is gone in one hit for the family with five children. Will that boost the economy? Will that help the people out there who are bleeding?

PARA.TAB: On unemployment, last night on television the Prime Minister said that the trend line, rather than the rate, is what matters. He should tell that to the marines. Tell it to the unemployed, to the school leavers, to the 55-year-old who has been retrenched and cannot get a job, to the parents of the kids who will come out of school next year, to the grandparents who did their bit and have watched this Government destroy the country. The Prime Minister's line will go down in history as his epitaph.

The tax proposals are too little, too late, unfunded; it is only bracket creep pay-back. The disadvantaged and lower paid are ignored. The 15 per cent wholesale sales tax that the Government is to apply to cars is on top of the costs, including payroll tax, petrol excise and all the other things which we will do away with. Under our scheme people will be better off. There is no industrial relations detail in this document. There is no information about health or how the Government will fix the hospital queues. There is nothing for the aged or the disabled; they do not get a mention. And what about women? P. P. McGuinness had a good line in the Australian this morning:

SPEECH.PARA: The most curious thing about Paul Keating's mini-budget is how old-fashioned, male-orientated and naive it is.
What about the promises the Prime Minister has made to the women of Australia? I say to the Prime Minister: women and children are the victims of his recession, too.

PARA.TAB: In summary, I have to say that this One Nation document is unfunded. It does only part of the job. In large measure it is a con because it puts off the evil day for this Government. I think there is a clear message coming out of all this for the Government backbenchers. I refer them to page 7 of today's Age newspaper, to an article that talks about a comparison between former President Ronald Reagan and President Bush and how they went in their country. Perhaps there is a parallel. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The President—
Bush—

has never enjoyed the kind of personal affection and support of the American people that Ronald Reagan enjoyed . . . in politics . . . if people like you, they will forgive you almost anything, and if they don't, look out.

Perhaps there is a parallel. The former Prime Minister had the personal affection. The people forgave him and they elected him time and time again. They do not like the present Prime Minister, and this document will confirm it when they start to rumble what a con it is. He and the Australian Labor Party had better look out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a rather sterile debate, but not without some surprising moments. First, we had the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) adopting a macho style, but not offering

SPEECH.PARA: one constructive suggestion. Then, in one of the funniest scenes I have ever witnessed in my eight years of parliamentary life, we had the honourable member for Farrer, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), stand up here before us this evening and try to sell the value and the worth of the goods and the services tax, the consumption tax.

PARA.TAB: We all know that whenever the honourable member for Farrer goes to a country area, there is a deafening silence about the GST. He knows that the farmers hate the GST and they are scared silly about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—If the honourable member for Cowper comes to the electorate of Hunter, I will prove that point to him. When the honourable member for Farrer came to my electorate recently, he mentioned only two things. He said, `The people of the Hunter will reject Eric Fitzgibbon because he voted for Prime Minister Keating instead of the former Prime Minister'. He also said that they would hate me because I had deserted some of my electors by moving my office from Maitland to Cessnock. There was not one mention of the GST. What a foolish visit that was.

PARA.TAB: It was pleasing to hear the shadow Minister for industry and commerce, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), pay tribute to the positives in the Prime Minister's package. The honourable member for Barker is far fairer, far more generous and far more discerning than his Leader. But even he makes mistakes. He stood here and said, `If we abolish the payroll tax, we will stimulate the textile and clothing industry. It is dying to have a Liberal government'. That is a load of codswallop.

Everyone in the textile and clothing industry knows this: it hates the Australian Labor Party because progressively we will remove protection from that industry until by the year 2000 it remains at 25 per cent. But the Liberals, who claim to be the friends of those people who are employed in the textile and clothing industry, will not leave a balance of 25 per cent in the tariff. It is made abundantly clear in the Fightback package that by the year 2000 the protection for the textile, clothing and footwear industry will be reduced to zero. The Liberals have no sympathy at all. What lunacy it is for a respected member of parliament to stand here and to speak nonsense of that nature.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), cries foul and says that the Labor Government has stolen ideas from the Opposition's Fightback package. Remember how we all convulsed with laughter when the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) revealed the extent to which the Opposition stole its Fightback package, virtually word for word, from New Zealand. Everyone who is present at the moment knows what the GST has done to that country.

The honourable member for Aston should tell his constituents that his Party wants to introduce a new tax which at the start will slug them 15 per cent and, as has happened in every other country, there will be an increase in that rate every year. Imagine the honourable member for Aston shedding crocodile tears for the unemployed. He mentioned the 55-year-old person who has been retrenched and who at that age finds it very difficult to gain employment. Does he remember that, after nine months of unemployment, under a Labor Government that person will still receive welfare? But under the coalition parties, should they ever gain power, that person's welfare benefit will be cut completely. We have crocodile tears, but they just do not mean a thing.

The Prime Minister's economic statement was seen as a critical test of this Labor Government's ability to return economic growth to labour, to get people into jobs. Fair critics are saying that the Keating Government has passed that test with flying colours. Have those people opposite not heard the message from the media? Fightback is forgotten; One Nation has centre stage. The miracle is that Labor has matched the Liberals' promises of tax cuts without resorting to the introduction of a new tax, the hated GST.

Equally pleasing is the fairness of the program which aids big business, small business, farmers, miners, factory workers, pensioners and families. Farmers starved of credit will get subsidised loans. People in my electorate of Hunter are happy. They recognise that the Government's package is one where social justice is a keynote. I told honourable members earlier today that we conducted a survey in my electorate. We rang people from all walks of life throughout the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—I think we rang 66 people, but when we asked which package they preferred the results were that 68 preferred the Keating package and none preferred the Hewson package. The discrepancy in the figures is due to the fact that my two secretaries voted. One person said to me, `Mate, how could you vote for them? GST—what a misnomer! It should be CTG, the cradle to the grave tax'. Effectively when we think about it, that is what it is. The pocket-money of all young children is taxed whenever they spend a few cents or a few dollars on goodies themselves. Another constituent said, `It is a tax on the needy to further bloat the greedy'.

PARA.TAB: Prime Minister Keating's economic cure will revive this nation's fortunes and create 800,000 jobs without increasing the current account deficit. There is help for business to invest and export. Next month, every Australian family receiving family allowance will share a $317m payment, and those who receive a supplement will get an increase of $3 per week for every child under 16 years of age. Let us compare that with what the Opposition offers. The Opposition will cancel family allowance when a child reaches 12 years. Furthermore, what we are doing for families is much better than the Opposition's plan to tax kids 15 per cent on the goodies they buy with their pocket money.

Over the next two years, the Government will spend more than $1 billion to upgrade rail and road networks. To provide a capital works spur to kick-start the economy and create jobs, the Government will upgrade ports, electricity grids, air terminals, waste management plants, TAFE colleges and schools—and, gee whiz, does this not upset the Opposition! But why, in its long terms of government, did the Opposition never attempt these worthwhile projects?

Possibly the greatest creation of jobs will flow from assistance to the tourist industry, and the Government has provided the proper environment for tourism to prosper. I know how delighted this makes the folk in the Hunter region. The potential for tourism in the Hunter Valley is virtually untapped, and with wise use of this government assistance tourism will certainly expand rapidly.

By 1995 no person on a full or part pension will pay income tax, and pensioners need not fear that a Labor government will ever burden them with a 15 per cent consumption tax on everything they eat, drink, wear or use. The Government's move to raise the status of vocational education training has been applauded. TAFE has long been the poor relation of the higher education system. The Commonwealth's offer of $720m over a three-year program to take full funding responsibility for TAFE—leaving the States with day-to-day administrative authority—should be accepted by the States.

Farmers in my electorate, and I am sure in all other electorates, welcome the $30m assistance package; small investors welcome the tax breaks; employees welcome the $150m for wage subsidies; and everyone welcomes the $720m for job training and particularly the decision not to fiddle with superannuation.

Overall, the Keating package offers something for most people. However, we have resisted throwing money at short term job creation schemes in order to cut the dole queues. This means that few of the 800,000 jobs promised will appear immediately. However, the important point is that the foundation has been laid and the economy will grow while interest rates and inflation remain low. The statement is a positive one, and we can be confident of recovery rather than succumbing to the despair of eternal recession.

In conclusion, this is a pretty fair measure by which we can judge the relative success of the Hewson package and the Prime Minister's package. Last Wednesday evening I went for a walk around Parliament House. It had been a fairly hectic day and I wanted to clear the brain and get a breath of fresh air. However, on every path I walked along I was astonished to see people with torches dashing around and searching every nook and cranny. Seeing four Federal Police officers standing together having a yarn, I walked up to them and said, `Hey fellows, what the heck is going on?'. `They're journalists', said the first policeman, `They've just heard Keating's statement and now they've lost something'. `It's Hewson's Fightback package', said the second policeman, `it's disappeared'. `Keating hit it for six and they can't find it', said the third policeman. `Well, I don't know,' said the fourth policeman, `maybe it's just embarrassed and prefers to stay in hiding'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) is a very likeable bloke and it is always entertaining to be in the chamber when he is speaking to listen to his flights of fancy. But, regrettably, those flights of fancy get swamped by the fantasy itself and, because of his lack of contact with the truth, the realities seem to escape and fly up onto the roof with those policemen he was telling us about.

PARA.TAB: I would like to correct one of the many errors that he made in his speech. It is not true, dear honourable member for Hunter, that the coalition's Fightback package will abolish family allowances at the age of 12 years. The honourable member has that totally mixed up; he is totally confused. I suggest that when the honourable member goes to bed tonight he should have a nightcap and read through the package again. Then he might come face to face with reality.

Let us face it; we are talking about reality. I think this Parliament should face up to the reality of what is facing the people of Australia at the present time. Last night we heard the package of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and I was reminded of that famous quote by Disraeli, `There are lies, damned lies and statistics'. After last night, I suppose one could say, `There are lies, damned lies and Keating'. Before anybody gets upset, let me say that I am certainly not calling the Prime Minister a liar; I am merely referring to his statistics, which are mostly untrue. But be that as it may.

The whole point is that, when one looks in detail at the package put down last night, one can see that it is unfunded. It is based on debt and more debt. If one were going to find a simple, significant difference between Fightback and the Prime Minister's One Australia package, it is that and that alone—that is the most significant thing. The Prime Minister's package is unfunded and the Fightback package is totally funded, and the costs are detailed everywhere. As I have said, the Prime Minister's package is based on debt and more debt.

But before we start to compare the packages—there will be a great deal of investigating, focusing and putting the spotlight on both packages in the next few months, and the people of Australia will be the judges—we should remember the situation we are in at present. Gross domestic product in this recession is down by 3.2 per cent. That is about 7 per cent below where it would be under normal circumstances. Bankruptcies are up 144 per cent. The honourable member for Hunter may smile, but I can tell him that the people in Cessnock and the rest of his electorate whose shops have closed and whose businesses have gone are not smiling. So it is with people right around Australia. Bankruptcies are up 144 per cent, and of course that is only the tip of the iceberg because so many of our farmers and small business people are in such drastic financial trouble that they are not going bankrupt; they are having to just walk away and close their doors.

There has been a 21 per cent fall in private sector investment. That is the level of the lack of confidence in the present Government during this recession that we had to have—the recession which was created and engineered by the present Prime Minister. The number of people in jobs in this country has fallen by 192,000 since July 1990. We get back to `Lies, damned lies and statistics'. We cannot look at them as statistics; these are people, these are families—and 192,000 have lost their jobs since July 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do they care?

—Those opposite do not care at all. The number of unemployed in this country is up by 418,000 since October 1989. There are now 920,000 Australians officially unemployed—and I emphasise `officially' because we all know that it is much more than that. A great many people have given up: they are no longer actively seeking work; they are not in the labour market. They would like to be, but they have given up because they know that under this present regime they have the chance of a snowflake in hell of getting a job.

PARA.TAB: On top of that, there are the underemployed—the people who really want to work a lot more but cannot get a full time job. About 1 1/2 million of our fellow Australians cannot work the hours they want to. There are 760,000 Australians on the dole. I know it is pretty unfashionable these days to talk about the dole. We call it unemployment benefit, but boil it down to the essentials and it is the dole.

I think we should stop for a moment and consider the situation of those families where the breadwinner is on the dole. There are 262,000 Australian families in which the chief breadwinner is unemployed. I suppose that a great many honourable members in this place and honourable senators in the other place have no great personal relationship to that, but I, for one, can recall as a small child my father being on the dole in the Depression, which was the last time we had the circumstances we have now. I can remember it very clearly, although I was only a small child. He was a steelworker. He tried to go it alone. He started a fruit shop in Hamilton, Newcastle, where I was born. He went all right for a while, ending up with five shops. When the banks and everybody else caught up with him, he was unemployed. I remember it well. I remember people coming around to the house, not actually begging, but trying, some way or other, to make a bob, a shilling—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are nearly back to that now.
—We are very nearly back to it. I can recall people coming with billy cans of blackberries that they had been out picking to sell for a penny or a tuppence.
—Trapping rabbits.

—As the honourable member for Parkes reminds me, people would trap rabbits and come around calling out `rabbit-oh' in the streets. Others would cut saplings. We would hear them calling out `clothes props' in the streets. They were selling saplings to hold up washing on the lines, because we did not have Hills hoists then. That is what people were forced into doing. I can recall getting a haircut on the back verandah of my parents' home. The barber did not have a job so he would come to people's homes with his scissors and comb to cut hair. I forget the price, but it was not very much.
—Sixpence.

—It was not sixpence; it was less than that. That is what we had the last time we were in the situation we are in today. Last Thursday evening in Melbourne I saw people begging on the streets. I felt ashamed to be an Australian when I saw people begging on the streets in one of our major cities. I will not be nasty. I will not focus on the Government members. I think every one of us in this Parliament should feel a degree of shame when we look at the statistics and the figures that I have quoted about Australians on the dole—the Australian families and the kids.
—They have no hope.

—They do have hope because the Fightback package provides the hope, the vision and the plan for Australia. God willing, the people's common sense will put us in the position after the next election where we can put that plan into action, bring the vision to maturity and restore hope to all Australians.

PARA.TAB: There are 218,000 Australian children living in families in which no-one has a job. We have to stop and think about this situation. Some kids have not had anybody in the family with a job since they were born. That is how long this recession has been in the making. That figure of 218,000 Australian children living in families in which no-one has a job is up 40 per cent on last year's figure. Who was it that said that no Australian child would be living in poverty by 1990? Which government leader said that? Right now there are 500,000 Australian kids living in poverty—half a million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Growing every day.

—Growing every day. They are the children who are the future of this country. We have a total obligation—every one of us—to do what we can to improve that situation. When I consider the kids of this country—75,000 of whom are homeless—I am sick. The Prime Minister last night was behaving in front of the television cameras. But during Question Time, he sits and he laughs and he jokes and gets that smarmy smile on his face; he waves his finger around in the air at his head, pointing at the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). I do not think the people of Australia need a Prime Minister with that lack of dignity.

PARA.TAB: An extra 140,000 Australian families have been pushed into extended poverty and 248,000 Australians have been unemployed for more than a year. Youth unemployment is about 30 per cent, but it is very much higher in some areas. There are 60,000 young Australians who cannot get into university this year. Nearly 100,000 cannot get into TAFE. We have 60,000 on the public hospital waiting lists. Just listen to what I have been saying. This is a success story? This is the way Australia should be after nine years of the honourable member for Blaxland as Treasurer and now Prime Minister? I cannot believe it. Juvenile crime has increased by five times.

Last night, tonight, tomorrow night and next week the Salvation Army will look after 1,000 homeless people, give out about 300 food parcels and provide a couple of thousand meals. Good old St Vincent de Paul will be doing the same. The Sydney City Mission and the other aid people around Australia will be doing the same. This is the vision for Australia? This is the great country we have? It is not good enough. We just cannot go along with this. We have to have change. Change is what we in the coalition are offering. We are offering the Fightback package.

I will mention just a few things we are going to do. Comparing Fightback with the Prime Minister's One Nation is a salutary exercise. They do not really compare. Although it is interesting to note that the Prime Minister has pinched a fair bit from Fightback. He has taken the 30 per cent marginal tax rate, but will not implement it until 1996—two years after we would bring it in. The Government might smile, as he did, and just dismiss it, but we cannot accept a situation in which half the Australian taxpayers are not getting a tax cut under the Prime Minister's package. That is not good enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —The low income ones.

—The low income earners; the battlers. They have been left out in the cold. We are very pleased that the Prime Minister will bring the tax rate down to 30c in the dollar, even though it is two years late—two years after we would bring it in. I am concerned about the students, the unemployed, the pensioners and the other low income earners who will not get a thing out of it. People in Australia need that tax cut right across the board, just as they need the abolition of the fuel levy so that every one of us will pay 19c a litre less for every litre of petrol we put in our cars. Those on the Government side are very keen to say—

PARA.TAB: Mr O'Keefe interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear it being said on my left now, `Yes, you are going to put 15 per cent onto every piece of food you eat'. That is not true. We are going to abolish seven taxes, including wholesale sales tax, customs tariffs, fuel excise levy and payroll tax. We will replace seven abolished taxes with one new tax—the 15 per cent goods and services tax. Everything we are doing is funded. It is all costed. It is all there. Finally, I say to the people of Australia: when we come to the next election, Paul Keating, PK, is going to be like his namesake. He will be chewed up and spat out.

—Before I say what I had intended to say, I would follow on from my friend the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). Of course, everyone in this chamber shares the sentiments that he expressed about people who are struggling today as a result of unemployment. There can be no question about the extent of his compassion and feeling about these issues.

PARA.TAB: With the greatest of respect and regard for my colleague, I find it a little strange that Opposition members who present their package, which has so much in it for the wealthy of Australia and so much not in it for the lower income earners of Australia, including a nice little 15 per cent consumption tax on just about everything they spend their money on, would choose to make this the issue on which they would have a debate such as this. I would have thought the honourable member for Cowper would be embarrassed about the goods and services tax and his package if he was going to talk in terms of low income earners.

How does one tell people like pensioners that one is going to add 15 per cent to everything they buy and then give them compensation of 8 per cent? I am yet to understand how 15 equals eight. No doubt those opposite will spend some time working it out; as will the pensioners. The honourable member for Cowper says that students and people who are unemployed—people who are not in the work force—somehow benefit from the Opposition's tax cuts. If people do not earn a wage they do not get tax cuts; but they do get to pay the 15 per cent consumption tax. How this all adds up as a package for people whom the honourable member for Cowper purports to be worried about here tonight does stretch the credibility.

Let us have a look at what is in the statement delivered last night. What is there is $2.3 billion of real spending that will take place in the economy over the next 12 months to get these people back in the work force. We have the funds because we have put a decent Budget together for nine years. We have removed the Government's debt and we are able to fund this sort of expansion.

I would like to publicly thank the Ministers who I, as a backbencher, have lobbied in the last three weeks. I have never lobbied harder in my life than in the last three weeks to get what I wanted in that statement last night. I have to say that it was all there. The view I put to the Ministers was: it is no good trying to solve a big problem with big answers; the way we have to tackle this is to look at the problems at a micro level, like smaller pieces of a jigsaw puzzle, and find answers for those smaller problems; and as they come into being, the bigger answer comes into being.

I put a plan for my electorate to the Ministers. If the House will forgive me, I will go through some of the components of that plan to demonstrate the way that it has happened. My electorate is right at the end of the most absurd position in the Australian railway network; that is, right at the end of the railway line that makes it way from Perth to Melbourne. What happens to goods being transported from Western Australia to the east via Melbourne is that somewhere around Adelaide they all get lifted off their axles and have new wheels put under them in order to come to Victoria on an absurd broad gauge railway line.

How on earth can we say to the world and to Australia that we are serious about a national rail corporation and reform if we cannot even have a decent standard gauge railway system around Australia? It is the question that those on the other side of the House should have asked themselves every year. The honourable member for Cowper talks about shame. Members of the Opposition should have asked themselves every year they were in government why they were not doing something about fixing up the broad gauge railway problem from Perth to Brisbane.Here it is being delivered, and here it is happening. My electorate happens to be right at the core of the decision to make Melbourne the commercial gateway of Australia by hubbing and linking the airports, the rail, the road and the infrastructure.

I turned to the Ministers and said, `I have people who work at motor vehicle component companies and motor vehicle companies like Ford in my electorate. They can't have jobs unless we can restore demand in the motor vehicle industry'. I have to say that I did not expect anything as big. I sat here last night dumbfounded. The best keep secret in that package last night was knocking 5 per cent off the sales tax for a Ford Falcon. I have already had people ringing up my electorate office today asking whether they get the $850 if they buy their car today. That is what we want. They know that there is a decent advantage there to get moving.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good move; straight from Fightback.

—As the honourable member for Cowper said, it is a good move. I am just thrilled that it has been there in the statement. Take companies like John Brown at Kyneton and Daytex at Gisborne. They are textile companies which have done everything that we have asked of them to reform, to look to export opportunities. The problem with them is that they have lost their domestic demand. We have to get people buying in the marketplace to return that demand. The kick-start in this economy will do that. Those people will in fact benefit further from the textile package that is in the statement delivered by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last night.

PARA.TAB: The biggest point for me, in a quick short sense, is my export abattoirs at Kyneton, which were disgracefully closed for the last three years. Four hundred jobs were just wiped out like that. This was not because of to Wally Curran and the meatworkers, as those on the other side of the House would run around saying, but because crooks were running the joint and because the bank had loaned millions of dollars over the asset valuation. The bank would not sell it.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Martin) knows exactly what I am talking about because he chaired the banking inquiry. The abattoirs were sitting there dead because the banks would not sell and would not write off the debt. The announcement last night to provide partial write-offs opens the door for 400 jobs in one of my key towns in the next few weeks. I will work on nothing harder than solving that problem.

The biggest success story in my region has been Melbourne airport. Melbourne airport is the one place in Australia where the international terminal and the domestic terminals are together. One has not this idiotic position of people having to catch a cab for five kilometres to get from Qantas around to Australian Airlines. We have opened up aviation policy; we have given Melbourne enormous opportunity to expand its airport facilities. I think that is tremendous. People living in towns like Sunbury, which depends on the airport, know the real value of a decision like that.

In regard to TAFE places, there is a brand new college and a university in my territory: Melton campus of the VUT, the new western university and Broadmeadows TAFE college. Just to give the House an example, when these centres were opened it was predicted that their enrolments would reach 5,000 in seven years; they reached 7,000 in three years. In Melton's case it will be 7,000 in 2 1/2 years. The numbers have blown out of all proportion. It is not only because people are staying there because they do not have a job to go—that is part of the short term problem—but also it is due to the demand for education from people in our region who have been denied it for decades by Liberal governments which did not care about the north and west of Melbourne. It is like a giant blotter; no matter how many opportunities we provide, these people will soak them up because they want them. Our decision last night to offer to take over the funding from the States and guarantee those places means that there will be no hitch in the growth and development of these opportunities.

Just to pick another point, in the early 1980s we had a phenomenal success rate in kick-starting the economy in my territory with a sensible use of the community employment program; that is, we provided locally based jobs which gave people a chance to get a foothold back into the work force. There were two little rippers in that statement last night: the job skills package and the community sports program, which is about to be announced by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly). Again, a couple of my colleagues in the chamber now have been punting away at these for a long time. These programs are ready to go tomorrow. The plans are there and the applications are there. When we give the money, the jobs will be there in two weeks. For me, last night was a turning point for this country. I am thrilled to support the One Nation statement by the Prime Minister.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford Mr F.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On seven separate occasions this century many thousands of Australians have selflessly risked their lives for what they believed was a cause worth fighting for. From the bloody beaches at Anzac Cove and the rugged hills of Gallipoli, from the nightmare of the Western Front, Tobruk, Kokoda, the Burma Railway, Malaya, Korea and Vietnam to the recent war in the Persian Gulf, Australians have fought and died, believing that this was the only way of ensuring that their descendants would live in a free and peaceful world.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the fact that the vast majority of Australians are rightly very proud of their nation's military achievements during this century is a continuing thorn in the side of the ageing hippies from the campuses of the 1960s who now occupy so many positions of influence in this phoney Labor Government. One can only wonder what the beard-stroking trendoids and ageing earth mothers must have made of the extraordinary pilgrimage to Gallipoli on Anzac Day 1990!

What could have gone wrong? Why were the crowds at Anzac Day marches larger than they had been for some years? Why had so many Australians in their twenties and thirties made such an effort to get to Gallipoli for the seventy-fifth anniversary? Why was there so much interest in that unique band of original Anzacs who returned to pay one final tribute to the mates of their youth?

Given the inordinate and destructive influence of the so-called intellectuals of the 1960s on government policy, it is therefore not at all surprising that Labor has engaged in a continual war of attrition against the veterans community since its election in 1983. I will give just two examples of many with which I am familiar. Firstly, there is a widow of a veteran who served in the Great War and in the 1939-45 war. The veteran had been totally deafened in the Battle of the Coral Sea. As his widow explained to me, his quality of life was hopelessly inadequate. Today his widow receives a pension of $1.64 per fortnight. What an insult!

Secondly, there is Mr Ken West, a former member of ground support on RAAF Mirage fighters both in Australia and Malaysia. Everybody who worked on this aspect of Mirage maintenance incurred back problems. Ken had several back fusions while still in the Air Force. However, he is now in constant pain and cannot work. Yet can he obtain a reasonable pension? Not a chance. Even the Veterans' Review Board where Ken and I have appeared has doubts. Yet it does not dispute the injury. This attitude towards our veterans community is absolutely scandalous.

The Australian community is well aware of the miserable treatment of our Vietnam veterans. However, given the activities of what Paddy McGuinness has so brilliantly described as the `anti-Vietnam RSL', the Government's hostility to those who served in Vietnam is hardly surprising. Nevertheless, it is now 1992 and one might ask: will they be punished forever?
In 1944 Ben Chifley made an historic promise to those who had been prepared to put Australian interests before their own. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: On this Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done.

Indeed, the animosity of the Government towards our veterans community and the traditions it represents reached a new low on Remembrance Day 1991. Not only did the Government, I am told, in a typical display of arrogance fail to observe the minute's silence at 11 a.m., but to add insult to injury it was conspicuous by its absence at the War Memorial service. I was at this service and I was embarrassed that only a handful of Government members bothered to attend. What a sorry comment on the depths to which this once great political party has sunk when its members have so obviously forgotten that it was its most outstanding leader who, speaking at the 1941 opening of the nation's tribute to its 60,000 dead sons, expressed his hope that the Memorial would give continuity to the Anzac tradition and the basic impulses of the nation.

PARA.TAB: These are not the sentiments of a returned soldier but of a man who spent 1916 and 1917 campaigning against Hughes's attempt to introduce conscription, a man who had been gaoled for refusing to register for the call up, a man who was to play a remarkable role in the defence of his country. I speak, of course, of that great Australian John Curtin, a man who would be sickened by the shabby treatment afforded to our defence personnel today. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I really feel I cannot let the remarks of the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford) go unnoted. As somebody whose father was a Rat of Tobruk—he also served in New Guinea and Buna—I find it quite extraordinary that I am hearing such rubbish from the other side of the House. I also spend a lot of time with the veterans community. Let me say that the one thing the veterans community is terrified of is a coalition government, because they know that will mean the end of the Department of Veterans' Affairs as they know it. They also know that they will be clubbed by the user pays syndrome and that a whole range of services which they now enjoy will go out the door.

PARA.TAB: I remind honourable members that this Government established the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service and a range of other services for our returned service men and women. Women, let me add, were forgotten through the 1950s and the 1960s by those opposite—the golden years that the honourable member opposite spoke about. Do not talk to us about the 1950s. We know what they were like. Women were particularly deprived of the opportunity to get an education, to have equality and to have dignity. Honourable members should not talk to me about the golden years of the 1950s. We know what the Opposition did to the veterans community and the veterans know very well what the Opposition is like.

The honourable member for Dunkley has come in here with a bleeding heart. The other thing the Opposition will do to them is to whack another 15 per cent onto all their goods and services—heating and everything else. We know what the Opposition is like. This new bleeding heart nonsense does not wash with us. I have had first-hand experience of what our Government does for veterans. In the 1950s and 1960s my father was terribly ill and could not receive treatment from the Opposition when it was in government at that time.
Tonight I wish to talk about a very important group in Logan City—the Logan City Scorpions, a very famous rugby league team. They will kick off tomorrow night—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, that's real big stuff!

—It is to the people in my electorate as it provides a number of jobs for them. There is a club house which also provides family entertainment. It is not as exclusive or as rich as members opposite. It is not the champagne set, of course, but this is indeed real workers' sport, a place where families can go, where their children are looked after. On any weekend 1,000 children are provided for in terms of sport and sporting skills. It is not an expensive or exclusive country club or gym club or one of those places which is provided by our so-called exclusive, great public schools, but it is a club which provides real opportunities for children to gain experience in sport and allows members of the community the opportunity to enjoy a drink and some food with their mates.

PARA.TAB: We hope that the facilities, which have been partially provided by this Government, will be expanded in the not too distant future by the community by means of sporting and recreational grants. It has taken a long time for the provision of such community facilities to be recognised by those opposite. It is a legacy—dare I say it—from the 30 or so years we suffered when those opposite were in government. No consideration was ever given to the fact that communities might actually like recreational and sporting facilities or that they might be deserving of them. I suppose the Opposition's approach was that if they cannot pay for it, they cannot have it. Not only will they now have to pay for it; they will have to pay for it, plus 15 per cent.

Of course at the real heart of this is the maintenance of privilege. We understand what members opposite are about. We know; we suffered at the other end of it. That is what members opposite really hate the most—the fact that we now have access to education, that we also are able to have access to jobs which perhaps earn more than $20,000 a year and in fact have access to a whole range of information that members opposite denied us for years.

It is with great joy that we look forward to our first competitive football match tomorrow, with the Logan City Scorpions. It will be a very interesting one against Wally Lewis's Seagulls. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just going through the Senators and Members photograph book for the Thirty-fifth Parliament of 1988. I know there has been one more Parliament since then, but I was looking at the very youthful member for Forde (Ms Crawford) and I just do not believe for one minute that she can remember the 1950s. I am sure she was but a twinkle in the eye—
—She certainly does; she went to school throughout the 1950s.
—Even in the late 1950s! I do not believe that the honourable member can possibly remember it.

PARA.TAB: Speaking of youthful things, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) has, since the leadership challenge, in a desperate attempt to go incognito, shaved his beard off. However, it is not working because he has not changed his seat so we know exactly who he is. The other night he was telling a story about a friend of his who was running a pottery business in the heartland of Australia. He told the Parliament in very moanful tones that in the craft markets throughout his electorate those who were in business were competing with those who were running pottery sales. Those who were running the pottery craft markets were not competing on an equal basis with those running businesses.

What the now youthful member for Fisher neglected to tell us all was that indeed all the business inputs for his friend's pottery business will now be claimable and rebatable under the coalition's goods and services proposal. I wish that the youthful member for Fisher would come clean with his potter constituent and tell him that every cent he spends on his business inputs will be fully rebated. That includes such things as travelling around the honourable member for Fisher's magnificent electorate, with a Bic shaver ready to spring. He will be able to claim every business input, whereas those at the craft markets will be unable to claim those business inputs. When he is travelling miles and miles, and spending dollar after dollar pursuing his competitors throughout the craft markets, every single cent he spends on petrol will be rebatable at 26 cents in the litre.
I hope the honourable member for Fisher tells his constituent what the coalition has; we have the opportunities under Fightback or we have the disaster of the `fraudpack', the One Nation fraudpack.
Let us really get down to the bottom of what is happening with this new Prime Minister (Mr Keating); let us talk about the One Nation, or at the end of the day, are we talking about a divided nation?
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! The honourable member will not talk about the One Nation. It is before the Parliament for debate and it is not open for debate in the adjournment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, dearie me. The document released by the new Prime Minister, which is spelt `O-N-E', blank, `N-A-T-I-O-N'—
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I must congratulate you on your sound ruling. It is obvious that the gentleman opposite has not even read his own document—
—It is absolutely disgraceful.
—I have started a publishing company called `Kalgoorlie Press'. I felt the need to do this because of the enormous—
—The honourable gentleman was able to make his speech; he can be made to sit down any time he goes beyond the Chair's ruling.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I felt the need to start my publishing company because of what I see as the bias in a lot of the present day media. I think the Australian Broadcasting Corporation ought to have a really good look at itself. Like so many organisations it has become a propaganda outfit and has lost any interest in purveying simply the truth. One finds that the ABC has its agenda and holds its views so strongly that it is prepared to defend them even to the extent of lying. The ABC is not alone in this; I think the Sydney Morning Herald and the Melbourne Age are other classic examples of this phenomenon. In fact in response to a case before the Australian Press Council accusing it of bias, the Melbourne Age recently said it was pro-immigration and pro-multiculturalism, and intended to put that case. That is all very well, but to put an exclusion or a distortion of the opposite case is certainly not Australian and not in the interests of free speech or, I might add, of good journalism.

PARA.TAB: I have published several titles under this new publishing company; Kerry Packer, eat your heart out. With An Australian Retrospective, a friend of mine, Mark Uhlmann, and I decided we would rewrite the history of Australia from 1788 to 1945. This is not anything new; it has been done many times before, usually in a very distorted way. It has usually been written so as to belittle Australia and to try to denigrate Australians by saying there is no culture in Australia. I commend to honourable members the words of Mary Gilmore, one of our great poets:
Never allow the thoughtless to declare that we have no tradition here.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very common failing these days for people to deride our past achievements, to denigrate what happened in the past and to fail to realise that judgments about the past should be made in the context of the past and not by present day standards.

PARA.TAB: If one applies the standards of the past, Australia's history was generally very benign. It was observed by one of America's great authors when he visited Australia that Australia's history was so great that it read like a fairy tale, but it was all true. He was very impressed with the history of Australia and I think it is a pity that more of that history is not taught.

That brings me to multiculturalism. We are having multiculturalism foisted upon us in Australia. I will read from one of my latest publications—I write the forewords to all my publications; I find I do it best—

TALK.START.PARA: —Modest as well.
—In all modesty, that is. My foreword reads:

PARA.TAB: The policy of multiculturalism is portrayed by its proponents as some sort of benign, natural manifestation of Australia's ethnic diversity. But the public justification for multiculturalism involves a series of insidious and deliberate distortions. Firstly, race and birthplace are made interchangeable with culture though it is clear that people of different racial backgrounds can and do identify with a single culture.

Nevertheless, because of Australia's component of different racial backgrounds or those born overseas we are designated as a `multicultural' country. If this deliberate distortion were to be accepted, it still would not follow automatically that a government policy was required to enshrine the designation.

But then comes the second deliberate distortion: `multicultural' is made interchangeable with the policy of multiculturalism. When Bob Hawke stated in 1989 that we had `no choice' but to be a `multicultural' nation, what he was really saying was that we had no choice but to pursue the policy of multiculturalism. Further, the implication was that those who questioned the policy were actually objecting to our `multicultural' makeup—ie our racial diversity—and so were clearly racists.

This intellectual dishonesty must be apparent to the academics, bureaucrats, journalists and politicians who support multiculturalism, but it seems that many of them have convinced themselves that the policy of multiculturalism is such a worthy ideal that they are justified in lying in its defence. People with a duty to inform and educate have become deliberate propagandists. Not only can we not trust them to tell the truth, they have actively attempted to suppress freedom of speech on behalf of the policy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I respect your earlier ruling and I indicate to you that I do not intend in any way to debate the Government's package, but I suggest to you that, inevitably, in this Parliament over the next few weeks there will be a great deal of debate about the package released by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last night, comparing it with the goods and services tax package, entitled Fightback, released some months ago by the Opposition.
