PARA.TAB: I see that my friend the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) is anxious to rise to his feet and, although I am not bold enough to anticipate the subject of his speech, I suggest that mention of the GST may even continue during the adjournment debate tonight.

In my opportunity to address the House for four minutes now, I want to make a comment or two about the not deliberate but nonetheless effective misinformation campaign that has been going on in this chamber today about the GST. With great respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, I heard your participation in the debate on the Prime Minister's package, and I have to indicate that you, too, have been misled in what you have read about the GST package—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Scholes) —The honourable member for Corio was.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Corio was misled. In his contribution, the honourable member for Corio suggested that, under our Fightback package, 15 per cent would be paid even by those who were purchasing second-hand cars and that, as a result, that package could be seen as an attack on those who could afford only second-hand cars rather than new ones. I have to tell you, Sir, that this indicates that the honourable member for Corio had not read the package as thoroughly as I would have expected of him. The goods and services tax would not apply on a second-hand car; it would apply only on the difference between the trade-in price and the sale price of a second-hand car. That point ought to be made loudly and clearly in the chamber for the information of those opposite who may care next week to peddle a similar sort of argument.
—You must be joking.

—Do I have to repeat the point? The tax would apply only on the value added in the second-hand car sale. The GST package is not intended to generate additional tax; that point must be stated and restated. The GST package is intended in fact to generate less tax than is presently taken by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) as at February 1992—$10 billion less tax.
—So there will be $10m cuts in services.

—Yes, I do not deny that. I have never denied that. I have never pretended otherwise. Of course there would be tax cuts and of course there would be less Commonwealth money collected. That has not been denied by anyone on this side of the House. In fact, the intention is to take the tax more fairly and to take less of it. So Treasurer Reith would not need to reach as deeply into the pockets of the taxpayers of Australia as does Treasurer Dawkins currently—and will continue to do even after his proposed tax cuts are delivered should he remain in office for that period.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the GST package is to tax people more fairly. Even the farmers around Australia, whom the honourable member for Hinkler purports to represent, can be reassured that every dollar in tax they pay on a business input—the point made by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson)—will be rebated to them.

I think I have heard the honourable member for Hinkler make the point that removal of the wholesale sales tax would not be advantageous to farmers. I am well aware of that; I agree with that. That is the superficial argument. But the removal of the wholesale sales tax would be deliberately advantageous, for example, to every trucking operator that services rural Australia because he or she currently pays wholesale sales tax on the rig and on the spare parts. With the removal of the wholesale sales tax, the rig would be cheaper, spare parts would be cheaper and so the servicing of rural Australia would be cheaper. If that were not enough, they would also buy their diesel for the same price as the farmer currently gets diesel—that is, wholesale sales tax exempt—because, although a GST would be applied, that GST would be rebated as a business cost, further reducing the cost of servicing rural Australia.

In the interests of a progressive and useful debate in this House, let us at least be prepared to see the facts as they are and then enter into a debate on what the impact of either of the packages may be on the community. Some of the misinformation that has been unintentionally but effectively spread must be corrected. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise two points tonight, although there will not be time to cover them fully. Firstly, I take umbrage at one of the earlier speakers who criticised the Government and the Australian Labor Party in regard to veterans affairs and the defence of this country. It is quite clear that no party in the history of this nation has ever done as much for the defence of this nation as has the Australian Labor Party in both wars. I would also like to make the point that, under the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), some $5.3 billion is allocated to the veteran community—more than twice what it was when Labor came to office. I am very disappointed that there would be partisanship, rather than bipartisanship, on this issue, because it should be above that. As the name of a member of my family is on a plaque at the Australian War Memorial, I am disappointed.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the issue that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) raised. I respect his genuine concern for the rural community and his integrity. He is one of the members on the other side—there are a couple, but not many—who has a lot of integrity. But, unfortunately, he has been locked into a monkey called the GST.

The honourable member for Wakefield talked about rebating inputs and all the rest of it. But the fact is that, under the GST package, the person at the end of the line, the person who pays the retail price, would pay the tax at 15 per cent. What was also not mentioned was that fruit and vegetables, which currently are not taxed, would incur a tax of 15 per cent. Meat would incur a tax of 15 per cent. Milk would incur a tax of 15 per cent. Bread would incur a tax of 15 per cent. In other words, the honourable member can forget about all the business inputs and all that nice rhetoric. At the end of the line, there would be a tax of 15 per cent and what it means is that 15 per cent of the purchasing capacity of the consumer would be lost because it would go to revenue. It would not go back to the farmers. It would not go back to the transport operator or to anybody within the agricultural structure. It would go to revenue.

I have said it many times and I will say it again: the fruit and vegetable industry in Queensland is worth $700m per annum. A 15 per cent tax on that would be $100m-plus. Bundaberg, the city of my birth and the biggest city in my electorate, is the biggest horticultural centre in Australia. That city would lose 15 per cent at the top retail rate. That money would not go back to growers or to the agents; it would go in tax. Over $100m from that industry in Queensland would go in tax. No matter how the Opposition wraps it up or talks about it, that is the bottom line.

Worse than that, tax on the people at the bottom end of the market, the people whom the Opposition was pretending to care about today, the people at the bottom end of the income scale, would drop back to about 16 per cent. Those opposite are proud of that. But those people would then have to pay 15 per cent on everything they buy—every service and every good. In other words, they would pay 31 per cent. The pensioners would get 8 per cent in compensation, yet every time they put their hands in their pockets to pull out a dollar they would lose 15 per cent of it. People do not have to be really bright to work out whether they would be better off or not.

Let us look at the history of taxation under the Liberal Party when it was last in office. We remember the straw companies. Why did we need a National Crime Authority? It was to stop the problems that were happening with straw companies in Western Australia when those on the other side of the House were in power. Where were the spivs and the people who rorted the system with tax fraud? They thrived under the former Liberal Party Government, which refused to act for seven years. That is why we have the NCA, and that is why we brought in a decent tax system.

Let us look at the other side of the coalition—at the National Party of Australia. What can one say? In Queensland, there are more of them in gaol than outside it. The only way that one could get a knighthood in Queensland, unless one was very lucky, was to be on the take. The biggest knight of the lot in Queensland, the biggest crook of the lot, the senior law officer in Queensland, Sir Terence Lewis, is in gaol right now.

So we do not need to be told anything about propriety; we do not need to be told anything about accountability; we do not need to be told anything about taxation. We will talk about straw companies over the next 12 months. We will talk about defending the poor. We will talk about defending the working class because we know that, when their hands go into their pockets to pay for fruit, vegetables and food, so will the hands of those opposite. (Time expired)

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 14 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the state of progress in the implementation of the Government Information Technology Contract (GITC).
(2) What consultative processes were undertaken in framing the GITC.
(3) What is the rationale for the GITC.
(4) Precisely how does the GITC affect the terms and conditions of contracts applying to the information industry sector with respect to acquisitions by federal and State government agencies.
(5) Do the terms and conditions referred to in part (4) differ from the requirements previously sought by Government purchasers of information related products; if so, precisely how.
(6) What specific requirements does the GITC make of suppliers with respect to liability in the event of malfunction.
(7) For what specific limit of liability does the GITC provide and what criteria were used to determine that limit.

(8) Is the Minister able to state what the conventional or standard liability requirements of suppliers are with respect to (a) private sector purchases and (b) overseas public sector purchases of information related products.
(9) Do the liability requirements referred to in part (8) differ from those of the GITC; if so, (a) how and (b) why.

(10) What is the requirement under the GITC for indemnity to public sector purchasers against any third party claim caused an act or omission on the part of the supplier in connection with the contract.
(11) How was the level of indemnity referred to in part (10) determined.

(12) Is the Minister able to state what the conventional or standard indemnity requirements of suppliers are with respect to (a) private sector purchases and (b) overseas public sector purchases of information related products.
(13) Do the indemnity requirements referred to in part (12) differ from those of the GITC; if so, (a) how and (b) why.
(14) Is there a correct balance between the value of a product or services provided and the risks a supplier must undertake in its provision; if so, what is the correct balance.
(15) Do the liability and indemnity requirements of the GITC restrict innovation in the information industry sector.

(16) Is the Minister able to state what the conventionally accepted understandings of commercial risk sharing are between (a) private sector purchasers and (b) overseas public sector purchasers of information related products and the suppliers of those products with respect to innovation and resulting gains in efficiency.
(17) What is the status of risk sharing between suppliers and customers with respect to the forces which contribute to innovation.
(18) Are other factors more important than risk sharing in promoting innovation in the information industry sector, if so, what are those factors.
(19) Does the National Procurement and Development Program (NPDP) acknowledge risk sharing in its operation.
(20) Is there a difference between the GITC and the NPDP with respect to risk sharing; if so, what is the difference.
(21) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to any concerns expressed by Australian or Australian-based companies with respect to risk sharing arrangements implicit within the GITC.
(22) Do the indemnity or liability requirements of the GITC jeopardise the operations of any information sector companies presently supplying information related products to the Government.

(23) Under the GITC, will a supplier be assessed at the time of purchase on its ability to meet liability or indemnity requirements relating to malfunction or difficulties with third parties; if so, what assessment will be made; if not, what is the effectiveness of the requirements.
(24) Will a company be considered as a prospective supplier if it cannot meet the potential liability or indemnity requirements of the GITC.
(25) Will the liability and indemnity requirements of the GITC be reviewed at any point.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, with advice from the Minister for Administrative Services, has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Drafting of some modules of the Government Information Technology Contract is not yet finalised. However, there is currently a total of 241 contracts signed with the Commonwealth by information technology (IT) suppliers which are based on Government Information Technology Contract (GITC) conditions; see summary at Attachment A.
(2) The consultative process in the development of the GITC included:
approximately 18 months of discussions with State and Territory Governments and relevant Commonwealth Government departments,
eight days of face to face consultation between the government purchasing and legal representatives and a representative team from the IT Industry,
numerous meetings with individual IT companies, and
correspondence with industry on aspects of various drafts of the GITC.
(3) The rationale of the GITC is to:
have standard terms and conditions for use by governments in Australia,
have simple and less costly purchasing processes,
have conditions which are protective of the buyer yet balanced to the interests of suppliers,
address the technical nature of IT products, and
treat the IT suppliers no more nor less favourably than other suppliers to government.

(4) Federal and State governments have agreed to use the GITC for new contracts in the procurement of IT. The rate of implementation of the GITC varies. The Commonwealth, NSW, QLD, and Tasmania being more advanced in implementing the GITC than the other States and Territories.
(5) Terms and conditions of the GITC differ significantly from requirements previously sought by Government purchasers.
A number of changes have been made in favour of suppliers, they include:
certain obligations on customers to protect data,
an optional provision for capping some liabilities, and

a mechanism which enables a supplier to refuse an order, where there are genuine commercial reasons to do so, for example, where the potential customer is a competitor, or where the supplier may be exposed to a high risk situation.

(6) The GITC contains alternative clauses dealing with liability. The general principle, however, is that common law provisions apply. One alternative clause contains liability provisions allowing some limitation of the supplier's liabilities in particular circumstances. See the summary of liability clauses under the Common Use Contracts at Attachment A

(7) The GITC does not set a specific limit for liability. The government contract authorities may, if they wish, limit liability through the optional capping clause in the GITC. The contract authorities negotiate the level of the cap based on their assessment of risk. The Commonwealth's capping practice is shown in the summary at Attachment A.
(8) (a) The Government has been unable to no access a representative sample of private sector IT contracts and cannot comment on whether a 'standard' liability requirement applies.
(b) The UK Government policy with regard to liability is to apply common law and their standard contract reflects this. However, some contracts contain capping clauses.
Capping of liabilities is common in the USA but comparison with the USA is not appropriate as the liability laws are very different.
A European Economic Community directive directs member Governments not to limit liability of IT suppliers below 70m European currency units which is slightly more than $US50m.
(9) See answer to Question 8, above.

(10) The common law indemnity clauses in the GITC reflect the common law and seek to indemnify the buyer from any damages for which the contractor is responsible. The contractor is not held responsible for any damages caused by the buyer.

(11) The common law indemnity clause in GITC is a standard clause and is essentially the same as that used widely in past contracts for IT and other purchases. By definition it is based on the common law.
(12) (a) See answers to Question 8 above.
(b) See answers to Question 8 above.
(13) See answers to Question 8 above.

(14)No.The balance between the value of a contract and commercial risk is one which is established on a case by case basis, whether by applying common law provisions or agreeing on some level of capping, through negotiation.
(17) For software development and systems integration contracts where innovation is important, the Commonwealth's practice is to assess risk and determine risk sharing on a case by case basis.
(18) There are many factors in promoting innovation in the information industry sector. They span issues including market size, tax regime,

ANSWER.PARA: access to credit and attitudes. The importance of these, and other, factors vary according to the situation.

PARA.TAB: (19) The National Procurement Development Program (NPDP) promotes the trialling and demonstration of products which have relevance to future government procurement needs by providing grants to successful applicants. There is no commitment on behalf of the Government to purchase the end product.
(20) Yes. The GITC is a standard set of contract terms and conditions to be used in IT procurement while the NPDP is a national industry development program.
(22) Some suppliers claim that they do. The Government is giving detailed consideration to those claims.
(23) The purchasing agency will decide.
(25) Yes, after 12 months of operation, in mid 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: Has the Minister received an application from Britannia Airways of Luton Airport, UK, for a further series of charter flights for the 1992-93 charter season; if so, does the application include services operating into and beyond (a) Hamilton Island, Qld, and (b) Alice Springs; if so, does the fact that these airports are not usually designated as international airports present a theoretical or practical difficulty to approving the application; if not, will the application be approved; if so, when.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Yes, an application has been received from Britannia for a program of charters between November 1992 and April 1993.
Yes, the application does include flights into and out of Hamilton Island and Alice Springs.

Yes, there are difficulties in providing customs and immigration clearances for these airports which are not designated international gateways. However, the Australian Customs Service has agreed in principle to the provision of clearance arrangements on a cost recovery basis.

I have written to Britannia advising them that their application has been approved, subject to a condition that all passengers on their Sydney flights spend at least some time at secondary gateways linked to Sydney. Britannia has accepted this condition and advised me that it will now commence marketing the flights.
